text:
(48 Hours) / 1950 / Black and white / Drama / Direction: Gerardo de Leon / Story: Cesar Gallardo / Screenplay: Ding de Jesus / Cinematography: Tommy Marcelino / Editing: Ben Acantilado / Sound: Demetrio de Santos / Music: Ariston Avelino / Produced by Premiere Productions / Cast: Rogelio de la Rosa (Carding), Virginia Montes (Mercedes), Enrico Pimentel (Melchor), Nena Cardenas (Estela), Lopito (Lopito), Dely Atay-Atayan (Dely), Bebong Osorio (Eddie), Oscar Keesee, Patria Plata, Dadang Ortega, Francisco Cruz, Tony Tolman, Poncing Reyes, Conrado Conde, and Totoy Torrente  

Ex-soldier Carding returns from Bataan to the still warm body of his wife, Estela, who has been killed under mysterious circumstances. He is jailed for his wife’s murder. In prison he meets a friend, Melchor, who vows to help him. On the eve of his execution, he escapes to look for the real murderer but is severely wounded in the process. A bullet is lodged in his body and cannot be removed, thus giving him only 48 hours to live. While the hunt is on, he seeks refuge among friends, like Lopito, Eddie, Dely, and his former girlfriend Mercedes, who do all they can to help him. In the final confrontation, he finds himself face-to-face with a cabaret owner who is a notorious gangster.

 

 

In this movie, de Leon reveals his masterful technique of creating suspense through the mise-en-scène. French critic Charles Tesson, in his review of 48 Oras published in the prestigious Cahiers du Cinema (Mar 1982) made the observation that “de Leon’s main concern is to preserve the integrity of every shot. He blocks his characters in such a way that there is no need for an answer shot: the instigator of the action is prominently positioned in the foreground while the rest face the camera and recede into the background.” He continues: “Each shot is a puzzling trap, like a door with two or three false bottoms.” The flashback scenes are well reenacted and the past orchestrated with the present.

48 Oras was the only film that survived when the Premiere Productions studio burned down in 1950. All the film negatives were destroyed and only one positive print of this movie in 16 mm remained.  Written by Lena S. Pareja

text:
2008 / Color / Drama / 116 minutes / Direction and Screenplay: Chris Martinez / Cinematography: Larry Manda / Editing: Ike Veneracion / Production Design: Aby Jamnague-Rivera / Sound: Mac Vasquez / Music: Brian Cua / Original Songs: Ricci Chan / Produced by Martinez Rivera Films / Cast: Mylene Dizon (Joyce), Eugene Domingo (Ruby), TJ Trinidad (Rod), Ryan Eigenmann (Emil), Tessie Tomas, Simon Ibarra, Tess Antonio, Kalila Aguilos, and Bart Guingona 

 

100 chronicles the last days of Joyce, a career woman who learns that she has cancer and has only three months to live. In an attempt to take control and make the most of her remaining days, she creates a list of things she must do before she dies. The list contains a mix of mundane, funny, outrageous, heartbreaking, and profound things. On top of the list are practical concerns, such as resigning from work, cleaning up the office, paying credit card dues, buying a coffin, and preparing for her funeral. But the tasks on the list become more complicated as they begin to involve her loved ones, such as letting her best friend Ruby and her mother know about her illness, breaking up her affair with a married man, Rod, and revisiting her romance with an old lover, Emil. Fulfilling the tasks becomes an occasion for Joyce, as well as her family and friends, to come to terms with death and other things in life that they cannot control.

 

For her performance in the film, Mylene Dizon received Best Actress trophies from the Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival, the Film Academy of the Philippines, and the Gawad Urian. At the Cinemalaya, the film also won Best Director, Best Screenplay, Best Supporting Actress (Domingo), and the Audience Award. The film competed in the New Currents section of the 13th Pusan International Film Festival and received the Korea New Network Award. It won the Emile Guimet Award in the 2009 Vesoul International Festival of Asian Films.  Written by Patrick Campos

text:
(ABC… Mother) / 2001 / Color / Drama / 106 minutes / Direction: Eddie Garcia / Story and Screenplay: Shaira Mella-Salvador and Ramon Bayron / Cinematography: Romulo Araojo / Editing: Ike Jarlego Jr / Production Design: Manny Morfe / Sound: Noel Cruz Bruan / Music: Jimmy Fabregas / Produced by Viva Films / Cast: Lorna Tolentino (Estella), Albert Martinez (Daniel), Nida Blanca (Matilda), Bobby Andrews (Jojo), Alicia Alonzo, Joanne Quintas, Matet De Leon, Aiza Marquez, Hannah Camille Bustillos, Alex Poe, and Jimmy Fabregas

Estella, an illiterate woman, is married to Daniel and has three daughters. Matilda, a teacher, is the domineering mother of Daniel and his brother Jojo, with whom Estella and her children have to live while Daniel tries his luck at different jobs. Daniel’s work is always precarious, while Estella can only work as a market vendor to help in their finances. Matilda, who ends up supporting her son’s family, looks down on Estella, thinking that her useless and unreliable daughter-in-law is incapable of being a good mother and is the cause of the family’s misfortunes. Matilda takes over the rearing of her grandchildren, distrusting Estella with their education. When their tension begins to take a toll on Estella’s relationship with her husband and children, Estella decides to leave Matilda’s house in an effort to regain her self-respect. She is separated from her family for a while, but in the end Estella reconciles with her mother-in-law and takes back her children. She returns to school while Daniel tries to find a life beyond the shadow of his mother. Estella and Daniel spend some time apart, but they look forward to being reunited.

Abakada… Ina won Best Picture, Best Director, Best Screenplay, Best Actress (Tolentino), Best Cinematography, Best Editing, and Best Sound in the 2002 Film Academy of the Philippines Awards; and Best Picture, Best Director, Best Screenplay, Best Story, Best Actress, Best Cinematography, Best Editing, and Best Sound in the 2002 Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Awards.  Written by Patrick Campos

text:
2008 / Color / Drama / 90 minutes / Direction: Adolfo Borinaga Alix Jr / Screenplay: Adolfo B. Alix Jr and Nick Olanka / Cinematography: Albert Banzon Editing: Aleks Castañeda / Production Design: Adolfo B. Alix Jr and Jerome Zamora / Sound: Ditoy Aguila and Junel Valencia / Produced by Bicycle Pictures / Cast: Anita Linda (Adela), Jason Abalos, Joem Bascon, Angeli Bayani, Arnold Reyes, Kenneth Ocampo, Perla Bautista, Iza Calzado, Ricky Davao, German Moreno , Zyra dela Cerna, Arman Reyes, Joy Napoles, Nonoy Guial, Minda Garcia, Silvano Ambos, J. R. David, Andrew Maccatompag, Raymond Alfonso, Romer Bautista, Johson Vallo, Rolly Palmes, Maxie Evangelista, Nick Olanka, Jose Jonie Ocampo, Aiza Santiago, Arleen Cuevas, Nora Tiene, and James Pasion

Adela follows a day in the life of Adela, a retired radio actress now living in poverty and anonymity, who is celebrating her 80th birthday. On this day, she goes about her daily business, encountering mostly mundane and sometimes unforeseen circumstances. She helps out a neighbor who unexpectedly gives birth, listens wistfully to a radio drama, loses her wedding ring, gets swindled by a sweet-talker, hears mass, goes to the cemetery, visits her drug-addict son in prison, meets an old co-worker, and, finally, goes out alone to a seaside dumpsite for a picnic to end the day and to watch the sunset. She has prepared food enough for a few people, but her son who works in Qatar and her daughter who works as a housemaid in Makati cannot make it. In the end, Adela conquers another day, literally and symbolically alone, and yet with self-sufficiency and dignity.

Anita Linda won for her performance in the Southeast Asian Film category of the 2008 Cinemanila International Film Festival and the Young Critics Circle (YCC) Film Desk Citations.Adela won five other prizes of the YCC: Best Film, Best Screenplay, Best Achievement in Cinematography and Visual Design, Best Editing, and Best Achievement in Sound and Aural Orchestration. The film opened the 2008 Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival. It competed in the 2009 Sarasota International Film Festival; 2009 Festival del Cinema Africano, d’Asia e America Latina; and 2009 San Francisco Asian-American Film Festival.  Written by Patrick Campos

text:
1980 / Color / Drama / 210 minutes / Direction, Story, and Screenplay: Eddie Romero / Cinematography: Mike de Leon and Rody Lacap / Editing: Ben Barcelon / Production Design: Mel Chionglo / Sound: Rolly Ruta / Music: Ryan Cayabyab / Produced by Bancom Audiovision Corporation / Cast: Fernando Poe Jr (Daniel Aguila), Amalia Fuentes (Isabel), Christopher de Leon (Mari Aguila), Elizabeth Oropesa (Lilian), Jay Ilagan (Osman), Charo Santos (Sally), Eddie Garcia (Simeon), Andrea Andolong aka Sandy Andolong (Farida), Ricky Sandico (Raul), Chanda Romero, Daria Ramirez, Celia Rodriguez, Orestes Ojeda, Susan Valdez, Ruben Rustia, and Johnny Delgado

In 1978, Mari Aguila, an industrial magnate and former senator, scours the country in search of his father, Daniel Aguila, who has suddenly disappeared. Daniel’s story unfolds through a series of flashbacks, which begins in Manila in 1898, at the height of the revolution against Spain. As a child, Daniel witnesses the death of his father in an uprising engineered by Simeon, an ilustrado (educated). This same traitor rapes Daniel’s mother, Isabel, who then marries him for convenience.

 

 

Many years later, under American rule, Daniel is a charming young soldier in the colonial army. He accompanies his stepfather and some Americans in Mindanao where they divest a Muslim tribe of its lands, through a combination of deception and outright massacre. Daniel does not take part in the operation that causes the death of his mother; instead, he has an affair with a Muslim woman, Farida, who consequently gets pregnant. The woman later entrusts her son, Osman, to Daniel’s care.

In Laguna in 1924, Daniel falls in love with Sally, a lawyer, whom he meets because of a court case involving an anti-American religious sect and his own townmates. The two marry and have a son, Mari. Japanese aggression at the time triggers a war. Meanwhile, Daniel uncovers the incestuous relationship between his half-sister, Lilian, and his stepfather. Lilian tries but fails to seduce Daniel, and turns instead to Osman, spurning him after they sleep together.

Daniel and Mari join the United States Army Forces in the Far East (USAFFE). However, Hukbalahap guerrillas abduct Mari and agree to free him only if Daniel joins forces with them to liberate a strategic town. When the war ends, the USAFFE arrest the Huks and take over the postwar government with their Filipino lackeys. Daniel arrives at the realization that the Filipinos sacrificed so much for victory against the Japanese not for their fellow Filipinos but for the imperialist Americans.

In midlfe, Daniel keeps a mistress who eventually leaves him. His wife finds out about the mistress, gets sick, and eventually passes away. Daniel’s disenchantment with life and society deepens as the years unfold. His son Mari runs for Congress in 1953 and uses his money to win. In the 1970s, Daniel’s activist grandson Raul rejects the family’s fascism and kills himself when he realizes that Daniel has blackmailed Raul’s political mentors into silence. The despondent Daniel thinks he has had enough and runs away from it all. The story comes full circle when Mari’s search for his father ends in an Aeta village, where Daniel finally finds the serenity a perverse society cannot offer.

Aguila won Best Picture, Best Director, Best Screenplay, and Best Cinematography in the 1980 Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Awards. The Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino conferred on Daria Ramirez its Gawad Urian for Best Supporting Actress.  Written by Menchie R. Tajan

text:
(I Love You 1941) / 2004 / Color / Drama / 107 minutes / Direction: Joel Lamangan / Story: Ricardo Lee and Joel Lamangan / Screenplay: Ricardo Lee Cinematography: Rolly Manuel / Editing: Marya Ignacio / Production Design: Joey Luna / Art Direction: Joey Bilbao / Sound: Ramon Reyes / Music: Von de Guzman / Produced by Regal Entertainment and Basfilm Productions / Cast: Judy Ann Santos (Inya), Dennis Trillo (Ignacio), Jay Manalo (Captain Ichiru), Raymart Santiago (Edilberto), Jaclyn Jose (Tiyang Melba), Angelu de Leon (Maura), Neil Ryan Sese (Hiroshi), Marco Alcaraz (Akihiro), Iya Villania (Julia), Anita Linda , and Yasmien Kurdi

 

 

Edilberto, Ignacio, and Inya are childhood friends. Ignacio secretly loves Edilberto, but Edilberto loves and marries Inya. When the Japanese troops arrive in 1941, Captain Ichiru catches a glimpse of Ignacio singing and falls for him as a woman. The townspeople coax Ignacio to pretend he is a woman to spy for his people. He assumes the identity of Inya, and the real Inya becomes Binya. Soon, however, Ignacio falls in love with Ichiru, and while the relationship blossoms, Edilberto and Inya’s marriage collapses. She suffers a miscarriage, is accused by the rebels of being a traitor, and eventually loses her husband to the war. The loss of Edilberto strengthens her resolve to fight the Japanese and she becomes Commander Berto. Ichiru reveals to Ignacio that he knows the latter’s true identity and loves him for what he is. However, Hiroshi eventually succeeds in unseating Ichiru and captures his superior, who manages to escape through the help of his loyal supporters. Ichiru, Ignacio, and Akihiro, who loves Julia, seek refuge in the house of Tiyang Melba. In the end, Ichiru performs hara-kiri, and Akihiro also kills himself. Having known Ignacio’s secret all along, the translator-collaborator Maura betrays Ignacio and he is tortured for days to reveal who Commander Berto is and her whereabouts. Ignacio does not betray his dearest friend. Commander Berto and her troops invade the Japanese headquarters and save Ignacio. In the end, however, Ignacio uses his body to protect his best friend.

Aishite Imasu 1941 won Best Supporting Actor (Trillo), Best Production Design, and Best Sound in the 2005 Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Awards; Best Picture, Best Director, Best Actor (Trillo), Best Supporting Actor (Manalo), Best Editing, and Best Production Design in the 2005 Film Academy of the Philippines Awards; and Best Performance (Trillo, tied with Jomari Yllana) in the Young Critics Circle Film Desk Citations for 2004. In the 2004 Metro Manila Film Festival, the film won Third Best Picture, Best Supporting Actor (Trillo), and Most Gender-Sensitive Film.   Written by Ronald Baytan

text:
(Pleasure) / 1979 / Color / Drama / 115 minutes / Direction: Ishmael Bernal / Story: Cecille Lardizabal / Screenplay: Franklin Cabaluna and Ishmael Bernal / Cinematography: Sergio Lobo / Editing: Ike Jarlego Jr / Production Design: Noel Mallonga / Sound: Rolly Ruta / Music: George Canseco / Produced by Seven-Star Productions / Cast: Lorna Tolentino (Lingling), Amy Austria (Ayet), Suzette Ranillo (Esper), Butz Aquino, Antoinette Bas, Alma Bonnevie, Rustica Carpio, Menggie Cobarrubias , Laura Danao, George Estregan, Edmund Farolan, Junix Inocian, Dick Israel, Ramon Recto, Ruthie Roces, Juan Rodrigo, Jojo Santiago, and Cesar “Yay”’ Topacio

 

 

Aliw explores the lives of three nightclub hostesses, their strengths and weaknesses, and their quest for happiness. Ayet is shrewd and no-nonsense, selling imported goods on the side to her fellow bar girls. She must also choose between a rich, married man she lives with but does not love, and a working student whom she does. When the man learns of her affair with the student, he beats her up. She leaves him for the student but later realizes that her relationship with the latter is hopeless, as he cannot even earn enough for himself. She breaks up with the student and returns to the nightclub, where she is happiest.

Lingling, at 16, is the youngest in the club. Headstrong and cynical, she hates being told how to run her life. She lives with and supports a band player in the nightclub. She leaves him when he becomes too possessive and demanding, and takes up with a young mestizo who still lives with his parents. Finally, she leaves the mestizo and moves in with a married businessman who gives her everything but forbids her to leave the house without his permission, obliges her to visit him in the office, and so on. Deciding in favor of her freedom, Lingling leaves him and returns to the club.

Esper is the breadwinner for her indolent, gossipy mother and delinquent brother. She has a child by a married man who keeps promising to live with her. She has a persistent suitor in the neighborhood whom she ignores because he is poor. Eventually the father of her child abandons her, while her suitor, tired of waiting, marries someone else. Esper returns to the club to get over her sorrow.

Film critics consider Aliw one of the best in Ishmael Bernal’s filmography. It was nominated for Best Picture in the 1980 Gawad Urian.   Written by Menchie R. Tajan

Film critics consider Aliw one of the best in Ishmael Bernal’s filmography. It was nominated for Best Picture in the 1980 Gawad Urian.   Written by Menchie R. Tajan

text:
(Entertainment Paradise) / 1992 / Short Film / Color / Drama / 27 minutes / Direction: Mike de Leon / Screenplay: Clodualdo del Mundo Jr / Cinematography: Johnny Araojo / Editing: Jose Almojuela / Production Design: Cesar Hernando / Music: Ding Achacoso / Produced by Cinema Artists Philippines, and organized by the Japan Foundation ASEAN Culture Center and NHK Enterprises / Cast: Julio Diaz (Julio Madiaga), Melissa de Leon (Ligaya Paraiso), Johnny Delgado, Dexter Doria, and Tony Mabesa

 

 

Julio Madiaga, a down-on-his-luck probinsiyano (country boy) in search of a better life, and Ligaya Paraiso, Madiaga’s former sweetheart, both roam the city to find work. They meet while queuing for a job audition for the largest employment agency in the country, “Aliwan Paradise,” organized by the newly established Ministry of Entertainment. Aliwan Paradise is searching for a unique and radically new type of entertainment (and entertainers) to help assuage the current national crisis. To this end, the ministry, headed by the impresario, has called for a national audition, where anyone can showcase his or her talent before a panel of judges comprised of two clerics, two military officials, a teacher, and a mute student. One by one hopeful contenders showcase their individual talents, ranging from a teacher who can “breathe fire” while teaching literature, to a former soldier-turned-dancing-traffic-enforcer, to a nurse-turned-stripper. Julio’s talent is to perform the role of Jesus Christ in a modern-day, high-tech staging of the Lenten play. The impresario finds his performance “traditional” and “too reactionary,” therefore not acceptable to Aliwan Paradise. Ligaya, on the other hand, does a song-and-dance number, singing about being a Filipina lass with simple dreams of going abroad to marry a rich foreigner. Cunningly, Ligaya seduces the impresario backstage, hoping she will be sent overseas as an entertainer. Julio discovers the seduction. Charging into the audition room in a fit of rage, he accuses the impresario of oppressing hopeless people like him and Ligaya, and rebukes the jury for their own participation. Ligaya, having a change of heart, rushes to Julio’s side and consoles him at center stage, before the eyes of the jury and the impresario. After their emotional exchange, the impresario erupts into wild applause, claiming the scene to be top-notch entertainment, the radically new kind of show that the ministry is looking for. In the end, Julio and Ligaya, now working for the impresario, act out scenes that showcase their poverty-stricken lives. The impresario then tells the audience that poverty is what the Philippines has in abundance, the natural resource that it should learn to develop: misery is the new entertainment, and poverty exploitation the name of the game.

A short feature under the omnibus Southern Winds, Aliwan Paradise was de Leon’s vehicle to stand on equal billing with the likes of Shôji Kôkami (Japan), Slamet Rahardjo (Indonesia), and Cherd Songsri (Thailand). A satire that explores the country’s fascination for entertainment, the film takes off from Lino Brocka’s Maynila: Sa mga Kuko ng Liwanag (Manila: In the Claws of Light), 1975, and presents the viewer with a “what-if” scenario.

The film won Best Editing in the Young Critics Circle Film Desk Citations for 1992, and received a special Ginintuang Gawad from the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino.  Written by Anne Frances Sangil

text:
(The Child) / 2000 / Color / Drama / 135 minutes / Direction: Rory B. Quintos / Screenplay: Ricardo Lee and Raymond Lee / Cinematography: Joe Batac / Editing: George Jarlego / Production Design: Nuel C. Naval / Sound: Ramon Reyes / Music: Jessie Lasaten / Produced by Star Cinema / Cast: Vilma Santos (Josie), Claudine Barretto (Carla), Joel Torre (Rudy), Baron Geisler (Michael), Sheila May Alvero (Daday), Amy Austria, and Cherry Pie Picache

Josie is a mother of three who goes to Hong Kong to work as a domestic helper in order to provide a better future for her family. Her failure to come home for the funeral of her husband, Rudy, leads her children, especially her eldest, Carla, to resent her.

 

 

Years later, Josie has finally saved enough money to come home and start a business of her own. Upon arriving at her house, Josie soon feels the huge gap between her and her children. Carla, now a college student, does nothing to disguise her hatred for what she sees as Josie’s coldhearted abandonment of her family. Her two other children, Michael, now in high school, and Daday, the youngest, are both aloof and shy away every time Josie tries to hug them. Josie tries her best to win back her children’s affection, and Michael and Daday eventually warm up to her. Carla, on the other hand, continues to openly show her contempt. She stops going to school and soon hooks up with a good-for-nothing boyfriend who goads her to drink alcohol and use drugs. In an attempt to save Carla, Josie confronts her and tells her the real reason why she could not come home for Rudy’s funeral and the hard life she experienced in Hong Kong, enduring all the suffering just so that she could send money for their education. When Josie’s plan to start a business fails, she decides to return to Hong Kong to work once again as a domestic helper. This time, however, she leaves with the full support and understanding of her children.

Anak explores with more insight a subject close to the hearts of many Filipinos. While the government and the media are quick to hail overseas Filipino workers (OFWs) as the country’s new heroes, they often fail to mention the tribulations of the OFWs and their families.

Anak was the Philippines’ official entry for the Best Foreign Language Film category in the 73rd Oscar Awards.  Written by Elvin Valerio

text:
(The Ruins) / 1956 / Black and White / Drama / 119 minutes / Direction: Lamberto V. Avellana / Screenplay: Rolf Bayer / Cinematography: Mike Accion / Editing: Enrique Jarlego / Sound: July Hidalgo / Music: Francisco Buencamino Jr / Produced by LVN Pictures / Cast: Rosa Rosal (Cita), Tony Santos (Vic), Joseph de Cordova, Vic Silayan, Vic Bacani, Leroy Salvador, Rosa Aguirre, Oscar Keesee, Alfonso Carvajal, Johnny Reyes, Eddie Rodriguez, and Arturo Moran

 

 

A veteran of the Korean War, Vic, returns to find his mother on her deathbed amidst the appalling squalor of the ruins of old Intramuros. She depends on the charity of a neighbor, Cita, who works as a prostitute. A relationship develops between the grateful ex-soldier and the pretty bar girl. When the mother dies, he moves in with her. But they are both so poor that survival is difficult. When his money runs out, he decides to join a smuggling syndicate. After a bitter quarrel over his decision to make a fast buck, the two lovers part ways. He is seen in the company of a notorious smuggler and, hunted by the authorities, he takes refuge in the home of the prostitute. The smuggler with whom he has fallen out catches up with him, and the defenseless ex-soldier is beaten up by the crime lord’s thugs. Angry and desperate, he takes his gun from its hiding place and goes after his enemies. The smuggler and the prostitute’s younger brother die in the ensuing shoot-out. But the tragedy has brought the lovers back together. In the end, the two look forward to a better life with the promise of resettlement in another place.

Anak Dalita deals with the dregs of society and in its hard-edged realism, uncommon in its time, has become a classic of Philippine filmmaking. It won the Golden Harvest Award (Grand Prix) for Best Picture at the 1956 Asian Film Festival. In the same year, LVN Pictures received the International Prestige Award from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences for the project. Anak Dalita was the first Filipino film to be shown at Frankfurt International Film Festival in 1957.  Written by Lena S. Pareja

text:
(Shadow) / 2000 / Short film / Color / Drama / 13 minutes / Direction, Screenplay, and Cinematography: Raymond Red; Editing: Renewin Alano, Mel Ladao, and Raymond Red / Production Design: Daniel Red / Music: Yano / Produced by Mistulang Pelikula / Cast: Ronnie Lazaro, John Arcilla, Eddie Garcia, Ermie Concepcion, and Ronnie Pulido

Anino tells the story of an unnamed man from the province who is unable to leave Manila for home because of his financial predicament. Without money and food, he wanders the city carrying around his only possession, an old camera. In the duration of one day, he has three unfortunate encounters. On his way out after spending some time to rest on a church pew, a young man in black calls his attention and berates him for wasting his life. After he walks aimlessly around the indigent spaces of the city, a street urchin offers to take his picture but steals his camera instead. Finally, stripped of everything, he is humiliated by an affluent middle-aged man, who alights from his Mercedes Benz to point a gun at him. The ending is ambiguous and double-edged. After these encounters, he is beaten ostensibly by policemen in civilian clothes. He passes out and awakens inside a jeep driven by the man in black, who mysteriously tells him that it is time for him to go home.

Like in Red’s earlier short films, Anino features a solitary figure, alienated from the world outside of him. It also sets the themes that Red returns to in his next feature film, Himpapawid (Manila Skies), 2009, such as the inner conflicts of the disenfranchised, the struggle against abuse of power, and the possibilities of solitude and innocence as responses to despair. Anino is the first Philippine film to win the Palme d’Or in the Cannes Film Festival short film category.  Written by Patrick Campos

text:
(Woman of Breakwater) / 2003 / Color / Drama / 124 minutes / Direction, Story, and Screenplay: Mario O’Hara / Cinematography: Rey de Leon / Editing: Roberto Vasadre / Production Design: Koko Teodoro / Sound: Noel Cruz Bruan / Music: Jesse Lucas / Produced by Entertainment Warehouse / Cast: Katherine Luna (Paquita), Kristoffer King (Basilio), Gardo Versoza (Dave), Alcris Galura (Buboy), Yoyoy Villame, Lou Veloso, Lucita Soriano, and Amy Austria

 

 

Babae sa Breakwater tells the story of Basilio, who escapes the penury of life in the province and travels to Manila with his younger brother Buboy in the hope of finding a better life. Instead, he finds himself living in the makeshift tenements underneath the breakwater of Manila Bay. He meets and falls in love with the prostitute Paquita, who, despite her young age, is already a veteran in her profession and has the bruises, sores, and diseases to prove it. Basilio and Paquita’s love for each other is beleaguered by poverty and the denizens of the breakwater. Their lives are also constantly threatened by Dave, a crooked and envious ex-cop and now the breakwater’s boss and protector, who sets off a series of tragedies. Renowned novelty singer/composer Yoyoy Villame appears as a street side entertainer, singing songs that he made famous twenty years ago. Ever the astute chronicler of urban life in Manila, Villame’s songs provide a commentary on the film’s characters and their inevitable fate.

Babae sa Breakwater received the awards for Best Picture, Best Production Design, and Best Music from the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino in 2004. The Young Critics Circle also recognized it with awards for Best Film and Best Screenplay. The film made the rounds of international film festivals, such as Fribourg International Film Festival, Vesoul Asian Film Festival, Cinefan: Festival of Asian and Arab Cinema, and the Directors’ Fortnight at Cannes Film Festival. Babae sa Breakwater features a breakthrough performance from newcomer Katherine Luna, who won Best Actress awards at Cinefan, Cinemanila International Film Festival, and the Young Critics Circle. In 2011, the Manunuri chose Babae sa Breakwater as one of its 10 Best Films of the Decade 2000-2009.  Written by Elvin Valerio

text:
(Woman on a Tin Roof) / 1998 / Color / Drama / 103 minutes / Direction: Mario O’Hara / Screenplay: Mario O’Hara (from a play by Agapito Joaquin) / Cinematography: Rey de Leon / Editing: Bee Jae / Production Design: James Quimson / Sound: Joe Climaco / Music: Blitz Padua / Produced by Good Harvest Productions / Cast: Mike Magat (Maldo), Aya Medel (Toying), Anita Linda (Amapola), William Romero (Federico), Frank Rivera (Nitoy), and Luciano B. Carlos (Temyong)

Set in a small community of homeless people who find shelter in the Manila North Cemetery, the story centers on Maldo, a poor stuntman waiting for his big break in the movies, and his wife Toying who, unbeknownst to Maldo, sidelines as a prostitute just to make ends meet. Among their neighbors in the cemetery are their wedding godmother Amapola, an elderly actress and singer, and Federico, a former musical composer for Sampaguita Pictures. The film follows Maldo’s struggle in the unforgiving world of show business and portrays how the movie industry takes advantage of the little people like the movie extras and stuntmen. Maldo will do anything to become a movie star, even allowing himself to be used as a punching bag by the action-star boss. He takes on the most dangerous stunts even without insurance and eventually offers his body to his gay director, Direk Temyong. When Direk Temyong promises Maldo that he will star in an international soft-porn gay movie, Maldo sees this as an opportunity and agrees to do the project. However, Maldo’s dreams are crushed when the producer decides to use another actor.

O’Hara’s masterful adaptation of Agapito Joaquin’s play is an elegy to the glory days of Philippine cinema when movies, not television, were the main source of entertainment for millions of Filipinos. It is also a tribute to the people who are often overlooked yet are vital to the movie industry—the stuntmen, movie extras, billboard painters, musicians, and, finally, the fans.

The film is one of the so-called pito-pito (seven-seven) movies produced by Good Harvest Productions, a Regal Films subsidiary that Lily Monteverde put up in order to give serious filmmakers, both new and veteran, a chance to make the kind of movies they wanted but with a limited budget of 2.5 million pesos, seven days of principal photography, and seven days of postproduction—hence the term “pito-pito.” With this film, O’Hara delivered a poignant farewell to an industry that he so dearly loved.  Written by Elvin Valerio

text:
(The Woman in the Septic Tank) / 2011 / Color / Comedy / 87 minutes / Direction: Marlon Rivera / Screenplay: Chris Martinez / Cinematography: Larry Manda / Editing: Ike Veneracion / Production Design: Reji Regalado / Art Direction: Michael Labora / Sound: Albert Michael Idioma and Addiss Tabong / Music: Vincent de Jesus / Produced by Cinemalaya Foundation, Martinez Rivera Films, Quantum Films Production, and Straight Shooters Media / Cast: Eugene Domingo, JM de Guzman, Kean Cipriano, Cai Cortez, Jonathan Tadioan, Carlos Dala, KC Marcelo, Cherry Pie Picache, Mercedes Cabral, Lani Tapia, and Sonny Bautista.

A film about making films, Ang Babae sa Septic Tank is a tongue-in-cheek look at both Philippine poverty and Philippine independent cinema, and how the latter exploits the country’s destitution in the guise of art. Three young filmmakers dream of making it big in the international film festival circuit. They conceptualize their new film, from script to casting, to rewrites, down to the actual shooting of the movie. Called Walang-Wala (Destitute), the movie is about an impoverished mother, Mila, who lives in the slums with her seven children and who is forced to sell one of her kids to a Caucasian pedophile. As the three filmmakers debate on the numerous choices for the cast, genre—musical? docu-drama?—and narrative of their film, the film dramatizes how these choices will affect the look of their future film. In the end, pressured by the demands from their main actor and by what they think various film festivals expect from an award-winning film, they decide to compromise and make significant changes in their project.

In the 2012 Asia Pacific Screen Awards (APSA), Ang Babae sa Septic Tank won the APSA Academy Network for the Promotion of Asian Cinema Development Prize. It also won the People’s Choice Award for Favorite Actress (Domingo) in the 2012 Asian Film Awards; the Special Jury Prize in the 2012 Granada Cines del Sur Film Festival; and the Best First Time Director in the 2012 Philadelphia Film Festival. It won the Audience Award for New Breed Full-Length Feature and the Balanghai trophies for Best Film, Best Director, Best Actress, and Best Screenplay in the 2011 Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival; Best Motion Picture (Musical or Comedy), Best Performance by an Actress in a Leading Role, Best Director, Best Original Screenplay, Best Editing, and Best Musical Score in the 2012 Golden Screen Awards; and Best Digital Movie Editor and Best Digital Movie Musical Score in the 2012 PMPC Star Awards. The film also competed in the 2012 Buenos Aires International Festival of Independent Cinema, the 2012 Hong Kong International Film Festival, and the 2011 Vancouver International Film Festival.  Written by Anne Frances Sangil

text:
1957 / Black and White / Drama / 100 minutes / Direction: Lamberto V. Avellana / Screenplay: Rolf Bayer / Cinematography: Mike Accion / Editing: Gregorio Carballo / Art Direction: Teody Carmona / Sound: July P. Hidalgo / Music: Francisco Buencamino Jr / Choreography: Francisca Reyes-Aquino / Produced by LVN Pictures / Cast: Rosa Rosal (Bala-amai), Tony Santos (Hassan), Leroy Salvador (Asid), Joseph de Cordova (Datu Tahil), Vic Silayan (Jikiri), Oscar Keesee (Ismail), Pedro Faustino, Arturo Moran, Tony Dantes, and Gerry Gabaldon

The Badjao (Sama Dilaut) are non-Muslim sea nomads of southern Mindanao who live in boats and in houses built on stilts above the coastal waters. Hassan is a pearl diver who is well known among his people. One day, his boat is attacked by Muslims from a nearby village. Together with his father and other Badjao elders, Hassan goes to their village to express their desire to live in peace on the waters around the Muslim lands.

 

 

Hassan meets and falls in love with a Muslim girl, Bala-amai, the niece of the tribal chief Datu Tahil. The Muslims, who look down on non-Muslims, such as the Badjao, disapprove, but Bala-amai’s greedy uncle is captivated by the rare blue pearls that Hassan offers as part of the dowry. He gives consent to the marriage on the condition that Hassan leave his home and settle down in the Muslim village with his bride, in defiance of Badjao tradition. Hassan’s father disowns him, and he is forbidden to rejoin his people. But Hassan’s love for Bala-amai is so strong that he willingly submits to Muslim ways of living, tilling the soil like the rest of her kin.

One day, Datu Tahil calls for Hassan, asking for him to leave farming and to return to pearl diving. Hassan politely refuses. When he leaves, the chief secretly orders his men to set fire to Hassan’s hut. Bala-amai is about to give birth and she almost loses her life and the baby but for Hassan’s timely arrival. Hassan decides to return to the Badjao with his wife and child, but before he does so, he confronts Datu Tahil who ordered the burning of his hut. Bala-amai’s decision to go with her husband prevents the Muslims from taking further action against Hassan, allowing them to leave in peace. Arriving in Badjao territory, he and his wife are rejected by the tribe. To appease his father’s anger, Hassan resorts to an old Badjao custom. In full view of everyone, he throws his newborn son into the sea (according to Badjao ancient belief, the baby is worthy to live if it survives). Nobody moves to save the baby until Hassan’s younger brother Asid finally dives into the water, followed by the other relatives. The baby survives, and Hassan is welcomed back into the clan.

Badjao won Best Director, Best Screenplay, Best Cinematography, and Best Editing at the 1957 Asian Film Festival. The Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences gave LVN Pictures the 1957 International Prestige Award for the fame and honor that Badjao brought to the country. The film was shown at the 1961 Vancouver Film Festival, the 1962 Edinburgh Film Festival, and the 1963 Coronado Film Festival.  Written by Lena S. Pareja

(Children Metal Divers) / 2009 / Color / Drama / 93 minutes / Direction: Ralston G. Jover / Screenplay: Henry C. Burgos and Ralston G. Jover / Cinematography: Ruben H. dela Cruz and Carlo Mendoza / Editing: Kats Serraon and Charliebebs Gohetia / Production Design: Deans V. Habal / Sound: Mark Locsin / Music: Teresa Barrozo / Produced by Apogee Productions / Cast: Gina Pareño (Sylvia), Meljun Ginto (Utoy), Vincent Olano (Bungal), J. R. Olano (Bengkong), Ian Villaroel (Potot), Paolo Parane (Paolo), Joven Paje (Joven), Aljon Ibañez, R. J. Kim Resulta, Simon Ibarra, Cherry Malvar, Joe Gruta, Ketchup Eusebio, Valentino Garcia, and Rheyay Paje

 

 

Utoy, Bungal, Bengkong, Potot, Paolo, and Joven are young metal divers who scavenge for scraps and junk in the polluted waters of Manila Bay in the area of Baseco, Tondo. One day, after the children salvage a sunken anchor near the lighthouse, Bungal hears a whistle in the air and thinks this is a mermaid’s lucky call, though the sound could have been just a boat siren. He swims out to follow the sound and never returns.

Utoy, the youngestmetal diver, is determined to search for Bungal, even while the other children have become fearful of diving. The adults appear unperturbed and seem to think that the disappearance is normal. Utoy is heartened when Bungal’s grandmother, Sylvia, attempts to look for her grandson. But even she accepts the fate of Bungal and only offers up her sufferings to Allah. Refusing to take things as they are, Utoy hopefully swims out after dark to search for his best friend.

Bakal Boys won the Network for the Promotion of Asian Cinema Award in the 2009 Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival. It won the Chiapputi Award in the 2009 Torino International Festival of Young Cinema, Best Screenplay in the 2010 Skip City International D-Cinema Festival, the Public Award for Best Film in the 2010 Lyons Asian Film Festival, and Best Film in the Young Critics Circle Film Desk  Citations for 2009. It earned a Special Mention in the 2009 Thessaloniki Film Festival and a Special Merit in the Dragons and Tigers section of the 2009 Vancouver International Film Festival.

 

Written by Patrick Campos

text:
(Why Is There a Yesterday?) / 1996 / Direction: Joel Lamangan / Screenplay: Roy Iglesias and Julius Alfonso / Cinematography: Romeo Vitug / Editing: Jess Navarro / Production Design: Manny B. Morfe / Sound: Ramon Reyes / Music: Jessie Lasaten / Produced by Viva Films and IAM Productions / Cast: Nora Aunor (Helen/Karina Salvacion), Eddie Garcia (Col Valderama), Dawn Zulueta, Angel Baldomar, Daniel Fernando, Tony Mabesa, Rolando Tinio, Ernie Zarate, Ray Ventura, Irma Adlawan, Jim Pebanco, Richard Quan, Madeleine Nicolas, Ama Quiambao, and Gamaliel Viray

 

 

Bakit May Kahapon Pa? focuses on the village girl Helen, who is spared when a platoon of soldiers led by Colonel Valderama massacres her father and mother, along with peasants accused of sympathizing with the communists. When Helen grows up, she is consumed with anger and is continually haunted by memories of the carnage committed by the “devils.” Hungry for revenge, she devises a scheme of retribution, killing Valderama’s son, Lt Mario Valderama, first. Posing as Karina Salvacion, she is able to enter the home of Valderama, now a well-admired general who is about to retire from the service. The revenge plot of Karina is interwoven with various junctures in Helen’s past, providing texture and motivation to her mission. The film finally closes with a violent shoot-out that culminates with the death of Valderama and Helen/Karina.

Bakit May Kahapon Pa? competed in the 1997 East Asian Film and Television Festival in Penang, Malaysia, where Nora Aunor won the Golden Pearl Award for Best Actress. It also competed in the 1997 Cairo International Film Festival, the 1997 Singapore International Film Festival, the 1998 International Film Festival of India, and was exhibited in the 1997 Fukuoka International Film Festival, the 1997 Asian Film Festival in Japan, and the 1998 Brussels International Independent Film Festival. Eddie Garcia won Best Actor in the 1997 Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Awards. Aunor received Best Actress award in the 1997 Gawad Urian, where the film also won Best Cinematography.  Written by Patrick Campos

text:
2008 / Color / Drama / 116 minutes / Direction: Mark Meily / Screenplay: Roy Iglesias / Cinematography: Lee Meily / Editing: Danny Añonuevo / Production Design: Aped Santos / Sound: Ditoy Aguila / Music: Vincent de Jesus / Produced by Viva Films / Cast: Jericho Rosales (Celso Resurrecion), Anne Curtis (Feliza Reyes), Phillip Salvador (Daniel), Joel Torre, Rio Locsin, Michael de Mesa, Baron Geisler, Ryan Eigenmann, Mark Bautista, Carlo Aquino, and Leo Martinez

Baler tells the story of Celso Resurrecion, a half-Spanish half-Filipino soldier stationed with the Spanish contingent in the far-flung town of Baler, in what is now Aurora Province. There he meets and falls in love with a beautiful local lass, Feliza Reyes. Celso and Feliza are forced to keep their love affair a secret because Feliza’s father, Daniel, is a member of the revolutionary movement. Their story unfolds amidst the true events that happened on 27 Jun 1898 when a group of Filipino rebels attack a Spanish military outpost. The Spanish soldiers are forced to seek sanctuary in the town church. Instead of blowing up the church with canons, the rebels decide that the more humane approach is to wait for the soldiers to voluntarily surrender. Convinced that Spain will send reinforcements, the soldiers decide to remain inside the church, even after they are reduced to eating stray animals. The standoff lasts 340 days, later to be known as the Siege of Baler. One day Spanish emissaries arrive to inform the Spanish contingent that Spain has lost the war. The Spanish officer in Baler refuses to believe this, and when Celso and his companions are caught trying to abandon the church, Celso is condemned to death. Just then, news of Spain’s surrender is confirmed and the Spanish soldiers finally leave their stronghold and surrender. In the end, Feliza, who by now has a child by Celso, excitedly looks forward to being reunited with her beloved. Instead she finds Celso’s lifeless body inside the church.

Although panned by some critics for its pro-Spanish point of view, overly melodramatic tone, and the problematic casting of the Caucasian-looking Anne Curtis as a provincial barrio lass, Baler is noteworthy because it brings to the fore an incident in the country’s colorful history that has been largely overlooked in the academe. It is also one of the few historical films in the early 21st century funded by a major studio to join the Metro Manila Film Festival, a festival that tends to favor films with box-office appeal instead of those that aspire for artistic excellence and/or sociocultural relevance.

Baler went on to become the most awarded movie of the year. The Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences, the Film Academy of the Philippines, and the PMPC Star Awards all acknowledged Baler as the Best Picture of 2008. The traditionally box office-oriented Metro Manila Film Festival awarded Baler in every category in which it was nominated—namely, Best Picture, Best Director, Best Screenplay, Best Cinematography, Best Production Design, Best Editing, Best Actress (Curtis), and Best Supporting Actor (Salvador).  Written by Elvin Valerio

text:
(Threat from the Past) / 1977 / Color / Action / Direction and Screenplay: Eddie Romero / Cinematography: Justo Paulino / Editing: Ben Barcelon / Production Design: Gay Dolorfino / Sound: Angel Avellana / Music: Berg and Marilyn Villapando and Vic Santiago / Produced by Hemisphere Pictures Inc / Cast: Vic Vargas (Reg Corpus), Rafael Roco Jr (Sgt Rigor), Roland Dantes (Tino), Lito Legaspi (Bobby Alvaran), Ruben Rustia (Don Julio Serrano), Chanda Romero, Roderick Paulate, and Celita de Castro.

 

 

Banta ng Kahapon is set against the backdrop of the 1969 congressional elections, a political milieu dominated by guns, goons, and gold. Don Julio Serrano is the mastermind behind the killing of Congressman Alvaran, but the slain solon’s son, Bobby, is unaware of it. Bobby is drawn into an alliance with Serrano for political reasons, not knowing that Serrano is his father’s murderer. Meanwhile, the hunt is on for Tino, the mute ex-convict who was hired for the job by Serrano’s henchmen on the very day he got out of prison. Among those after him are the policemen headed by Sgt Rigor, Serrano’s men who want to silence him, and a former bodyguard of the slain congressman, Reg Corpus. In the final confrontation, the mute who poses a threat to the unholy alliance of Serrano and Alvaran confronts his pursuers in a gun-blasting finale.

From Gawad Urian, Banta ng Kahapon got an award for Best Editing and a nomination for Best Director. The film is notable for its realistic and detailed depiction of the contemporary political scene as material for cinema.  Written by Emelie Capulong and Rosalie Matilac

text:
(Lea’s Story) / 1998 / Color / Drama / 109 minutes / Direction: Chito S. Roño / Screenplay: Lualhati Bautista / Cinematography: Charlie Peralta / Editing: Jaime D. Davila / Production Design: Manny Morfe / Sound: Albert Michael Idioma / Music: Jessie Lasaten / Produced by Star Cinema / Cast: Vilma Santos (Lea), Albert Martinez (Ding), Ariel Rivera (Raffy), Angel Aquino (Elinor), Carlo Aquino (Ogie), Serena Dalrymple (Maya), Raymond Bagatsing (Johnny), Cherry Pie Picache (Sr Anne), Rosemarie Gil (Mrs Zalameda), Cita Astals (Mrs Olivarez), Dexter Doria (Mrs Gatmaitan), and Andrea del Rosario (Jinky)

Based on the Palanca award-winning novel of the same title, the movie revolves around the life of Lea, a mother of two who works at a women’s crisis center. While she facilitates the rescue and recovery of abused women and children, she also tries to raise her two children, Ogie and Maya, both of whom are attempting to come to terms with the fact that while they share the same mother, they have two different fathers. Raffy is the father of Ogie, and Ding is the father of Maya. Things get complicated when the long-absent Raffy returns and asks for regular visits with his son. Lea agrees, as it is an ideal opportunity for Ogie to get to know his father. Raffy asks if he can take sole custody of Ogie in the long run so that he can bring the boy with him to America, where he and his new wife Elinor plan to migrate. Lea tells Ogie that he must make his own decision, but she will always be his mother. Meanwhile, Lea’s relationship with Ding ends, as Ding decides to marry another woman. He also wants his daughter Maya to live with him and his new wife. As she did with her son, Lea tells Maya that she must decide for herself but, no matter what her decision turns out to be, she will always be her mother. In the end, the two children decide to stay with Lea. The movie, like the novel it is adapted from, attempts to showcase the role of women in a patriarchal society—as mothers, wives, daughters, or workers—and how women try to live up to all the labels society imposes upon them.

The film won the Special Jury Award in the 1999 Asia-Pacific Film Festival; Best Actress (Santos) and Best Director in the 1999 Brussels International Independent Film Festival; Best Picture, Best Actress, Best Supporting Actress (Dalrymple), and Best Screenplay in the 1999 Gawad Urian; Best Picture, Best Actress, Best Supporting Actress, Best Supporting Actor (Aquino), and Best Production Design in the 1999 Film Academy of the Philippines Awards; Best Child Actor (Aquino), Best Child Actress (Dalrymple), and Best Story in the 1999 Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Awards; and Best Film, Best Screenplay, and Best Performance (Santos) in the Young Critics Circle Film Desk Citations for 1998.  Written by Anne Frances Sangil

text:
(13th Battalion) / 1949 / Color / Drama / Direction: Manuel Silos / Story: Jaime de la Rosa / Music: Quin Velasco / Produced by LVN Pictures / Cast: Carmen Rosales, Jaime de la Rosa, Joseph de Cordova, Jose Cris Soto, Johnny Reyes, Ven Medina, Alfonso Carvajal, Tony Santos, Mario Montenegro, and Justina David

 

 

A rich boy (de la Rosa) falls in love with a poor girl (Rosales). They plan to get married but war breaks out. He becomes a soldier and later forms a guerrilla group called Batalyon XIII. Rosales also fights in the hills as “Kapitan Ligaya.” Some of Rosales’s men turn out to be bandits, who capture de la Rosa. According to the laws of Rosales’s group, de la Rosa must be executed, but because of her love for him, Rosales tricks her men into helping him escape.

Batalyon XIII was the first film done in Anscocolor, which gave the movie a “full natural color.” It was not only the “first LVN 100 percent color super production” processed in Hollywood but also the first full-color film ever produced by any studio in the Philippines. The movie’s commercial success prompted LVN Pictures to acquire its own color-processing laboratory.  Written by Rosalie Matilac

A rich boy (de la Rosa) falls in love with a poor girl (Rosales). They plan to get married but war breaks out. He becomes a soldier and later forms a guerrilla group called Batalyon XIII. Rosales also fights in the hills as “Kapitan Ligaya.” Some of Rosales’s men turn out to be bandits, who capture de la Rosa. According to the laws of Rosales’s group, de la Rosa must be executed, but because of her love for him, Rosales tricks her men into helping him escape.

Batalyon XIII was the first film done in Anscocolor, which gave the movie a “full natural color.” It was not only the “first LVN 100 percent color super production” processed in Hollywood but also the first full-color film ever produced by any studio in the Philippines. text:
(Phil-American Boy) / 1997 / Color / Drama / 113 minutes / Direction and Screenplay: Jose Javier Reyes / Cinematography: Ding Achacoso / Editing: Danny Gloria / Production Design: Benjie De Guzman / Art Direction: Lito Bonus / Sound: Ramon Reyes / Music: Nonong Buencamino / Produced by Star Cinema / Cast: Patrick Garcia (Christopher Dahoff), Zsa Zsa Padilla (Tessie), Edu Manzano (Danny), Nida Blanca (Cedes), Anna Larrucea (Angela), Joshua Spafford (Michael Dahoff), Cherry Pie Picache, Eula Valdez, Laura James, and Piolo Pascual

 

 

Christopher Dahoff or “Amboy,” who is 15 years of age and out of school, is the son of American soldier Michael Dahoff and Tessie, an untalented Filipina nightclub singer in Olongapo. Coming from a string of failed relationships and running on empty, Tessie decides it is time for her and Amboy to move to Manila to try their luck. In their new home, Amboy forges friendships with the neighborhood kids, especially Angela whose grandmother Cedes owns the house they are renting. Tessie finds work in a shoe store where she meets and falls in love with Danny, a luxury car salesman. Despite Amboy’s protests, Danny moves in with Tessie and provides for the family. For love of his mother, Amboy gives Danny a chance, but Danny turns out to be irascible, abusive, and violent. He eventually loses his job because of unliquidated funds, and the tables are turned: Tessie is now the provider for the jobless Danny. Michael Dahoff resurfaces, kindling hopes in Amboy about living with his father in the States. Amboy threatens to leave his mother if she does not kick Danny out of the house. Tessie finally explodes and tells her son to go away. Amboy decides to live with his father, but Michael is not yet ready to take his son to America. Danny and Tessie fight over Tessie’s personal savings, which Danny has stolen. Danny beats up Tessie, and Amboy comes home just in time to help defend his mother from the vicious monster. In the end, Amboy realizes that he and his mother are an inseparable and unbeatable duo, and are each other’s source of strength and comfort.

A realistic film about the life of Amerasians left behind by their fathers, Batang PX won Best Actress (Padilla) in the Film Academy of the Philippines Awards and the Gawad Urian, as well as Best Film, Best Screenplay, and Best Performance (Garcia) in the Young Critics Circle Film Desk Citations.  Written by Ronald Baytan

(West Side Avenue) / 2001/ Color / Drama / 315 minutes / Direction and Screenplay: Lav Diaz / Cinematography: Miguel Fabie III / Editing: Ronald Allan Dale / Production Design: Cesar Hernando / Sound: Rudy Gonzales and Alex Tomboc / Music: Joey Ayala / Produced by Hinabing Pangarap Productions / Cast: Yul Servo (Hanzel Harana), Joel Torre (Juan Mijares), Gloria Diaz (Lolita), Angel Aquino (Elvira), Priscilla Almeda (Dolores), Jomar Roldan (Frederick), Raul Arellano (Dindo), Arthur Acuña (Bartolo), Ruben Tizon (Abdon), Preston Barnes (Gordon), Arianne Recto (Dr Santos), Malik Walton (Falcon), and Eric Celerio (Filmmaker)

 

 

The story revolves around the investigation by Filipino-American police detective Juan Mijares of the fatal shooting of newly arrived immigrant Hanzel Harana in Jersey City. The film follows Mijares as he interrogates Arab storeowners, a Caucasian street bum, and Black and Latino apartment dwellers, along with Filipino Americans, including Harana’s mother Lolita, grandfather Lolo Abdon, girlfriend Dolores, and sometime housemates Frederick and Dindo. Even as he pursues the question of who killed Hanzel, Mijares deals with his own torments and, during sessions with his psychiatrist, he unburdens himself of memories and dreams of his mother Elvira in her younger days, or of youths amidst some ruins, staring accusingly at him.

As Mijares’s investigation unfolds, he learns that Hanzel’s mother Lolita had come to the United Statesto find means to provide for her husband and four children back home. While working as a nurse’s aide for the elderly, she had been courted by one of her well-to-do patients, Gordon, and consented to marrying him for the sake of a better life for her children in the United States. By the time Hanzel arrives, his mother is taking care of Gordon, now rendered a mute quadriplegic by a series of strokes. A Filipino housekeeper and aide named Bartolo turns out to be Lolita’s lover who malevolently refuses her wishes to end the affair. The situation arouses Hanzel’s disdain for and resentment toward his mother, whom he accuses of being a whore twice over.

But Hanzel’s love for Lolita outweighs his anger, his greatest wish being to see his family complete once again by bringing his mother back to the Philippines. The situation at Gordon and Lolita’s house leads Hanzel to move in with Lolo Abdon in Jersey City, in whom he finds comfort for a while. However, Hanzel’s despair over his family situation, alienation in a foreign land, and the need to belong lead him to fall in with some Filipinos who offer the prospect of quick fixes for all sorrows, psychological or financial. Mijares eventually drops the case, admitting that he would have ended up killing a lot of Filipinos otherwise.

In withholding the identity of the killer, and its ambiguity in stating the death as a suicide or a murder, the film places emphasis on the responsibility shared by those who have come in contact with Hanzel. Mijares himself shares in this guilt. He turns out to be as lost and tormented a soul as the dead youth haunting the investigation. In an attempt to find redemption, he confesses names, places, and details of his murderous past to the camera of a young filmmaker named Taga-Timog, the first of a number of appearances of this Diaz alter ego.

Batang West Side won the Silver Screen Award for Best Asian Feature in the 2002 Singapore International Film Festival. The Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino awarded it the Gawad Urian for Best Picture, Best Director, Best Screenplay, Best Cinematography, Best Production Design, Best Music, Best Sound, Best Actor (Torre), Best Supporting Actor (Arellano), and Best Supporting Actress (Diaz). In the 2001 Cinemanila International Film Festival, it won the prize for Ensemble Performance and the Network for the Promotion of Asian Cinema Award.  Written by Gil Quito

1982 / Color / Drama / 100 minutes / Direction: Mike de Leon / Screenplay: Clodualdo del Mundo Jr, Raquel Villavicencio, and Mike de Leon / Cinematography: Rody Lacap / Editing: Jess Navarro / Production Design: Cesar Hernando / Sound: Ramon Reyes / Music: Lorrie Ilustre / Produced by MVP Pictures / Cast: Mark Gil (Sid Lucero), Sandy Andolong (Tina), Ward Luarca (Pacoy Ledesma), Noel Trinidad (Santi Santillan), Ricky Sandico (Ronnie Roxas Jr), Jimmy Javier (Vince), Rod Leido (Arni Enriquez), Mike Arvisu (Abet), Bing Pimentel (Mariel), Vic Lima (Gonzalez), Dodo Cabasal (Pete Magtibay), Edwin Reyes (Ding Quintos), Nanette Inventor (Miss Casuso), Joe Jardi (Dick), Ed Trinidad (King), Joseph Olfindo (Vergara), Chanda Romero (Jenny Estrada), Charito Solis (Arni's Mother), Johnny Delgado (Frat Doctor), Armida Siguion-Reyna (Sid's Mother), Dang Cecilio (Pearl), and Chito Ponce Enrile (Ronnie's Father)

 

 

Among the aspiring neophytes of the Alpha Kappa Omega fraternity is Sid Lucero, a 26-year-old premed student. Over a six-month initiation period, he and six other neophytes are subjected to severe physical and psychological torture in and outside of the fraternity house. The neophytes come to accept the senseless violence as a requisite for their acceptance into the brotherhood. Only five of them survive the brutal, fascistic ordeal due to the fraternity rumble with Sigma Omicron Sigma.

De Leon treats the fraternity as a microcosm of Philippine society to spotlight issues relating to human rights and autocratic rule at the height of Marcos’s martial rule. The significance of the film derives from the parallelism it draws between authoritarian society and the fraternity, and between the fraternity and Philippine society under Marcos.

Batch ’81 was presented at the Directors’ Fortnight at Cannes Film Festival in 1982. It won the Gawad Urian for Best Screenplay and Best Editing. It was also adjudged one of the 10 Best Films of the Decade by the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino. The Film Academy of the Philippines cited the film as the Best Picture of 1982.  Written by Lena S. Pareja

text:
(My Country: Gripping the Knife’s Edge) / 1984 / Color / Drama / 108 minutes / Direction: Lino Brocka / Story and Screenplay: Jose F. Lacaba / Cinematography: Conrado Baltazar / Editing: George Jarlego, Robert Yujeco, and Hero Reyes / Production Design: Joey Luna / Sound: Pierre Rissient / Music: Jess Santiago / Produced by Malaya Films and Stephan Films / Cast: Phillip Salvador (Turing), Gina Alajar (Luz), Raoul Aragonn (Lando), Carmi Martin (Carla), Claudia Zobel (Dhalie), Lorli Villanueva (Mrs. Lim), Paquito Diaz (Hugo), Rez Cortez (Boy Echas), Ariosto Reyes Jr (Willy), Venchito Galvez (Ka Ador), Bey Vito (Binggo), Nomer Son (Mr. Lim), Mona Lisa (Turing's Mother), Lucita Soriano (Turing's Sister), Joe Taruc (Reporter), and the PETA Kalinangan Ensemble

Turing is a casual worker in a printing firm. He earns barely enough to support himself and his pregnant wife, Luz. Although theirs is a hand-to-mouth existence, they find happiness in being together and having friendly neighbors who lead equally simple lives. But things change when the printing press is shut down by a strike and Turing is made to choose between joining the strike and being jobless, and continuing to work as a scab. With his pregnant wife needing medication, he makes a private deal with his employer and turns scab. For this, he is ostracized by his friends and coworkers.

 

 

Suddenly, it seems as though the whole world has turned against Turing. At the hospital where his wife undergoes treatment, the authorities will not release her when she is ready to go home because her bills have not been paid in full. His friends have deserted him and there is no one to talk to about his financial problems. His employer, his last recourse, refuses to advance the money, and fires Turing after an argument. With his back to the wall, the desperate Turing decides to rob the printing firm of its payroll money. But things go wrong during the robbery and he is shot to death while his wife watches helplessly.

The title of the movie is taken from “Bayan Ko” (My Country), a popular kundiman (love song) composed in 1928 by Constancio de Guzman with lyrics by Jose Corazon de Jesus. It was used as an anthem by the opposition from the 1970s to the 1990s to protest the United States’ domination of the Philippines and the Marcos dictatorship. Against the background of social unrest, Turing’s fight for survival becomes every worker’s quest for bread and freedom. His plight is a reminder to all of the proverb, “Ang taong nagigipit, sa patalim ma’y kumakapit” (A desperate person will grip the knife’s edge in order to survive).

Bayan Ko: Kapit sa Patalim won the award for Best Picture of 1985 from the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino and the Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP). It gave Phillip Salvador four Best Actor awards: from the Gawad Urian, FAP, Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences, and the Catholic Mass Media Awards. It was also cited for Best Screenplay by the Gawad Urian and FAP, and won the Gawad Urian for Best Actress (Alajar) and the FAP award for Best Director. It was enthusiastically received in France, where it competed at the 1984 Cannes International Film Festival, and in England, where it won the Best Film of the Year award from the British Film Institute. Its significance, however, lies as much in its status as a landmark case in Philippine movie censorship. Controversy attended the film’s commercial run in the Philippines when it was denied an exhibition permit on the grounds that the film was subversive and inciting to rebellion. After a lot of protests from the Concerned Artists of the Philippines (CAP), the subversive charge was withdrawn and the film was allowed to be shown but with cuts because of alleged “lascivious” scenes. Brocka and Malaya Films filed a suit in the Supreme Court. When the decision was released, the censors’ board was ordered to approve its showing to adult audiences (persons over 18 years of age) and not to cut any portion of the film. The board of censors, the high tribunal’s decision pointed out, was mandated only to classify and not to cut films. For Brocka and the CAP, it was a considerable victory because they had believed all along that the Board of Review for Motion Pictures and Television should be abolished and replaced by a ratings board set up by the film industry itself.   Written by Lena S. Pareja

text:
(3rd World Hero) / 1999 / Black and White / Drama / 93 minutes / Direction: Mike de Leon / Screenplay: Clodualdo del Mundo Jr and Mike de Leon / Cinematography: Ding Achacoso / Editing: Armando Jarlego / Production Design: Roy Lachica / Sound: Raffy Baladjay / Music: Lorrie Ilustre / Produced by Cinema Artists Philippines / Cast: Ricky Davao (the director), Cris Villanueva (the scriptwriter), Joel Torre (Jose Rizal), Rio Locsin (Trining), Daria Ramirez (Doña Teodora), Cherry Pie Picache (Narcisa), Lara Fabregas (Josephine Bracken), Joonee Gamboa (Paciano), and Ed Rocha (Padre Balaguer)

 

 

A director and a scriptwriter are consumed with the idea of creating a movie about Jose Rizal. But almost all aspects of the national hero’s life have been explored at great length, both by historians and by other filmmakers. The two argue about the path their film should pursue: should it be an academic exploration of Rizal’s heroism? Or should they choose a more spirited, music-video-like commercial movie, something along the line of a deodorant commercial (Agua Rizalina: Para hindi mag-amoy indio! [Agua Rizalina: So you will not smell like an indio!])? As the two examine Rizal’s controversial life, they are confronted with so many unanswered questions about the life and choices made by the hero. Did he or did he not retract his writings before his execution? Did he or did he not condemn the revolution of 1896? The director and the writer attempt to recreate Rizal’s past as they go through his correspondences and other historical accounts. They come “face-to-face” with different personalities close to Rizal: his lover Josephine Bracken, his mother Doña Teodora, his sisters Narcisa and Trinidad, his brother Paciano, and the Jesuit Balaguer. The process of “cross-examining” all these characters visualizes the burdensome research process that they actually go through using historical documents. As a result of their research with all these curious characters, they obtain varying, if not unreliable, opinions and recollections about Rizal and the issues surrounding him. But as the hero’s past is gradually revealed, the two filmmakers discover more gray areas in Rizal’s life. They find themselves having a difficult time reconciling their personal beliefs with “recorded history” and the conflicting testimonies of eyewitnesses. After much spadework, the retraction document controversy remains unresolved. In the end, they give up their pursuit of the one true Rizal account. Both conclude that, in the end, every person has his own concept of Rizal (“kanya-kanyang Rizal”), and that Dr Jose Rizal—for all his great heroism—is not cinematic enough, and will remain the Third World hero that he is.

At the 1999 Gawad Urian, the film won six awards out of 11 nominations: Best Picture, Best Director, Best Supporting Actor (Torre), Best Cinematography, Best Music, and Best Sound. In the Young Critics Circle Film Desk Citations for film year 2000, it won Best Film (tied with Tanging Yaman [A Change of Heart]), Best Achievement in Cinematography and Visual Design, Best Editing, and Best Achievement in Sound and Aural Orchestration.  Written by Anne Frances Sangil

The process of “cross-examining” all these characters visualizes the burdensome research process that they actually go through using historical documents. As a result of their research with all these curious characters, they obtain varying, if not unreliable, opinions and recollections about Rizal and the issues surrounding him. But as the hero’s past is gradually revealed, the two filmmakers discover more gray areas in Rizal’s life. They find themselves having a difficult time reconciling their personal beliefs with “recorded history” and the conflicting testimonies of eyewitnesses. After much spadework, the retraction document controversy remains unresolved. In the end, they give up their pursuit of the one true Rizal account. Both conclude that, in the end, every person has his own concept of Rizal (“kanya-kanyang Rizal”), and that Dr Jose Rizal—for all his great heroism—is not cinematic enough, and will remain the Third World hero that he is.

At the 1999 Gawad Urian, the film won six awards out of 11 nominations: Best Picture, Best Director, Best Supporting Actor (Torre), Best Cinematography, Best Music, and Best Sound. In the Young Critics Circle Film Desk Citations for film year 2000, it won Best Film (tied with Tanging Yaman [A Change of Heart]), Best Achievement in Cinematography and Visual Design, Best Editing, and Best Achievement in Sound and Aural Orchestration.
Written by Anne Frances Sangil

text:
(The Palawan Script) / 2012 / Color / Drama / Direction and Screenplay: Auraeus Solito / Cinematography: Louie Quirino / Editing: Mikael Pestaño / Production Design: Bumbo Villanueva and Hai Balbuena / Sound and Music: Diwa de Leon / Produced by Cinema One Originals and Solito Arts Productions / Cast: Assunta de Rossi (Alban), Alessandra de Rossi (Alba), Adrian Sebastian (Bagtik), Ruby Moreno (Sadya), Mon Confiado (Sergeant Mac), Olivier Borten (Philippe Tiessen), and Sue Prado

From the root word baybay—meaning, to spell—baybayin is the general term for the ancient Filipino writing system. The film features a specific baybayin called Surat Inaborlan or simply Aborlan, named after the municipality it originated from in the island province of Palawan. The film Baybayin is anchored on this ancient Palawan script and tells the story of two half-sisters, Alban and Alba, who both fall in love with the deaf-mute Bagtik, who can only communicate in Aborlan writing. The sisters part ways when Alba’s Canadian father Philippe Tiessen takes her to Manila after their mother Sadya dies from malaria, the same illness that took the life of Alban’s father. Several years later, Alba returns to their hometown in Puring following her father’s death. Alba boards a boat where she meets Sergeant Mac. He tries to rape Alba the night she arrives, but she defends herself and escapes to the forest. Alba reaches the shore where Alban comes to her aid. The sisters only recognize each other the next day in Alban’s hut, where Alba sees Bagtik again. Knowing that Alban and Bagtik have been living together, Alba tries suppressing her feelings for Bagtik, but Alban inevitably learns about this. In the end, the two sisters marry Bagtik, following the ancient tradition of Duay. One day, the community is threatened with the loss of its land. Sergeant Mac is helping a foreign investor convince the locals to give up their properties for a pearl farm business, but Alba steps forward to defend and protect their ancestral ground. Not accepting defeat, Sergeant Mac insults one of the elders and steals the traditional gongs used in their rituals. Bagtik becomes furious and fights off the offenders to his last breath.

More than a story of familial and romantic love, Baybayin is about remembering one’s past and being rooted in one’s culture by using language to empower one’s identity and thereby preserve one’s cultural heritage. Shot entirely in Palawan, Baybayin represents the island’s culture and is the second installment in Solito’s film trilogy based on Palawan’s folklore and mythology. The first is called Busong (Palawan Fate) and embodies Palawan’s philosophy, while the third to be titled Sumbang (The Palawan Deluge) will present the history of the Palawan people. Baybayin was a finalist in the Cinema One Originals Plus category. It received the Gawad Urian for Best Music. It also won the Best Indigenous Language Production Award at the 14th imagineNATIVE Film + Media Arts Festival in Canada and was screened at the 2014 International Workshop on Endangered Scripts of Island Southeast Asia in Japan.  Written by Michael Kho Lim

text:
(Bertoldo and Balodoy) / 1938 / Black and White / Comedy / Direction and Screenplay: Piux A. Kabahar / Cinematography: Prudencio Iriarte / Sound: Saturio Alvarez Villarino / Music: Tomas Villaflor / Produced by Estudio America-Filipino / Cast: Piux Kabahar, Concepcion Maniago, Ben Zubiri, Isidora Silloria, Cresencia Ollada, and Mondoy de la Cerna

This comic film about the adventures and misadventures of a pair of Siamese twins is the first and only Cebuano talking picture produced before World War II. Its entire cast and production crew were conscripted from the theatrical stage. To prepare for the making of the film, the equipment was ordered from the United States and a team composed of Kabahar, Villarino, and Iriarte, which was in charge of the technical aspects of the production, was sent to Manila to train under Carlos Vander Tolosa and observe film production at Sampaguita Pictures and Parlatone Hispano-Filipino.

 

 

The movie premiered at Vision Theater on Colon Street in Cebu City. It was a commercial success and elicited a lot of interest despite its technical lapses (such as a kissing scene that sounded thunderous due to sound recording defects). A copy of the film was reportedly bought for the sum of 26,000 pesos and shown in Hawaii.  Written by Erlinda K. Alburo

text:
(Count the Stars in the Sky) / 1989 / Color / Drama / 125 minutes / Direction: Elwood Perez / Screenplay: Jigz Recto and Jake Cocadiz / Cinematography: Ricardo Jacinto / Editing: George Jarlego / Production Design: Raymond Bajarias, Ray Maliuanag, Gerry Pascual, and Freddie Valencia / Sound: Joe Climaco / Music: Lutgardo Labad / Produced by Regal Films / Cast: Nora Aunor (Magnolia/Maggie), Tirso Cruz III (Anselmo/Jun), Miguel Rodriguez (Arturo), Gloria Romero (Martina), Perla Bautista (Chedeng), Ana Margarita (Margot), and Mario Escudero (Damian)

Magnolia is an intelligent peasant girl whose ambition is to graduate from college and become a doctor. To fulfill her dreams, her father, Damian, mortgages his farm to a rich landowner, Doña Martina. Magnolia’s mother, Chedeng, is also employed by Martina as a laundrywoman. Martina and her son, Anselmo, look down on Magnolia’s family, considering them below their class level. Martina scoffs at Magnolia’s ambitions, but the latter perseveres. Through hard work and persistence, she not only gets her college degree but, with the help of a friend, Arturo, is also able to redeem their mortgaged property from Martina.

 

 

Despite their social differences, Magnolia has fallen hopelessly in love with Anselmo, though he is too dense to appreciate her. In an indiscriminate moment, they make love. Their union bears fruit, but Doña Martina prevents Anselmo from marrying Magnolia. Pride stops Magnolia from revealing to Anselmo that she is pregnant with his child. She marries Arturo instead over the objections of his sister Margot, who resents Magnolia and who later drives her brother to violence and suicide by revealing that Magnolia’s child was sired by another man.

A reversal of fortune finds Magnolia holding the deeds to the properties of Doña Martina and Anselmo. Sick and dying, the impoverished Martina demands of her unexpected visitor, “Did you come to claim my land and drive me away from my house?” Magnolia replies, “I cannot hate the mother of the only man I ever loved.” But Anselmo refuses reconciliation. At his mother’s wake, he arrogantly tells Magnolia that he has a wife and child, that Magnolia can have all their property and his mother’s jewelry but she can never have him.

Years pass, and Magnolia’s daughter, Maggie, grows up to be a beautiful and rebellious young lady who has her mother’s looks but is her exact opposite in temperament and character. She falls in love with Jun, who turns out to be Anselmo’s son. Horrified that her daughter is headed for an incestuous relationship, Magnolia swallows her pride and goes to Anselmo, revealing the truth that Margie is his own daughter and the half-sister of Jun. The revelation has a shattering effect on the young lovers: they commit double suicide. In the final outcome, Magnolia and Anselmo decide to reconcile and live out the rest of their days as husband and wife.

Bilangin ang Bituin sa Langit won the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences awards for Best Picture, Best Actress (Aunor), Best Actor (Cruz), Best Director, Best Screenplay, Best Production Design, Best Song, and Best Sound. It won the Gawad Urian for Best Actress, Best Music, and Best Production Design. Critics have described it as the “quintessential Tagalog movie” because it contains all the elements of the traditional film melodrama.  Written by Lena S. Pareja

text:
(Trespassers) / 2011 / Color / Drama / 87 minutes / Direction: Jeffrey Jeturian / Screenplay: Paul Sta. Ana / Cinematography: Boy Yñiguez / Editing: Lawrence Fajardo / Production Design: Digo Ricio / Art Direction: Victor Villanueva / Sound: Albert Michael Idioma / Music: Joseph Lansang / Produced by Cinemalaya Foundation, Quantum Films, and Hong Kong–Asian Film Financing Forum / Cast: Tirso Cruz III (Ramon), Raquel Villavicencio (Salud), Julia Clarete, Jennifer Sevilla, Edgar Allan Guzman, Aryanna Santiago, Jen Donaire, Kimmy Maclang, and Troy De Guzman

 

 

Taking place on Christmas Eve and Christmas Day, the film revolves around the members of the Aguinaldo family, who are first seen participating in the panunuluyan, a folk Catholic procession that reenacts the journey of Joseph and Mary through Bethlehem as they searched, in vain, for an inn where Mary could give birth. Upon the close of the ritual and after midnight mass, the Aguinaldos return home from church, looking forward to the traditional noche buena (Christmas midnight meal). Instead, they find their house ransacked by burglars. The shock of the invasion triggers various fights and outbursts within the family, revealing that, beneath the exterior they present to the world, they are not as devout, as close-knit, or as prosperous as they appear to be. Even as mother Salud strives hard to restore a measure of normalcy to the household, insisting that the family carry on with their dinner as planned, the ghosts of the past haunt them, like father Ramon’s gambling problem. Like her kin, Salud has difficulty maintaining her composure. By the next morning, however, they carry on just as before, with everyone on hand for the Christmas Mass. The tensions between them may have found some release the previous night, but, as with the crime committed against them, their many problems remain without resolution or redress.

Bisperas won the awards for Best Film, Best Cinematography, Best Production Design, Best Actress (Villavicencio), and Best Supporting Actress (Clarete) in the Directors Showcase of the 2011 Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival. It also won the Best Asian-Middle Eastern Film Award at the 2011 Tokyo International Film Festival and the FIPRESCI Prize in the Eurasia International Film Festival 2011 in Kazakhstan.  Written by Jaime Oscar M. Salazar
