text:
(Beautiful Star) / 1937 / Black and White / Musical Drama / Direction: Carlos Vander Tolosa / Story and Screenplay: Luis F. Nolasco and Carlos Vander Tolosa / Cinematography: Cesar Silos / Laboratory Process: Augusto Silos / Sound: William Smith / Music: Miguel Velarde Jr, Jose A. Estella, and Juan Silos Jr / Theme Song: Nicanor Abelardo / Choreography: Bernie Nolasco / Produced by Luis F. Nolasco for Sampaguita Pictures Inc / Cast: Elsa Oria (Estrella del Mar), Rogelio de la Rosa (Mario Castillo), Ely Ramos (Alberto Miranda), Silvia Rosales (Lucia), Teddy Benavidez (Carlos), Naty Rubi (Doña Clara), Billy Vizcarra, Baron “Amateur” Unterheisen, SSS Trio, Four Orphans, Molina’s Symphony Orchestra, and Moonlight Troubadours

 

 

Estrella del Mar, a young soprano, captivates Mario Castillo with her singing at a lavish party given by a rich cousin, Lucia. Estrella’s mother, Doña Clara, frowns on the match; she is eyeing a young and successful businessman, Alberto Miranda, to be her son-in-law. Mario is tall and handsome but poor, and has little to offer Estrella except his sincere love.

The romance is threatened by the death of Estrella’s rich uncle in Paris; she is declared sole heiress to his fortune on the condition that she marry a rich, educated man, or forfeit the money to charity. Doña Clara, who dreams of a life of ease and fortune, does her best to discourage her daughter from seeing Mario and asks Alberto to press his suit. To make her come to her senses, Doña Clara sends Estrella to a convent and cuts off all communication with Mario. Thinking that Estrella no longer wishes to see him, Mario goes away. When Estrella finally gets out of the convent, a big homecoming party is prepared for her. Estrella secretly sends an invitation to Mario, not knowing that her mother will announce her engagement to Alberto at the party. When this happens, Estrella is embarrassed and speechless, and Mario walks out promising never to see her again.

Sensing that his impending marriage is threatened by Mario, Alberto sends his trusted aide, Carlos, to arrange a meeting with the man. When Mario shows up, Alberto offers him money to stay away from Estrella. Grossly insulted, Mario flares up and hits Alberto, who strikes back. As the two rivals fiercely exchange blows, Doña Clara realizes it is Mario whom her daughter really loves and casts aside all her objections to their marriage.

Bituing Marikit was the very first movie made by Sampaguita Pictures. It also established the team of Tolosa-Nolasco-Velarde, who were behind the most successful prewar musicals. Miguel "Mike" Velarde Jr composed the song "Dahil sa Iyo" (Because of You) for this movie and it has since become one of his most popular compositions.    Written by Lena S. Pareja

text:
(Blessings of the Land) / 1959 / Black and White / Drama / 111 minutes / Direction: Manuel Silos / Story: Celso Al. Carunungan / Screenplay: Celso Al. Carunungan and Pablo Naval / Cinematography: Remigio Young / Editing: Enrique Jarlego / Sound: July P. Hidalgo / Music: Juan Silos Jr / Produced by LVN Pictures / Cast: Rosa Rosal (Maria), Tony Santos (Jose), Carlos Padilla Jr (Arturo), Leroy Salvador (Miguel), Marita Zobel (Angelita), Joseph de Cordova (Bruno), Mila Ocampo (Choleng), Danilo Jurado, Tony Dantes, Mario Roldan, Miguel Lopez, Priscilla Ramirez, Jerry Reyes, Pedro Faustino, and Carmen del Ocampo

 

 

The film begins with a young couple, Maria and Jose, who are deeply in love; they decide to marry and start a life together tending a lanzones orchard in the countryside. Three children are born to the couple. Life is good to them, and their three children—Arturo, Miguel, and Angelita—grow up and bring joy to the community. But trouble enters their lives when Jose incurs the envy and enmity of Bruno, who is much feared in the village. A widower, Bruno is rumored to have caused the death of his wife, and he has difficulty looking for a second wife. The women in the village fear him. He pursues one of them, Choleng, and she jumps off a cliff and dies. From that time on, Bruno is no longer seen in the village. He hides in the mountains, where he organizes a band of brigands. Having been frustrated with Choleng, he turns to Jose and Maria’s daughter and rapes her. Jose hunts him down, but is killed by Bruno and his men. The angry townspeople band themselves to go after Bruno. He flees to another town, where a greedy landowner hires him to sabotage the lanzones blooms. But before Bruno can succeed, the townspeople attack him. With Bruno’s death, peace returns to the community once more and the people reap the fruits of their bountiful land.

Biyaya ng Lupa won the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences awards for Best Picture and Best Story in 1959 and gained international fame at the Asian Film Festival in 1960 when the award for Best Supporting Actor went to Leroy Salvador, who played the deaf-mute son.  Written by Lena S. Pareja

text:
1980 / Color / Drama / 85 minutes / Direction: Lino Brocka / Screenplay: Cenen Ramones / Cinematography: Conrado Baltazar / Editing: Augusto Salvador / Production Design: Joey Luna / Sound: Ben Patajo and Rudy Baldovino / Music: Lutgardo Labad / Produced by NV Productions Inc / Cast: Nora Aunor (Bona), Phillip Salvador (Gardo Villa), Raquel Montesa (Nancy), Marissa Delgado (Katrina), Nanding Josef (Nilo), Rustica Carpio, Venchito Galvez, Spanky Manikan , and the PETA Kalinangan Ensemble

Bona is an avid fan of movie bit player Gardo Villa. She follows him everywhere—to shootings, basketball games, and drinking sessions. Her father beats her up one day for coming home late after attending to Gardo’s needs. Bona runs away from home and pleads with Gardo to take her in as his girl Friday. She serves Gardo hand and foot: she prepares his food, washes his clothes, cleans his house, fetches water for him, and even bathes him.

 

 

Nilo, a neighbor attracted to Bona, tells her father where to find her. The father suffers a heart attack after he fails to persuade Bona to come home. Meanwhile, Bona persists in her devotion to Gardo despite his gross neglect of her emotional and physical needs. She even pays for the abortion of one of Gardo’s girlfriends.

Bona’s father dies and, at the wake, she is confronted by her enraged brother. He beats her up and throws her out of the house. Bona goes back to Gardo’s house where she meets Katrina, whom Gardo will live with from then on. Bona has no choice but to accept his decision to move out. After a prolonged absence, Gardo comes back and tells Bona of his plans to quit show business and live abroad with Katrina. Bona responds by attacking Gardo, pouring a pot of boiling water over him.

The film reaffirmed director Lino Brocka’s genius for recording the nuances of poverty. Nora Aunor won Best Actress in the 1981 Gawad Urian, where the film was also nominated for Best Picture, Best Director, and Best Actor (Salvador). Bona was exhibited in the Directors’ Fortnight program of Cannes Film Festival in 1981. It won the Premio de le Juri de la Federacion Internationale des Cine Clubs in the 1982 Figueira da Foz International Film Festival.

In 2012, a theatrical adaptation of Bona, under the direction of Soxie Topacio and the script of Layeta Bucoy, was staged by the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA). It starred Eugene Domingo and Edgar Allan Guzman.  Written by Menchie R. Tajan, with notes from Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

Julian Duque in Boses, 2008

(Photo courtesy of Ellen Ongkeko-Marfil)

text:
(Voice) / 2008 / Color / Drama / 100 minutes / Direction: Ellen Ongkeko-Marfil / Screenplay: Froilan Medina and Rody Vera / Cinematography: Nap Jamir / Editing: Orlean Tan / Production Design: Bianca Gonzalez / Sound: Allan Marcelo Hilado / Music: Coke Bolipata and Jourdann O. Petalver / Produced by Erasto Films / Cast: Coke Bolipata (Ariel), Julian Duque (Onyok), Ricky Davao (Marcelo), Cherry Pie Picache (Amanda), Meryll Soriano (Bianca), and Tala Santos (Shirley)

 

 

The film opens with a point-of-view shot of the abused seven-year-old Onyok, who takes refuge inside a cabinet. Knocks on the door break the silence when concerned neighbors, together with some social workers and policemen, try to rescue him from his abusive father Marcelo. Onyok is brought to a center for abused children under the auspices of its owner-founder Amanda, who learns about the child’s inability to speak due to a damaged larynx caused by physical trauma. Still engulfed by fear, Onyok is generally aloof to people but has found new friendship in fellow shelter kid Shirley. However, violence still seems to follow Onyok when some children in the facility bully him. He eventually fights back, hurting one of them. Afraid of the consequences of his actions, Onyok once again finds himself hiding in a cabinet, this time in the nearby hut within the compound occupied by Amanda’s brother, Ariel.

A concert violinist in Manila, Ariel returns to their family house to live in seclusion after being consumed by guilt over the passing of his beloved protégé Bianca. Though both haunted by their past experiences, Onyok and Ariel are brought together by the violin, which becomes instrumental to their process of healing. Onyok realizes his gift of music as Ariel discovers a child prodigy. Together, they find a renewed hope and complement each other’s need—the child’s longing for affection and the violinist’s fulfillment of a lost dream. Along the way, they fill each other’s emptiness by receiving and giving love, and thereby attaining inner peace. Soon after Marcelo has shown considerable improvement in his rehabilitation, the shelter prepares a ceremony to return Onyok to his father, where he sees his son playing the violin for the first time in a mini recital with Ariel.

Boses debuted in the 2008 Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival. It participated and competed in Jecheon International Music and Film Festival in Seoul, International Children’s Film Festival in India, Louis Vuitton Hawaii International Film Festival, Filipino Film Festival in Honolulu, Women’s International Film and Television Showcase in West Hollywood, Woods Hole Film Festival in Boston, Eugene Celebration Film Festival in Oregon, Chicago Filipino-American Film Festival, Philippine Film Festival in Geneva, and the International Children’s and Youth Film Festival in Madrid. It received Star Awards for Best Music and Best Child Performer (Duque) from the Philippine Movie Press Club.  Written by Michael Kho Lim

Christopher de Leon and Vilma Santos in Broken Marriage, 1983
(Mario A. Hernando Collection)

text:
1983 / Color / Drama / 106 minutes / Direction: Ishmael Bernal / Screenplay: Jose N. Carreon, Bing Caballero, and Ishmael Bernal / Cinematography: Manolo Abaya; editing, Jess Navarro; production design, Len Santos; sound, Rolly Ruta; music, Max Jocson. Produced by Regal Films. Cast: Vilma Santos (Ellen), Christopher de Leon (Rene), Orestes Ojeda (Wowee), Lito Pimentel, Tessie Tomas, Harlene Bautista, Richard Arellano, Ray Ventura, Spanky Manikan , Laura Hermosa, Len Santos, Beth Mondragon, Evelyn Vargas, Idda Yaneza, Marivic Mercado, and Cesar Montano

 

 

After 10 years of marriage and two children, Rene, a news reporter, and Ellen, a TV floor director, find themselves on the brink of a breakup. Both hold jobs that take up much of their time, but neither wants to give way because both are obsessed with making a name for themselves in their profession. They seem to have fallen out of love with each other, and life has become a series of verbal tussles and conflicts. They decide that the only way out is temporary separation.

Rene moves into his friend’s apartment while Ellen has to cope with running a household all by herself. Rene is mauled for his exposé of a brothel owned by a high-ranking government official and he temporarily stays in the house of Ellen’s mother. Rene becomes jealous when a TV executive, Wowee, aggressively pursues Ellen. Ellen’s younger sister, about to be married, quarrels with her boyfriend. Ellen begins to reflect on her relationship with Rene, and as Rene recuperates from his injuries, he and Ellen decide to rebuild their shattered relationship.

Broken Marriage is one of the few successful dramatizations of the tensions that beset married life among urban middle-class professionals. Its success also lies in its technical innovations, such as overlapping sound tracks and naturalistic photography, colloquial dialogue, and production design. It won the Gawad Urian for Best Picture, Best Director, Best Screenplay, Best Editing, Best Sound, and Best Actress (Santos). It was nominated by the Film Academy of the Philippines for Best Picture, Best Director, Best Actor, Best Actress, Best Screenplay, Best Production Design, and Best Editing.  Written by Mauro Tumbocon

Amy Austria and Jay Ilagan in Brutal, 1980

(Cesar Hernando Collection)

text:
1980 / Color / Drama / 105 minutes / Direction: Marilou Diaz-Abaya / Story and Screenplay: Ricardo Lee / Cinematography and Editing: Manolo Abaya / Production Design: Don Escudero / Sound: Amang Sanchez / Music: George Canseco / Produced by Bancom Audiovision Corporation / Cast: Amy Austria (Monica Real), Gina Alajar (Cynthia), Charo Santos (Clara Valdez), Jay llagan (Tato), Johnny Delgado (Jake), Perla Bautista (Charing), Joonee Gamboa, Nello Nayo, Robert Tongko, and Boy Sabiniano

The news media sensationalize a grisly murder case: Monica Real is accused of killing her husband and two other men in her apartment in Manila. In jail, Monica completely withdraws from the world and refuses to talk even to her lawyer.

 

 

Undaunted, Clara Valdez, an aggressive journalist, is determined to find out what really happened. A feminist, Clara refuses to accept Monica’s guilt without hearing her side first. When Monica does not cooperate, Clara seeks out others who may be able to shed light on her past.

Aling Charing, Monica’s mother, tells Clara that she brought up her daughter in the conventional way, preparing her for marriage and the role of wife and mother in the home. Monica was a sweet child and never gave her mother any trouble.

Cynthia is Monica’s promiscuous best friend. Monica was unaware that Cynthia secretly resented her for being everything that she, Cynthia, was not. It was Cynthia who incited Tato to rape Monica, telling him that Monica secretly loved him.

Slowly, the real reason behind the triple murder dawns on Clara. She confronts Monica. Monica snaps out of her stunned silence, breaks down, and confirms what Clara had suspected all along. Monica was the victim of male violence: Tato and his two friends, high on liquor and drugs, had taken turns raping her. When they passed out in their drunken stupor, Monica slashed their wrists and left them to bleed to death.

Brutal won the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences award for Best Supporting Actress (Alajar), and was nominated for Gawad Urian’s Best Picture, Best Director, Best Screenplay, Best Actress (Austria), and Best Supporting Actor (Delgado). Brutal is the first Filipino movie to tackle rape as a feminist issue in the context of the Philippine patriarchal society.  Written by Lena S. Pareja

text:
(Brutus: The Journey) / 2008 / Color / Drama / 110 minutes / Direction and Screenplay: Tara Illenberger / Cinematography: Jay Abello / Editing: Fiona Borres and Tara Illenberger / Production Design: Fritz Silorio / Sound: Raffy Magsaysay / Music: Joey Ayala / Produced by Bonfire Production / Cast: Ronnie Lazaro (Sarge), Yul Servo (Ka Milo), Timothy Mabalot (Adag), and Rhea Medina (Payang)

“Brutus” is a motorcycle brand manufactured in Japan that has a powerful engine capable of transporting heavy loads. In Oriental Mindoro, where the film is set and which is home to the Mangyan, “Brutus” also refers to young laborers, mostly local children, who smuggle lumber for illegal loggers. Paid a measly amount, the kids drag the boards uphill and downhill until they reach a river, where they tie the logs underneath a bamboo raft to hide them from forest rangers. The film follows the journey of two Mangyan kids, Adag and Payang, who become Brutuses in a poverty-stricken and malaria-infested community that has also become a stronghold for armed rebels from New People’s Army (NPA). Aside from helping their families make ends meet, the two embark on their own personal missions: Adag needs to buy malaria medicines to help his ailing sibling, while Payang hopes to find her missing brother Falyus. Along the way on their journey, Adag notices the dark clouds hovering above them and suggests resting for a while because of the impending storm. Payang insists on rafting some more, optimistic that they will make it through. Unfortunately they hit a rock, which destroys their raft and dislodges the boards.

After the downpour, Adag and Payang make a new raft, and add to their mission the goal of locating the displaced wood. In the process, they meet an army group led by Sarge, who is on a manhunt operation against the alleged NPA leader Ka Milo. Soon after, the young Brutuses encounter Ka Milo himself, who goes by the name of Carlito. Adag immediately recognizes the man from a photo that Sarge has shown them, but keeps quiet. Ka Milo helps Adag and Payang finish the raft and joins them in their journey. At one stop, Adag searches for food in an open field, but a man claiming to own the land beats him like a thief. Ka Milo comes to Adag’s rescue and ends up killing the man. They soon find all the boards that the current has washed away and reach their destination.

As they approach the town, Ka Milo notices army soldiers at the foot of the hill and decides to hide on the hilltop. He asks Adag to bring a note to a friend who is waiting at a store in the town. On the way down the hill, the young Brutuses are apprehended by the soldiers and detained. Sarge finds out about the detention and requests the kids’ release. By accident, he discovers Ka Milo’s note in Adag’s belongings and executes an entrapment plan. The soldiers capture Ka Milo’s friend, so the kids quickly run to inform Ka Milo. Fearing the end, Ka Milo gives his bagful of medicines to Adag and Payang. When the soldiers come for him, Ka Milo tries to fight back but he is outnumbered and eventually killed. As they head back, Adag takes Payang to the location where Sarge has found and buried Payang’s brother Falyus. The kids return home penniless but richer in wisdom.

Brutus won the Special Jury Prize in the New Breed category of the 2008 Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival as well as the prizes for Best Cinematography, Best Music, and Best Actor (Servo). The film also received the Best Asian Film award in the 35th Brussels International Independent Film Festival and the Network for the Promotion of Asian Cinema Award in the 28th Louis Vuitton Hawaii International Film Festival.  Written by Michael Kho Lim

text:
(Easy Come, Easy Go) / 1952 / Black and White / Drama / Direction and Story: Eddie Romero / Screenplay: Eddie Romero and Cesar Amigo / Music: Tito Arevalo / Produced by Vicente Sinco for Lebran Pictures / Cast: Fred Montilla, Anita Linda , Mona Lisa, Tito Arevalo, Vera Legaspi, Eddie Garcia, Conrado Conde, and Artemio Tecson.

An only son is disowned by his rich parents when he chooses to marry a poor woman. He is not used to a life of hardship and sacrifice, and his failure to find a job soon leads to marital discord. The young couple rents a room in a house owned by a mother and daughter team. Their neigbors are an odd assortment of characters. A macho type seduces the landlady’s daughter. Another neighbor, a pensionado, is living with a perennially unfaithful nightclub hostess. A third makes a living as a pickpocket. In the end, some characters are better and some are worse off than before. The rich boy finally gets a job while the pickpocket is chased and caught by the police. Naku! Katapusan ko na ’ata! (God! This must be the end!), the pickpocket cries, ending the film on a wryly resigned, somewhat poignant note.

Buhay Alamang derives its significance from the use of a neorealist style to depict the lives of the urban poor in a comic manner. It won the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences award for Best Screenplay.  Written by Rosalie Matilac

Angelu de Leon and Elizabeth Oropesa in Bulaklak ng Maynila, 1999
(Mario A. Hernando Collection)

text:
(Flower of Manila) / 1999 / Color / Drama / 101 minutes / Direction: Joel C. Lamangan / Screenplay: Ricardo Lee (based on the novel Bulaklak ng Maynila by Domingo Landicho) / Cinematography: Monino S. Duque /  Editing: Tara Illenberger / Production Design: Benjie De Guzman / Sound: Ramon Reyes / Music: Jessie Lasaten / Original Theme Song: Vehnee Saturno / Produced by Viva Films / Cast: Elizabeth Oropesa (Azun), Christopher de Leon (Timo), Jomari Yllana (Ed), Angelu de Leon (Ada), Bembol Roco (Roque), Jake Roxas, Jim Pebanco, Domingo Landicho, Melisse Santiago, Joy Viado, Leonard Obal, Perla Bautista, and Tony Mabesa

 

 

Azun is a wife and mother living on the fringes of Manila, where she earns a living by peddling goods. Her husband, Roque, gets involved in a robbery gone wrong. He is caught and slapped with a jail sentence. Fending for herself and her teenage daughter, Ada, Azun turns to Timo for safety and support. But the good-for-nothing Timo, the leader of a crime syndicate and owner of a strip club, rapes Ada, makes her leave her boyfriend Ed, and forces her to dance in his club. When Azun learns of Timo’s treachery, she plots to bring him down and get her revenge.

Bulaklak ng Maynila premiered in the 1999 Metro Manila Film Festival, where it received the awards for 2nd Best Picture, Best Actress (Oropesa), Best Actor (C. de Leon), Best Supporting Actress (A. de Leon), and Best Original Theme Song. In the 2000 Film Academy of the Philippines Awards, the film also received the Best Picture, Best Director, Best Screenplay, Best Actor, Best Actress, Best Production Design, Best Original Theme Song, and Best Sound prizes. In the 2000 PMPC Star Awards for Movies, it also garnered trophies for Movie of the Year, Director of the Year, Adapted Screenplay of the Year, Actress of the Year, and Production Designer of the Year. For her performance in the film, Oropesa also won the Best Actress in the 2000 Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Awards, the 2000 Gawad Urian, and the Young Critics Circle Film Desk Citations for 1999.  Written by Patrick Campos

text:
(The Youngest) / 2004 / Documentary / Color / 64 minutes / Direction: Ditsi Carolino / Cinematography: Ditsi Carolino and Sadhana Buxani / Editing: Emile Guertin / Sound: Peter Marquez / Music: Gary Granada / Produced by Consuelo Foundation and United Nations International Children’s Emergency Fund

This 64-minute documentary follows the lives of three minor boys—namely Tisoy (Bunso), 11; Anthony, 13; and Diosel, 11—who are detained in a Cebu provincial jail. These juvenile offenders share a dingy, cramped environment with adult male criminals convicted of rape, murder, and drug dealing. Tisoy used to beg for food until hunger forced him to steal. Anthony, on the other hand, has been in and out of jail, claiming he only steals from the rich. Diosel was caught stealing money from a sari-sari store. His father insisted that he be sent to jail. Inside the prison cell, the children are allowed to speak for themselves as equals, combining their great sense of humor and heartaches.

Bunso was used by children’s rights advocates to generate support for the passage of the Juvenile Justice and Welfare Bill.The film won the Best Director award at the 2005 One World Human Rights International Film Festival in Prague, Czech Republic; the Grand Prize at the 2005 EBS International Documentary Film Festival in Seoul, Korea; the Youth Jury Prize at the 2006 Perspektiv: Nuremberg International Human Rights Film Festival; and Best Short Film at the 2005 Gawad Urian.  Written by Rica Arevalo

text:
(Burlesque Queen) / 1977 / Color / Drama / 129 minutes / Direction: Celso Ad. Castillo / Screenplay: Mauro Gia Samonte / Cinematography: Ben Lobo / Editing: Abelardo Hulleza, Bert R. Mendoza / Production Design: Jose Tamayo Cruz / Sound: Gregorio Ella / Music: George Canseco / Produced by Ian Films / Cast: Vilma Santos (Chato/Czarina), Rolly Quizon (Jessie), Leopoldo Salcedo (Mang Roque), Rosemarie Gil (Virgie Nite), Roldan Aquino (Ander), Joonee Gamboa (Louie Fernando), Chito Ponce Enrile, Yolanda Luna, Dexter Doria, Canuplin, and Bayani Casimiro 

 

 

Chato does girl Friday chores for Virgie Nite, a burlesque star, to support her paralytic father. She wishes to be a dancer herself and grabs at the chance when Virgie is unable to perform after drinking too much. Virgie is drunk because her lover, Ander, has run off with another woman. Chato’s Inday Theater job enables her to buy her father a wheelchair. Mang Roque finds out how his daughter earned the money and urges her to quit the burlesque stage. To keep her dancing and stripping, Louie Fernando, the impresario, invests his new star with an intriguing personality as Czarina, the masked goddess. She subsequently has an affair with Jessie, a law student and the son of a politician. Defeated and depressed, Mang Roque commits suicide. Chato and Jessie elope, but Jessie leaves her when her savings begin to dwindle. Pregnant and abandoned, Chato finds her life at a dead end. Louie decides to stage a lavish, spectacular show and Chato agrees to dance. In a tour de force performance, Chato grinds and bumps to a screaming audience that is unaware that Chato is aborting her child.

Burlesk Queen swept all the awards, beginning with the Best Picture honor, in the 1977 Metro Manila Film Festival (MMFF). It caused a furor during the awards ceremonies, however, when the MMFF jurors singled it out as the only film worthy of the awards and then roundly criticized the other festival entries. This so insulted the industry that the MMFF, in an unprecedented move, decided to withdraw all the awards a few days later.

It was nominated in the Gawad Urian for Best Picture, Best Director, Best Screenplay, Best Actress (Santos), Best Supporting Actor (Quizon), Best Supporting Actress (Gil), Best Music, and Best Sound.  Written by Mauro Tumbocon

text:
(Palawan Fate) / 2011 / Color / Drama / 95 minutes / Direction: Auraeus Solito / Screenplay: Kanakan Balintagos and Henry Burgos / Cinematography: Louie Quirino / Editing: Chuck Gutierrez / Production Design: Hai Balbuena / Sound and Music: Diwa de Leon / Produced by Cinemalaya Foundation, Solito Arts, Alternative Vision Cinema, and Voyage Studios / Cast: Alessandra de Rossi (Punay), Rodrigo Santikan (Angkadang), Clifford Bañagale (Aris), Bonivie Budao, and Dax Alejandro

 

 

The first in a planned trilogy of films about Palawan, Busong weaves together local myths, motifs, and beliefs to create a mystical allegory of the present state of the island and its inhabitants, and to engage in thoughtful reflection on the titular term—a Palawan word that refers to a local concept of karma or fate. At the heart of the story are Punay and Angkadang, her brother. Afflicted with a mysterious illness that manifests itself as painful sores all over her body, including the soles of her feet, Punay must be borne by Angkadang in a hammock as they seek out a cure—a journey that serves to link the other parts of the film to one another. As they travel around Palawan, Punay and Angkadang meet people with quests of their own. The last of these, Aris, is a young man of Palawaneño descent searching for his roots, and it is the siblings’ encounter with him that proves crucial to the healing of Punay.

Busong won the awards for Best Director, Best Original Musical Score, and Best Sound Design in the Directors Showcase of the 2011 Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival. Internationally, it won the Emile Cantillon Cinema of Tomorrow Award at the 2011 Brussels International Independent Film Festival, the International Federation of Film Critics Award at the 2011 Almaty Eurasia International Film Festival, the Terroir of Cinema Award at the 2012 Wine Country Film Festival, and the Merata Mita Best of Stories Award at the 2012 National Geographic All Roads Film Festival. It was also shown in the Directors’ Fortnight program at the 2011 Cannes Film Festival.  Written by Jaime Oscar M. Salazar

text:
2012 / Color / Drama / 110 minutes / Direction and Screenplay: Jun Robles Lana / Cinematography: Carlo Mendoza / Editing: Lawrence S. Ang / Production Design: Joey Luna / Sound: Albert Michael Idioma / Music: Jeff Hernandez and Jema Pamintuan / Produced by Cinemalaya Foundation, Octobertrain Films, and APT Entertainment / Cast: Eddie Garcia (Rene), Rez Cortez (Sol), Princess (Bwakaw), Bibeth Orteza (Rose), Joey Paras (Tracy), Beverly Salviejo (Nitang), Soxie Topacio (Zaldy), Luz Valdez (Minda), Gardo Versoza (Fr Eddie), Armida Siguion-Reyna (Alicia), Allan Paule (Berting), May-i Fabros, Jonathan Neri, Soliman Cruz, Ronaldo Bertubin

Bwakaw is the story of Rene, a gay man who only learned to accept his homosexuality late in life. Believing that there is nothing more to look forward to given his advanced age, he has made extensive preparations for the end of his days. He has purchased a coffin and regularly fusses over his will. Gruff and sour-tempered, Rene has few friends, and his sole constant companion is a dog named Bwakaw. When the dog falls ill, Rene finds comfort in the friendship of Sol, a tricycle driver who helps the old man to search for treatment for Bwakaw. Their relationship slowly awakens in Rene feelings he had thought to be dead. Sol rejects Rene. And this forces Rene to come to certain realizations about love and loss.

Bwakaw won the Audience Choice Award, Network for the Promotion of Asian Cinema Award, and Best Actor (Garcia) in the Directors Showcase section of the 2012 Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival; Special Mention in the Winds of Asia-Middle East category of the 2012 Tokyo International Film Festival; Best Actor at the 2012 Asia Pacific Film Festival; Best Actor and People’s Choice for Best Actor at the 2013 Asian Film Awards; Best Motion Picture (Drama), Best Performance by an Actor in a Leading Role (Drama), Best Director, Best Original Screenplay, Best Story, and Best Cinematography at the 2013 Golden Screen Awards; Emile Guimet Award, Grand Prix du Jury International, and High Schools Award at the 2013 Vesoul International Film Festival of Asian Cinema. Bwakaw was selected by the Film Academy of the Philippines as the country’s official entry for Best Foreign Language Film in the 85th Academy Awards in 2013.  Written by Jaime Oscar M. Salazar

text:
(The Church Bell of Baler ) / 1961 / Documentary / Color / Direction and Screenplay: Lamberto V. Avellana / Historical Research: Daisy Hontiveros-Avellana / Cinematography: Marcelino Borja / Editing: Felix Damian / Production Design: Noly Panaligan / Sound: Flaviano Villareal / Music: Restituto Umali / Spanish Translation: Antonio Abad / Narration: Antonio Serrano / Produced by the Manila Times Publishing Company / Cast: Alfred Xeres-Burgos (Lt Martin de Cereso), Francisco de la Cruz, Agapito Lumayak, Cayetano Donato, and Raymundo Pantalunan.

During the long siege, the Spaniards survive on the cavans of palay (rice grains) stored by the parish priest, pounding rice with their rifle butts. They plant and harvest tomatoes and other vegetables in the churchyard while under fire from Filipino soldiers entrenched not more than 20 ft away. When their water supply is cut off, the intrepid Spaniards dig a well in front of the main altar where a spring of clean, cool water is discovered.

Spanish courage is matched by Filipino gallantry when the moment of surrender finally comes. Instead of subjecting their prisoners to humiliation, the Filipino troops give the Spaniards a smart salute as the latter emerge from their captivity. They are treated with kindness and courtesy befitting the nobility of their gesture in giving up a lost cause to save more lives.

La Campana de Baler won the Conde de Foxa prize, a silver medal, “for the best film exaltation of Spanish valours,” at the 21-nation film festival held in Bilbao, Spain, in 1961.  Written by Lena S. Pareja

article_title: City After Dark / Manila By Night

photos.desc:
Cherie Gil, left, Sharon Manabat, and Rio Locsin in City After Dark, 1980

(Photo courtesy of Mario A. Hernando)

text:
1980 /  Color / Drama / 150 minutes / Direction and Screenplay: Ishmael Bernal / Cinematography: Sergio Lobo / Editing: Augusto Salvador / Production Design: Peque Gallaga / Music: The Vanishing Tribe / Produced by Regal Films / Cast: Rio Locsin (Bea), Cherie Gil (Kano), Lorna Tolentino (Baby), Alma Moreno (Ade), Bernardo Bernardo (Manay Sharon), Orestes Ojeda (Pebrero), William Martinez (Alex), Gina Alajar (Vanessa), Sharon Manabat (Gaying), Charito Solis (Virgie), Jojo Santiago (Greggy), Maya Valdez, and Johnny Wilson

The story presents a profile of Manila’s underworld characters and the problems that beset the city: unemployment, prostitution, drug addiction, and lack of decent housing.

 

 

Bea is a blind girl who works in a massage parlor. Her closest companion is Kano, a lesbian who sells dope and is always high on drugs. They are joined by innocent provincial girl Baby, who was lured into the city by her sweet-talking lover Greggy, and now works as a waitress in a restaurant. Baby falls in love with a taxi driver, Pebrero, who is the father of two kids. He gets her pregnant and she winds up as a single mother. Ade, the live-in partner of Pebrero, pretends to work as a nurse to support her lazy, good-for-nothing lover. Unbeknownst to her, he is also the lover of a gay couturier, Manay Sharon. But Manay’s real love is a handsome teenage nightclub singer named Alex, who is a drug addict.

Alex’s mother, Virgie, gets so worried about her son that she goes to look for him at a known gay hangout. She runs into Manay, who knows that Virgie used to be a prostitute. Manay loves Alex so much that he agrees to turn him over to his mother, wishing for him not to get more involved in the worlds of narcotics and homosexuality.

As Baby’s pregnancy becomes increasingly obvious, she is forced to quit her job as waitress and earn a living as a prostitute just before giving birth. Kano is pursued by the police and eventually arrested. Ade meets a bloody and senseless death just as noisemakers and sparklers start to explode on New Year’s Eve. Ironically, at the film’s end, it is only the blind girl who is able to get out of the mess in which she finds herself.

Manila By Night was a daring movie, depicting the bad and ugly aspects of life in Manila at a time when such films were frowned upon by the Marcos regime. A censored version was shown in Manila under the title City After Dark. It was invited for screening at the Berlin Film Festival, but the authorities refused to issue an export permit. Later, the censored version was shown in film retrospectives abroad.

In Gawad Urian, City After Dark won Best Picture, Best Screenplay, Best Actor (Bernardo), and Best Production Design, and was nominated for Best Director, Best Actress (Gil and Locsin), and Best Musical Score. It was one of the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino’s 10 Best Films of the Decade 1980-89.  Written by Lena S. Pareja

text:
(Unlicensed Taxicab) / 2009 / Color / Drama / Direction and Story: Jobin Ballesteros / Screenplay: Jobin Ballesteros, Diana Malahay, and Jerry Gracio / Cinematography: Anthon Tarnate / Editing: Jobin Ballesteros and Lawrence Fajardo / Production Design: Francisco Sebanes / Sound: Ditoy Aguila and Arnold Reodica / Music: Jun Lopito, Jobin Ballesteros, and Melvin Sumalinog / Produced by Cinemalaya Foundation and Wild Coyote Pictures / Cast: Alfred Vargas (Simon), Lou Veloso (Pedro), Andoy Ranay, Cherry Alba, Archie Adamos, Jose Mari Avellana, and Neil Ryan Sese

 

 

Simon is a young policeman in the province who moonlights as the driver of an unlicensed taxicab owned by his godfather, who happens to be a colonel. He picks up a newly released ex-convict, Pedro, who is looking for his estranged son. As the two bicker about where Pedro can find the bus depot, they accidentally run over an American pedestrian. In a fit of panic, Simon attempts to flee, but not before Pedro threatens to report the incident to the authorities. Simon leaves the scene of the crime, taking Pedro hostage. Pedro tries to escape from his captor several times but soon realizes that Simon is on his way to Leyte. Pedro becomes a willing hostage, hoping the journey would bring him closer to finding his son. As the two go on a road trip, they meet various individuals along their many stops—a frustrated writer, a young woman who plans on having an abortion, a phony spiritual preacher, and a guitarist for a Christian ministry. Later, Simon realizes that his godfather hired thugs to meet them in Leyte in order to kill Pedro, the only witness to the accident. Simon is guilt-stricken and decides to go home with Pedro. He tells Pedro that he will surrender to the authorities. Pedro finally gets to talk to his son on the phone. He realizes the impossibility of starting life anew with his son. The next day as they wait in the cab outside the precinct, Pedro decides to sacrifice his now “meaningless” life to save Simon. He grabs Simon’s gun, shoots the latter in the leg, and then rushes out of the cab to “surrender” himself to the police. But because he is carrying a gun, the police shoot him to death.

Colorum won the Special Jury Prize and the Balanghai trophy for Best Actor (Veloso) in the 2009 Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival. Veloso also won Best Actor in the 2009 Brussels International Film Festival and the 2010 Gawad Urian. The film also participated in the 2009 Tokyo International Film Festival.  Written by Anne Frances Sangil

Angel Aquino, Sharon Cuneta, and Hilda Koronel in Crying Ladies, 1998

(Mario A. Hernando Collection)

text:
2003 / Color / Drama / 110 minutes / Direction and Screenplay: Mark Meily / Cinematography: Lee Meily / Editing: Danny Añonuevo / Production Design: Norman Regalado / Sound: Raffy Magsaysay / Music: Vincent de Jesus / Produced by Unitel Pictures / Cast: Sharon Cuneta (Stella Mate), Hilda Koronel (Doray), Angel Aquino (Choleng), Eric Quizon (Wilson Chua), Ricky Davao (Guido), Julio Pacheco (Bong), Shamaine Buencamino (Cecile), Bella Flores , Raymond Bagatsing, Edgar Mortiz, Johnny Delgado, Sherry Lara, Gilleth Sandico, and Joan Bitangcol

 

 

Stella Mate is an ex-convict struggling to keep her life together by working at a Chinese store. She is hired by Wilson Chua, a Filipino-Chinese man, to act as a tagaiyak (crier/mourner) during the wake of the latter’s father. Stella agrees and convinces her friends Choleng and Doray to cry with her during the five-day wake. Stella belatedly realizes that the deceased was the man who sent her to prison for swindling. Unable to back out of the arrangement, Stella and her two friends spend the next five evenings crying at the wake. During the day, Stella spends time with her son Bong, who is set to fly to Cagayan de Oro with his father Guido and stepmom Cecile. She auditions for a singing job at several recruitment agencies. She also tries to make ends meet by joining a few radio and TV game shows, and even resorts to conning jeepney drivers in order to save a buck or two in her daily fare. After the funeral, Bong leaves for Cagayan de Oro and Stella finds herself alone once again. She is able to turn her life around, thanks to Wilson who recommends her to a recruitment agency looking for talents to be sent to Japan. In the end, Stella is hired as a videoke (music video) actress, later winning the Best Actress award for a videoke appearance in the 1st International Golden Oke Awards in Tokyo.

Crying Ladies won the 2003 Metro Manila Film Festival awards for Best Picture, Best Director, Best Actor (Quizon), and Best Supporting Actress (Koronel); the 2004 Film Academy of the Philippines award for Best Supporting Actor (Quizon); and the 2004 Gawad Urian for Best Cinematography. It also won Best Film, Best Director, and the Network for the Promotion of Asian Cinema Award in the 2004 Kerala Film Festival in India, as well as the Best Actress (Cuneta) award in the 2004 Brussels International Independent Film Festival. It was the Philippines’ official entry for Best Foreign Language Film in the 2004 Academy Awards.  Written by Anne Frances Sangil

It also won Best Film, Best Director, and the Network for the Promotion of Asian Cinema Award in the 2004 Kerala Film Festival in India, as well as the Best Actress (Cuneta) award in the 2004 Brussels International Independent Film Festival. It was the Philippines’ official entry for Best Foreign Language Film in the 2004 Academy Awards.

(Cesar Hernando Collection)

text:
(Curacha: The Woman Without Rest) / 1998 / Color / Drama / 141 minutes / Direction: Chito S. Roño / Story: Chito S. Roño and Ricardo Lee / Screenplay: Ricardo Lee / Cinematography: Charlie Peralta / Editing: Jaime Davila / Production Design: Tatus Aldana / Sound: Albert Michael Idioma / Music: Jaime Fabregas / Visual Effects: Raul Pedro Bulaong and Dodge Ledesma / Produced by Regal Films / Cast: Rosanna Roces (Curacha/Corazon), Jaclyn Jose (Myrna), Ruby Moreno, Ara Mina, Lucita Soriano, Maureen Mauricio, Mike Magat, Dick Israel, Tito Arevalo, Lito Legaspi, Richard Bonnin, Roy Alvarez, Richard Quan, Tom Olivar, Bea Lopez, Alex Cortez, Tony Mabesa, Vangie Labalan, Ama Quiambao, Allen Dizon, Rolando Tinio, Winnie Cordero, Ronnie Lazaro, Connie Chua, and Eva Darren

 

 

Structured around loosely connected episodes, the film follows a day and a night in the life of Corazon, who goes by the name Curacha, a torera (live sex performer). Her vulgar thoughts throughout the film are laid bare for the viewers. But it is not an ordinary day, for as Curacha goes through her personal ordeals, a coup d’état is being staged against her namesake, President Corazon Aquino. The film opens as she wakes up one morning, thinking of how the sex trade has exploited her whole body, which she compares to the geography of the Philippines. It ends the following morning, with her listening to the national anthem and thinking that, in spite of everything she has gone through, no one has ever possessed her life. In between, she has sex with a couple of soldiers (a colonel and a private), is left by a torero-lover, goes on a search for a dead friend, dreams of the Virgin Mary, visits a home for the aged, considers joining the coup d’état, and tries to save her drug-addicted and suicidal friend Myrna, among others. The film was released during the centennial of the Philippine Revolution and alludes to films released during the presidency of Ferdinand Marcos, such as Ishmael Bernal’s City After Dark, 1980; Nick Deocampo’s Oliver, 1983; and Roño’s debut feature, Private Show, 1985.

 

Curacha: Ang Babaeng Walang Pahinga won Best Achievement in Sound and Aural Orchestration in the Young Critics Circle Film Desk Citations for 1998.  Written by Patrick Campos

text:
(The Road to Kalimugtong) / 2005 / Color / Drama / 89 minutes / Direction, Screenplay, and Production Design: Mes de Guzman / Cinematography: Albert Banzon / Editing: Mes de Guzman (as Abbas Tabas) and Noel Montano (as Arasaw Kurabokov) / Sound: Bob Macabenta Music: Bernard “Nio” Manzano / Produced by Sampaybakod Productions / Cast: Rhenuel Ordoño (Potpot), Analyn Bangsi-il (Jinky), Hallen Sumingwa, Joey Almoete, Jay Bassig, and Nemee Tocdangan

 

The film centers on the story of young Benguet orphans Potpot and Jinky, who live with their invalid grandfather and two older brothers who work odd jobs to provide for the family. Every day the children traverse the mountain, braving a rocky terrain, a dense forest, a raging river, a precarious hanging bridge, and gunfire heard through the trees in order to go to school. In school, they are taught by a young teacher who has failed in the board exam thrice and who dreams of leaving the province for a better life. This is the normal routine of the children until, one day, after their brothers find jobs in a mining company, the family breadwinners fail to come home for weeks. The neighbors begin to suspect that the older boys were killed in a landslide in the mines. But Potpot and Jinky press on, caring for their grandfather, harvesting herbs and sayote (chayote) in the backyard so as not to starve, while quietly hoping for their brothers’ safe return. When the brothers do return, hurt but alive, the young ones are happy. The family is once again complete. The next day, with gratitude and joy, they begin their journey again through the arduous path to their school in Kalimugtong.

 

Ang Daan Patungong Kalimugtong won Best Director and Best Production Design in the 2006 Gawad Urian, which nominated it for nine other awards. It won Second Best Picture in the 2005 Cinemanila International Film Festival, Special Mention for Best New Director in the 2006 San Sebastián International Film Festival,Best Independent Motion Picture and Best Sound in the 2006 ENPRESS Golden Screen Awards, and Movie Child Performer of the Year (Bangsi-il) in the 2006 PMPC Star Awards for Movies.  Written by Patrick Campos

article_title: Dahil Mahal Kita: The Dolzura Cortez Story
text:
(Because I Love You) / 1993 / Color / Drama / Direction: Laurice Guillen / Screenplay: Ricardo Lee, based on the work of Ceres P. Doyo / Cinematography: Eduardo Jacinto / Editing: Efren Jarlego / Production Design: Edgar Martin Littaua / Art Direction: Buboy Tagayon / Sound: Monching Reyes / Music: Nonong Buencamino / Produced by OctoArts Films / Cast: Vilma Santos (Dolly), Christopher de Leon (Paolo), Nonie Buencamino (Gardo), Jackie Aquino (Elena), Richard Chaney (Keith), Saameer (Abbul), Eula Valdez (Cora), Maila Gumila, Mikee Villanueva, Charito Solis, and Shamaine Centenera

 

 

Dolzura, who goes by Dolly, is a liberated woman who has known many men in her life. Her first partner, Gardo, turns out to be married to Elena, and despite her initial protest, she agrees to live with Elena and Gardo in Pampanga. After six years of emotional and physical abuse, she and her children leave Gardo. She meets Paolo, a researcher who has problems with commitment and who eventually leaves her. She then marries the American and Vietnam War veteran Keith, and they put up a bar in Ermita. Abbul takes an interest in her, drugs her, and gets her pregnant. The American threatens to kill her and kicks her out of the house. She ends up with Abbul, who eventually leaves her too.

 

Dolly takes on different jobs to survive and later on puts up an agency for overseas Filipino workers while her sister Cora takes care of her children. She encounters a man who has a severe case of gonorrhea, but she tests negative for the said sexually transmitted infection and goes on with her bohemian life. While dancing in a club, she faints and gets hospitalized and decides to go back to her hometown of Cotabato to recuperate. She is diagnosed with AIDS. She cannot quite accept it, and she becomes a pariah in her hometown. Even the hospital shoos her away. With her loving and supportive mother, she goes back to Manila where she gets appropriate treatment from a government hospital. Paolo resurfaces in her life. He is now training as an AIDS counsellor and is working on a project on AIDS in the Philippines. Paolo and Dolly become friends again. She agrees to become an informant for his case study, and he convinces her to come out to the public, to help combat the stigma attached to persons living with AIDS. Dolzura Cortez is the first person to come out as a person with AIDS in the Philippines.

 

The first Filipino film on AIDS, Dahil Mahal Kita won Best Actress (Santos), Best Story Adaptation, and Best Musical Score in the 1994 Film Academy of the Philippines Awards. It also received Best Actress and Best Music awards from Gawad Urian.  Written by Ronald Baytan

Jet del Mundo and Robert Arevalo in Ang Daigdig ng mga Api, 1965
(Cesar Hernando Collection)

text:
(The World of the Oppressed) / 1965 / Black and White / Drama / Direction: Gerardo de Leon / Story and Screenplay: Pierre Salas / Cinematography: Mike Accion / Music: Tito Arevalo / Produced by Cinemasters Inc / Cast: Robert Arevalo (Inong), Jet del Mundo (Israel), Barbara Perez, Oscar Keesee, Leni Alano, Ben Perez, Manny Ojeda, Ana Trinidad, Dely Villanueva, Mona del Cielo, Ruben Ilagan, Francisco Cruz, and Quiel Mendoza

 

 

Israel, a student in Manila, goes home to his province for a vacation. The vacation becomes a rude awakening to social realities in his hometown. The student witnesses the oppression of farm tenants like Inong and his wife. The landlessness of Inong and the rest of the farmers is exacerbated by the usury practiced by the wicked encargado or land overseer who manages the vast agricultural estate of the landlord. Among the crimes of the overseer is the rape of an innocent peasant girl.

 

More tension and conflict come into the couple’s life when Inong’s pregnant wife dies on the way to the hospital. Inong’s personal tragedy culminates in the revolt of the peasants against their oppressive situation. During the bloody uprising, Inong kills the land overseer. He is imprisoned. But Israel, a witness to the helplessness and despair of the peasants, vows that, as a lawyer, he will defend the poor peasants against the injustice and oppression.

 

Ang Daigdig ng mga Api won the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences awards for Best Picture, Best Director, Best Story and Screenplay, Best Cinematography, Best Actor (Arevalo), Best Actress (Perez), Best Supporting Actress (Alano), and Best Child Actress (Trinidad).  Written by Rosalie Matilac

text:
(The Dream of Eleuteria) / 2010 / Color / Drama / 90 minutes / Direction, Screenplay, and Editing: Remton Siega Zuasola / Story: Maria Victoria Beltran / Cinematography: Christian Linaban / Production Design: Kaloy Uypuanco / Art Direction: Victor Villanueva / Sound: Vanya Fantonial / Music: Jerrold Tarog / Produced by Cinema One Originals and Panumduman Pictures / Cast: Donna Gimeno (Terya), Gregg Tecson, Lucia Juezan, and Emelda Mabusay

 

Shot in its entirety in one long take, the film begins with a mother searching for her daughter, the titular Eleuteria or Terya. With the help of her husband and her younger daughter, the mother finds Terya in a creek, trying to drown herself. Terya has been scheduled to leave her home for Germany where she is supposed to marry a much older man she has never met, a transaction calculated to rescue her family from mounting debts. Foiled in her suicide attempt, Terya tries to sort things out in her mind as her relatives accompany her to the pier, where the boat that will take her to the airport waits. As she walks, Terya must come to a decision in the midst of the conflicting assertions, pleas, and advice of the people around her, including her parents who are divided on the prospect of her departure, her boyfriend who proposes elopement, and her cousin who herself had been married to a German but has returned to the island for good. In the end, Terya resigns herself to the hurt that she has to endure to fulfill her family’s dream for a better life.

 

Ang Damgo ni Eleuteria won Best Director, Best Music, Best Cinematography, and Best Picture at the 2011 Gawad Urian; Best Screenplay at the Young Critics Circle Film Desk Citations for 2010; and Best Music and Special Jury Prize at the 2010 Cinema One Originals Digital Film Festival. Internationally, it won Best Southeast Asian Film at the 2010 Cinemanila International Film Festival, Special Jury Prize at the 2011 Jeonju Film Festival, the Network for the Promotion of Asian Cinema (NETPAC) Award (Special Mention) at the 2011 Moscow International Film Festival, and the Geber Award and the Golden Hanoman Award at the 2011 Jogja-NETPAC Asian Film Festival.  Written by Jaime Oscar M. Salazar

photos.desc:
Romnick Sarmenta and Beth Tamayo in Damong Ligaw, 1997

(Mario A. Hernando Collection)

text:
(Wild Grass) / 1997/ Color / Drama / Direction and Screenplay: Jose Mari Avellana (based on the novel Kangkong 1896 by Ceres Alabado) / Cinematography: Ricardo Remias / Editing: Dante Nava / Production Design: Manny Samaniego / Sound: Noel Cruz Bruan and Nestor Mutia / Music: Irwin Cafugauan / Produced by Premiere Entertainment Productions Inc / Cast: Romnick Sarmenta (Florante), Beth Tamayo (Clara), Ronnie Lazaro (Andres Bonifacio), Robert Arevalo (Victor), Marla de Vera (Gregoria de Jesus), Jed Guzman (Emilio Jacinto), Perla Bautista (Tandang Sora), Daria Ramirez, Alvin Anson, Marco Ballesteros, Rustica Carpio, Ray Davao, Lawrence David, Alek Labay, Dado Mitra, and Ernie Zarate

 

 

Released in 1998 just before the Centennial of the Philippine Revolution, Damong Ligaw retells the story of the revolution of the Philippines against Spain in 1898. But the retelling puts into the foreground the story of an ordinary man, as opposed to the historical figures Andres Bonifacio, Gregoria de Jesus, Emilio Jacinto,and Tandang Sora, who are only in the film’s narrative sidelines. The film is centered on the coming-of-age of a young man who joins the Katipunan, a secret revolutionary organization, and learns what it means to be a hero. Florante is an angry farm boy who was brought up by his strict, exacting, and even angrier father, Victor, though they are angry for different reasons. Victor rages against the colonizers, while Florante does not understand why his father is forcing him to join the revolutionaries. But when Florante obeys Victor, he develops courage and sharp wit, and he begins to understand the cause of freedom. Amidst the atrocities of war, however, Florante must learn another lesson—to let go of the love of his life, Clara, so that he can go to war. After a major confrontation between the Filipino and Spanish forces, Florante survives. He returns for Clara who has, likewise, decided to live the revolutionary life. The film ends with a title card, saying: “Ito ang simula” (This is the beginning).

 

Damong Ligaw won Best Cinematography, Best Musical Score, and the Centennial Award in the 1998 Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Awards. In the 1998 Film Academy of the Philippines Awards, it won Best Story Adaptation.  Written by Patrick Campos

Muhlach, Veronica Jones, and Vilma Santos in Darna at Ding, 1980.

(Mario A. Hernando Collection)

text:
1951 / Black and White / Fantasy / 90 minutes / Direction: Fernando Poe / Story and Screenplay: Mars Ravelo (as serialized in Pilipino Komiks) / Cinematography: Remigio Young / Music: Constancio de Guzman / Produced by Royal Productions / Cast: Rosa del Rosario (Darna), Mila Nimfa (Narda), Cristina Aragon (Valentina), Manuel Ubaldo (Ding), Ben Perez, Elena Mayo, and Leonora Ruiz

 

 

Darna is the original full-length action-fantasy movie featuring the girl who comes to possess the powers of a superwoman. The very first version faithfully followed the original comic strip. A little girl, Narda, swallows a stone that has fallen from the sky. The talisman gives her the power to transform herself into a beautiful and mighty superheroine when she utters her name backward, Darna. As Darna, she can fly anywhere at amazing speed with her friend, Ding. With superhuman strength, she defends the oppressed and fights Valentina, the Medusa-inspired villain, who is wreaking havoc on a village.

 

A number of Darna versions have been produced by various outfits, including films that feature Darna as a male transvestite, like Terribol Dobol (Terrible Duo), 1974, with Chiquito, and Darna, Kuno? (They Say It’s Darna), 1979, with Dolphy. The role has been played by Liza Moreno, Eva Montes, Gina Pareño, Rossana Ortiz, Vilma Santos, Rio Locsin, Sharon Cuneta, Nanette Medved, and Anjanette Abayari. There have also been a number of TV remakes, like one by KBS 9 in 1977 that featured Lorna Tolentino, another by GMA Network in 2005 starring Angel Locsin, and another one by GMA in 2009 with Marian Rivera. Like Dyesebel, Darna is a komiks and movie character that has become part of Filipino popular culture, inspiring a modern choreographic production by Ballet Philippines, 2003, and a graphic novel, Carlo Vergara’s Ang Kagila-gilalas na Pakikipagsapalaran ni Zsazsa Zaturnnah (The Amazing Adventures of Zsazsa Zaturnnah), 2002.  Written by Ellen Bomasang and Ramon Jocson, with notes from Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

article_title: Dawn of Freedom / Liwayway ng Kalayaan
text:
1944 / Black and White / Action / Direction: Yutaka Abe and Gerardo de Leon / Story: Yutaka Abe and Denjiro Odochi / Screenplay: Ryichiro Yagi and Hideo Kokumi / Cinematography: Giyu Miyajima and Higino Fallorina / Produced by Toho for release through Eiga Haikyusha / Cast: Leopoldo Salcedo (Captain Reyes), Fernando Poe (Captain Gomez), Angel Esmeralda (Lieutenant Garcia), Ricardo Pasion (Tony), Denjiro Okochi, Seisaburo Kawazu, Ichiro Tsukata, Bert Le Roy, Rosa Aguirre, Norma Blancaflor, Franco Garcia, Guillermo Carlos, and Tessie Quintana

On Christmas Eve, 1941, Manila is declared an open city and everyone is directed to stay at home. That evening Filipino soldiers, with the United States Armed Forces in the Far East (USAFFE), bid their families goodbye to join the troops in Bataan. Captain Gomez reassures his sweetheart that he will return, while his neighbor, Lieutenant Garcia, allays the worst fears of his mother and promises to bring home a helmet as a souvenir for his younger brother, Tony.

The Filipino soldiers in Bataan are treated harshly by their American officers. Captain Reyes protests the abuses suffered by his men. He is sent out on a patrol mission, unaware that secret orders have been given to an American sergeant to kill him. His death is avenged by Lieutenant Garcia. The Japanese forces enter Manila and are welcomed by the citizens. Tony, a hit-and-run victim, is abandoned by the retreating Americans. A Japanese officer saves his life. Tony’s mother is so grateful that she personally sends out an appeal to her other son, Lieutenant Garcia, and the Filipino soldiers in Bataan, to lay down their arms and return to their homes, because the Japanese are their friends and not their enemies as they had been misled to believe.

Captain Gomez heeds the call and defects to the Japanese side. Over a microphone, he urges his fellow Filipino soldiers to stop fighting the Japanese. He volunteers to join the assault on Corregidor but is told that only Japanese soldiers can go on that dangerous mission. The film ends with the victory of the Japanese and the unconditional surrender of the American forces in Bataan and Corregidor under General Wainwright. As he surveys the battlefield, Captain Gomez comes across the dead soldier, Lieutenant Garcia, still clutching the US Army helmet intended for his brother, Tony, with the scribbled message that it is the helmet of the enemy.

Liwayway ng Kalayaan, as an instrument of propaganda, had a threefold aim: to unmask the Americans as the real enemies and thus eradicate their influence on the Filipino people, to emphasize Japan’s role as the leader in the Greater East Asia Co-Prosperity Sphere, and to recover the native Asian character that Filipinos had lost after centuries of Western colonization. Actual footage of the Bataan and Corregidor campaigns was used to document Japanese gains during the Pacific War. The film was first shown in Tokyo on 5 Feb 1944 under the title Ano Hatta o Utte (Tear Down the Stars and Stripes). The Philippine premiere was held a month later in Manila on 7 Mar 1944.  Written by Lena S. Pareja

article.value: On Christmas Eve, 1941, Manila is declared an open city and everyone is directed to stay at home. That evening Filipino soldiers, with the United States Armed Forces in the Far East (USAFFE), bid their families goodbye to join the troops in Bataan. Captain Gomez reassures his sweetheart that he will return, while his neighbor, Lieutenant Garcia, allays the worst fears of his mother and promises to bring home a helmet as a souvenir for his younger brother, Tony.

The Filipino soldiers in Bataan are treated harshly by their American officers. Captain Reyes protests the abuses suffered by his men. He is sent out on a patrol mission, unaware that secret orders have been given to an American sergeant to kill him. His death is avenged by Lieutenant Garcia. The Japanese forces enter Manila and are welcomed by the citizens. Tony, a hit-and-run victim, is abandoned by the retreating Americans. A Japanese officer saves his life. Tony’s mother is so grateful that she personally sends out an appeal to her other son, Lieutenant Garcia, and the Filipino soldiers in Bataan, to lay down their arms and return to their homes, because the Japanese are their friends and not their enemies as they had been misled to believe.

Captain Gomez heeds the call and defects to the Japanese side. Over a microphone, he urges his fellow Filipino soldiers to stop fighting the Japanese. He volunteers to join the assault on Corregidor but is told that only Japanese soldiers can go on that dangerous mission. The film ends with the victory of the Japanese and the unconditional surrender of the American forces in Bataan and Corregidor under General Wainwright. As he surveys the battlefield, Captain Gomez comes across the dead soldier, Lieutenant Garcia, still clutching the US Army helmet intended for his brother, Tony, with the scribbled message that it is the helmet of the enemy.

Liwayway ng Kalayaan, as an instrument of propaganda, had a threefold aim: to unmask the Americans as the real enemies and thus eradicate their influence on the Filipino people, to emphasize Japan’s role as the leader in the Greater East Asia Co-Prosperity Sphere, and to recover the native Asian character that Filipinos had lost after centuries of Western colonization. Actual footage of the Bataan and Corregidor campaigns was used to document Japanese gains during the Pacific War. The film was first shown in Tokyo on 5 Feb 1944 under the title Ano Hatta o Utte (Tear Down the Stars and Stripes). The Philippine premiere was held a month later in Manila on 7 Mar 1944.

text:
(Grandpa Is Dead) / 2009 / Color / Comedy / 90 minutes / Direction and Screenplay: Soxie Topacio / Cinematography: Journalie Payonan / Editing: Danny Añonuevo / Production Design: Edel Templonuevo / Sound: Ditoy Aguila / Music: Noel Cabangon / Produced by APT Entertainment / Cast: Roderick Paulate (Junee), Gina Alajar (Mameng), Elizabeth Oropesa (Dolores), Manilyn Reynes (Charing), Dick Israel (Isidro), Perla Bautista (Pilar), BJ Forbes (Bobet), and Rainier Castillo (Jimmy)

 

Told through the eyes of a young boy, Bobet, Ded Na si Lolo is the hilarious tale of a family mourning the death of a loved one. When the patriarch of the family dies, his children—Isidro, Dolores, Mameng, Charing, and Junee—gather together at their family home to mourn his passing. All the children have a flair for the dramatic (each of them fainted when they heard of their father’s death). As they gather around their father’s wake, all their beliefs relating to the dead are remembered, observed, and critically presented: bathing and sweeping the floor are prohibited because these bring bad luck; for good luck, money should be placed in the hands of the deceased during the wake and removed before the funeral; no soup-based food should be served. The list goes on and on, prompting Junee to finally ask aloud, “Who started all these silly rituals?” Nobody knows the answer. Meanwhile, the siblings’ issues with each other also come to the fore, leading to confrontations and tearful breakdowns. The siblings quarrel about the past, the present, and the future, but in the end remain one family.

 

The story is a brilliant, comical exploration of Filipino culture with all its strange superstitions about death and the sometimes inexplicable expressions of love for one’s family. Director Topacio’s theater background comes into full play in the mise-en-scène and the over-the-top performances. The campy, histrionic acting by Gina Alajar, Elizabeth Oropesa, Manilyn Reynes, and especially Roderick Paulate is done with such bravado and perfect comic timing. Ded Na si Lolo, one of six screenplays produced in digital format by Antonio P. Tuviera for the Sine Direk series, became a certified blockbuster hit. It won Best Picture, Best Screenplay, and Best Actor (Paulate) at the 2010 Golden Screen Awards. It was also chosen as the Philippines’s official entry for Best Foreign Language Film in the 82nd Oscar Awards.  Written by Elvin Valerio

text:
(The 1970s) / 2002 / Color / Drama / 128 minutes / Direction: Chito S. Roño / Screenplay: Lualhati Bautista / Cinematography: Neil Daza / Editing: Jess Navarro / Production Design: Manny Morfe / Sound: Albert Michael Idioma and Alex Tomboc / Music: Nonong Buencamino / Produced by Star Cinema / Cast: Vilma Santos (Amanda), Christopher de Leon (Julian), Piolo Pascual (Jules), Marvin Agustin, Carlos Agassi, Ana Capri, Danilo Barrios, Dimples Romana, Jhong Hilario, Carlo Muñoz, Orestes Ojeda, John Wayne Sace, Tirso Cruz III, and Marianne de la Riva

 

 

Based on Lualhati Bautista’s Palanca award-winning novel of 1983, the movie situates its narrative in the mid-1960s to the 1970s, focusing on a middle-class Filipino family that tries to cope with the changes happening then in the country—from the numerous student demonstrations and the suspension of the writ of habeas corpus, to the declaration of martial law in 1972 and its aftermath. Amanda Bartolome, a wife and mother of five boys, together with her husband Julian, struggles to deal with the various complications caused by the choices of their sons.

 

She tries to understand the reasons why their eldest son Jules decided to join the underground movement against the Marcos government, ultimately becoming a wanted political officer of the underground movement. After a long period of hiding, Jules is eventually captured and tortured by the military, while Jason, the fourth son, is murdered by unknown individuals. Unfazed by the tragedies, the Bartolome family goes on with their own lives, much like the country itself which struggles to survive amidst the inhumanity caused by martial law. In the end, Amanda is transformed from a simple, naive wife and mother to a self-aware and confident woman determined to prevail over the ordeals that the decade has imposed upon her and her family.

 

At the 2003 Gawad Urian, Dekada ’70 won Best Picture, Best Actress (Santos), Best Supporting Actor (Pascual), and Best Screenplay. It also won Best Actress, Best Supporting Actor, and Best Production Design in the 2003 Film Academy of the Philippines Awards; Best Supporting Actor in the 2003 Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Awards; Best Actress and the Special Jury Prize from the Network for the Promotion of Asian Cinema in the 2003 Cinemanila International Film Festival; and Best Performance (Santos and Pascual), Best Film, Best Screenplay, and Best Achievement in Sound and Aural Orchestration in the Young Critics Circle Film Desk Citations for 2002. Dekada ’70 was also voted the Best Film in the 25th Catholic Mass Media Awards, and was the country’s official entry for Best Foreign Language Film in the 76th Oscar Awards.  Written by Anne Frances Sangil

text:
2013 / Documentary / Color / 89 minutes / Direction: Jose Antonio Vargas and Ann Lupo / Screenplay: Jose Antonio Vargas / Cinematography: Clarissa de los Reyes / Editing: Sabrina Schmidt Gordon / Music: Brendon Anderegg / Produced by CNN Films and Apo Anak Productions / Cast: Jose Antonio Vargas, Emelie Salinas, and Leonila Salinas

 

Documented starts in the year 2011 when journalist Jose Antonio Vargas awaits the publication of his New York Times article. Vargas is anxious as he reveals in the article his undocumented status in the United States. Vargas is a Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist, awarded for his work in the reportage of the 2007 Virginia Tech University massacre. Documented recounts his journey as a minor, sent to the United States by his mother to live with his grandparents. As a minor, Vargas is unaware of his undocumented status. Later, when he is forced to use false documents to secure a driver’s license, he realizes the implications of his circumstance. Yet, he obtains a journalism degree from San Francisco State University, and becomes a prolific and respected writer. A Skype conversation with his estranged mother with whom he has not had contact since he was 12 ends the documentary, his status in the United States still hanging in the balance.

 

Documented was the official selection in the following film festivals: AFI DOCS presented by Audi, 2013; the Hawaii International Film Festival, 2013; and the Boulder International Film Festival, 2014.  Written by Mario Mendez Jr

text:
2010 / Color / Drama / 84 minutes / Direction, Screenplay, and Music: Mark Meily / Cinematography: Jay Abello / Editing: Neil Sayno and Mark Pandy / Production Design: Aped Santos / Sound: Albert Michael Idioma / Produced by Spark Films / Cast: Meryll Soriano (Lizette Bernal), Baron Geisler (Danny), Jao Mapa (Busko), Karla Pambid (Rose), Joy Viado (Angie), Lilit Reyes, and Kristina Syfu

 

Donor follows the story of Lizette Bernal, who sells pirated DVDs for a living. One day, a fellow vendor Angie asks her if she might be interested in selling one of her kidneys for a hefty sum. Lizette is then introduced to Busko, a middleman to the wealthy Middle Eastern man awaiting a kidney transplant. She initially dismisses the idea but finally agrees to the transaction, as she wants to work abroad and needs to raise funds to pay the placement fee when she gets accepted. This will eventually allow her to leave her jobless and self-absorbed live-in partner Danny. Later, Lizette learns that she also needs to marry the recipient of her kidney, as Philippine law forbids organ transplants between Filipinos and foreigners unless they are related. Lizette tells Danny, and he yields to her decision but asks her to fund a Glock gun he wants to purchase. After the successful operation, Lizette is now ready to pursue her overseas job application. However, she discovers another hurdle she has to face—her pregnancy. Out of desperation, she seeks help from her friend Rose in finding an abortionist.

 

With some punches of humor, Donor exposes the harsh reality of surviving poverty—from engaging in the risky business of peddling DVDs to risking it all by giving up one’s organ for the right price. Donor won Best Film, Best Production Design, and Best Performances (Geisler, Soriano, Pambid) at the 2010 Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival. The film also bagged the grand prize in the 2010 Brussels International Independent Film Festival. Donor was in the official selection to the Deauville Asian Film Festival in France, and at the Pusan, Hawaii, Göteborg, Seattle, and Marrakesh International Film Festivals.  Written by Michael Kho Lim

text:
2006 / Color / Drama / 105 minutes / Direction and Screenplay: Adolfo Alix Jr / Cinematography: Eli Balce / Editing: Tara Illenberger / Production Design: Gessan Enriquez / Sound: Ari Trofeo / Music: Jesse Lucas / Produced by Cinemalaya Foundation and Bicycle Pictures / Cast: Sid Lucero (Daniel), Angel Aquino (Teresa), Cherie Gil (Mars), Jaclyn Jose (Ligaya), Bembol Roco (Fidel), and Mark Gil

 

 

Set in the town of Donsol, Sorsogon, Daniel, the town hunk, is a butanding (whale shark) interaction officer who accompanies tourists on whale shark watching expeditions and assists them in swimming with the butanding. With a heart broken from a previous relationship, he meets Teresa, along with her journalist friend Mars. Teresa is a recently widowed breast cancer survivor who is returning to the area for the first time since her husband’s untimely death. Daniel’s friendship with Teresa soon leads to a brief romantic encounter. Used to his easy life and still recovering from his past relationship, Daniel finds it difficult to deal with his feelings for Teresa, a much older woman who has gone through a lot in her life. Eventually, they both realize that their relationship is as fleeting as the whale shark season. Teresa leaves Donsol with a renewed sense of moving on with her life while Daniel, now more mature, continues to wait for the love of his life.

 

Part of the second batch of the Cinemalaya Philippine Indepedent Film Festival grantees, Donsol launched the directorial career of screenwriter Adolfo Alix Jr. The film won Best Cinematography and Best Actress (Aquino) in the 2006 Cinemalaya, the Spirit of the Independent Award in the 2006 Fort Lauderdale International Film Festival, Best Cinematography in the 2007 Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Awards, and Best Cinematography and Breakthrough Performance by an Actor (Lucero) in the 2007 Golden Screen Awards.  Written by Elvin Valerio

text:
(Doubt) / 2003 / Color / 112 minutes / Direction and Screenplay: Cris Pablo / Cinematography: Alma de la Peña / Editing: Cris Pablo, Julian Quinto, Randy Elepaño, and Tyrone Santiago / Production Design: Zhur Salucana and Joey Herrera / Music: Isha, Julian Quinto, and Maria Christine Muyco / Produced by Grupong Sinehan and UP Cineastes’ Studio / Cast: Andoy Ranay (Cris), Paolo Gabriel (Eric), Rey Pumaloy, Jojo Nones, Larry Kurl, Buddy Caramat, Larry Burns, Bel Clerigo, and John Lapus

 

Duda charts the development of a tumultuous romance between Cris and Eric. Cris is a TV director who apparently has a sexual appetite so voracious that he has slept with thousands of men. During a Holy Week getaway at the White Beach of Puerto Galera, an area that has been called the summer capital for gay men, he meets Eric, falls in love, and decides to commit himself to monogamy. Eric, for his part, does not feel ready to do the same, and the resulting tensions trigger in Cris a desperate passion that leads to a suicide attempt. The film uses a complex format, weaving together vignettes of Cris and Eric’s life together, interviews with Cris’s many friends, and, toward the end, a couple of parodical talk-show episodes regarding the pair’s deteriorating relationship.

 

Duda earned nominations for Best Director at the 2004 New York Asian-American Film Festival and the 2004 Barcelona International Lesbian and Gay Film Festival. In the Philippines, it was screened as part of the 2004 Second International Gay and Lesbian Film and Video Festival. The first digital gay film in the country, Duda is also recognized as the first full-length independent digital feature to be screened in its original video format in commercial venues, where it succeeded on the strength of word-of-mouth publicity. This was a particularly significant achievement at a time when there was little in the way of a support system for independent films—it would not be until two years later, for instance, that the first edition of the Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival would be held—or, for that matter, digital films, as most theaters were not yet equipped with digital video projectors.  Written by Jaime Oscar M. Salazar

text:
1953 / Black and White / Fantasy / Direction: Gerardo de Leon / Story: Mars Ravelo (as serialized in Pilipino Komiks) / Screenplay: Pierre Salas / Cinematography: Emmanuel Rojas / Editing: Frank Estepa / Sound: Demetrio de Santos / Music: Tito Arevalo / Produced by Premiere Productions / Cast: Jaime de la Rosa (Fredo), Edna Luna (Dyesebel), Carol Varga (Betty), Paquito Salcedo (Diangga), Fernando Royo, Etang Discher, Vicente Liwanag, Nello Nayo, Luis San Juan, Neonita Bona, Mary Williams, Max Alvarado, Lito Anzures, Jesus Lapid, and Isa Rifto

 

A pregnant mother who was obsessed with a mermaid’s calendar picture while she was conceiving gives birth to a baby girl with a fishtail instead of legs. The father tries to get rid of the freak child but is stopped by thunder and lightning. To escape the prying eyes of the townsfolk, the couple leaves the town with their daughter and resides in another place, a village by the sea.

 

 

The child with the fishtail is christened Dyesebel and kept away from the village folk. She spends most of her time in the water close to the shore. One day she strays farther out into the ocean and meets other mermaids. Delighted, she joins them in exploring the ocean depths. There she meets Diangga, a sea witch with magical powers who can transform mermaids into real, normal women complete with legs.

Dyesebel falls in love with Fredo, a young man vacationing at a beach resort, who is nursing a broken heart after being jilted by his girlfriend, Betty. With the help of Diangga’s magical powers, Dyesebel turns into a beautiful woman. But Betty discovers her secret and conspires with her ex-lover, Gildo, to kidnap Dyesebel and take her to a carnival fair to be displayed as a freak attraction. Fredo rescues Dyesebel after a thrilling chase. With the help of the sea witch, she is permanently transformed into a real, normal woman.

 

Dyesebel, the top moneymaker of 1953, was popular not only in the Philippines but all over Southeast Asia. In succeeding years, other versions of Dyesebel were made. Eva Montes starred in Anak ni Dyesebel (Dyesebel’s Daughter), 1964; Vilma Santos in Dyesebel, 1973; Alma Moreno in Dyesebel, 1978; Alice Dixson in Dyesebel, 1989; and Charlene Gonzales in Dyesebel, 1996. TV series have also featured the popular mermaid in the person of Marian Rivera in GMA Network’s Dyesebel, 2008, and Anne Curtis in ABS-CBN’s Dyesebel, 2014. Like Darna, Dyesebel is a komiks and film character that has become part and parcel of the Filipino’s cultural vocabulary.  Written by Lena S. Pareja, with notes from Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu
