text:
(Evolution of a Filipino Family) / 2004 / Black and White / Drama / 540 minutes / Direction, Screenplay, and Editing: Lav Diaz / Cinematography: Richard de Guzman, Larry Manda, Paul Tañedo, and Lav Diaz / Production Design: Patty Eustaquio, Jun Sabayton, and Rishab Tibon / Sound: Rafael “Bulan” Luna and Bob Macabenta / Produced by Paul Tañedo, Sine Olivia, and Ebolusyon Productions / Cast: Elryan de Vera (Raynaldo), Angie Ferro (Puring), Pen Medina (Kadyo), Marife Necesito (Hilda), Ronnie Lazaro (Fernando), Lui Manansala (Marya), Banaue Miclat (Huling), Sigrid Andrea Bernardo (Ana), Lorelie Futol (Martina), Angel Aquino (Rica), Roeder (Bendo), Rey Ventura (Ka Harim), Dido de la Paz (Dakila), Gino Dormiendo (Lino Brocka), and Joel Torre

 

The film covers the period from 1971, a year before the declaration of martial law, to 1987, a year after the EDSA Revolt that overthrew the Marcos regime, telling the poignant stories of two Filipino families. The title, however, may actually refer to the single unity that is the Filipino family, particularly as Diaz weaves in historical footage of key moments in the nation’s history throughout the film. The first family, the Gallardos, are peasant farmers in the lowlands of Luzon, headed by stoic matriarch Puring. The other is another humble family of wood gatherers in the mountainous Benguet Province, ruled by patriarch Fernando, who is obsessed with digging for gold in the mountains.

 

 

The character that ties the two families together is the boy Ray, who is not even a blood relative of either, having been abandoned as an infant by his birth mother on a trash pile in Manila and picked up by Hilda, a wandering, deranged woman. A deep bond forms between Hilda and the boy, whom she cares for despite her insanity. Hilda somehow manages to take Ray back to the rural farm, and he is accepted as a member of the family by Hilda’s mother Puring, widowed brother Kadyo, and Kadyo’s three daughters Huling, Ana, and Martina. They work as hired hands for harvests so that each one of the girls may obtain a college education. Hilda’s return to their home taints the family’s reputation, to the ire of Puring. Helpless and beautiful, Hilda falls prey to some drunkards who rape and then kill her. The film’s complexity is heightened not only by the sheer number of characters it follows and the extended period of time it covers, but also by the variety of footage it uses: 16 mm film, digital film, TV footage, documentary format, and fiction. photos.desc:
Ina Feleo and Jason Abalos in Endo, 2007

(Photo courtesy of Jade Castro)

text:
(Love on a Budget) / 2007 / Color / Drama / 96 minutes / Direction: Jade Francis Castro / Story and Screenplay: Jade Francis Castro with Michiko Yamamoto and Raymond Lee / Cinematography: Wowie Hao / Editing: J. D. Domingo / Production Design: Jeck Cogama / Sound Design: Corrine de San Jose / Music: Owel Alvaro / Produced by Cinemalaya Foundation and UFO Pictures / Cast: Jason Abalos (Leo), Ina Feleo (Tanya), C. J. Javarata (Candy), Ricky Davao, Andrew Torres, Alcris Galura, and Tess Jamias

 

 

Leo, a contractual employee, works in a fast-food joint. He is taking care of his ailing father and younger brother who turns out to have dropped out of school. He has issues about being left behind because his mother abandoned him and his family when he was still young. He buys a pair of shoes for the “endo” (end of contract or last day of work) of Candy, his co-worker and girlfriend. Unfortunately, Candy dumps him on her “endo.” The breakup has affected his work: he snaps at an irritating customer and gets fired in the process. He finds himself working in the mall where he bought the pair of shoes. He and the saleslady Tanya, who sold him Candy’s shoes, eventually become lovers.

 

Career-driven and hardworking, Tanya is a positive presence in Leo’s life; she helps him apply for jobs, pushes him to dream, and fixes his life as she has fixed his defective CD player. They both apply for a job in a hotel; only Tanya gets accepted. Leo ends up as a merchandiser in a grocery. She convinces him to undergo maritime hospitality training, but he refuses, to her disappointment. She finally gets accepted for maritime work, and when she breaks the good news, he unwittingly takes it negatively because he will be left behind. The couple takes a break from each other, and Leo goes back to Candy who still has feelings for him. Tanya is left alone to deal with fears of unwanted pregnancy, and just when Leo has realized he loves Tanya more than Candy, she discovers Leo’s infidelity. Leo returns to Tanya, declares his love for her, begs on his knees to make her stay, and even proposes to marry her. But Tanya has already made her choice. Before she leaves, Leo pays her a visit just to say he loves her even if she is leaving him. The film ends with Leo, single, but not quite heartbroken—for he has come to terms with being left behind, for Tanya has changed his life.

 

Endo is the first digital indie film to explore the lives of contractual employees in the country. It won Best Actress (Feleo) and the Special Jury Prize in the 2007 Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival; Best Actor (Abalos) and Best Screenplay in the 2008 Gawad Urian; Best Performance (Abalos), Best Editing, and Best Achievement in Sound and Aural Orchestration in the Young Critics Circle Film Desk Citations for 2007.  Written by Ronald Baytan

Fernando Poe Jr in Eseng ng Tondo, 1997

(Photo courtesy of FPJ Productions)

text:
(Eseng of Tondo) / 1997 / Color / Action / 113 minutes / Direction: Ronwaldo Reyes (aka Fernando Poe Jr) and Augusto Salvador / Screenplay: Pablo S. Gomez and Manny Buising / Cinematography: Ver Reyes / Editing: Augusto Salvador / Production Design: Ben Payumo / Sound: Ramon Reyes / Music: Jimmy Fabregas / Original Theme Song: Pablo Vergara / Produced by FPJ Productions / Cast: Fernando Poe Jr (Eseng), Ina Raymundo (Elvie), Jenny Syquia (Digna), Chuck Perez, Mandy Ochoa, Bob Soler, Zandro Zamora, Anita Linda, Marita Zobel, Bing Davao, Eddie Arenas, Jose Romulo, Tony Carreon, Johnny Vicar, and Romy Diaz

 

 

Eseng ng Tondo is an action film inspired by true events. It follows the story of the sharpshooting policeman Eseng, and how he straddles domestic family life and the hazards of police work. His jealous wife, the teacher Digna, cannot take his closeness with other women, which seems to come with his profession—especially his relationship with Elvie, the street-smart bar singer and informer who falls in love with Eseng. Eseng is engaged in busting various crimes in the city. He is determined to find out who is at the bottom of a series of kidnapping, rapes, and murders in the “university belt” of Manila. His mission becomes urgent when the gang of criminals kidnaps Digna. Fortunately, he is able to save her before any harm could befall her. After some sleuthing, Eseng learns the identities of the gang members and serendipitously catches them. Eseng is also determined to run after a big crime syndicate engaged in the trafficking of illegal drugs. The syndicate hires an assassin, who organizes a team to hunt down the policeman. The film concludes with a shoot-out. Eseng, with the help of Elvie, is able to take down the criminals. The final scene shows Eseng coming home at the end of the day, his wife waiting for him.

 

Eseng ng Tondo won Best Picture, Best Director, Best Actor (Poe), Best Editing, and Best Production Design in the 1998 Film Academy of the Philippines Awards.  Written by Patrick Campos

photos.desc:
Kris Aquino in The Fatima Buen Story, 1994

(Mario A. Hernando Collection)

text:
1994 / Color / Drama / 105 minutes / Direction: Mario O’Hara / Screenplay: Frank Rivera / Cinematography: Johnny Araojo and Romulo Araojo / Editing: George Jarlego / Production Design: Benjie De Guzman / Art Direction: Allan Balbuena and Joselito Bonus / Sound: Joe Climaco / Music: Nonong Buencamino / Produced by Regal Films / Cast: Kris Aquino (Fatima), Zoren Legaspi (Oscar), Janice de Belen (Batman), John Regala (Leslie), Gina Pareño, Perla Bautista, Leni Santos, Shintaro Valdez, and Naty Mallares

 

 

From petty mischiefs to teenage misbehaviors, Fatima always finds herself in trouble. Wanting to please her well-meaning mother (Bautista), Fatima decides to work in Malaysia as a guest relations officer where she meets Jake who gets her pregnant. The couple returns to the Philippines to get married, and they put up an illegal recruitment agency. When authorities investigate the agency, Jake flies to Amsterdam, leaving his wife to take the fall. Fatima is imprisoned, and her son is left to the care of her mother-in-law. While awaiting her trial, Fatima gets involved in a love triangle with two jail guards, Leslie and Oscar. Together with her fellow inmate Batman, Fatima escapes from prison only to meet up with Oscar. But Leslie is able to catch up with them and gets Fatima back in prison and Oscar suspended from his post.

 

Once in prison, Fatima, who by now is carrying Oscar’s child, is beaten up by some of the inmates and suffers a miscarriage. Fatima thinks that Oscar betrayed her and had her beaten up. Fueled by rage, Fatima escapes and looks for Oscar with the intention of killing him. She fails and ends up begging Oscar to take her back so they can start anew. Without committing to anything, Oscar leaves Fatima in search of Leslie whom he plans to murder as revenge for his suspension; but during the face-off, Leslie ends up killing Oscar. Fatima reunites with Batman who, after all this time, is still harboring feelings for Fatima. The two end up doing petty crimes until Fatima, tired of running from the law, tells Batman that she wants to surrender to the authorities. Enraged, Batman reveals that she had Fatima beaten up in jail because she was jealous of Fatima’s relationship with Leslie. As she is about to shoot Fatima, Batman is accidentally electrocuted. Fatima goes back to prison to serve her time and is reunited with Leslie.

 

Based on the life story of felon Fatima Buen, the movie won the Gawad Urian for Best Picture, Best Director, Best Supporting Actor (Regala), Best Screenplay, Best Cinematography, Best Editing, and Best Sound in 1995. It also won Best Achievement in Cinematography and Visual Design in the Young Critics Circle Film Desk Citations for 1994.  Written by Anne Frances Sangil

photos.desc:
Kris Aquino in Feng Shui, 2004

(Mario A. Hernando Collection)

text:
2004 / Color / Horror / Direction: Chito S. Roño / Story and Screenplay: Roy C. Iglesias and Chito S. Roño / Cinematography: Neil Daza / Editing: Vito Cajili / Production Design: Raymond Bajarias / Sound: Albert Michael Idioma / Music: Carmina Robles-Cuya / Visual Effects: Dodge Ledesma / Produced by Star Cinema / Cast: Kris Aquino (Joy Ramirez), Cherry Pie Picache (Lily), Joonee Gamboa (Hsui Liao), Luz Fernandez (Aling Biring), Jay Manalo, Lotlot de Leon, Ilonah Jean, John Manalo, Julianne Gomez, Nonie Buencamino, Jenny Miller, Daria Ramirez, Archie Adamos, Emil Sandoval, Mon Confiado, Jon Achaval, Hazel Espinosa, and Jenine Desiderio

 

 

Joy Ramirez is a wife and mother under much stress. Her family has recently moved into a new house, and she discovers her husband’s philandering. One day, she finds a bagua mirror in the bus. A neighbor, Aling Biring, tells Joy that this mirror can change her luck, so Joy hangs it in her house. True enough, Joy’s fortune begins to change. She gets a promotion, wins a raffle prize, and receives an inheritance from a stranger. But then, freakish deaths begin to occur around her, as if at the cost of her own good luck. Joy meets Lily, the previous owner of the bagua, who recounts similar experiences. Joy also consults with feng shui expert Hsui Liao, who reveals the family curse behind the bagua, that it is haunted by Lotus Feet, a Chinese woman who was burned to death, and that whoever stares into it will be killed in a manner related to his or her Chinese zodiac animal birth sign. Meanwhile, Joy’s friends and family who have stared into the bagua scramble to save themselves, but they fail. Joy is instructed by Hsui Liao that she must refuse any more good luck and then break the bagua in order to break the curse, both of which she does. The deaths surrounding Joy stop, but it seems that the bagua cannot be destroyed and will wreak more havoc on other people.

Feng Shui was the first of Aquino’s and Roño’s string of local box-office hits in the horror genre. They would team up again for Sukob (Wedding Curse), 2006. Aquino subsequently starred in Dalaw (Visit), 2010, and Segunda Mano (Secondhand), 2011, and Roño directed Tenement 2, 2009, and The Healing, 2012. The film won Best Sound in the Film Academy of the Philippines Awards. It also won Best Editing in the 2005 Golden Screen Awards and Best Child Actor (John Manalo) and Best Child Actress (Gomez) in the 2005 Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Awards. Feng Shui was released in the midst of the worldwide popularity of “Asian Horror.”  Written by Patrick Campos

text:
(Subversion) / 1962 / Black and White / Drama / Direction: Gerardo de Leon / Story: Jose P. Rizal (based on his novel El Filibusterismo, 1891) / Screenplay: Gerardo de Leon, Adrian Cristobal, and Jose Flores Sibal / Cinematography: Mike Accion / Editing: Teofilo de Leon / Sound: Luis Reyes / Music: Tito Arevalo / Produced by Bayanihan/Arriva Films / Cast: Pancho Magalona (Simoun), Charito Solis (Juli), Editha Vital (Maria Clara), Oscar Keesee (Padre Camorra), Robert Arevalo (Basilio), Joseph de Cordova (Padre Florentino), Ben Perez (Kabesang Tales), Lourdes Medel (Paulita Gomez), Carlos Padilla Jr (Isagani), Paquito Diaz (Vicente), Jerry Pons (Juanito Pelaez), Monang Carvajal, Teody Belarmino, Ramon D’Salva, Paquito Salcedo, Dadang Ortega, Boy Francisco, Alfonso Carvajal, Jose Garcia, Nello Nayo, Francisco Cruz, Pianing Vidal, Andres Centenera, and Manny Ojeda

 

Simoun, the rich jeweler, is none other than Juan Crisostomo Ibarra in disguise. He has traveled around the world to amass wealth with which he intends to topple the corrupt and abusive regime in his native land. Simoun’s real motive is personal: to rescue his beloved Maria Clara from the convent and to avenge the death of his father. In a forest on Christmas Eve, Basilio discovers Simoun’s true identity, recognizing the stranger as the man who helped him bury his mother, Sisa, more than a decade ago. Simoun is in the forest to retrieve the gems buried under the tree near Sisa’s grave.

 

 

Basilio is a medical student engaged to Juli, the daughter of Kabesang Tales. Kabesang Tales is a law-abiding man who becomes impoverished after a Spanish priest grabs his land. To aggravate the situation, bandits kidnap Tales for ransom, forcing Juli to sell all her jewelry and work as a servant.

 

Simoun plots to incite a general uprising with the help of Basilio, the bandits, and citizens who have legitimate grievances against the Spanish friars and the colonial government. Hours before the uprising, Maria Clara dies in the convent. Kapitan Tiago, the adoptive father of Maria Clara, also dies, a victim of drugs. The uprising is aborted and the authorities imprison Basilio along with some students. Juli, who was earlier freed from slavery by Basilio, solicits the aid of Padre Camorra so that Basilio may be freed. The priest attempts to rape her. She jumps to her death from a convent window.

 

Simoun frees Basilio from prison and schemes to explode a bomb to spark anarchy and revolt. The bomb is inside a lamp, which Simoun brings as his gift for Paulita and Juanito at their wedding party. The wedding feast is held at the house of Kapitan Tiago. Simoun leaves hurriedly before the bomb is set to explode. As Basilio prepares to flee from the imminent explosion, he sees his friend, Isagani, Paulita’s jilted lover, on the premises. Basilio warns Isagani about the bomb. Instead of running away, Isagani seizes the lamp and throws it into the river. Meanwhile, the wounded and dying Simoun, a fugitive from the law, has managed to drag himself to the house of Padre Florentino, a Filipino priest. Before he dies, he confesses his secrets to Padre Florentino. From a nearby cliff, the priest throws Simoun’s jewels—and the greed, violence, and other evils they could have spawned—into the sea.

 

El Filibusterismo garnered many Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences awards in 1963: Best Picture, Best Director, Best Story, Best Screenplay, Best Cinematography, Best Sound, and Best Musical Score.  Written by Rosalie Matilac

text:
(Florante and Laura) / 1939 / Black and White / Drama / Direction: Vicente Salumbides / Story: Francisco Baltazar (aka Balagtas) based on his metrical romance / Production Design: Richard Abelardo / Special Effects: Ben Resella / Produced by Salumbides Film Company Ltd / Cast: Carlos Padilla (Florante), Rogelio de la Rosa (Menandro), Lila Luna (Laura), Rosita Rivera (Flerida), Cesar Basa (Aladin), Nemesio Caravana (Adolfo), Vicente Salumbides, Fred Montilla, Manuel Barbeyto, Precioso Palma, Jose del Prado, and Jose Cris Soto

 

Prince Florante, son of the Duke Briseo of Albania, is taken prisoner by the usurper, Count Adolfo. He is tied to a tree in a forest and left to starve and die, exposed to wild beasts. A wandering Moor, Aladin, hears his cries and saves him from two fierce lions. Florante, who fainted when the lions attacked, regains consciousness and is surprised to find that the person who saved him is an enemy. But Aladin is kind to him and Florante is grateful, and they become fast friends. They tell each other their stories.

 

 

Florante left his victorious army in Etolia under the command of his friend, Menandro, because a letter from Albania urged him to come home at once. Upon his arrival, he was arrested by the treacherous Adolfo who had already seized the throne from King Linceo. Adolfo also had designs on Linceo’s daughter and Florante’s sweetheart, Laura. Aladin, on the other hand, was banished by his father, the ruler of Persia, who wanted Aladin’s sweetheart, Flerida, for himself.

Unknown to Florante and Aladin, their sweethearts are in another part of the forest. Flerida, disguised as a warrior, escaped from the sultan on her wedding night. Wandering in the forest, she comes upon Laura held captive by Adolfo. When Adolfo tries to rape Laura, Flerida kills him with her bow and arrow. The two women are finally reunited with their lovers. At this point, Menandro appears with his army and they hail the new king, Florante. Aladin and Flerida convert to Christianity and return to their own kingdom.

 

Florante at Laura was the first Filipino movie to combine poetry and visual effects. There were six poets in the cast and the dialogue consisted of 1,200 lines of poetry, about 400 of which were quoted directly from the literary classic. The set design recreated Albania’s walls, drawbridge, and palace with ingenious backdrops.  Written by Lena S. Pareja

text:
1995 / Color / Drama / 120 minutes / Direction: Joel Lamangan / Story: Efren Contemplacion / Screenplay: Bonifacio Ilagan and Ricardo Lee / Cinematography: Romeo Vitug / Editing: Joyce Bernal and Edgardo Vinarao / Production Design: Manny Morfe / Sound: Ramon Reyes / Music: Vehnee Saturno / Produced by Viva Films / Cast: Nora Aunor (Flor Contemplacion), Julio Diaz (Efren Contemplacion), Amy Austria (Delia Maga), Jaclyn Jose (Neneng), Ian de Leon (Sandrex Contemplacion), Vina Morales (Russel Contemplacion), Tony Mabesa, Caridad Sanchez, Gloria Sevilla, Charito Solis, Ronaldo Valdez, Rolando Tinio, and Rita Avila

 

 

Flor Contemplacion, a Filipino domestic helper in Singapore, is accused and convicted of the murder of a fellow Filipina maid named Delia Maga and the boy the latter was taking care of back in 1995. The news is received with a heavy heart by Contemplacion’s family back in the Philippines, and even by her husband who has been living with another woman for years now. The family is certain that Flor has been falsely accused of murder. To the last minute, the Philippine government and several local organizations try to appeal to the Singaporean authorities for a reopening of the case, if not clemency for Contemplacion, but to no avail. Contemplacion is put to death by hanging. But with her death, Contemplacion becomes a national symbol for millions of poverty-driven overseas Filipino workers who are forced to work abroad.

 

The film won the following international and local awards: the Golden Pyramid (Best Film) and the Princess Pataten Statue (Best Actress) for Aunor in the 1995 Cairo International Film Festival; Circle of Excellence (Aunor) and Best Musical Score in the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Awards; Best Actress, Best Director, and Best Supporting Actress (Jose) in the Gawad Urian; Best Picture, Best Director, Best Actress, Best Adapted Screenplay, Best Supporting Actress, and Best Sound in the Film Academy of the Philippines Awards; and Best Performance (Aunor) and Best Achievement in Cinematography and Visual Design in the Young Critics Circle Film Desk Citations. The film was also exhibited in several international film festivals, including the 1995 Toronto International Film Festival, 1996 Minneapolis Pan Asian Film and Video Festival, 1996 Fukuoka International Film Festival, 1996 Hawaii International Film Festival, the 1996 Dublin Film Festival, the 1996 Pusan International Film Festival, and the 1996 Human Rights Watch International Film Festival in New York.  Written by Anne Frances Sangil

text:
2007 / Color / Drama / 98 minutes / Direction: Brillante Mendoza / Story and Screenplay: Ralston Jover / Cinematography: Odyssey Flores / Editing: Charliebebs Gohetia / Production Design: Benjamin Padero / Sound: Emmanuel Clemente / Music: Jerrold Tarog / Produced by Center Stage Production and Seiko Films / Cast: Cherry Pie Picache (Thelma), Kier Segundo (John-John), Eugene Domingo, Jiro Manio, Alwyn Uytingco, and Dan Alvaro

 

 

Foster Child follows the last day of the titular character John-John with his foster family before he is turned over to his adopting American parents. While John-John is the film’s central figure, Foster Child shines a spotlight on foster mother Thelma and her family, who has spent three years raising the asthmatic kid to be healthy and ready for formal adoption. Despite receiving compensation as a foster parent, Thelma doesn’t see taking care of abandoned children as a job. From bathing John-John to dressing him up, feeding him, and sending him to school, Thelma becomes a doting mother through and through, treating every foster child assigned to her as her own. For eight years, Thelma has been a foster parent to several children and a consistent awardee of the center that hired her. Nevertheless, she still feels the pain and anxiety of turning over a child to the new adopting family.

 

Shot in documentary style, the film utilizes a number of long takes and handheld camera techniques that mostly follow the characters from behind. The shaky camera movement comes to represent the instability of Thelma’s emotions throughout the day. Mendoza’s fourth full-length feature film, Foster Child was exhibited at the Directors’ Fortnight in Cannes, and the New Directors, New Films in New York. It also competed at the Cinema Novo Film Festival. It received the Special Jury Award in the 4th Eurasia International Film Festival, the Signis Award in the 9th Palmas de Gran Canaria Film Festival, and the prize for fiction at the 2007 International Environmental Film Festival. The Young Critics Circle Film Desk awarded Foster Child Best Film and Best Screenplay. It also won Best Picture and Best Actress (Picache) in the Durban International Film Festival. The Osian’s Cinefan Film Festival and Gawad Urian also bestowed Best Actress honors on Picache, while the Filipino Academy for Movie Arts and Sciences awarded Segundo Best Child Actor.  Written by Michael Kho Lim

article_title: Ganito Kami Noon... Paano Kayo Ngayon?

photos.desc:
Gloria Diaz, Dranreb Belleza, and Christopher de Leon in Ganito Kami Noon... Paano Kayo Ngayon?, 1976
 (Joey Romero Collection)

text:
(This Was How We Were … What Happens to You Now?) / 1976 / Color / Drama / 136 minutes / Direction: Eddie Romero / Screenplay: Eddie Romero and Roy Iglesias / Cinematography: Justo Paulino / Editing: Ben Barcelon / Production Design: Laida Lim-Perez and Peque Gallaga / Sound: Demetrio de Santos / Music: Lutgardo Labad / Produced by Hemisphere Pictures Inc / Cast: Christopher de Leon (Kulas), Gloria Diaz (Diding), Eddie Garcia (Don Tibor), Dranreb (Bindoy), Tsing Tong-Tsai (Lim), Leopoldo Salcedo, Rosemarie Gil, E. A. Rocha, and Johnny Vicar

 

The film narrates the adventures and misadventures of a naive peasant boy, Kulas, who wanders through the Philippine Revolution of 1896-98 and the Philippine-American War of 1899-1901. The events serve as catalysts for Kulas to come to a realization about his identity as a man and as a Filipino.

 

 

The hut that Kulas calls home burns down as a result of his negligence. Forced to leave the farm to look for temporary shelter, he encounters a priest fleeing a band of thieves. They get acquainted and the priest begs Kulas to take his illegitimate son Bindoy to Manila. On their way to the city, Kulas and the boy meet a traveling theater troupe. Kulas falls in love with the lead, Diding. But he is not given the chance to declare his love as he must proceed to the city with the boy and the troupe has to move on.

 

With the boy in tow, Kulas reaches Manila by boat. Lim, a Chinese merchant he meets on board, guides him through the city. Kulas is at a loss after escorting the boy to his destination, until he encounters Diding again, who is now married to a Spanish mestizo, Don Tibor.

 

Another misfortune befalls Kulas when Spanish soldiers mistake him for a rebel. He is incarcerated but escapes with the help of a fellow prisoner, a revolutionary, just before he is to be executed. Meanwhile, Manila is in chaos because of the arrival of the Americans. The Spanish regime falls, and Kulas decides to see Diding for the last time. After a brief encounter with the woman, Kulas leaves in pursuit of his future and his identity as a Filipino.

 

Ganito addresses the question of Filipino identity at the time of the wars against Spain and against America. The film won the Gawad Urian for Best Picture, Best Director, Best Screenplay, and Best Production Design, and the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences awards for Best Actor (de Leon), Best Supporting Actor (Salcedo), and Best Music. It was adjudged one of the 10 Best Films of the Decade 1970-79 by the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino. In 2014, the ABS-CBN Archives and Central Digital Lab showed the digitally restored version of the film on Cinema One.  Written by Luna Sicat, with notes from Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

text:
1950 / Black and White / Action / 88 minutes / Direction: Manuel Conde and Lou Salvador Sr / Story and Screenplay: Manuel Urbano (aka Manuel Conde) / Cinematography: Emmanuel Rojas / Editing: Rex Heinze / Production Design: Carlos V. Francisco / Sound: Flaviano Villareal / Music: Juan Silos Jr / Produced by Manuel Conde Productions / Cast: Manuel Conde (Temujin), Elvira Reyes (Princess Lei Hai), Lou Salvador Sr (Burchou), Andres Centenera, Darmo von Fraser Acosta, Jose Villafranca, Inday Jalandoni, Ric Bustamante, Africa de la Rosa, and Juan Monteiro

 

In a test of strength to see which tribe gets the right to a water hole, Temujin, a Mongol tribesman, wins by ruse and daring. At the height of the celebration, a rival tribe headed by the cruel Burchou raids Temujin’s village, killing his father. Temujin himself is captured by another rival chief. Facing possible death, Temujin is freed by a sympathetic character and returns to his village only to find it sacked and his father dead. He assembles a force and attacks Burchou’s stronghold to avenge his father’s death. He captures the chieftain’s daughter, Princess Lei Hai, and forces her to work as a servant. Meanwhile, while Genghis is away, Burchou is attacked by another tribe and he is held prisoner. His captor wants Burchou’s princess daughter for a wife, but Temujin shows up in time to save the girl, win her favor, and triumph over his foes.

 

Genghis Khan brought the Filipino film to the attention of the European film community. It was shown at the 1952 Venice International Film Festival and the 1952 Edinburgh International Film Festival where it earned good reviews. Critics have noted the film’s impressive production design and mise-en-scène. United Artists distributed the film worldwide. In 2012, the American version of Genghis Khan with English narration by James Agee was digitally restored in high definition by L’Immagine Ritrovata using the prints found in Italy, France, and the United Kingdom, with funding from the Film Development Council of the Philippines.  Written by Ramon Jocson and Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

(Mowelfund Film Institute Collection)

text:
(Geron the Vagabond) / 1964 /  Black and White / Action, Drama / 140 minutes / Direction: Cesar Gallardo / Screenplay: Augusto Buenaventura / Cinematography: Arsenio Dona / Editing: Augusto Salvador / Sound: Demetrio de Santos / Produced by Emar Pictures / Cast: Joseph Estrada (Geron), Oscar Roncal (Digno), Bebong Osorio (Beto), Imelda Ilanan (Nena), Vic Andaya, Avel Morado, Angel Buenaventura, Angel Confiado, Larry Silva, Lenny Trinidad, and Bong Alvarez

Geron is a young laborer in Quiapo. Strong and brawny, he is a friend and protector of market vendors, stall owners, jeepney drivers, and other poor, humble folk victimized by tong (protection money) collectors. The most notorious of these crooks call themselves the “Quiapo Gang.”

 

 

An old meat vendor is harassed for refusing to pay up. His grandson, Beto, runs to Geron for help. Geron rushes to the scene and thrashes the gang members, but it is too late to save the old man’s life. With no place to go, Beto comes to live with Geron as his buddy and sidekick. Through Beto, Geron meets and falls in love with Nena. The pretty daughter of a laundrywoman and an American GI, she sells sampaguita flowers in Quiapo. Nena’s mother hopes to marry her off to a rich man or even to an old widower like Mr Lopez, who is courting Nena. But Nena loves Geron and, whenever she has the chance, meets him furtively with the help of Beto.

Trouble enters in the person of Digno, who exploits Geron’s pity for him when he is beaten up by the Quiapo Gang. Digno comes from Sampaloc and, unknown to Geron, has been collecting tong using Geron’s name. When Geron discovers this, Digno runs off to join the Quiapo Gang.

An underworld character, Murillo, tries to rape Nena. Geron and Beto arrive in time to rescue her. Murillo escapes and is later found dead. The blame falls on Geron, and the police launch a massive search for him. At the same time, Digno is ordered by the Quiapo Gang to get rid of Geron. In the ensuing chase scene, Geron is caught between the underworld characters and the long arm of the law, in the Quiapo underpass. But Digno has a change of heart and shouts a warning to save Geron’s life.

Geron Busabos established the character of what would later on be the archetype of the Filipino action hero: a champion of the masses, an essentially peaceful person who is drawn to the fight against violent forces as defender of the weak and the oppressed. The film won the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences awards for Best Picture, Best Screenplay, and Best Actor (Estrada).  Written by Lena S. Pareja

text:
(My Love) / 1939 / Black and White / Drama, Musical / Direction, Story, and Screenplay: Carlos Vander Tolosa / Cinematography: Remigio Young / Editing: Nario Rosales / Sound: Julio Hidalgo / Music: Juan Silos Jr and Ariston Avelino / Choreography: Manalo Rosado / Produced by LVN Pictures / Cast: Fernando Poe (Jose), Ely Ramos (Antonio), Mila del Sol (Guia), Fleur de Lis (Rosie), Ben Rubio (Takio), Precioso Palma (Don Alvaro), Cecilio Joaquin (Mang Juan), Vita Ortega (Doña Lucia), Nieves Obieta (Atang), and the SSS Trio

Guia, the adopted daughter of Don Alvaro and Doña Lucia, is the most sought-after woman in town because of her beauty and sweet singing voice. Her ardent suitors are Jose, a tenant, and Takio, Don Alvaro’s overseer. Don Alvaro’s son, Antonio, comes to take his disabled mother to Manila. During a tenants’ serenade for Antonio, Guia sings “Tunay na Tunay,” which so impresses Antonio that he persuades her to try her luck as a singer in Manila. Guia falls for the debonair Antonio, a radio broadcaster, and in Manila he becomes her manager. He teaches her English hit songs like “I’m So in Love with You.” But she is dismayed to discover that Antonio is engaged to be married to Rosie.

 

 

Meanwhile, the cocksure Takio uses hacienda funds to build a house for Guia and himself. The anomaly is reported to Don Alvaro by Atang, the housemaid who is attracted to Jose. Atang squeals on Takio to please Don Alvaro and thus help Jose get promoted to the role of overseer.

Back in Manila, Guia is introduced during her maiden radio performance as the “Madonna of the Airlanes.” Hurt by Antonio’s engagement to Rosie, she defies him by singing the native “Tunay na Tunay” instead of the foreign “I’m So in Love with You” on the air. As she sings the Tagalog song, she slowly realizes that it is Jose whom she has really loved all along.

Don Alvaro fires Takio and appoints Jose as hacienda manager. Believing that Jose is to blame for his dismissal, Takio tries to kill him but is stopped by Mang Juan, Jose’s blind father. Takio is imprisoned for wounding the old man, but Jose forgives him. Jose and Guia marry. Their fiesta-like wedding reception is attended by newlyweds Antonio and Rosie. Don Alvaro urges Antonio to promote Filipino music by taking Mang Juan and his bamboo orchestra to Manila. Takio and Atang find themselves in each other’s arms. Thus the story ends happily for all tried-and-true lovers in this song-filled film romance.

Giliw Ko is LVN’s very first production. It affirmed Mila del Sol’s place in the industry and established LVN’s tradition of extravagant musicals. It is one of five pre-World War II films that have survived the war and studio fires. The other four are Zamboanga (Fury in Paradise), 1937, Tunay na Ina (Real Mother), 1939, Pakiusap (Plea), 1940, and Ibong Adarna (Adarna Bird), 1941.  Written by Rosalie Matilac

Back in Manila, Guia is introduced during her maiden radio performance as the “Madonna of the Airlanes.” Hurt by Antonio’s engagement to Rosie, she defies him by singing the native “Tunay na Tunay” instead of the foreign “I’m So in Love with You” on the air. As she sings the Tagalog song, she slowly realizes that it is Jose whom she has really loved all along.

Don Alvaro fires Takio and appoints Jose as hacienda manager. Believing that Jose is to blame for his dismissal, Takio tries to kill him but is stopped by Mang Juan, Jose’s blind father. Takio is imprisoned for wounding the old man, but Jose forgives him. Jose and Guia marry. Their fiesta-like wedding reception is attended by newlyweds Antonio and Rosie. Don Alvaro urges Antonio to promote Filipino music by taking Mang Juan and his bamboo orchestra to Manila. Takio and Atang find themselves in each other’s arms. Thus the story ends happily for all tried-and-true lovers in this song-filled film romance.

Giliw Ko is LVN’s very first production. It affirmed Mila del Sol’s place in the industry and established LVN’s tradition of extravagant musicals. It is one of five pre-World War II films that have survived the war and studio fires. The other four are Zamboanga (Fury in Paradise), 1937, Tunay na Ina (Real Mother), 1939, Pakiusap (Plea), 1940, and Ibong Adarna (Adarna Bird), 1941.
Written by Rosalie Matilac

text:
2011 / Documentary / Color / 95 minutes / Direction: Michael Collins / Cinematography: Joshua Z. Weinstein / Editing: Eric Daniel Metzgar / Produced by Marty Syjuco and Creative Visions, in association with Thoughtful Robot Productions / Cast: Francisco “Paco” Larrañaga, Mimi Larrañaga Syjuco, Margarita González Larrañaga, Manuel Larrañaga, Imanol Larrañaga, Thelma Chiong, Dionisio Chiong, Cheryl Jimenea, Marijoy Chiong, Jacqueline Chiong, Pablo Labra, Napoleon Estilles, Florencio Villarin, Teresita Galanida, Judge Martin Ocampo, Mike Armovit, Sandra Coronel, Sarah de Mas, Leo Lastimosa, Suzzane Salva, Teddy Locsin Jr, Ricardo “Dong” Puno, Solita “Winnie” Monsod, and Lucia Gomez

This documentary focuses on one of the most sensational (and sensationalized) crimes in the country: the 1997 kidnapping, rape, and slaying of the Chiong sisters, Marijoy and Jacqueline Chiong. The Chinese-Filipino siblings, who were in their early 20s, were waiting for their ride home at Ayala Center in Cebu when six men forcibly dragged them inside a vehicle and took them to Guadalupe, a nearby town. Days later, Marijoy’s remains were recovered down a ravine in Carcar, Cebu. Jacqueline’s body, however, is still missing to this day.

Spurred by an outraged public, authorities hastily arrested eight men, some of them belonging to Cebu’s most illustrious families. The media focused its attention on Francisco “Paco” Larrañaga, who was then a 19-year-old culinary arts student in Manila. With his brawny physique, record of petty misdeeds, and connection to the Osmeña political clan, the Spanish mestizo was perfect for a role he didn’t sign up for: an unrepentant hoodlum using his privilege to literally get away with murder.

Give Up Tomorrow presents Larrañaga’s side of the story, and viewers learn early on that producer Marty Syjuco is a relative—a necessary disclosure. While accusations of bias seem inevitable, Give Up Tomorrow relies on documentary evidence, personal testimonies, and archival footage to prove its points. As a result, it cobbles together a convincing, disquieting picture of how Larrañaga, despite his obvious advantages, became a victim of an incredibly corrupt political system and a whipping boy of crumbling social institutions.

On 3 Feb 2004, the so-called Chiong Seven were convicted of murder and sentenced to death by lethal injection. In 2006, however, capital punishment was abolished, so their sentences were commuted to life imprisonment. By 2009, Larrañaga was housed in a Spanish jail, a move made possible under the Treaty on the Transfer of Sentenced Persons, which both the Philippines and Spain signed. Larrañaga, who holds dual Filipino and Spanish citizenship, was eligible to benefit from the agreement. Of course, what was a small triumph for the Larrañagas was a major blow for the Chiongs.

More than an exposé on how the carriage of justice can go awry, the film is a tale of families valiantly carrying on despite their unbearable losses. Margarita González Larrañaga and Thelma Chiong are two mothers unafraid to take the cudgels for their children, spending over a decade trying to save or end the life of one man. So far, this crusade has yielded no clear victories, only ceaseless suffering.

Give Up Tomorrow won the Heineken Audience Award and Best New Documentary Director (Special Jury Mention) at the 2011 Tribeca Film Festival, Audience Award at the 2011 Sheffield Doc/Fest, Activism Jury Award at the 2011 Traverse City Film Festival, Audience Award at the 2011 Antenna Sydney Film Festival, Audience Award at the 2011 Valencia Human Rights Film Festival, Best Documentary at the 2011 Anchorage International Film Festival, Human Rights Award at the 2011 Docs Barcelona Film Festival, Editing Award at the 2012 Salem Film Festival, Audience Award at the 2012 The Hague Movies That Matter Festival, Audience Award at the 2012 San Sebastian Human Rights Festival, Human Rights Award and Audience Award at the 2012 Los Angeles Asian Pacific Festival, Human Rights Award at the 2012 Galway Film Fleadh, and Special Jury Award at the 2012 DMZ Korean Film Festival. In addition, it was nominated for Outstanding Investigative Journalism, Long Form category, at the 34th Annual News and Documentary Emmy Awards.  Written by Eileen Ang

text:
2012 / Color / Crime Drama-Thriller / 84 minutes / Direction and Screenplay: Ron Morales / Cinematography: Sung Rae Cho / Editing: James Lesage, Jorge Olortegui, and Ron Morales / Produced by Imprint Pictures / Cast: Arnold Reyes (Marlon Villar), Menggie Cobarrubias (Manuel Chango), Dido de la Paz (Detective Ramos), Leon Miguel (Visel), Ella Guevara (Elvie), Marife Necesito (Marcy Chango), Patricia Ona Gayod (Sophia), Angie Ferro, and Archie Adamos

An intense crime drama-thriller, Graceland explores the underbelly of Manila’s squalid underclass with an unflinching eye for the grimiest details. The film, which is the second feature from Filipino-American writer-director Ron Morales, centers on Marlon Villar, the long-suffering family chauffeur/man Friday to Manuel Chango, an unscrupulous congressman. With a seriously ill wife needing an organ transplant, Marlon hangs on to his job, even as it makes him an unwitting accomplice to Chango’s sordid activities, particularly his favorite vice—bedding underage girls.

Chango’s pedophilia is especially repugnant, given that he has a young daughter, Sophia, who becomes fast friends with Marlon’s own child, Elvie. Despite their different stations in life, the girls’ fates become intertwined when Marlon finds himself in an impossible bind. While driving them home from school one day, Marlon is stopped by an armed ruffian disguised as a cop who wants to take Sophia for ransom. Fearing for their lives, Marlon obeys the thug’s instruction and drives to a remote location. But things go terribly wrong, with Marlon suffering a nasty beating that knocks him unconscious. When he comes to, he realizes that Elvie has been seized as well.

Marlon gets a phone call from the abductor, instructing him to tell his boss to cough up a huge amount for the safe return of Sophia. To ensure Marlon’s cooperation, Elvie will remain his captive. Marlon has no choice except to do as he is told, even as Chango and a seedy policeman, Detective Ramos, relentlessly pressure him into admitting that he colluded in the crime to get some of the ransom.

To save Elvie, Marlon must navigate murky moral waters as he helps Chango meet the kidnapper’s demands while dodging Ramos’s relentless attempts to tag him as a suspect. As he finds himself caught up in events totally out of his control, Marlon quickly realizes one thing: in the bleak world he lives in, no one remains untainted by deceit and betrayal.

Graceland won the Jury Award for Best Narrative Feature at the 2012 San Diego Asian Film Festival. It also placed second in the Audience Award category for feature films at the 2012 Tribeca Film Festival in New York. In addition, it was nominated for Best Film at the 2012 Ghent International Film Festival in Belgium.  Written by Eileen Ang

text:
(Dirty Affair) / 1990 / Color / Drama / 120 minutes / Direction: Lino Brocka / Screenplay: Ricardo Lee / Cinematography: Pedro Manding / Editing: George Jarlego / Production Design: Benjie de Guzman / Sound: Rolly Ruta / Music: Nonong Buencamino / Produced by Viva Films / Cast: Christopher de Leon (Levi), Dina Bonnevie (Rachel), Alan Paule (Jonathan), Eddie Garcia (Mayor Edmundo Guatlo), Charo Santos (Rowena), Bembol Roco (Falcon), William Lorenzo (Eric), Perla Bautista, Ernie Zarate, Anita Linda, Francis Magalona, Timothy Diwa, Ray Ventura, Tess Dumpit, Fred Capulong, Jimmy Reyes, Rikki Jimenez, Benjie Ledesma, Archie Adamos, Boy Roque, Manny Mendoza, Tom Alvarez, Richard Peralta, Chito Bahasa, Larry Matic, Jojo Caidic, Fredmoore de los Santos, Victor Alba Jr, Ana Adama, and Alvin John

Jonathan dreams of becoming a pilot and hopes that by joining Eric’s gang, he would find someone to pay for his studies. His mother, a caterer of take-out meals, is not happy about his affiliation, as she feels he is treated like a servant by the rich kids.

 

 

Jonathan’s rich companions introduce him to starlets and take him to parties. One night in a disco, he sees the former star Rachel, drunk and dancing alone. Rachel is the mistress of the powerful mayor, Edmundo Guatlo, who supports her and her family. Edmundo is a jealous man and wants her to stop appearing in movies. He has his sidekick, Falcon, follow her wherever she goes. Outside the disco, Rachel’s date is beaten up by Falcon’s men. Jonathan helps Rachel get away. This is the beginning of a warm relationship.

It is election time. Edmundo’s wife wants him to get rid of his mistress and to project a morally upright image. Edmundo tells Rachel to lie low. Rachel agrees in exchange for the release of her boyfriend, Levi, who has been in jail for several years.

Levi is released but Edmundo has other plans. He wants Levy killed. With the help of Jonathan, Rachel and Levi escape from Edmundo’s men. However, Rachel’s parents are held as hostages. In trying to rescue them, Levi is shot and killed.

Rachel resolves to outsmart Edmundo. She makes a tape recording of their conversation, which finally unmasks him. At a political rally, Rachel manages to have the tape played over the sound system. In the ensuing bedlam, Rachel is shot by Falcon. She succeeds, however, in exposing the corrupt politician.

Gumapang Ka sa Lusak won Best Picture in the Gawad Urian, the Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP) Awards, and the Catholic Mass Media Awards in 1991. It also won the Gawad Urian for Best Screenplay and the FAP awards for Best Director and Sound. It was the Philippine entry in the 1992 ASEAN Film Week.  Written by Lena S. Pareja

text:
(To the Ends of the Earth) / 1958 / Black and White / Drama / Direction: Gerardo de Leon / Screenplay: Cesar Amigo / Cinematography: Jose Pagsisihan / Editing: Fely Crisostomo / Sound: Flaviano Villareal / Music: Ariston Avelino / Produced by Pacific Motion Pictures / Cast: Pancho Magalona (Carding), Loretta de Lara (Conching), Ben Perez, Gil de Leon, Mona Fernandez, Mercy Guia, Martin Marfil, and Shirley Rodriguez

 

 

Carding, a farmer’s son, is prodded by his sister, Conching, to go after their father’s killers. He manages to kill all of the men he is hunting except the actual triggerman, who eludes pursuit. Pretending to be a friend of his victims, Carding joins an outlaw band. With the help of a camp follower who has fallen in love with him, Carding locates the triggerman he is after and exacts his revenge. In time, Carding gains notoriety as a most notorious and wanted criminal, the terror of his province.

Meanwhile, a police sergeant, Ben, who is the suitor of Conching, pleads with Carding’s family to make him surrender and give up his life of crime. Carding’s sweetheart, Neneng, follows him to his hideout and there marries him and bears him a son. But the infant dies, and when Carding’s brother, Miguel, also dies, Carding goes on a killing rampage. Inevitably, Carding and Ben meet face-to-face. Again, Ben asks him to surrender, but Carding responds by shooting him instead. Realizing how hopeless the situation has become for her brother, Conching picks up Ben’s rifle, aims it at Carding, and fires. In death, Carding’s right hand is seen tightly clutching a big crucifix.

Hanggang sa Dulo ng Daigdig won the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences awards for Best Picture, Best Director, Best Actor, Best Screenplay, Best Cinematography, and Best Editing in 1959.  Written by Hubert Adoreno

text:
(Serenade) / 2012 / Documentary / Color / 104 minutes / Direction: Benito Bautista / Screenplay: Benito Bautista and Florante Aguilar / Cinematography: Peggy Peralta / Editing: Chuck Gutierrez / Sound: Jason Galindez and Raffy Magsaysay / Music: Florante Aguilar / Produced by New Art Media, Pacific Ethnographic, and Wanderlustproject Films / Cast: Florante Aguilar, Celestino Aniel, Felipe Alonzo, and Romeo Bergunio

This is a documentary about the folk tradition in which a man enlists a group of friends to help him serenade a woman beneath her window, whether out of a simple wish to introduce himself in a mannerly fashion or, as is more commonly known, out of a desire to win the woman’s heart. The harana uses a repertoire of songs with guitar accompaniment. The film follows Filipino-American Florante Aguilar, a classically trained guitarist who returns to the Philippines 12 years after the death of his father. He journeys to the hinterlands of Luzon in search of skilled practitioners of the art form that has long faded away in popularity—the so-called master haranista or serenaders who are recognized as the best musicians in their respective towns whenever a harana needs to be staged. After traveling through Ilocos and Cavite, Aguilar finds three such men—a farmer, a fisherman, and a tricycle driver—and forms a singing group with them. The four then perform at various public venues, even helping a shy young man express his affections for his classmate. At the end of the film, Aguilar records an album with the haranistas.

Harana won Best Documentary at the 2013 Gawad Urian, the Audience Award for Documentary at the 2013 Center for Asian American Media Festival (formerly the San Francisco International Asian American Film Festival), the Harrah’s Rincon Audience Award at the 2013 Annual Spring Showcase of Pacific Arts Movement, the Golden Space Needle Award for Documentary (2nd runner-up) at the 2013 Seattle International Film Festival, Honorable Mention for Cinematography at the 2013 Los Angeles Asian Pacific Film Festival, the Audience Award at the 2013 New Filipino Cinema Festival in San Francisco, and the Audience Award for Documentary at the 2012 Hawaii International Film Festival. It has been shown in other international festivals, including Dubai International Film Festival.  Written by Jaime Oscar M. Salazar

text:
1979 / Color / Drama / Direction: Maryo J. de los Reyes / Story: Tom Adrales / Screenplay: Jake Tordesillas / Cinematography: Joe Batac Jr / Editing: Edgardo Vinarao / Production Design: Fiel Zabat / Music: Rudy Rivero / Produced by Agrix Films / Cast: Charo Santos (Chit), Liza Lorena (Lilibeth), Eddie Rodriguez (Lauro), Margie Braza (Debra), Azenith Briones, Betty Mendez, Soxie Topacio, Angie Ferro, Ike Lozada, and Roderick Paulate

Chit Pengson, a fresh graduate of the University of the Philippines, is appointed teacher-in-charge of the high school graduating class. During a celebration, a cranky old teacher carrying a cake trips on a string tied by some mischievous students. She blames the painful prank on Chit’s students. Chit takes offense, defending her students and daring their accuser to prove her charges. By taking the side of her young wards, she incurs the ire of her fellow teachers.

 

 

One faculty member who is friendly to Chit is Lauro Romero. In time, their friendship becomes the school scandal. Since Romero has been having difficulties with his socialite wife, Lilibeth, he is an easy target for those who resent his closeness to Chit. To compound matters, Romero’s daughter, Debra, is one of Chit’s students.

Things come to a head when parents complain about Chit’s alleged adulterous affair with Romero. Lilibeth confronts Chit and discovers that there is no basis for her suspicions. Chit loves her profession too much to fall for a married man. She tells Lilibeth that Lauro Romero loves his wife and was never unfaithful to her. In the end, Chit is forced to leave the school. The students graduate and moral values centered on the family are affirmed.

The film is significant for its engaging characterizations, its recreation of a particular period, and its intelligent mix of drama and comedy. High School Circa ’65 earned Gawad Urian nominations for Best Director, Best Supporting Actor (Paulate), Best Editing, and Best Production Design. It is one of the first significant films of Maryo J. de los Reyes.  Written by Lena S. Pareja

text:
(Above All) / 1955 / Black and White / Drama / Direction and Screenplay: Gregorio Fernandez / Story: Mario Mijares Lopez / Cinematography: Enrique Rosales / Editing: Enrique Jarlego / Sound: July P. Hidalgo / Music: Santiago Suarez, Restie Umali / Produced by LVN Pictures / Cast: Rogelio de la Rosa (Roberto), Emma Alegre (Rosa), Ike Jarlego Jr (Junior), Oscar Keesee (Roldan), Rosa Aguirre (Kumadre), Jose Corazon de Jesus Jr (Tacio), Vic Silayan (Totoy), Eddie Rodriguez (Gorio), Venchito Galvez (Indo), Ludy Carmona, Cynthia Gomez, Gerry de los Reyes, Melita Gutierrez, Natoy Catindig, and Sim Pajarillo

Roberto, a painter, comes from a rich family but is disinherited because of his marriage to Rosa. They have two children. Jobless and penniless, Roberto despairs of his inability to support his wife and children, who survive on the charity of their neighbors. Fortunately, an opportunity comes for him to work as a laborer in a chemical laboratory.

 

 

Roberto experiences a baptism by fire from his arrogant supervisor, Max. To win Max’s friendship, Roberto gives him a coveted necklace, which was Rosa’s gift to Roberto before they got married. Max asks Roberto to attend to an ailing relative in a distant province. During his absence, a fire breaks out in the laboratory, killing everyone. Rosa and the insurance company mistake the body of Max for Roberto’s because of the necklace. The insurance company awards 10 thousand pesos to the family. When Roberto finds out about the insurance payment, he decides to make the supreme sacrifice of remaining “dead” for the financial betterment of his family.

Roberto becomes a drifter, assuming various false names and secretly observing Rosa and the children from a distance. He learns from the newspapers that Rosa is about to marry their rich friend Mr. Roldan. The family is reunited during the Christmas season when the children see their father peeping through a window. Roberto tries to escape, but Rosa chases him and convinces him to return to them.

Higit sa Lahat won six Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences awards: Best Picture, Best Director, Best Actor (de la Rosa), Best Editing, Best Sound, and Best Story. At the Asian Film Festival held in Hong Kong in 1956, Fernandez and de la Rosa won the Golden Harvest awards for Best Director and Best Actor, respectively.  Written by Rosalie Matilac

text:
(The Disobedient Son) / 1922 / Black and White / Drama / Direction: Florentino Borromeo / Screenplay: Celestino Rodriguez / Cinematography: Prudencio Iriate / Produced by Max Borromeo / Cast: Buenaventura Rodriguez, Eulalia Hernandez, Jose Rosales, Isabelo Rosales, Epifania Teves, and Isabel Climaco

This story of a prodigal child was the first Cebuano full-length movie. The entire production staff was made up of Cebuano theater personnel. The film was shot in Mainit, Barili, Cebu.

Some scenes intended to elicit pathos in this sad plight of a homesick waif torn away from his family produced comic reactions instead when the movie projector ran in reverse. A woman going up the steps of the stairs was shown moving down backward while a tartanilla (horse-drawn vehicle) was also seen running backward. Dramatic moments in this silent film were acted out to the accompaniment of a comparsa (native string band) on stage during the screening of the film.

Of the original cast, two actresses continued in the movies: Hernandez, whose last film was probably Ang Bayan (The Country), 1970, an attempt to revive Cebuano movies, and Climaco, the child star who grew up to do a mother role in Garbosa, 1957.

The movie was well-received and shown a number of times. It was also, unfortunately, the last film venture of the producer and his group of theater personalities.  Written by Erlinda K. Alburo

text:
(Miracle) / 1982 / Color / Drama / 124 minutes / Direction: Ishmael Bernal / Story and Screenplay: Ricardo Lee / Cinematography: Sergio Lobo / Editing: Ike Jarlego Jr / Production Design: Raquel N. Villavicencio / Art Direction: Dennis Cid, Benjie Garcia, and Bing Fabregas / Sound: Vic Macamay / Music: Winston Raval / Produced by Experimental Cinema of the Philippines (ECP) / Cast: Nora Aunor (Elsa), Spanky Manikan (Orly), Laura Centeno (Chayong), Gigi Dueñas (Nimia), Ama Quiambao (Sepa), Vangie Labalan (Saling), Veronica Palileo (Mrs Alba), Cris Daluz (Igme), Ben Almeda, Aura Mijares, Ray Ventura, Crispin Medina, Lem Garcellano, Estela de Leon, Cesar Dimaculangan, Joel Lamangan, Joe Gruta, Tony Angeles, Richard Arellano, Mahatma Canda, Erwin Jacinto, Vicky Castillo, and Tommy Yap.

A quiet, nondescript town, Cupang, changes drastically after Elsa reveals her visions of the Virgin Mary and starts healing people. Cupang is instantly transformed into a bustling community as the sick and hopeless, pilgrims, and tourists flock to it to be healed. The townsfolk become entrepreneurs, selling anything and everything: religious articles, bottled holy water, bedspaces, even daughters.

Orly is a filmmaker who has cynical views about religion, but he comes to Cupang hoping to capture the miracle on film. Instead, he witnesses the rape of Elsa and her best friend Chayong. Chayong commits suicide and the shattered Elsa stops healing people. All town activities grind to a halt until the discovery of Elsa’s pregnancy, which coincides with the end of a long drought that the townsfolk believe to be a curse. They believe that Elsa’s pregnancy is another miracle and they come to her in droves once more. However, Elsa publicly denies the existence of miracles, and an assassin’s bullet kills her.

Ricardo Lee based his screenplay on an account of alleged apparitions of the Virgin on Cabra Island in 1967. In 1982, his screenplay won the top prize in the ECP scriptwriting contest. At the 1982 Metro Manila Film Festival, Himala won Best Picture, Best Director, Best Story, Best Cinematography, Best Production Design, Best Editing, Best Actress (Aunor), Best Supporting Actress (Dueñas), and Best Supporting Actor (Manikan). In 1983, it opened the Manila International Film Festival and competed at Berlin International Film Festival. It won the Bronze Hugo Award in the 1983 Chicago International Film Festival. The film was hailed by CNN as the Best Asia-Pacific Film of All Time during the 2008 Asia Pacific Screen Awards held in Australia. It bested other entries like The Seven Samurai from Japan, Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon from China, Pather Panchali from India, and Gallipoli from Australia. In 2012, ABS-CBN and Central Digital Lab restored Himala in high definition. This restored version was shown in the 69th Venice International Film Festival, and was released in the Philippines in 2012. In the same year, Ricardo Lee published Sa Puso ng Himala (In the Heart of the Miracle), a coffee-table book that explores the making of the film.  Written by Menchie R. Tajan, with notes from Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

text:
(Manila Skies) / 2009 / Color / Drama / Direction, Screenplay, and Cinematography: Raymond Red / Editing: David Hukom, Jay Halili, and Raymond Red / Production Design: Danny Red / Design Consultants: Cesar Hernando and Ronald Red / Sound: Ditoy Aguila / Music: Diwa de Leon / Produced by Pelikula Red / Cast: Raul Arellano (Raul), John Arcilla (Crispin), Soliman Cruz (Tatang Juan), Karlo Altomonte (Karlo), Raul Morit (Morit), Ronnie Lazaro, Sue Prado, Pen Medina, Nonie Buencamino, Archie Adamos, Nanding Josef, Lav Diaz, Tony Mabesa, and Mon Confiado

 

 

Inspired by a true event, Himpapawid focuses on Raul, a menial worker in Manila who wants to go home to the province to be with his sick father. However, he has no means to return. Out of luck in his attempt to find a job overseas, he gets embroiled in arobbery with a gangof amateurs, Crispin, Tatang Juan, Karlo, and Morit, who plan to get back at the bogus recruiter who swindled them. The heist goes wrong, but Raul survives. He decides to hijack a plane. He robs the passengers of their money and jewelry and jumps off with a homemade parachute, but this time he does not survive. A poor farmer finds Raul’s body on a dirt road. He takes the bloodied stash and plans to use it to send his son to Manila, on the condition that the boy should never return to the poverty of the province.

 

Himpapawid was nominated forthe TokyoFilm Festival Sakura Grand Prix. It was screened at various festivals, including the International Film Festival Rotterdam,Vancouver International Film Festival, MontrealWorld Film Festival, HawaiiInternational Film Festival, and LondonFilm Festival of the British Film Institute. It won Best Drama Film, Best Direction, and Best Screenplay at the Movie and Television Review and Classification Board Film Awards; Best Cinematography, Best Supporting Actor (Cruz), and Best Supporting Actress (Prado) in the 2010 Gawad Urian; and five out of six awards in the Young Critics Circle Film Desk Citations for 2010—namely, Best Film, Best Screenplay, Best Achievement in Cinematography and Visual Design, Best Editing, and Best Performance (Arellano).  Written by Patrick Campos

text:
(Wrenched from Heaven) / 1985 / Color / Drama / Direction: Ishmael Bernal / Screenplay: Amado Lacuesta Jr / Cinematography: Rody Lacap / Editing: Jess Navarro / Production Design: Elmer Manapul / Sound: Rudy Baldovino / Music: Willy Cruz / Produced by Regal Films / Cast: Maricel Soriano (Carmen Castro), Charito Solis (Juling), Dante Rivero (Maning Sison), Al Tantay (Jerry), Amy Austria (Stella), Rowell Santiago (Bobby), Ray Ventura (David), and Marilou Diaz-Abaya

 

 

A young office employee, Carmen Castro, has an affair with a married man, Jerry, even if she has Bobby, a faithful suitor from Davao. She confides her problems to a friend, Stella. When she gets pregnant, both her lover and Stella advise her to have an abortion. Her landlady, Juling, a fanatical born-again Christian, advises her to let the child live. Carmen decides to have an abortion. Upon her return to the boarding house, she witnesses a succession of events: the murder of Juling by a slum-dweller whom she had evicted from her land, the nervous breakdown of Stella, and the departure of both her suitor and lover. Carmen emerges from these experiences wiser, stronger, and more resolute.

Hinugot sa Langit focuses on a subject that is taboo in Philippine society: abortion. It also deals with male chauvinism and religious hypocrisy, even as it depicts dismal economic conditions brought about by retrenchment, overseas employment, lack of urban housing, and the squatter problem. It won the Gawad Urian for Best Director, Best Production Design, and Best Editing.  Written by Lena S. Pareja

text:
(A Hero Stripped) / 1977 / Color / Drama / Direction: Robert Ylagan (aka Robert Arevalo) / Screenplay: Teloy Cosme and Robert Ylagan / Cinematography: Rudy Dina / Editing: Edgardo Vinarao / Production Design: Dez Bautista / Sound: Gregorio Ella and Rudy Baldovino / Music: Tito Arevalo / Produced by Rainbow Productions / Cast: Robert Arevalo (Ruben), Boots Anson-Roa(Luisa), Daria Ramirez (Pilar), Ray Marcos (Dario), Mervyn Samson (Don Sebastian), Fernando Fernandez, Ben Medina, Rustica Carpio, and Karim Kiram

The film revolves around the protagonist Ruben, a peasant who dreams of saving enough money to pay for the treatment of his sick mother, the education of his sister Pilar, and his own marriage to Luisa. Modest as his dreams are, however, he can never realize them, because he and his family become victims of economic exploitation and harassment.

Don Sebastian decides to convert his ricelands into sugar haciendas. Luisa’s father protests and is burned alive in his house by Don Sebastian’s son, Dario. To harass the peasants into giving up their lands, they are coerced into selling their palay to Don Sebastian after harvest, when the price is lowest. Furthermore, they are given crop loans, only at usurious rates. Ruben, like the other peasants, is forced to borrow more and more from his landlord, till he is buried in debt.

To lessen the family’s debts, Ruben allows his sister Pilar to serve in the landlord’s house. Dario rapes Pilar, and attempts to do the same to Luisa. To complete the tragedy, Ruben’s mother dies, and Ruben himself is mercilessly beaten to a pulp by Dario’s goons, when he tries to avenge Pilar’s honor.

Pushed against the wall and convinced of their weakness as individuals, Ruben, Luisa, and Pilar join the Colorums. Under the leadership of the Supremo, the Colorum peasants attack their landlords at the latter’s decadent baile (dance). The rebels capture the town’s armory, kill Don Sebastian, and take over the town. Victory is fleeting, however, for soon well-armed government troops, led by an American officer, arrive. Against Ruben’s rational advice, the Supremo attacks these troops with bolo and anting-anting (talisman). A massacre follows and the remaining Colorums limp their way to their church. Ruben and his men take away the body of the Supremo. The townspeople mistakenly believe that the Supremo has resurrected. Ruben disabuses their minds of such superstition—and all superstitions—convincing the mob that power grows out of unity and arms, and not out of miracles and talismans. As he speaks, government troops arrive, round up the rest of the Colorums, parade Ruben around town on a bullcart as a “huwad na bayani” (fake hero), and tie him to the same stone base where the Supremo’s corpse was exhibited. Ruben is mocked by the fickle mob. But once pardoned by the government, Ruben rises, talks to his fellow peasants, and then leads them into the sunrise of a new beginning.

Hubad is significant for its sympathetic but objective portrayal of peasant revolts, and its statement that social change can be effected not with anting-anting but by the unity of all peasants. In the 1978 Gawad Urian, it won Best Film, Best Screenplay, and Best Production Design, and was nominated for Best Director, Best Actor (Arevalo), Best Supporting Actress (Ramirez), Best Cinematography, and Best Editing.  Written by Nicanor G. Tiongson

text:
(Earth’s Whisper) / 2008 / Color / Drama / 107 minutes / Direction and Screenplay: Arnel Mardoquio / Cinematography: Edgardo Navarro / Editing: Arthur Ian L. Garcia / Production Design: Marie Contaoi / Sound: Patrick Seras / Music: Popong Landero / Produced by the Brothers of the Sacred Heart, Loradzen del Fierro Youth Foundation, and Sky Phoenix Production for the Brothers of the Sacred Heart Youth Ministry / Cast: Jaymar Generana (Makdung), Nelson Dino (Vigo Cruz), Joan Mae Soco (Faima), Marvin Mindog (Mustapa), Lucia Cijas (Buyag Inggan), Christine Lim (Amrayda), Popong Landero (Taok), and Mario Leofer Lim (Wahab)

 

Makdung is an 11-year-old Moro warrior from whose perspective the story of Hunghong sa Yuta is told. The story presents the situation of a people who have been continually devastated by war and how they have continually survived. The mountain community of Hinyok consists of Christians, Muslims, and lumads who live together but are always caught in the cross fire between the military and the armed rebels. Makdung is among many other children in Hinyok who are deaf and mute, and their fathers are set to train them, young as they are, to defend their land. This is the environment of war, in which an artist and toymaker from the city, Vigo Cruz, arrives to become a barrio teacher. With his alternative approach, he is able to teach not only the children but also their mothers, to read and do math. As such, Vigo is able to foster an alternative environment of peace and hope. But peace is soon broken when Taok, a man presumed to be a rebel leader, turns out to be a soldier spy. War is at hand again. Everyone including the women and children in the village are forced to fight. The ensuing battle reveals the consequences of a conflict that does not spare the lives of even good people, like Vigo, the tribal woman leader Buyag Inggan, the warrior Wahab, and the recalcitrant Amrayda.

Hunghong sa Yuta, produced in Davao, is expressly an advocacy project, part of a “mobile peace education campaign” of the Brothers of the Sacred Heart Youth Ministry. It won Best Music in the 2009 Gawad Urian.  Written by Patrick Campos

text:
(Never Forget Me) / 1960 / Black and White / Drama / Direction: Gerardo de Leon / Story: Jose F. Sibal / Screenplay: Gerardo de Leon and Jose F. Sibal Cinematography: Ricardo Marcelino / Editing: Gerardo de Leon and Vic Calub / Sound: Demetrio de Santos / Music: Tito Arevalo / Produced by Premiere Productions / Cast: Cesar Ramirez (Arturo), Cynthia Zamora (Elena), Aura Aurea (Lucila), Arsenia Francisco (Doña Consuelo), Oscar Keesee (Don Pedro), Ramon D’Salva (Leoncio), Robert Arevalo (Alfredo), Nello Nayo, Danilo Jurado, Dadang Ortega, Dina Morales, Max Alvarado, Jesus Lapid, and Domeng del Valle

 

Arturo and Alfredo are brothers. Arturo violates Alfredo’s trust by dishonoring the latter’s sweetheart, Lucila. Lucila tries to commit suicide but is thwarted. Arturo is estranged from his wife Elena and has taken to the bottle—he was under the influence of alcohol when he mistook Lucila for his wife. Despite Elena’s infidelity, Arturo continues to pine for her return to the marital abode. Meanwhile, Elena’s desire is to get her son away from Arturo. She plots with Leoncio, a nightclub operator, to kidnap the boy. In the process, the boy’s grandfather, Don Pedro, is killed. Arturo seeks police action to go after his father’s killer and son’s kidnapper. But his mother, Doña Consuelo, takes matters into her own hands. She confronts her former paramour to demand the release of her grandson. In the ensuing gun battle, Elena is caught in the cross fire. But the boy is saved and reunited with his father.

Huwag Mo Akong Limutin is one of the earliest films to delve seriously and realistically into questions of adultery and sexuality, subjects considered distasteful in the earlier decades. It encountered censorship problems because of its depiction of adultery and premarital sex. Specific scenes cut were the kissing scene between Cynthia Zamora and Cesar Ramirez and the suggestion of abortion. value.desc:
Cesar Ramirez and Cynthia Zamora in Huwag Mo Akong Limutin, 1960

(Cesar Hernando Collection)

article.value: Arturo and Alfredo are brothers. Arturo violates Alfredo’s trust by dishonoring the latter’s sweetheart, Lucila. Lucila tries to commit suicide but is thwarted. Arturo is estranged from his wife Elena and has taken to the bottle—he was under the influence of alcohol when he mistook Lucila for his wife. Despite Elena’s infidelity, Arturo continues to pine for her return to the marital abode. Meanwhile, Elena’s desire is to get her son away from Arturo. She plots with Leoncio, a nightclub operator, to kidnap the boy. In the process, the boy’s grandfather, Don Pedro, is killed. Arturo seeks police action to go after his father’s killer and son’s kidnapper. But his mother, Doña Consuelo, takes matters into her own hands. She confronts her former paramour to demand the release of her grandson. In the ensuing gun battle, Elena is caught in the cross fire. But the boy is saved and reunited with his father.

Huwag Mo Akong Limutin is one of the earliest films to delve seriously and realistically into questions of adultery and sexuality, subjects considered distasteful in the earlier decades. It encountered censorship problems because of its depiction of adultery and premarital sex. text:
(Adarna Bird) / 1941 / Black and White With Colored Sequences / Fantasy, Adventure / Direction: Vicente Salumbides and Manuel Conde / Screenplay: Vicente Salumbides / Cinematography: Remigio Young, Ray Lacap, and Vicente Salumbides / Editing: Enrique Jarlego / Production Design: Richard Abelardo / Sound: July Hidalgo / Music: Francisco Buencamino Sr and Francisco Buencamino Jr / Special Effects: Ben Resella / Produced by LVN Pictures / Cast: Mila del Sol (Maria), Fred Cortes (Juan), Ester Magalona (Leonora), Vicente Oliver (Diego), Deanna Prieto (Juana), Ben Rubio (Pedro), Cecilio Joaquin (King Fernando), Rosario Lam (Queen Valeriana), Miguel Anzures, Canuplin, Juan Rodriguez, Regio Villa, and Amador Alegre

In the kingdom of Berbania, the union of King Fernando and Queen Valeriana is blessed with three sons: Pedro, Diego, and Juan. One day, their idyllic existence is marred by a strange illness that afflicts the king. The only cure for his ailment is the song of the Ibong Adarna.

The three brothers set out, one after the other, to look for the bird. First to go is the eldest son, Pedro. After some time passes and he does not return, the second son, Diego, follows him but also fails to return. The queen becomes truly worried that some evil has befallen them and she is hesitant to let her youngest son, Juan, go. But he is insistent and, moreover, the king’s ailment has worsened.

Prince Juan discovers what has happened to his two brothers: they have been turned to stone by the excretion of the Adarna bird. It is Juan’s kindness to a leprous old man that makes him privy to the bird’s secret, which enables him to capture the bird and release his brothers from the spell. However, they are so ungrateful and envious of him that, in their desire to bring the bird home themselves, they beat up Juan and leave him for dead by the roadside. But Juan survives with the help of his friend, the old hermit, and he is able to surmount great odds not only in fulfilling his mission with the Adarna but also in rescuing from the underworld the princesses Leonora, Juana, and Maria.

When the Adarna is presented to the ailing king, it refuses to sing or exercise its curative powers unless Juan is present. Juan finally makes it back to the palace and the bird joyously breaks into song. Juan’s brothers are repentant and he forgives them. A triple wedding celebration is set in the kingdom for the princes and princesses: Diego and Juana, Pedro and Leonora, and Juan and Maria.

Ibong Adarna thrilled moviegoers with an exhibition of what Filipino ingenuity could do. For the first time, a Filipino movie used matte shots and background projections without synchronous motors. The scene of the bird bursting into full plumage was colored frame by frame. Ibong Adarna is one of five pre-World War II films (reduced to 16 mm) that have survived to the present.

Ibong Adarna pioneered in the successful translation of a literary classic to screen. Subsequent productions of this korido (metrical romance) include Manuel Conde’s Ang Ibong Adarna (The Adarna Bird), 1955, starring Nida Blanca, Nestor de Villa, Nita Javier, Cecilia Lopez, Jose Vergara, and Carlos Salazar, and Prinsipe Abante at ang Ibong Adarna (Prince Abante and the Adarna Bird), 1991, starring Rene Requiestas.  Written by Lena S. Pareja

text:
1954 / Color / Action, Drama / Direction: Gerardo de Leon / Story: Cornelio Hermoso (as serialized in Hiwaga Komiks) / Screenplay: Ding M. de Jesus and Cirio H. Santiago / Cinematography: Emmanuel Rojas / Produced by Premiere Productions / Cast: Efren Reyes (Lutab), Leila Morena (Immay), Juan Monteiro (Dr Artajo), Gloria Sevilla (Aniway), Fernando Royo (Sergeant Crow), Leticia Ojera (Elena), Leonora Ruiz (Kaweng), Jennings Sturgeon (Colonel MacPhimster), Mario Barri (Suyok), and Ric Bustamante

Early in the American occupation of the country, Colonel MacPhimster of the United States-trained Philippine Constabulary fails in his mission to conquer a defiant Ifugao tribe by benevolence. The rival leaders of the Ifugao tribe are Suyok and Lutab. The elders choose Lutab as their tribal chief. He becomes a legendary figure as he leads his people in fierce battles against the constabulary.

 

A Christian doctor, Serafin Artajo, and his sister Elena come to the aid of Colonel MacPhimster. They are no strangers to the tribal folk among whom they have worked. In negotiating with the Ifugao rebels, Artajo is helped by Apo Tabuk, a village elder whom the doctor once saved from a deadly disease. Dr Artajo succeeds in convincing Lutab that the Americans have good intentions. This view is disputed by Suyok, who then challenges Artajo to a duel. Suyok is trounced by Artajo. Lutab falls in love with Elena. Immay, Lutab’s sister, falls in love with Artajo. But complications arise, for Immay is betrothed to Suyok, while another Ifugao maiden, Aniway, is in love with him.

Immay declares her love for Artajo. Suyok and Artajo fight each other in a duel, and again Artajo is the victor. Artajo wins Immay’s love.

Suyok forms his own rebel group and buys guns from Sergeant Crow, a mercenary traitor. MacPhimster’s force and Suyok’s men go on fighting. Many are killed on both sides. All this fighting does not stop Suyok from falling for Elena, who is almost raped by Crow before she escapes to MacPhimster’s camp. MacPhimster launches an all-out attack on Suyok and his followers. In the bloody encounter, Crow, Suyok, and Aniway are killed. A period of peace follows. Before going back to America, MacPhimster promises Lutab that he will write a book about the Ifugao’s heroism.

Ifugao won the Best Actor (Reyes), Best Director, and Best Screenplay awards at the 1955 Asian Film Festival in Singapore. It started the trend of depicting indigenous Filipino culture on the wide screen exemplified by other acclaimed films like Badjao, 1957, and Igorot a (Mountain Maiden), 1968. The epic production was acclaimed for, among other things, its use of Filipino local color in the Western or “Indians vs US Cavalry” genre.  Written by Rosalie Matilac, J. Bejarin, and Ramon Jocson
