text:
(Illusion) / 2005 / Color / Drama / 100 minutes / Direction, Editing, and Animation: Paolo Villaluna and Ellen Ramos / Story: Jon Red / Screenplay: Jon Red and Paolo Villaluna / Cinematography: Odyssey Flores / Production Design: Danny Red / Sound: Allan Marcelo Hilado / Music: Eduardo Canlas, Josefino Cenizal, LC de Leon, Isha, Larry Miranda, Jason Moss, Eazer Pastor, and Pike Ramirez / Produced by Pelipula Productions, Pollen Productions, and Digital Viva / Cast: Yul Servo (Miguel), Jaycee Parker (Stella), Jennifer Lee (Tess), Ronnie Lazaro (Pablo), Bella Flores (Manang Karing), Anita Linda, and Bituin Escalante (Clara)

 

 

Set in the late 1950s, Ilusyon follows the story of a young country boy, Miguel, who decides to join his painter-father Pablo in Manila, only to discover that Pablo has gone soul-searching elsewhere. Miguel goes job hunting and finds himself painting house walls. One day, a professional nude model, Stella, goes to visit Pablo for a painting session. She enters the house clad in a red polka-dot dress fashioned after the 1930s American cartoon character Betty Boop. Stunned by her beauty and wanting to know her more, Miguel does not correct Stella when she mistakes him for Pablo. Even if Miguel knows nothing about art, he assumes his father’s role and does his best to paint Stella’s portrait until they find themselves falling for each other. Unable to create a work of art, Miguel resorts to paying an artist-for-hire to finish the task by showing him rough sketches of Stella and likening her to Marilyn Monroe. Miguel shows his supposed masterpiece to Stella and learns that she has developed an unknown skin disease. Soon, their relationship falls into a decline and Stella is forced to distance herself from Miguel. However, Miguel cannot get Stella out of his mind and tries to paint her from memory until he succeeds. Miguel searches for Stella to give her his masterpiece and make amends, but everything is too late.

The film incorporates a number of dream sequences, animation montages, and a song-and-dance production number alluding to the onscreen love team of Nida Blanca and Nestor de Villa. It also utilizes the epistolary storytelling technique where letters act as a source of information and as Miguel’s conscience, which is characteristic of early Filipino films. Shot in only five days, Ilusyon was graded “A” by the Cinema Evaluation Board. It earned awards for Best Cinematography and Breakthrough Performance (Parker) from the 2006 Golden Screen Awards. The film premiered in the 2005 Digital Lokal program of the Cinemanila International Film Festival and was an official selection at the Winds of Asia program of the 2006 Pusan International Film Festival and the 2008 Atlanta Asian Film Festival.  Written by Michael Kho Lim

text:
(Portrait of a Nation) / 2006 / Color / Short Film Anthology / 130 minutes / Concept: Jon Red and Carol Bunuan Red / Direction: 5 Minutes, Ogi Sugatan; Biyaheng EDSA (EDSA Trip), Neil Daza; Talahib (Wild Sugarcane), EJ Salcedo; Between Intersections, Poklong Anading; Tsinelas (Slippers), Mes de Guzman; La Pula (Red Chief), Roxlee; Aksyon Star (Action Star), Sigfreid Barros Sanchez; Silid (Room), Yeye Calderon; Tawa (Laughter), Dennis Empalmado; Imagining EDSA, Emmanuel dela Cruz; Speci Men, Ellen Ramos; Lugaw (Rice Porridge), Milo Alto Paz; Local Unit, Tad Ermitaño; One Shot, Paolo Villaluna; Nang Matapos ang Ulan (After the Rain), Lav Diaz; Public Service Announcement, R. A. Rivera; Ang Manunulat (The Writer), Topel Lee; W. I. P., Lyle Sacris; Barado (Clogged), Robert Quebral; Mistulang Kamerang Obskura (Like a Camera Obscura), Raymond Red / Produced by Pelipula Productions and Digital Viva / Cast: Pen Medina, Ping Medina, Bella Flores, Janice Jurado, Bodjie Pascua, Soliman Cruz, Paolo Villaluna, Bombi Plata, Raul Morit, and Elmo Redrico

 

Imahe Nasyon is a collection of 20 short films that commemorates the 20th anniversary of the EDSA Revolt that ousted President Ferdinand Marcos in 1986. Given a budget of 20,000 pesos each, 20 filmmakers were selected to produce a five-minute film that represents how they envision the country 20 years after the end of martial law. The project showcases the filmmakers’ different directorial styles, ranging from the linear narrative structure, to the music video format, to experimental techniques in addressing social ills and national issues. Among these filmmakers is Ramos who, being the only female director in the omnibus film, approaches gender inequality by creating a world dominated by women and putting them to the fore. Another is Diaz who, known for his lengthy cinematic masterpieces, presents his vision of the nation’s prolonged absence of development through one steady shot that stretches to eight minutes. The collection also explores other pressing socioeconomic concerns, such as the struggles of a daily wage earner, the use of contraceptives, a developing country’s response to technological advances, the nation’s progress or lack thereof, and its retrogression. Resonating themes include patriotism, social injustice, oppression, poverty, media censorship, artistic freedom, political ineptitude, and the youth’s perception of the spirit of the EDSA Revolt. Pen Medina, who stars and plays multiple roles in all the shorts, demonstrates his versatility as an actor and serves as the common thread that ties the whole film together. Shot with a digital camera, Imahe Nasyon is more than just a critical depiction of a country torn by political and social upheavals. It is also a celebration of the nation’s regained democracy and independence and a testament to the growth of Philippine independent cinema in the last 20 years.

In partnership with the Philippine Independent Filmmakers Multipurpose Cooperative, Imahe Nasyon premiered at the Robinsons Galleria cinema in 2006 and had its international debut at the 20th Singapore International Film Festival in 2007.  Written by Michael Kho Lim

text:
(Sewers) / 2008 / Drama / 212 minutes / Direction, Screenplay, and Editing: Sherad Anthony Sanchez / Cinematography: John Torres, Mark Limbaga, Jose Bagane Fiola, and Joel Geolamen / Production Design: Joel Geolamen / Sound: John Barredo / Music: Eric Gancio / Produced by Creative Programs Inc and Salida Productions / Cast: Jelieta Mariveles-Ruca (Gigi), Allen Lumanog (Allen), and Joel San Juan (Joel).

Imburnal is a three-and-a-half-hour non-narrative film that intertwines poverty and sexuality. Shot on the fringes of Punta Dumalog, near the coast of Davao City, the film is set in and around the sewers, where people loaf around, talk, smoke, drink, sleep, and even die. The sewers embody a bleak reality that is inhabited and used as refuge by many people. The only semblance of narrative and point of view are anchored on the wanderings of the young boys, Allen and Joel, who see most of what goes on in and around the sewers. They are young enough to be interested in playing games, but the sewer, their “second home,” is not the best place for children. They are cared for by Gigi, the only adult around, but she is not exactly the best mother for them.

The long takes and stretches of silence and plotlessness give the impression that nothing is happening. But instead of doing nothing exactly, the young people are doing something. They curse, talk about sex, masturbate, engage in public sex, watch others having sex, collect cockroaches in jars, and swim in the filthy waters. The provocative images are further distorted by abstractions in the cinematography and editing, such as when shots are deliberately blurred or when frames are frozen. The imagery functions as a counterpoint to the reputation of Davao City as safe and clean.

Imburnal won Best Picture, Best Screenplay, and Best Cinematographyin the 2008 Cinema One Originals Digital Film Festival and the Lino Brocka Grand Prize in the 2008 Cinemanila International Film Festival. It won the Woosuk Award and the Network for the Promotion of Asian Cinema Award in the 2009 Jeonju International Film Festival, Special Mention in the Southeast Asian Competition of the 2009 Bangkok International Film Festival, and the Cinema of the Future Award (Special Mention) in the 2010 Buenos Aires International Festival of Independent Cinema.  Written by Patrick Campos

text:
2003 / Color / Documentary / 103 minutes / Direction: Ramona S. Diaz / Cinematography: Ferne Pearlstein / Editing: Leah Marino / Sound: Brian Cunneff / Music: Bob Aves and Grace Nono / Produced by CineDiaz

Imelda is a documentary on the rise, fall, and rise again of former First Lady Imelda R. Marcos. It features interviews with Imelda herself, her children, her close friends and allies, and even her political rivals and detractors. The film traces Imelda’s life from her early years in Leyte province, her arrival in Manila where she worked as a singer and joined the Miss Manila pageant, her first meeting with then congressman Ferdinand Marcos who later became her husband, her meteoric rise as First Lady of the Philippines for 20 years, to her family’s tragic downfall after the 1986 EDSA Revolt and the death of Ferdinand Marcos, and their seeming resurgence in the Philippine political arena in recent years. Throughout her interview, Imelda remains genuinely firm in her belief that she has done nothing wrong and that she was simply misunderstood, despite the numerous cases filed against her and her late husband and the overwhelming evidence that could prove their guilt and complicity. The film also shows a quirky and somewhat eccentric side to Imelda seldom seen by the public. Ramona S. Diaz is able to paint a portrait of an Imelda Marcos who, then until now, is seemingly insulated by wealth and power from the drudgery of real life and the everyday struggles of ordinary Filipinos.

 

 

Imelda was a critical success worldwide and a commercial hit in the Philippines, quite unusual for a documentary film. It received the Excellence in Cinematography for Documentary award from the 2004 Sundance Film Festival and the Video Source Award from the 2004 International Documentary Association.  Written by Elvin Valerio

text:
(Independence) / 2009 / Black and White / Drama / 77 minutes / Direction: Raya Martin / Screenplay: Ramon Sarmiento and Raya Martin / Cinematography: Jeanne Lapoirie / Editing: Jay Halili / Production Design: Digo Ricio / Sound: Ronald de Asis, Arnel Labayo / Music: Lutgardo Labad / Produced by Arte France Cinema, Cinematografica (Philippines), Atopic (France), Razor Film (Germany), and Volya Films (Netherlands) / Cast: Sid Lucero, Tetchie Agbayani, Alessandra de Rossi, and Mika Aguilos

Set on the eve of the 20th century, an elderly mother and her son retreat into the forest as American troops begin to invade the Philippines. The son later finds a wounded woman, who was raped by American soldiers, and brings her home. The mother eventually dies, and the man and the woman live as husband and wife. They become father and mother to a mestizo child and their family makes the forest their permanent home. Years pass. The man and woman recall their past, sharing their memories with their son, who has none of his own of memories of life outside the forest. Aside from hunting and gathering food, they do nothing else but tell each other stories. A storm visits the forest and kills the man and woman. In the end, the American troops, aided by a Filipino conspirator, reach the forest. The boy runs away and chooses to jump off a cliff rather than be captured by the Americans.

Visually reminiscent of silent films of a bygone era, Independencia was shot mainly in a sound studio, strewn with foliage and surrounded by painted backdrops. It is part of Martin’s trilogy on fin de siècle Philippine history, all of which foreground the artifice of cinema. The trilogy includes Maicling Pelicula nang Ysang Indio Nacional o Ang Mahabang Kalungkutan ng Katagalugan (A Short Film about the Indio Nacional or The Prolonged Sorrow of the Filipinos), 2005, which is set during the Philippine revolution against Spain, and Autohystoria, 2007, which recasts the killing of Andres Bonifacio and his brother.

Independencia was screened in the Un Certain Regard section of the 2009 Cannes Film Festival. It won Best Film in the Southeast Asian category, as well as the Network for the Promotion of Asian Cinema Jury Prize, in the 2009 Bangkok International Film Festival. It won Best Film and the Critics Prize in the 2009 Valdivia International Film Festival.  Written by Patrick Campos

John Lloyd Cruz and Luis Manzano in In My Life, 2009

(Star Cinema)

text:
2009 / Color / Drama / 120 minutes / Direction: Olivia M. Lamasan / Story: Raymond Lee and Olivia M. Lamasan / Screenplay: Raymond Lee, Senedy Que, and Olivia M. Lamasan / Cinematography, Charlie Peralta; editing, Marya Ignacio; production design, Elfren Vibar; sound, Albert Michael Idioma; music, Nonong Buencamino / Produced by Star Cinema. Cast: Vilma Santos (Shirley Templo), John Lloyd Cruz (Noel), Luis Manzano (Mark), Dimples Romana (Dang), Tirso Cruz III (Benito), Marshall Factora (Tito Ed), Janice Y. Perez (Pamela), Nikki Valdez, Rafael Rosell, Vice Ganda, Paw Diaz, Arnold Reyes, Nonie Buencamino, and Shamaine Buencamino.

Shirley Templo, an American citizen who has never lived in America, is an irritable librarian and former PE teacher who does not want anything new in her life. Her daughter Dang and neighbors have been trying to convince her to sell her property to real-estate developers for a huge profit, but she refuses to do so. Fed up with her daughters and ex-husband Benito, she decides to go to New York to spend some time with her gay son Mark, whose lover is Noel, an illegal alien. Despite Noel’s kindness and patience, it takes some time for Shirley to warm up to him, especially since her son has broached the idea of her marrying Noel to fix his illegal status. She tries working in New York but cannot quite find a job suitable for her. One day, after a harrowing day at work, she takes the wrong train, gets lost in New York, and blames Noel for it. Soon, however, she lands a job as a fitness instructor in a senior center and her relationship with Noel improves.

 

 

Unfortunately, Mark, who has been having abdominal pain, is diagnosed with stage one colon cancer and has to undergo an operation. The couple conceals the truth from Shirley, who eventually finds out. Shirley feels betrayed by her son and Noel, but mother and son eventually patch things up. Mark survives his cancer, but is hit by a truck while crossing the street. Noel and Shirley fight over Mark’s body, with Shirley wishing to return with it back to Manila, and Noel insisting that Mark be cremated as the latter had expressly wished. Shirley relents and goes back to Manila with Mark’s urn. She also decides to sell her property, to the surprise of her daughters and ex-husband. To her horror, she realizes she knows so little about her children and has been quite unkind to them. She returns to the United States to start life anew. Noel is about to marry Pamela, the daughter of Tito Ed, one of his employers. Shirley intervenes. In the end, she decides to marry Noel, not only as an act of kindness for the younger man but also as an act of love—to honor Mark’s request, to be a good mother to her beloved son.

In My Life marks a queer turn in mainstream diaspora movies in Philippine cinema. It won seven PMPC Star Awards for Movies—namely, Movie of the Year, Movie Director of the Year, Movie Actress of the Year (Santos), Movie Actor of the Year (Cruz), Movie Supporting Actor of the Year (Manzano), Movie Original Screenplay of the Year, and Movie Cinematographer of the Year.  Written by Ronald Baytan

Mona Lisa and Hilda Koronel in Insiang, 1976
(Cesar Hernando Collection)

text:
1976 / Color / Drama / 95 minutes / Direction: Lino Brocka / Story: Mario O’Hara / Screenplay: Mario O’Hara and Lamberto E. Antonio / Cinematography: Conrado Baltazar / Editing: Augusto Salvador / Production Design: Fiel Zabat / Sound: Rudy Baldovino / Music: Minda Azarcon / Produced by CineManila Corporation / Cast: Hilda Koronel (Insiang), Mona Lisa (Tonya), Ruel Vernal (Dado), Rez Cortez (Bebot), Marlon Ramirez, and the PETA Kalinangan Ensemble

Insiang is the only child of Tonya, a market vendor abandoned by her husband. Mother and daughter live in a slum shanty with the parasitic relatives of Tonya’s husband. When the relatives leave, Tonya takes in a “live-in” partner, Dado, a hoodlum who is also attracted to Insiang. Tonya is jealous of her daughter. Insiang starts to hate Tonya and Dado even more when Dado stops Bebot, her boyfriend, from seeing her.

 

 

Dado rapes Insiang, but Tonya believes Dado’s tale that Insiang seduced him. The desperate Insiang asks her boyfriend to run away with her. After she and Bebot make love in a cheap motel, Bebot leaves her. Disillusioned, Insiang returns to her mother who accepts her, but is determined to prevent Insiang from “seducing” Dado again. With revenge in mind, Insiang yields to Dado’s sexual advances, and manipulates him into mauling Bebot in a garbage dump. Meanwhile, Tonya grows more suspicious of her daughter and Dado. At the right time, Insiang reveals her relationship with Dado and leads Tonya to murder Dado.

In the end, Insiang visits Tonya in prison and asks for forgiveness but receives only Tonya’s bitter iciness. Insiang leaves without looking back at Tonya, who peers out of the barred window of her cell, her face full of hate, anger, and pain.

Insiang won Best Actress (Koronel), Best Supporting Actress (Lisa), Best Supporting Actor (Bernal), and Best Cinematography in the 1976 Metro Manila Film Festival; Best Supporting Actress in the 1977 Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Awards; and Best Supporting Actor in the 1977 Gawad Urian. Shown in the Directors’ Fortnight at Cannes Film Festival, Insiang earned for Brocka recognition in the international film community. The Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino voted the film as one of the 10 Best Films of the Decade 1970-79. In 2015, the restored version of Insiang was included in the Classics section of the 68th Cannes Film Festival. The restoration was a joint project between the Film Development Council of the Philippines and Martin Scorsese’s World Cinema Project/The Film Foundation. In 2007, Insiang was adapted for the stage by O’Hara himself and directed by Chris Millado for Tanghalang Pilipino at the Cultural Center of the Philippines.  Written by Menchie R. Tajan, with notes from Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

text:
(The Rites of May) / 1976 / Color / Drama, Thriller / 105 minutes / Direction: Mike de Leon / Screenplay: Clodualdo del Mundo Jr and Gil Quito / Cinematography: Rody Lacap and Ely Cruz / Editing: Ike Jarlego Jr / Production Design: Mel Chionglo / Sound: Ramon Reyes, Sebastian Sayson, and Luis Reyes / Music: Max Jocson / Produced by Cinema Artists Philippines / Cast: Charo Santos (Teresa), Tommy Abuel (Jun), Mario Montenegro (Dr Torres), Mona Lisa (Aling Pining), Susan Valdez (Rosa), Moody Diaz (Aling Bebeng), and Sarah Joaquin (Aling Angelina)

 

 

A young photographer, Jun Torres, encounters a strange woman, Teresa, during a Lenten visit to his father’s ancestral house in their hometown. They become friends. Both are intrigued by Teresa’s periodic lapses into strange behavior, over which Teresa has no control. With Teresa’s mother Aling Pining, they seek the help of an espiritista (medium). It is revealed that Teresa is possessed by the spirit of her sister Rosa, who died under mysterious circumstances. Gradually, the puzzle is solved when the spirit, through Teresa, tells her sad story: Jun’s father, Dr Torres, with whom Rosa was having an affair, forced her to abort their child, leading to her death. As the spirit recounts her tale, Rosa exacts her revenge: the father falls down the stairs and dies.

The movie, which displays technical excellence in its innovative cinematography and haunting musical score, is Mike de Leon’s first film. The film won Best Picture and Best Actress (Santos) at the 1978 Asian Film Festival held in Sydney, Australia. It won Gawad Urian trophies for Best Cinematography, Best Music, Best Editing, and Best Sound, as well as the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences awards for Best Cinematography, Best Sound, and Best Production Design. The Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino cited it as one of the 10 Best Films of the Decade 1970-79.  Written by Luna Sicat

Phillip Salvador, Menggie Cobarrubias, and Johnny Delgado in Jaguar, 1979

(Mario A. Hernando Collection)

text:
(Guard) / 1979 / Color / Drama / 100 minutes / Direction: Lino Brocka / Story: Nick Joaquin / Screenplay: Jose F. Lacaba and Ricardo Lee / Cinematography: Conrado Baltazar / Editing: Rene Tala / Production Design: Bobby Bautista / Sound: Ramon Reyes and Luis Reyes / Music: The Vanishing Tribe / Produced by Bancom Audiovision Corporation / Cast: Phillip Salvador (Poldo), Amy Austria (Cristy), Menggie Cobarrubias (Sonny), Johnny Delgado (Direk San Pedro), Anita Linda, Tonio Gutierrez, Roi Vinzon, and Mario Escudero.

Poldo is a security guard at a publishing company owned by the parents of Sonny. From a poor family, Poldo dreams of becoming rich. One day he defends Sonny during a quarrel with employees. Impressed by Poldo’s courage and skills, Sonny makes him his personal bodyguard. Poldo gets a taste of the carefree and extravagant lifestyle of his boss.

 

In one of the nightclubs they frequent, Sonny meets Cristy, a dancer who is having an affair with movie director San Pedro. In spite of San Pedro’s warning, Sonny aggressively pursues the woman and promises to introduce her to another movie producer. This enrages San Pedro; he chances upon Sonny and they fight.

Poldo defends his boss and guns down San Pedro. Sonny gives Poldo some money to go into hiding while Cristy, who secretly admires Poldo, arranges his escape to Mindoro. The police conduct a zoning operation in the slum community the night before Poldo’s departure. He is caught and thrown into jail. Sonny visits Poldo in prison, not to help Poldo but to ask him not to implicate Sonny. Enraged and frustrated, Poldo attacks Sonny; the police step in and Poldo is put in another cell.

Jose F. Lacaba and Ricardo Lee based their script on an article about a Manila hoodlum, “The Boy Who Wanted to Be Society” by Quijano de Manila (pseud. of Nick Joaquin), in the Philippines Free Press. Jaguar (from “guar-ja” or “gwar-dya,” meaning “guard”) won the 1980 Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences awards for Best Picture and Best Director, and the 1980 Gawad Urian for Best Picture, Best Director, Best Screenplay, Best Cinematography, Best Supporting Actor (Cobarrubias), and Best Supporting Actress (Austria). In 1980, Jaguar was favorably received at the Cannes Film Festival and at the 26th Asian Film Festival in Indonesia. The Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino chose it as one of the 10 Best Films of the Decade 1970-79.   Written by Menchie R. Tajan

text:
2013 / Color / Documentary / 75 minutes / Direction: Baby Ruth Villarama / Cinematography: Dexter de la Peña / Editing: Chuck Gutierrez / Sound: Albert Michael Idioma / Music: Nani Naguit / Produced by Voyage Studios / Cast: Ernesto Tigaldao Jr and Theodor Rutkowski

Jazz in Love opens with a long-distance call between Ernesto “Jazz” Tigaldao from Davao and his German boyfriend Theo Rutkowski. They have been in a long-distance relationship for 11 months. Jazz barely passes the language exam at the Goethe-Institut, which he needs to be able to get a visa for Germany, a fiancé visa if plans to marry Theo do not miscarry. Theo visits Jazz in Davao, where Jazz and his family live. The lovers enjoy their time visiting scenic destinations. Theo is introduced to the family. The Filipino family is conservative, but the parents and relatives respect the relationship of the gay couple. On the other hand, Theo, who is used to a quiet life with a small family back home, seems overwhelmed by all the fuss from a big, extended family, especially during the birthday celebration for him. In the end, Theo seems reluctant in pursuing the marriage. Jazz, on the other hand, is the ever hopeful gay lover.

Jazz in Love opened the 9th Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival in 2013 and was the recipient of the Regal Prize of the Manila Film Financing Forum of the 2012 Cinemalaya. It was selected for the Wide Angle Section of the 18th Busan International Film Festival.  Written by Mario Mendez Jr

Cesar Montano, center, with Cesar Xerez-Burgos and Jaime Fabregas in Jose Rizal, 1998

(Mario A. Hernando Collection)

text:
1998 / Color and Black and White / Drama / 178 minutes / Direction: Marilou Diaz-Abaya / Screenplay: Ricardo Lee, Jun Lana, and Peter Ong Lim / Cinematography: Rody Lacap / Editing: Manet Dayrit and Jess Navarro / Production Design: Leo Abaya / Sound: Albert Michael Idioma / Music: Nonong Buencamino / Produced by GMA Films / Cast: Cesar Montano (Jose Rizal), Joel Torre (Ibarra/Simoun), Jaime Fabregas (Luis Taviel de Andrade), Gloria Diaz (Teodora Alonso), Monique Wilson (Maria Clara), Gardo Versoza (Andres Bonifacio), Chin Chin Gutierrez (Josephine Bracken), Pen Medina (Paciano Mercado), Peque Gallaga, Mickey Ferriols, Subas Herrero, Tony Mabesa, Bon Vibar, and Alexis Santaren

 

 

Depicting the life and struggles of national hero Jose Rizal, this three-hour-long movie begins in Belgium, with Rizal in the middle of writing his second novel, El Filibusterismo (Subversion). As Rizal’s voice narrates the story of Spanish abuses in the country, the narrative comes to life, in black and white, with the main character Simoun articulating Rizal’s own thoughts about the current situation in Spanish Philippines. Meanwhile, Rizal’s first novel, Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), has already motivated the discontented locals, headed by Andres Bonifacio, to start the separatist Katipunan movement. Fearing an uprising, the Spanish colonial officials, under pressure from Church officials, decide to put all the blame for the Katipunan on Rizal and his subversive literature. Upon the completion of El Filibusterismo and his subsequent return to the country in 1892, Rizal is captured and detained. From hereon, the movie shuttles back and forth in time and space, from Rizal’s childhood up to Rizal’s imprisonment at Fort Santiago, from Rizal’s own life to Rizal’s imagined world as immortalized in his novels. This back-and-forth action in the narrative also reflects Rizal’s indecision about the resolution of his second novel, as cinematically illustrated in the scene where Rizal debates with his alter-ego, Simoun. The movie ends with the execution of Rizal in Bagumbayan, followed by a quick scene showing Andres Bonifacio and the Katipuneros as they plan their next move against the Spaniards, with Rizal’s photograph prominently hung in the Katipunan headquarters.

First shown locally in June 1998 to coincide with the celebrations of the centennial of the Philippine Revolution, the film was subsequently shown during the Metro Manila Film Festival (MMFF) later that year. It won all the major awards in the 1998 MMFF: Best Picture, Best Director, Best Actor (Montano), Best Supporting Actor (Fabregas), Best Supporting Actress (Diaz), Best Screenplay, Best Cinematography, Best Editing, Best Production Design, Best Sound, Best Musical Score, Best Makeup Artist, Best Visual Effects, and Gatpuno Antonio J. Villegas Cultural Award. It was nominated in nine categories in the 1999 Gawad Urian and won six: Best Director, Best Supporting Actor, Best Cinematography, Best Production Design, Best Music, and Best Sound. Jose Rizal was also shown in various international film festivals, including the 1999 Chicago International Film Festival, the 49th International Berlin Film Festival, and the Asian American International Film Festival in New York City in 1999. Due to alleged internal conflicts within the Film Academy of the Philippines, the film received no awards from the academy.  Written by Anne Frances Sangil

article.value: Depicting the life and struggles of national hero Jose Rizal, this three-hour-long movie begins in Belgium, with Rizal in the middle of writing his second novel, El Filibusterismo (Subversion). As Rizal’s voice narrates the story of Spanish abuses in the country, the narrative comes to life, in black and white, with the main character Simoun articulating Rizal’s own thoughts about the current situation in Spanish Philippines. Meanwhile, Rizal’s first novel, Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), has already motivated the discontented locals, headed by Andres Bonifacio, to start the separatist Katipunan movement. Fearing an uprising, the Spanish colonial officials, under pressure from Church officials, decide to put all the blame for the Katipunan on Rizal and his subversive literature. Upon the completion of El Filibusterismo and his subsequent return to the country in 1892, Rizal is captured and detained. From hereon, the movie shuttles back and forth in time and space, from Rizal’s childhood up to Rizal’s imprisonment at Fort Santiago, from Rizal’s own life to Rizal’s imagined world as immortalized in his novels. This back-and-forth action in the narrative also reflects Rizal’s indecision about the resolution of his second novel, as cinematically illustrated in the scene where Rizal debates with his alter-ego, Simoun. The movie ends with the execution of Rizal in Bagumbayan, followed by a quick scene showing Andres Bonifacio and the Katipuneros as they plan their next move against the Spaniards, with Rizal’s photograph prominently hung in the Katipunan headquarters.

First shown locally in June 1998 to coincide with the celebrations of the centennial of the Philippine Revolution, the film was subsequently shown during the Metro Manila Film Festival (MMFF) later that year. It won all the major awards in the 1998 MMFF: Best Picture, Best Director, Best Actor (Montano), Best Supporting Actor (Fabregas), Best Supporting Actress (Diaz), Best Screenplay, Best Cinematography, Best Editing, Best Production Design, Best Sound, Best Musical Score, Best Makeup Artist, Best Visual Effects, and Gatpuno Antonio J. Villegas Cultural Award. It was nominated in nine categories in the 1999 Gawad Urian and won six: Best Director, Best Supporting Actor, Best Cinematography, Best Production Design, Best Music, and Best Sound. Jose Rizal was also shown in various international film festivals, including the 1999 Chicago International Film Festival, the 49th International Berlin Film Festival, and the Asian American International Film Festival in New York City in 1999. Due to alleged internal conflicts within the Film Academy of the Philippines, the film received no awards from the academy.  Written by Anne Frances Sangil

text:
(Lazy Juan Goes to Congress) / 1959 / Black and White / Comedy / Direction: Manuel Conde / Screenplay: Jess Banguis and Manuel Conde / Cinematography: Emmanuel Rojas / Production Design: Carlos V. Francisco / Music: Ariston Avelino / Produced by Manuel Conde Productions / Cast: Manuel Conde (Juan Tamad), Tessie Quintana (Karima), Adorable Liwanag (Leah), Greg Urbano (Gat Uto), Naty Bernardo (Laging Litga), Alfonso Carvajal (Lakan Hangin), Miniong Alvarez (Lamy-Dacky), Joseph de Cordova (Lakan Tabil), Tony Dantes, Flaviano Miranda, Pianing Vidal, Rolando Liwanag, Eddie Boy Serrano, Ben Castillo, Manuel Rivera, and Julian Yulo

Juan Tamad is running for reelection as congressman of Distrito Lawang-Lawa, but people now throw stones at him. He wonders how he got to be so hated after just one term as congressman.

 

Flashback to four years ago. Juan’s debtors convince him to run for Congress, so he can become rich from bribes and so have the money to pay his debts to them. Juan launches his campaign, kissing babies and jumping over fences. He gives away cash in exchange for votes so he wins over his rivals Lakan Hangin and Lakan Tabil. After his victory, he is swamped with requests for all kinds of jobs and contributions to baptisms, weddings, and burials. Meanwhile, Juan sees congressmen sleeping, playing sungka (mancala), listening to a transistor radio, and flirting with women—while the House is in session. Outside the halls of Congress, Congressman Ismagol brings in contraband goods for free as “personal effects.”

The flashback ends. Defying the crowd outside his house, Juan walks to the platform and delivers a speech. He says he is no longer running for reelection, so he will speak the truth. He admits he did nothing in Congress and that many congressmen committed abuses. But the people are also to blame for this. During election campaigns, the people ask candidates for bribe money. Therefore, once elected, the congressmen will try to recover what they spent in the elections by stealing from government. There will be no real change in society for as long as the people peddle their votes. At supper that night, Juan tells his family he is turning his back on politics. But a crowd has gathered outside his house. The people have realized their mistake, so they now want Juan to run for the Senate.

Conde deliberately used the folk character Juan Tamad and set the film in “precolonial Philippines” to avoid court cases. Just the same, his audiences understood all his allusions to “flying voters” and “influence peddlers.” Likewise, Botong Francisco’s production design was witty and loaded. Because the film was expected to touch on political issues, even well-known politicians lined up with ordinary moviegoers to see if they were alluded to by the movie. Congress established Conde as a master of the political satire. Because of its success, it was followed by Juan Tamad Goes to Society, 1960, and Si Juan Tamad at si Juan Masipag sa Pulitikang Walang Hanggan (Lazy Juan and Industrious Juan in Never-Ending Politics), 1963.  Written by Nicanor G. Tiongson

text:
(Lazy Juan Goes to Society) / 1960 / Color / Comedy / Direction: Manuel Conde / Story and Screenplay: Manuel Conde and Jess Banguis / Cinematography: Remigio Young / Music: Francisco Buencamino Jr / Produced by LVN Pictures / Cast: Manuel Conde (Juan Tamad), Tessie Quintana (Karani), Lita Gutierrez (Ganid-a), Adorable Liwanag (Leah), Patsy (Sobhra), Alfonso Carvajal (Sikatdao), Liza Moreno, Mila Ocampo, Patria Plata, Jose Vergara, Joseph de Cordova, Perla Bautista, FEU Folk Dance Group, and LVN stars in cameo roles

Juan Tamad, a newly elected senator, unknowingly saves the sultan from harm in a public gathering. Grateful to Juan for saving his life, the sultan anoints Juan as his successor. Because of this, Juan and his family take on the airs and manners of “hay sosayti” (high society). More importantly, Juan becomes the target of ambitious women looking for a husband, especially Ganid-a (greedy), the daughter of Sobhra (excessive) whose lifestyle pushes her husband Sikatdao (supposedly famous) to desperation. At Ganid-a’s lavish debut, a fashion show, satirizing contemporary women’s clothes, is staged. Ganid-a invites Juan to the debut, hoping to ensnare him there, but Juan instead notices and falls for Karani, a pretty girl who is against the social-climbing ways of her own mother Inggiteray (envious).

 

Because of his stature, the matrons of the Family First Association invite Juan to chair their fund-raising beauty contest through which they intend to raise 30,000 pesos, half of which will be donated to the youth hospital. The winner, who will receive 10,000 pesos, will be selected through ballots that will be sold everywhere. Ganid-a, Karani, and even Juan’s sister Leah are forced to run by their social-climbing mothers, together with other contestants. Juan promises to support Ganid-a and Karani. On the night of the competition itself, the three candidates lose out to the winner, a truly beautiful but unknown contestant.

Sobhra and Inggiteray bring Juan to court, complaining that they sold properties to raise funds for the contest but lost everything because of Juan. Even the winner complains that she spent 12,000 pesos for her candidacy but when she won, the association could not give her the prize money of 10,000 pesos. The judge, aided by the representatives of the major dailies, asks Juan to explain himself. Juan admits that he decided to make the most deserving contestant win to wake people up. If this is wrong he will accept punishment for it. Moreover, he reveals that he and the association were able to raise 120,000 pesos for the benefit show they sponsored, but the bulk of this money went to the representational expenses of the matrons and the production costs of the extravagant show, leaving only one peso for the youth hospital. In the end, Juan advises those who only have chicken wings not to compete with the eagles, and the eagles not to spend their disposable income on trivialities but to help the poor even without publicity.  Written by Nicanor G. Tiongson

text:
(Enemy) / 1983 / Color / Short Film (Super 8) / Direction: Raymond Red and Ian Victoriano / Story and Screenplay: Ian Victoriano / Cinematography: Raymond Red / Editing: Raymond Red and Ian Victoriano / Produced by Mowelfund Film Institute and Red-Victoriano / Cast: Juvinic Andrion, Ian Victoriano, Alwin Reamillo, Danny Red, and Randy Punsal

 

The setting is pastoral southern Luzon in 1981. Four young men, “shepherds of the stars,” are trained in a special school atop a mountain. The young men are dedicated artists and invoke the Muses whenever they guard the stars. They believe that one night the enemy will attack in a blaze of light. On the eve of their graduation as full-fledged guardians, the enemy takes the life of one shepherd. The remaining shepherds talk about why they were chosen, their sacred task, and how they can fight the enemy. They realize that they must look for the core of blazing light where the heart of the enemy lies. Only one shepherd encounters the enemy; the other decides that he is not a real guardian. He feels that someone must survive to tell the fable of the wounded stars to future generations. When the first shepherd encounters the enemy, he discovers that he himself is the enemy. He dies, a spear thrust into his heart. Kabaka mourns the dead star shepherds, laments their helplessness against the enemy.

Kabaka is a highly introspective and philosophical allegory on the artist in society. Described by critics as an “elegiac science fiction fable,” the film won Second Prize, Experimental Category, at the Second Experimental Cinema of the Philippines Short Film Festival in 1983. It was cited as one of the 25 Best Super 8 Films at the 1990 Quezon City International Super 8 Film Festival. Red’s film—together with Ang Hikab (Yawn), 1983; Kamada (State of Being), 1984; and Pelikula (Film), 1985—was shown at the 1986 Edinburgh International Film Festival, 1987 PIA Film Festival in Tokyo, and 1987 Hong Kong International Film Festival.  Written by Luna Sicat

text:
(Chain of Mud) / 1960 / Black and White / Drama / Direction: Cesar Gallardo / Story: Clodualdo del Mundo Sr (as serialized in Pilipino Komiks) / Screenplay: Cesar J. Amigo / Cinematography: Tommy Marcelino / Sound: Demetrio de Santos / Music: Tony Maiquez / Produced by People’s Pictures Inc / Cast: Tessie Quintana (Emilia), Efren Reyes (Don Sebastian), Alicia Vergel (Dalmacia), Leonor Vergara (Elena), Bob Soler (Fernando), Ronald Remy (Arturo), Lily Marquez, Belen Velasco, Max Alvarado, Dencio Padilla, Eddie Boy Serrano, Danilo Jurado, and Ruby Roxas

An adaptation of del Mundo’s popular komiks serial novel, Kadenang Putik deals with male infidelity. Don Sebastian is a successful businessman married to Dalmacia. Their marriage begins to crumble as Dalmacia constantly nags Sebastian. He tries to endure his wife’s ill temper but soon finds solace in another woman, Emilia, who is the opposite of Dalmacia in wealth and breeding. Emilia bears Sebastian a son, Fernando, who is also different from Sebastian’s legitimate son, Arturo. Arturo himself gets married, and, his marriage failing, finds comfort in a mistress, Elena. The movie ends with everyone realizing that they have to conform to social norms even if it means losing the ones they love. Sebastian and Arturo go back to their wives. As Sebastian agonizes on his deathbed, everyone forgives everyone else and all their troubles are ironed out.

This film takes a close look at diverse relationships, complete with well-chosen details and symbolic nuances. It reworks the hackneyed love-triangle theme by treating the querida (other woman) sympathetically. Kadenang Putik won the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences awards for Best Actor (Reyes), Best Story, and Best Screenplay.  Written by Emelie Capulong

photos.desc:
Gemma Cuenca and Roeder Camañag in Kagadanan sa Banwaan ning mga Engkanto, 2007

(Photo courtesy of Lav Diaz)

text:
(Death in the Land of Encantos) / 2007 / Black and White / Drama / 540 minutes / Direction, Story, Screenplay, Cinematography, and Editing: Lav Diaz / Production Design: Dante Perez / Sound: Jay Ramirez, Earl Drilon, and Arvie Bartolome / Produced by Sine Olivia Pilipinas / Cast: Roeder Camañag (Benjamin Agusan), Angeli Bayani (Catalina), Perry Dizon (Teodoro), Dante Perez, Sophia Aves, Soliman Cruz, Gemma Cuenca, At Maculangan, Jenny Guinto, Amalia Virtucio, Kalila Aguilos, and Lav Diaz

Drawn by longing, Filipino poet Benjamin Agusan returns to his native hometown of Padang in Bicol after spending years of traveling in Europe and living in Russia, publishing books, teaching, falling in love, and burying his son. He comes home to find the town devastated by a super typhoon and mudslides from Mount Mayon, the perfectly cone-shaped volcano, which was his muse as a young man. He finds that he has lost his family and loved ones to the natural disaster and reconnects with friends who have survived.

 

The nine-hour black-and-white film mainly features the wanderings of Agusan in the oddly beautiful and desolated landscape and his long-winding poetic and philosophical exchanges with friends, poet Teodoro and painter Catalina, about God, art, love, death, the social and political ills that beset the Philippines, and many other topics. The film is interspersed with Agusan’s surreal visions of his parents and his old loves, as well as a series of documentary-like interviews between a film crew and survivors of the actual super typhoon, which hit the Bicol region in 2006, and an ambiguous conclusion of torture.

Kagadanan sa Banwa an ning mga Engkanto won the Venice Horizons Special Mention Award in the 2007 Venice Film Festival; the Silver Hanoman prize and the Network for the Promotion of Asian Cinema (NETPAC) Prize for Best Asian Feature in the 2008 Jogja-NETPAC Asian Film Festival; the NETPAC Prize in the 2008 Jeonju Film Festival; Best Achievement in Cinematography and Visual Design in the Young Critics Circle Film Desk Citations for 2007; and Best Production Design in the 2008 Gawad Urian.  Written by Patrick Campos

Charo Santos, Sandy Andolong, Christopher de Leon, and Jay Ilagan in Kakabakaba Ka Ba?, 1980

(Cesar Hernando)

text:
(Will Your Heart Beat Faster?) / 1980 / Color / Comedy, Musical / 104 minutes / Direction: Mike de Leon / Screenplay: Clodualdo del Mundo Jr, Raquel Villavicencio, and Mike de Leon / Cinematography: Rody Lacap / Editing: Ike Jarlego Jr / Production Design: Raquel Villavicencio / Art Direction: Noli Gamboa / Sound: Ramon Reyes / Music: Lorrie Ilustre / Choreography: Lea Locsin / Produced by LVN Pictures / Cast: Christopher de Leon (Johnny), Charo Santos (Melanie), Jay Ilagan (Nonong), Sandy Andolong (Nancy), Boboy Garovillo, Johnny Delgado, Armida Siguion-Reyna, Leo Martinez, Nannette Inventor, Moody Diaz, Joe Jardi, Danny Javier, George Javier, and the UP Concert Chorus

Kakabakaba Ka Ba? is an expressionistic, satirical comedy-musical on the misadventures of two pairs of lovers caught in the cross fire between warring agents of Japanese and Chinese drug traders.

 

 

The Japanese smuggle into the country a shipment of opium ingeniously packed in a cassette tape. Inadvertently, the tape lands in the pocket of Johnny, a young Filipino returning from Japan. The young man, his girl Melanie, and their friends Nonong and Nancy, who are also lovers, are hounded by the Japanese who seek to recover the contraband. The Chinese agents are also hot on their trail. Running for their lives, the lovers reach Baguio.

Hoping to find refuge, the lovers enter a church, only to find out that it is the headquarters of the Japanese syndicate. They uncover a plot by the syndicate to use fake priests and nuns for the large-scale distribution of opium in the country. The scheme is supposed to put the country under Japanese control. Finally, the Chinese agents penetrate the Japanese headquarters and a riotously funny battle ensues: the Chinese against the Japanese and both against the Filipinos. The Filipinos win and the lovers get married.

Kakabakaba Ka Ba? was a comeback production both for LVN Pictures, which had been inactive for several years, and for de Leon, who made the film after a three-year hiatus. The film was considered by critics as one of the landmark films of the 1980s in its absurdist, comical, and irreverent treatment of an otherwise serious theme about foreign control of the Philippine economy. It had to hurdle the censors, who originally sought to ban the film for its alleged racist attacks against the Japanese and the Chinese.

Kakabakaba Ka Ba? won the Gawad Urian for Best Director, Best Supporting Actor (Delgado), Best Music, Best Editing, and Best Sound.  Written by Menchie R. Tajan

Kakabakaba Ka Ba? won the Gawad Urian for Best Director, Best Supporting Actor (Delgado), Best Music, Best Editing, and Best Sound.

article_title: Kano: An American and His Harem
text:
2010 / Color / Documentary / 79 minutes / Direction: Monster Jimenez / Cinematography: Ike Avellana and Jay Abello / Editing: Mario Cornejo, Lawrence Ang, and Monster Jimenez / Sound: Corinne de San Jose / Music: Allan Feliciano / Produced by Arkeofilms

The film tells the horrific yet fascinating story of Victor Pearson, a decorated American Vietnam War soldier who was discharged due to post-traumatic stress disorder. With his pension from the United States government, Pearson decided to live out his retirement in a remote and poor area in Ilog, Negros Occidental. In his resort-like haven, Pearson housed several women with ages ranging from 11 to 35. When stories of his harem spread, he was arrested and charged with raping a 14-year-old girl. The police also found VHS tapes showing Pearson having sex with various women. He was then convicted and sentenced to 80 years in prison. While this may appear to be nothing more than the profile of a sexual deviant and pedophile, Jimenez nevertheless creates acomplex portrait of a troubled man that challenges stereotypes.She also gives equal time to the women, and some of the wives, who came todepend on and even love Pearson, the Amerikano or “Kano” who gave them a sense of financial and emotional security even as he also patronized and abused them.

The film won Best Documentary in the Young Cinema Competition of the 2010 Cinemanila International Film Festival and Best Documentary in the 2011 Gawad Urian. It also won in the First Appearance section of the International Documentary Film Festival in Amsterdam in 2010.  Written by Elvin Valerio

text:
(Of the Flesh) / 1983 / Color / Drama / 123 minutes / Direction: Marilou Diaz-Abaya / Screenplay: Ricardo Lee / Cinematography: Manolo Abaya / Editing: Marc Tamate / Production Design: Fiel Zabat / Sound: Rudy Baldovino / Music: Ryan Cayabyab / Produced by Cine Suerte/ Cast: Phillip Salvador (Narcing), Vic Silayan (Gusting), Cecille Castillo (Puring), Joel Torre (Goryo), Charito Solis (the narrator), Grace Amilbangsa (Doray), Crispin Medina, Joonee Gamboa, Rolando Tinio, Ella Luansing, Rustica Carpio, and Vangie Labalan

A middle-aged spinster, serving as the narrator, unfolds the tragic drama of a prominent family ruled by a wealthy landowner.

Newlyweds Narcing and Puring arrive from the city to settle in the groom’s hometown of Mulawin. His father, Gusting, is struck by Puring’s resemblance to his dead wife. The similarity drives Gusting to lust after his daughter-in-law. He makes sexual advances toward Puring, who shows her resentment by egging Narcing on to become more assertive. At the same time, she has to put up with the barrio folks’ indignation over her friendship with a deaf-mute, Goryo. In the violent family quarrel that ensues, Narcing attacks his father with a long hunting knife, decapitating him in the process.

 

While her husband is in jail, Puring gives birth to a freak daughter, which the barrio folk consider a child of the devil. After burying her child to escape a doomed existence, Puring flees back to the city with Narcing, who has escaped from jail. But the authorities catch up with him and he commits suicide.

The storyteller reveals her identity as the niece of Narcing and Puring. Her mother, Doray, was Narcing’s sister. Forced by her father into a marriage not of her own choice, Doray eventually escaped from the family home with her lover. She, too, was a victim of the family’s entrapment in the past.

Karnal won six Gawad Urian trophies: Best Actor (Salvador), Best Supporting Actor (Silayan), Best Supporting Actress (Solis), Best Cinematography, Best Production Design, and Best Music. It won Best Director, Best Supporting Actress, and Best Production Design in the Film Academy of the Philippines Awards. The Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences honored it with the Best Picture, Best Director, Best Supporting Actor, Best Musical Score, Best Production Design, and Best Sound awards.  Written by Lena S. Pareja

text:
(Partner, Participant, Partaker) / 2006 / Color / Comedy / 100 minutes / Direction: Jose Javier Reyes / Screenplay: Jose Javier Reyes and Mary Ann Bautista / Cinematography: Monchie Redoble / Editing: Vito Cajili / Production Design: Willy Urbino / Art Direction: Bert Habal / Sound: Albert Michael Idioma / Music: Jesse Lucas / Produced by Malou N. Santos and Charo Santos-Concio for Star Cinema / Cast: Judy Ann Santos (Angie), Ryan Agoncillo (Jed), Gina Pareño (Belita), Gloria Diaz (Charito), Ariel Ureta (Carlo), Derek Ramsay (Ronnie), Tuesday Vargas (Kaye), Soliman Cruz (Rommel), Lui Villaruz (Erwin), Kat Alano (Sandra), and Juliana Palermo (Mariel)

Jed and Angie meet and fall in love despite their many differences: Jed is from a traditional rich family while Angie comes from a lower middle-class, single-parent household. Their whirlwind romance meets its first challenge when Jed’s parents force him to go to the United States for good. Bucking the odds, Jed and Angie decide to get married, notwithstanding their own families’ interference with their planned wedding. As the newlyweds learn to adjust to married life while figuring out each other’s quirks and habits, they also continue to suffer from the incessant meddling of their parents. The couple then decides to move out of Jed’s parents’ house and live on their own, despite the financial impracticalities this presents. Their marriage is further complicated by Angie’s pregnancy, her mood swings, and later on by Jed being caught cheating on Angie. Angie packs her bags and leaves Jed to figure out his mistakes. Jed tries to apologize before Angie goes into labor and gives birth to their son. As Angie and Jed, now mom and dad, discuss their marriage while they cradle their newborn at the hospital, they realize that it is their first wedding anniversary, and so decide to reconcile and start anew.

Kasal, Kasali, Kasalo received nine awards from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences in 2007—namely, Best Picture, Best Director, Best Screenplay, Best Story, Best Actress (Santos), Best Supporting Actress (Pareño), Best Editing, Best Musical Score, and Best Theme Song. It won six Luna awards from the Film Academy of the Philippines: Best Picture, Best Director, Best Screenplay, Best Actress, Best Supporting Actress, and Best Editing. The film also won the Gatpuno Antonio J. Villegas Cultural Award, 2nd Best Picture, Best Director, Best Screenplay, Best Actress, and Best Supporting Actress in the 2006 Metro Manila Film Festival. A blockbuster hit, Kasal, Kasali, Kasalo was followed up by Sakal, Sakali, Saklolo (Strangle, Perchance, Help) in 2007, also directed by Reyes and starring the same cast.  Written by Anne Frances Sangil

text:
(The Execution of P.) / 2009 / Color / Drama / 105 minutes / Direction: Brillante Mendoza / Screenplay: Armando Lao / Cinematography: Odyssey Flores / Editing: Kats Serraon / Production Design: Brillante Mendoza / Art Direction: Harley Alcasid and Deans Habal / Sound: Albert Michael Idioma / Music: Teresa Barrozo / Produced by Swift Productions and Centerstage Productions Philippines / Cast: Coco Martin (Peping), John Regala (Sarge), Maria Isabel Lopez (Madonna), Julio Diaz (Kap), Jhong Hilario (Abyong), Mercedes Cabral (Cecille), Alan Paule (Leo), Ping Medina (Bong), and Susan Africa (Socorro)

 

Peping, a criminology student and a newlywed, helps his friend Abyong collect “protection” money from street vendors. As the night wears on, Abyong asks Peping to join him in a job supervised by Kap and Sarge. Hoping to earn some money, Peping joins them. Little does he know that the job is the kidnapping of a prostitute named Madonna, who has refused to pay her debts to Kap’s group. Gagged inside the van, Madonna is beaten up, much to the shock of Peping who stays quiet in the backseat. The group brings the woman to a “safehouse” outside Manila. All this time Peping is silent, fearful of the company he keeps. Kap asks the boys to buy some beer at a nearby store. As Peping wanders off from Abyong and the others, he sees a bus waiting for passengers at a nearby terminal. Peping boards the bus, but his attempt to escape is interrupted by a phone call from Abyong, wondering where he has gone. Peping returns to the men and is given a gun, apparently a gift from Kap. The men go back to the safehouse, and Peping is asked to keep watch over Madonna. After a short while, one of the men enters the room and rapes Madonna. Then she is murdered and chopped to pieces. Peping helps the men clean up the crime scene; then they all leave the house and go back to the city, throwing body parts along the way. The group eats breakfast at a small restaurant; Peping excuses himself to go to the bathroom where he throws up. He then asks Kap’s permission to leave so he can finally go home. Kap gives him some money and Peping hails a cab. As Peping dozes off inside the taxi, a loud popping sound wakes him up. The cab has a flat tire. Peping realizes that his gun is still inside his bag; he tries to flag other rides to no avail. The taxi driver replaces his tire and Peping rides back with him. The movie ends with Peping’s wife Cecille cooking breakfast while taking care of their child.

The film won Best Director for Brillante Mendoza in the 2009 Cannes Film Festival; Best Director and Best Original Soundtrack in the 2009 Sitges Catalonian Film Festival; and Best Picture, Best Director, and Best Sound in the 2010 Gawad Urian. It was also chosen by the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino as one of the 10 Best Films of the Decade 2000-2009.  Written by Anne Frances Sangil

Charo Santos and Charito Solis in Kisapmata, 1981

(Cesar Hernando)

text:
(Blink of an Eye) / 1981 / Color / Drama / 90 minutes / Direction: Mike de Leon / Story: Nick Joaquin / Screenplay: Clodualdo del Mundo Jr, Raquel N. Villavicencio, Mike de Leon / Cinematography: Rody Lacap / Editing: Jess Navarro / Production Design: Cesar Hernando / Sound: Ramon Reyes / Music: Lorrie Ilustre / Produced by Rolando S. Atienza for Bancom Audiovision Corporation / Cast: Vic Silayan (Dadong Carandang), Charo Santos (Mila), Charito Solis (Aling Dely), Jay Ilagan (Noel Manalansan), Ruben Rustia, Aida Carmona, and Juan Rodrigo

 

Kisapmata is the gripping tale of a father’s incestuous relationship with his daughter that ends in tragedy. Dadong Carandang, a retired police officer, is so possessive of his daughter, Mila, that he never allows her to entertain suitors. Although angered by Mila’s revelation of her pregnancy, Dadong allows her to marry Noel Manalansan after his unreasonable demands for a dowry are met. Dadong asks Mila and Noel to spend their wedding night and the days thereafter in the Carandang house, on the pretext that Aling Dely, Mila’s mother, is sick. Coming back late one evening, Noel finds himself locked out of the house. Indignant, he confronts Dadong the following day but leaves without Mila, who has been cowed into staying. Noel tries to call Mila but his efforts are frustrated by his father-in-law. Mila plans to escape but is dissuaded by her mother. Mila recalls how she was repeatedly raped by her father. Finally Mila outwits Dadong and manages to escape.

In a fit of rage, Dadong storms into the Manalansan house. He goes home fuming mad because the couple have fled. He threatens to kill his wife Dely if she does not bring Mila back. Frightened, Dely pleads with Noel’s father to speak with Dadong. An apparently apologetic Dadong persuades Noel’s father to bring the newlyweds back to Manila. As soon as Mila and Noel are back in the Manalansan house, Dadong urges Mila to come home, saying her mother is again ill. Mila goes home with Noel, but only to pack her things. Dadong pleads with his daughter to stay, but she has made up her mind to leave. Deliberately, with icy desperation, Dadong takes out his gun and kills his wife, Noel, Mila, and, finally, himself.

Kisapmata was based on Nick Joaquin’s “The House on Zapote Street,” one of the feature articles anthologized in his book Reportage on Crime, 1977. The first major treatment of incest in a Filipino film, it was both a critical and box-office success. At the 1981 Metro Manila Film Festival, it won 10 awards: Best Picture, Best Director, Best Story, Best Screenplay, Best Actor (Silayan), Best Supporting Actor (Ilagan), Best Supporting Actress (Solis), Best Production Design, Best Editing, and Best Sound. The film also won the Gawad Urian for Best Actor, Best Supporting Actor, Best Supporting Actress, Best Cinematography, Best Production Design, Best Music, and Best Sound. Kisapmata was presented at the Directors’ Fortnight at the 1982 Cannes Film Festival and was adjudged by the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino as one of the 10 Best Films of the Decade.  Written by Menchie R. Tajan

text:
(The Bet Collector) / 2006 / Color / Drama / 98 minutes / Direction: Jeffrey Jeturian / Screenplay: Ralston Jover / Cinematography: Roberto Yñiguez / Editing: Jay Halili / Production Design: Leo Abaya / Sound: Ditoy Aguila / Music: Jerrold Tarog / Produced by MLR Films / Cast: Gina Pareño (Amy), Fonz Deza (Eli), Nanding Josef (Father Buboy), Domingo Landicho (Tatay Nick), Soliman Cruz, Joe Gruta, and Neil Ryan Sese

 

Amy is a kubrador, or bet collector, for jueteng, an illegal numbers game, in a shanty neighborhood. She is the breadwinner in her family, with a husband, a daughter, a son-in-law, and a grandchild to support. Her daily rounds are complicated by the cops who regularly arrest collectors like her. Covertly, these cops are also jueteng bettors who trust Amy with their betting money. Aside from her job as jueteng collector, Amy is also requested by the parish priest to collect donations for the dead. As she struggles to do both tasks, collecting bets for her bosses and charitable donations for the dead, she meanders through the mazelike chaos of the neighborhood, constantly haunted by the spirit of her son who died in the army.

Her routine picks up steam when she is sent by her jueteng supervisor to the drawing of numbers in a secret location. Punctuated by constant fears of being discovered by the police, the rigged drawing of winning numbers culminates when Amy assists a young man, a kubrador like herself, in collecting a huge payout from a rich influential man in some residential village. A problem arises at the end of the day when her husband Eli tells Amy that he forgot to surrender to her a winning bet made by a friend. Amy promises to fix the problem but accuses Eli of being a burdensome fool. The next day, Amy goes with the entire family to the cemetery to commemorate All Saints’ Day. Still furious at Eli, Amy leaves the family and witnesses a traffic altercation turned violent. Amy, grazed by a bullet shot by one of the men involved in the row, helps the young man who is shot next to her.

Kubrador won international Best Actress awards for Pareño at the 2006 Amiens International Film Festival, 2006 Brussels International Film Festival, and 2006 Cinefan New Delhi Festival. The film also won the Fédération Internationale de la Presse Cinématographique Award at the 2006 Moscow International Film Festival, the Network for the Promotion of Asian Cinema Award at the 2007 Brisbane International Film Festival, the Youth Jury Award (Special Mention) at the 2006 Valladolid International Film Festival in Spain, the Best Asian Film at the 2006 Cinefan New Delhi Festival, the Special Jury Prize for Best Asian Feature Film at the 7th Asiatica Filmmediale in Rome, the Lino Brocka Award at the 2006 Cinemanila International Film Festival, and the Gawad Urian for Best Picture, Best Director, Best Actress, Best Cinematography, and Best Production Design in 2007. It was also chosen by the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino as one of the 10 Best Films of the Decade 2000-2009.   Written by Anne Frances Sangil

article_title: Ang Lalaki sa Buhay ni Selya
text:
(The Man in Her Life) / 1997 / Color / Drama / 96 minutes / Direction: Carlos Siguion-Reyna / Screenplay: Bibeth Orteza / Cinematography: Yam Laranas / Editing: Manet A. Dayrit / Production Design: Joey Luna / Sound: Albert Michael Idioma / Music: Ryan Cayabyab / Produced by Reyna Films / Cast: Rosanna Roces (Selya), Ricky Davao (Dave), Allan Paule (Carding), Gardo Versoza (Bobby), and Eva Darren (Piling)

Selya is a young schoolteacher who is in a sexual relationship with Bobby, a salesman. She wants a more permanent relationship with Bobby, but Bobby refuses to commit himself and leaves her. Selya runs away to look for Bobby and ends up in a small town that Bobby frequently visits. There she meets Piling, a schoolteacher who also takes care of Dave, a closeted gay man who serves as the principal of the school owned by his family. Dave is secretly in a sexual relationship with Carding, making them the subject of vicious gossip among the homophobic townsfolk. Realizing that Selya does not know anything about Dave, Piling sets Selya up with Dave. Selya feels that things won’t end well as Dave is not interested in a sexual relationship, so she walks out on him even as he proposes to her. 2009 / Color / Drama / 85 minutes / Direction: Veronica B. Velasco / Story: Winston Villanueva Acuyong / Screenplay: Veronica B. Velasco and Jinky Laurel / Cinematography: Mo Zee / Editing: Veronica Velasco and Pablo Biglang-awa Jr / Production Design: Michaela Tatad and Giselle Andres / Sound: Andrew Millalos and Addis Tabong / Music: Dan Gil / Produced by Beinte Singko Mil Productions and Cinemalaya Foundation / Cast: Joey Paras (Wilson Nañawa), Jojit Lorenzo (Gareth Pugeda), JM de Guzman (Andoy Pamatid), Beverly Salviejo (Aling Suming), Debraliz Valesote, Dante Balois, Ness Roque, Andoy Ranay, Cecile Torre, Marlon Hofer, Rommel Luna, Malou Crisologo, Mark Meily, Bernard Laxa, Maricel Soriano, Alex Tiglao, Gina Lumauig, Kalila Aguilos, Jason Moss, Rita Iringan, Liza Lorena, Ronli Vergel de Dios, and Ricky Davao

 

Last Supper No. 3 is a satirical courthouse comedy on the disastrous relationship between bureaucracy, inefficiency, and a corrupt legal system. Wilson Nañawa is an assistant production designer who is tasked to look for a Last Supper image, a common décor in Filipino homes. He auditions dozens of Last Supper pieces of different makes and sizes, lined up by his neighbors who all hope to receive a thousand pesos each if their piece is picked out. Three of these become finalists. But Last Supper no. 3, a not so remarkable tapestry, owned by Gareth Pugeda and his mother, Aling Suming, is lost in the process. What follows is a series of misfortunes that befall Wilson, which appear absurd on the surface but are, in fact, based on a true story and the actual court records of Winston Villanueva Acuyong. Wilson, along with his assistant Andoy Pamatid, spends the next two years and two months of his life entangled in red tape and facing charges of swindling and serious physical injury. But Wilson is persistent, and he believes that justice is worth fighting for. He also gets to know Gareth and Aling Suming, who are also fighting for their own cause. In the end, Wilson and Andoy are acquitted.

Last Supper No. 3 won Best Film in the 2009 Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival.  Written by Patrick Campos

text:
(Wildflower) / 1976 / Color / Drama / Direction: Ishmael Bernal / Story and Screenplay: Edgardo Reyes (based on his novel Bulaklak ng Apoy serialized in Kislap magazine, 1972 / Cinematography: Arnold Alvaro / Editing: Edgardo Vinarao / Production Design: Betty Gosiengfiao / Music: Ernani Cuenco / Produced by Crown Seven Films / Cast: Vic Silayan, Alma Moreno, Yvonne, Marissa Delgado, Charina Alonzo, Anita Linda, Jun Mariano, Elvie Escarro, and Edgar Garcia

 

A young girl sells flowers in a cabaret, where she is lusted after by a young stud, who happens to be the son of the school principal. The girl is taken in by an old gardener, who tries to protect her from the world but at the same time secretly covets her in spite of his impotence caused by the war. She goes to grade school where morality and empty platitudes are mouthed. These teachings are foiled by the realities of the cabaret. Hence, the school and the old gardener attempt to guard the young girl’s innocence, but the cabaret has awakened her and continues to lure her, virgin that she is, into a sordid world. These two types of education mold the nymphet.

Ligaw na Bulaklak won for Vic Silayan his first major award as Gawad Urian Best Actor. The movie also garnered from Gawad Urian an award for Best Supporting Actress (Yvonne) and nominations for Best Supporting Actress (Delgado), Best Production Design, and Best Editing.  Written by Mauro Tumbocon

article_title: Ligaya ang Itawag Mo sa Akin
text:
(They Call Me Joy) / 1997 / Color / Drama / 105 minutes / Direction: Carlos Siguion-Reyna / Screenplay: Bibeth Orteza / Cinematography: Marissa Floirendo / Editing: Manet Dayrit / Production Design: Joey Luna / Sound: Ramon Reyes / Music: Ryan Cayabyab / Produced by Reyna Films / Cast: Rosanna Roces (Ligaya), Chanda Romero (Lolay), John Arcilla (Polding), Isabel Granada (Estela), Pen Medina (Tikyo), Eva Darren (Ima), Armida Siguion-Reyna, and Myrna Castillo

Ligaya is a prostitute who dreams of leaving the sex trade and leading a normal life. She and other prostitutes, including the young Estela who was sold by her own mother, work for Lolay in a countryside brothel. She has saved enough money to start anew and is already planning to leave, but she does not really have a place to go. One day, a customer, the farmer Polding, is smitten by Ligaya and wants her for himself. He offers her a respectable life outside of the whorehouse, as his wife. Ligaya accepts the offer, and she moves in with him. But she finds out soon enough that society will not easily let a prostitute off the hook. She is denounced by Polding’s mother, Ima, and humiliated by her clients in the past. Polding’s stepfather, Tikyo, who sees Ligaya as an easy girl, rapes her. Most tragically, Polding, too, cannot see Ligaya any differently, and abuses her.

Ligaya returns to her old life in the brothel. Estela, who is now planning to leave the trade, asks Ligaya to come with her, but Ligaya, this time, refuses. She decides, instead, to stay with Lolay who, while trapped in her own whorehouse, considers the trade her strength. In her later years, however, Ligaya succumbs to insanity, still dreaming of a better life.

Ligaya ang Itawag Mo sa Akin won for Isabel Granada the Best Supporting Actress trophy in the 1998 Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Awards. It won for John Arcilla the Best Supporting Actor trophy in the 1998 Gawad Urian of the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino. The film also won Best Musical Score in the 1998 Film Academy of the Philippines Awards, as well as Musical Scorer of the Year and Movie Theme Song of the Year in the 1998 PMPC Star Awards for Movies.  Written by Patrick Campos

Marcus Madrigal and Ana Capri in Live Show, 2001

(Cesar Hernando Collection)

text:
2001 / Color / Drama / 110 minutes / Direction and Screenplay: Jose Javier Reyes / Cinematography: Eduardo Jacinto / Editing: Vito Cajili / Production Design: Jake de Asis / Sound: Albert Michael Idioma / Music: Jesse Lucas / Produced by Regal Films / Cast: Paolo Rivero (Rolly), Ana Capri (Rosita), Klaudia Koronel (Gigi), Hazel Espinosa (Sandra), Daria Ramirez (Elma), Simon Ibarra (Vio), and Marcus Madrigal

 

This film depicts the sad plight of various torero or live sex performers. Rolly, the film’s cynical narrator, has no regrets about his job as a torero even as he watches his mother, Elma, herself a former prostitute, die of cancer. He is surrounded by his friends Gigi, a tough-talking yet kindhearted torera; Rosita, Gigi’s suicidal roommate; and Sandra, a retired torera, and her husband and former live sex partner, Vio. Gigi dreams of going to Japan, but that dream is crushed when the money she has saved and entrusted to a friend is stolen. Rosita hopes to meet her son whom she gave up for adoption but is vehemently turned away by the boy’s adoptive mother. Sandra and Vio struggle to provide for their young child and soon decide to go back to their old job as live sex performers. As the seemingly hopeless lives of each character unfold, Rolly resolves to let go of any dreams he may have and accept his and his friends’ doomed fate.

Originally titled Toro, Live Show was among the last films to be approved for screening by the Movie and Television Review and Classification Board (MTRCB) under Armida Siguion-Reyna in 2000 but was shown only in February 2001 after EDSA People Power II and Gloria Macapagal Arroyo’s ascent to power. Within days of its release, Live Show received harsh criticism from conservative groups, particularly the Roman Catholic Church. To appease the Church, President Arroyo ordered the recall and banning of the film, which resulted in an uproar and the clash between those who favored Reyes’s honest depiction of the lives of live sex performers and those who saw his film as sheer pornography. Furthermore, Nicanor Tiongson, a highly respected cultural critic/scholar who was the newly appointed chair of the MTRCB at the time, resigned from his post as an act of protest against the pressure by the government and the Church to stop the showing of the film.

Live Show was shown at the Panorama section of Berlin International Film Festival where it received rave reviews from both critics and audiences.  Written by Elvin Valerio

article_title: Liwayway ng Kalayaan / Dawn of Freedom
text:
(Dawn of Freedom) / 1944 / Black and White / Action, Drama / Direction: Yutaka Abe and Gerardo de Leon / Story: Yutaka Abe and Denjiro Odochi / Screenplay: Ryichiro Yagi and Hideo Kokumi / Cinematography: Giyu Miyajima and Higino Fallorina / Produced by Toho for release through Eiga Haikyusha / Cast: Leopoldo Salcedo (Captain Reyes), Fernando Poe (Captain Gomez), Angel Esmeralda (Lieutenant Garcia), Ricardo Pasion (Tony), Denjiro Okochi, Seisaburo Kawazu, Ichiro Tsukata, Bert Le Roy, Rosa Aguirre, Norma Blancaflor, Franco Garcia, Guillermo Carlos, and Tessie Quintana

On Christmas Eve, 1941, Manila is declared an open city and everyone is directed to stay at home. That evening Filipino soldiers, with the United States Armed Forces in the Far East (USAFFE), bid their families goodbye to join the troops in Bataan. Captain Gomez reassures his sweetheart that he will return, while his neighbor, Lieutenant Garcia, allays the worst fears of his mother and promises to bring home a helmet as a souvenir for his younger brother, Tony.

 

The Filipino soldiers in Bataan are treated harshly by their American officers. Captain Reyes protests the abuses suffered by his men. He is sent out on a patrol mission, unaware that secret orders have been given to an American sergeant to kill him. His death is avenged by Lieutenant Garcia. The Japanese forces enter Manila and are welcomed by the citizens. Tony, a hit-and-run victim, is abandoned by the retreating Americans. A Japanese officer saves his life. Tony’s mother is so grateful that she personally sends out an appeal to her other son, Lieutenant Garcia, and the Filipino soldiers in Bataan, to lay down their arms and return to their homes, because the Japanese are their friends and not their enemies as they had been misled to believe.

Captain Gomez heeds the call and defects to the Japanese side. Over a microphone, he urges his fellow Filipino soldiers to stop fighting the Japanese. He volunteers to join the assault on Corregidor but is told that only Japanese soldiers can go on that dangerous mission. The film ends with the victory of the Japanese and the unconditional surrender of the American forces in Bataan and Corregidor under General Wainwright. As he surveys the battlefield, Captain Gomez comes across the dead soldier, Lieutenant Garcia, still clutching the US Army helmet intended for his brother, Tony, with the scribbled message that it is the helmet of the enemy.

Liwayway ng Kalayaan, as an instrument of propaganda, had a threefold aim: to unmask the Americans as the real enemies and thus eradicate their influence on the Filipino people, to emphasize Japan’s role as the leader in the Greater East Asia Co-Prosperity Sphere, and to recover the native Asian character that Filipinos had lost after centuries of Western colonization. Actual footage of the Bataan and Corregidor campaigns was used to document Japanese gains during the Pacific War. The film was first shown in Tokyo on 5 Feb 1944 under the title Ano Hatta o Utte (Tear Down the Stars and Stripes). The Philippine premiere was held a month later in Manila on 7 Mar 1944.  Written by Lena S. Pareja

Anita Linda and Rustica Carpio in Lola, 2009

(Photo courtesy of Brillante Mendoza)

text:
(Grandmother) / 2009 / Color / Drama / 110 minutes / Direction: Brillante Mendoza / Screenplay: Linda Casimiro / Cinematography: Odyssey Flores / Editing: Kats Serraon / Production Design: Dante Mendoza / Art Direction: Harley Alcasid / Sound: Albert Michael Idioma, Addis Tabong / Music: Teresa Barrozo / Produced by Swift Productions in cooperation with Center Stage Productions / Cast: Anita Linda (Lola Sepa), Rustica Carpio (Lola Puring), Ketchup Eusebio (Mateo Burgos), Tanya Gomez, and Jhong Hilario

 

Lola Sepa is grief-stricken over the death of her grandson who was killed by a thief, Mateo Burgos, the grandson of a vegetable vendor, Lola Puring. Seeking justice, Lola Sepa files a criminal case against Mateo. As she waits for updates about the case, Lola Sepa goes around her flooded community to ask for monetary donations for her grandson’s funeral. Lola Puring, on the other hand, goes to the Public Attorney’s Office to seek help for the release of her grandson. Counseled by the lawyer to pursue an amicable settlement with the complainant, Lola Puring goes to her relatives to raise money, telling them that her grandson Mateo was the one who was stabbed by a thief and needs immediate operation. She sells the eggs and vegetables given to her by relatives, pawns a television set, and mortgages their home to come up with the money for an amicable settlement. She also learns how to cheat the passersby who buy vegetables from her. Lola Puring meets Lola Sepa and the latter’s family at a restaurant, and the two women share stories about their late husbands and their own health concerns. Lola Sepa accepts the money and agrees to drop her complaint against Mateo. As the case is resolved, the two lola go their separate ways with their own families.

The film won the Muhr Award for Best Feature Film in Africa and Asia in the 2009 Dubai International Film Festival; the Crystal Simorgh Award for Best Film and Performance (Linda and Carpio) in the 29th Fajr International Film Festival in Iran in 2011; the Ecumenical Jury and the Don Quijote awards in the 2010 Fribourg International Film Festival in Switzerland; Best Film in the 8th Rome Asian Film Festival in 2010; the Golden Lady Harmiguada Grand Prize, the Best Cinematography, and the Ex Aequo Best Actress (Linda and Carpio) awards at the 11th Las Palmas de Gran Canaria International Film Festival in Spain in 2011; and the Grand Knight Jury Prize at the 2010 Miami Film Festival. Lola also won Best Screenplay, Best Actress (Linda and Carpio), and Best Production Design in the 2010 Gawad Urian, and included in the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino’s 10 Best Films of the Decade 2000-2009.  Written by Anne Frances Sangil

text:
2007 / Color / Drama / 120 minutes / Direction: Maryo J. de los Reyes / Screenplay: Vanessa R. Valdez / Cinematography: Gary L. Gardoce / Editing: Tara Illenberger / Production Design: Gerry Santos / Sound: Albert Michael Idioma / Music: Jesse Lucas / Produced by Star Cinema / Cast: Maricel Soriano (Joanna Villanueva), Aga Muhlach (Ian Montes), Angelica Panganiban (Karyn Torres), Dante Rivero, Chin Chin Gutierrez, Mark Gil, Bobby Andrews, TJ Trinidad, Baron Geisler, John Arcilla, Gerald Madrid, Bart Guingona, Eva Darren, and Anita Linda

A Love Story revolves around a love triangle between Ian Montes, Joanna Villanueva, and Karyn Torres. Ian, the son of a shipping tycoon, becomes a successful real estate businessman in his own right. When his mother leaves them, Ian is driven by the desire to be more successful than his father, whose continuing love for his mother Ian could not understand and forgive. And yet, deep inside, he yearns for his father’s approval and the stability of his love. On a business trip to Macau, Ian meets Karyn, a flight attendant, who allows him to be spontaneous and carefree. For the first time he feels loved. They eventually marry. But Ian craves the constancy of domesticity, which Karyn cannot seem to satisfy. Later, in a water-skiing accident in La Union, he meets the doctor Joanna, who affectionately nurses him back to health. Joanna comes from a failed marriage and yet falls for Ian. She and Ian begin an affair. In the end, Ian, Karyn, and Joanna make a decision to set things right.

A Love Story departs from the typical love triangle, in that the rightful wife is young and sensual, while the other woman is mature and nurturing. The expectations derived from conventional love triangle dramas are played up in the film with the twists in nonlinear storytelling. A Love Story won Best Picture, Best Director, Best Screenplay, Best Supporting Actor (Rivero), and Best Supporting Actress (Panganiban) in the 2008 Film Academy of the Philippines Awards. It won Best Director, Best Editing, and Best Musical Score in the 2008 Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Awards. It won Movie Original Screenplay of the Year in the 2008 PMPC Star Awards for Movies.  Written by Patrick Campos
