text:
(Dark Victory) / 1956 / Black and White / Drama / Direction: Gregorio Fernandez / Story: Mike Velarde (as inspired by Sergei Rachmaninoff’s 2nd Piano Concerto) / Screenplay: Mike Velarde and Consuela O. Padilla / Cinematography: Remigio Young / Editing: Enrique Jarlego / Sound: Ben Patajo / Music: Francisco Buencamino Jr / Produced by LVN Pictures / Cast: Jaime de la Rosa (Ricardo Llamas), Delia Razon (Anita), Rebecca del Rio (Lucy), Eddie Rodriguez (Major Bustamante), Oscar Obligacion, Leonora Ruiz, Fe Galvez, Joseph de Cordova, Alfonso Carvajal, Oscar Keesee, and Manuel Silos

 

Anita has waited for years for her husband, Major Bustamante, who has been reported missing in the Korean War. Presuming her husband dead, she finally agrees to marry someone else, Dr Ricardo Llamas. One day, Bustamante returns. Dr Llamas gives way to him, treats his failing eyes, and goes back to the province. Bustamante starts to enjoy what he missed during his wartime service. In a night club he meets Lucy, former girlfriend of Dr Llamas, who tells him of his wife’s infidelity. He becomes angry and schemes with Lucy to blind Anita. Dr Llamas discovers the plot and warns Anita. The doctor subsequently finds the major dying after a violent altercation with Lucy. Dr Llamas is accused of murder, but the timely confession of Lucy saves him.

Luksang Tagumpay is one of the few movies by master filmmaker Gregorio Fernandez that have survived. Despite its hackneyed plot, the film shows the masterful touches that have made Fernandez’s films truly significant, particularly in the editing of the last scenes where the hero is snatched from the electric chair. The film won the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences awards for Best Picture and Best Cinematography.  Written by Agustin L. Sotto

text:
(Perfumed Nightmare) / 1977 / Color / Comedy, Drama / 93 minutes / Direction, Screenplay, and Editing: Kidlat Tahimik (nom de cinema of Eric de Guia) / Cinematography: Hermut Lerch and Kidlat Tahimik / Music: Philippine Traditional Music / Musical Arrangement: Kristan Muller / Produced by Kidlat Tahimik / Cast: Dolores Santamaria, Mang Fely, and Kidlat Tahimik.

In this 16 mm feature-length color film, a jeepney driver from Balian, Laguna, dreams of visiting Cape Canaveral, the center of the American space program. He also wishes to see his idol, rocket scientist Werner von Braun, who is in Europe. On his journey, he wants to take his jeepney with him. He is transported by a fluke to the West (principally Paris and then Bavaria), where he pursues his fascination for things that range from rocketships to onions and yo-yos. In Paris, he accepts an offer to operate a chewing-gum business. He sees it as one way of ultimately fulfilling his dream. The process may be circuitous, but it is certain to get him there. Throughout his metaphysical meanderings, he muses on the varied aspects of technology and racial temper.

Mababangong Bangungot seeks to question the myth of technology as progress, a theme recurrent in Kidlat Tahimik’s films. He delves into the reality of alien dominance, which is not only economic but cultural, even spiritual. The film takes a seriocomic look at the Filipino’s loss of self-worth because of colonization, in a manner that a critic has described as “digestible.”

The film brought to the attention of both Filipinos and foreigners the existence and capability of Philippine alternative cinema. It was shown at the Young Filmmakers Forum of the 1977 Berlin Film Festival, where it won the Fédération Internationale de la Presse Cinématographique (FIPRESCI) jury prize and a special mention from the Organization Catholique Internationale du Cinema et de L’Audiovisual (OCIC).  Written by Lena S. Pareja

text:
(Stepmother) / 1996 / Color / Drama / 120 minutes / Direction: Olivia M. Lamasan / Screenplay: Ricardo Lee and Olivia M. Lamasan / Cinematography: Joe Batac / Editing: John David Hukom / Production Design: Jayjay Medina / Art Direction: James Wright Price and Jude Quinito / Sound: Ronald de Asis,  Bongbong Dimaano, Albert Michael Idioma / Music: Willy Cruz / Produced by Star Cinema / Cast: Sharon Cuneta (Mariel), Christopher de Leon (Edward), Zsa Zsa Padilla (Sandra), Claudine Barretto (Rachel), Patrick Garcia (Ryan), Camille Prats (Liza), Nida Blanca, Eula Valdez, Rico Yan, Tita Muñoz, Teresa Loyzaga, Koko Trinidad, Cris Villanueva, and Vangie Labalan

Mariel marries Edward, a single dad with three kids, Rachel, Ryan, and Liza. As Mariel finds herself adjusting to married life, she also finds herself adapting to a ready-made family, which is not too keen on having her as the stepmom. Things do not improve even after Mariel gets pregnant and later on gives birth to Mikey, the fourth child in the family. After a heated argument with Edward concerning her issues with the children, Mariel leaves Edward. She decides to live with her mother, who advises her to keep on working at their marriage, which Mariel does.

But just when things seem to turn for the better, Sandra, the former wife of Edward, returns after many years of absence. Sandra’s reappearance aggravates Mariel’s low self-esteem, further underscoring her second-class status in the family. Sandra, who now has her own family, reveals that she has returned to bring Ryan with her to America. Edward contests Sandra’s wish, and as Sandra becomes witness to Mariel’s affection for her children, she lets go of Ryan, happy with the knowledge that her children are in good hands with Mariel. As the film ends, not only has Mariel adjusted perfectly to Edward’s family, but Edward and his children have accepted Mariel as a significant part of their lives, despite her pejorative title, madrasta.

The film won several awards—namely, the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences awards for Best Actress (Cuneta) and Best Child Actor (Garcia); the Film Academy of the Philippines awards for Best Actress and Best Original Song; the Gawad Urian for Best Actress; the PMPC Star Awards for Actor of the Year (de Leon), Actress of the Year, and Movie Theme Song of the Year; and the Young Critics Circle Film Desk’s citation for Best Performance (de Leon). The movie also performed well at the box office, earning for Cuneta the Guillermo Mendoza Memorial Scholarship Foundation Box-Office Queen Award for 1996.  Written by Anne Frances Sangil

text:
1996 / Color / Fantasy, Adventure / 106 minutes / Direction and Screenplay: Peque Gallaga and Lore Reyes / Story: Peque Gallaga, Lore Reyes, and Erik Matti / Cinematography: Joe Tutanes / Editing: Danilo Gloria / Production Design: Rodell Cruz / Sound: Albert Michael Idioma / Music: Archie Castillo / Special Effects: Benny S. Batoctoy, Nestor Yadao, and Danette L. Melocoto / Produced by Star Cinema / Cast: Jason Salcedo (Jubal), Junell Hernando (Sambag), Marc Solis (Omar), Anna Larrucea (Yasmin), Jun Urbano (Sifu), Jackie Lou Blanco (Ravenal), Aljon Jimenez (Rexor), Gina Pareño, Cholo Escaño, Koko Trinidad, Sydney Sacdalan, and Chubi del Rosario

 

Magic Temple is an adventure film set in magical worlds. The wise teacher Sifu searches for young and able children who have special powers, so that he could train them to use their powers for good. He finds Jubal, whose power is flight; Sambag, who can talk to animals; and Omar, who can spit fire. But Sifu refuses to train the arrogant Rexor, who thinks he has nothing else to learn, because his power exceeds the other three children’s capabilities. During their trainings, a messenger arrives and tells Sifu that the neighboring kingdom of Samadhi is threatened by the evil forces ofthe powerful Ravenal. Sifu sends the children to a journey to the Magic Temple in order to find a crystal that would save Samadhi. Along the way, they fight with different creatures. Rexor appears again as a treacherous enemy who has sided with evil, and he is able to capture Sambag and Omar. But Jubal and Sifu, disguised as a Shaolin kid, are able to rescue the two. Together, with courage and camaraderie, as well as the help of some newfound friends along the way, including Yasmin, the three children are able to save the day and triumph over evil.

Magic Temple premiered in the 1996 Metro Manila Film Festival, where it received all the major awards, including Best Picture, Best Director, Best Original Story, Best Screenplay, Best Production Design, Best Cinematography, Best Editing, Best Musical Score, Best Original Theme Song, Best Visual Effects, Best Makeup, Best Sound Recording, and the Gatpuno Antonio J. Villegas Cultural Award. It also won Best Sound in the 1997 Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Awards. A sequel to Magic Temple, titled Magic Kingdom, was produced the following year.  Written by Patrick Campos

text:
2003 / Color / Drama / 120 minutes / Direction: Maryo J. de los Reyes / Screenplay: Michiko Yamamoto / Cinematography: Odyssey Flores / Editing: Manet Dayrit / Production Design: Gerry Santos / Art Direction: Bobet Lopez / Sound: Aurel Claro Bilbao / Music: Lutgardo Labad / Produced by Violett Films Production / Cast: Jiro Manio (Magnifico), Lorna Tolentino (Edna), Albert Martinez (Gerry), Gloria Romero (Lola Magda), Celia Rodriguez (Ka Doring), Mark Gil (Domeng), Tonton Gutierrez (Ka Romy), Amy Austria (Tessie), Cherry Pie Picache (Cristy), Danilo Barrios (Miong), Isabella de Leon (Helen), Girlie Sevilla (Isang), and Susan Africa (Pracing)

 

A second son is born to Gerry and Edna. Gerry names him “Magnifico” after a magician who performed at the town carnival. As the boy grows up, he learns to deal with his family’s financial difficulties, aggravated by the illness of his younger sister and the terminal condition of his grandmother recently diagnosed with pancreatic cancer. Realizing that his family will need a huge amount of money for his grandmother’s imminent burial, Magnifico decides to construct a coffin out of wood scraps he is able to get for free from a local entrepreneur. With the help of his best friend, Magnifico also sells water and juice at the newly arrived carnival, hoping to earn more money for other burial-related expenditures and save some cash on the side so he could rent a wheelchair for his sister. As Magnifico works on his coffin project, he does odd jobs and favors for his neighbors, thereby affecting the lives of other people in his community. But one day Magnifico meets a fatal accident while crossing the street. In the end, the coffin Magnifico made for his grandmother is used for the boy’s own burial, and the entire town comes in droves to pay their last respects to the boy who touched their lives in so many ways.

Magnifico won several awards from both local and international award-giving bodies—namely, Best Picture, Best Director, Best Story, Best Supporting Actor (Gil), Best Supporting Actress (Rodriguez), Best Child Actor (Manio), and Best Child Actress (de Leon) in the 2004 Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Awards; Best Picture, Best Director, Best Screenplay, Best Actor (Manio), Best Supporting Actress (Romero), and Best Musical Score in the 2004 Film Academy of the Philippines Awards; Best Picture, Best Director, Best Screenplay, Best Actor (Manio), Best Supporting Actor (Martinez), Best Supporting Actress (Romero), and Best Sound in the 2004 Gawad Urian; the Crystal Bear and the Deutsches Kinderhilfswerk Grand Prix awards in the 2004 Berlin International Film Festival. It was also chosen as one of the 10 Best Films of the Decade 2000-2009 by the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino. The film was also nominated for the Golden Maile Award in the 2003 Hawaii International Film Festival, and for the Crystal Globe Award in the 2003 Karlovy Vary International Film Festival.  Written by Anne Frances Sangil

text:
(Eternity) / 1983 / Color / Short Film (Super 8) / Direction, Story, and Cinematography: Raymond Red / Cast: Jon Red (Jose), Boy Lopez, and Lanie Canlas

This short film, which has 13 parts, each with its own title card, deals with a crime, the after-effects of that crime, and a cathartic escape. It begins with a dream sequence in which Jose dreams of himself as the crucified Christ. He wakes up very disturbed. He proceeds to a darkly lit office where he confers with a fat man. The latter reads Jose’s papers, the contents of which are unspecified but apparently offensive to the man. After drifting around, Jose returns to his house and dreams again. This time, the images are more haunting and demonic. Jose goes back to see the man in the office, and, frustrated and angry, kills him. He leaves the body, and his crime is undetected. A woman enters the room, discovers the body, takes the dead man’s wallet. Jose walks about the city once more, winding up in a church where he encounters a mysterious lady who follows him everywhere. The authorities eventually learn that Jose is the killer and they raid his house. Jose drinks a potion he has concocted, the “Magpakailanman.” The police find him dead, his mouth frothing. The film ends with the playful silhouette of the police marching, with the sunset in the background.

The strength of Ang Magpakailanman lies in its recognition of film as an instrument of abstraction. Red maximizes the expressive potentials of film by extending its capacity beyond merely reproducing images that articulate the unconscious. This short film won first prize at the University of the Philippines Film Center’s Third Manila Film Festival (experimental film category) and in the Experimental Cinema of the Philippines student film competition in 1983.  Written by Luna Sicat

text:
1993 / Color / Drama / Direction and Screenplay: Jose Javier Reyes / Cinematography: Jun Perreira / Editing: Edmund Jarlego / Production Design: Benjie de Guzman / Music: Nonong Buencamino / Produced by Regal Films / Cast: Maricel Laxa (Corinne Mayoralgo), Alma Moreno (Elsa), Chanda Romero (Bessie), Karla Estrada (Marilen), Gina Leviste (Stella), Carmina Villarroel (Lisette), William Martinez (Noli), Miguel Rodriguez (Bobby), Al Tantay (Leo), John Estrada (Dondi), Eric Fructuoso (Arnel), Nonie Mauricio (Philip), Cherry Pie Picache, Dingdong Dantes, and Marco Ballesteros

 

Corinne Mayoralgo, a senior manager in her family-owned company, is preparing for her wedding to Philip, an advertising executive. Corinne’s parents insist that they sign a prenuptial agreement as protection for Corinne. Feeling insulted, Philip backs out of the wedding, leaving Corinne depressed and almost suicidal. Corinne’s brother Bobby is a womanizer who is married to Stella, a jaded socialite who has come to accept her husband’s infidelity. Corinne’s assistant Bessie is a single mother to a teenage son, Arnel. Arnel is secretly in love with his friend Lisette, Philip’s younger sister. Elsa, one of Corinne’s secretaries, works doubly hard just to provide a comfortable life for her husband Leo and young son. When Elsa finds out that Leo is cheating on her, she leaves Leo and moves into an apartment with the help of her good friend Noli. Another secretary is the liberated Marilen, who feels that she has found Mr Right with her new boyfriend Dondi, a law student. Dondi, however, brings Marilen to an abandoned building and rapes her. In the end, Corinne gathers enough strength to confront Philip. She leaves him for good and resolves to move on with her life.

Makati Ave. (Office Girls) is Reyes’s tribute to National Artist Ishmael Bernal’s classic Working Girls, 1984. It won Best Picture, Best Director, Best Screenplay, and Best Editing at the 1994 Gawad Urian.  Written by Elvin Valerio

text:
1958 / Black and White / Drama / 101 minutes / Direction: Gregorio Fernandez / Story: Clodualdo del Mundo Sr (serialized in Espesyal Komiks) / Screenplay: Consuelo P. Osorio / Cinematography: Mike Accion / Editing: Enrique Jarlego / Music: Francisco Buencamino Jr / Produced by LVN Pictures / Cast: Charito Solis (Rosa), Carlos Padilla Jr (Alberto), Eddie Rodriguez (Avelino), Vic Silayan (Melanio), Vic Diaz (Leonides), Rey Ruiz (Vedasto), Leroy Salvador, Caridad Sanchez, Rebecca del Rio, Linda Roxas, Johnny Reyes, Priscilla Ramirez, Johnny Legarda, Ramon Olmos, and Levi Celerio

 

Rosa lives with her mother and father, and four older brothers in the slums. When their drunkard father is run over by a train and dies, their mother wastes away in guilt and melancholia. Rosa is engaged to be married, but she chooses to serve her family first. Rosa’s brothers go through their own agonies. Melanio is pursued by the women he has had affairs with and is arrested by the police. Alberto, who is driven away by the mother of the girl he loves, attempts to rape the girl and, frustrated, commits suicide. The crafty Vedasto persuades Rosa to work for a wealthy man who has designs on her. The violent Leonides kills a man and dies in a bloody encounter with the police. The youngest, Avelino, is the only brother who is patient and responsible enough to help Rosa bear the family’s burdens.

The action builds up when Rosa’s employer tries to rape her. She is saved by the arrival of her fiancé. Vedasto tries to cover his tracks by accusing Rosa of immorality. She attempts suicide, but once again the arrival of Avelino and her fiancé saves her. Meanwhile, her mother faints inside their burning hut. They rescue her, and Vedasto repents.

The film is classic Filipino melodrama but distinguished by artistry and acting. Del Rio, a familiar kontrabida (villain), subsequently won the 1958 Asian Film Festival Best Supporting Actress award for her performance in the film. In 1959, LVN received from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences the International Prestige Award for this film, considered one of the best melodramas of director Gregorio Fernandez.  Written by Luna Sicat

article_title: Manila Kingpin: The Asiong Salonga Story

photos.desc:
Jeorge Estregan, with Baron Geisler standing behind him, 

in Manila Kingpin: The Asiong Salonga Story, 2011

(Carlo Mendoza)

text:
2011 / Black and White / Action, Drama / 145 minutes / Direction: Tikoy Aguiluz (uncredited) / Story and Screenplay: Roy Iglesias and Rey Ventura / Cinematography: Carlo Mendoza / Editing: Jason Cahapay, Ryan Orduña, and Mirana Medina-Bhunjun / Production Design: Fritz Silorio and Mona Soriano / Art Direction: Mona Soriano / Sound: Albert Michael Idioma / Music: Jessie Lasaten / Produced by Viva Films, Scenema Concept International, and CMB Film Services / Cast: Jeorge “ER” Estregan (Nicasio “Asiong” Salonga), Carla Abellana, Phillip Salvador, John Regala, Baron Geisler, Ronnie Lazaro, Yul Servo, Dennis Padilla, Ketchup Eusebio, and Ping Medina

 

Manila Kingpin portrays the storied life of Nicasio “Asiong” Salonga as he rises from a small-time hoodlum to a notorious outlaw. Operating out of Tondo, Manila, Salonga steals from the rich and gives his booty to the poor, earning him the nickname “Robin Hood of Tondo.” Even as he plots various crimes, Salonga strives to be a good son, brother, husband, and friend. He grows in power and influence, inciting not only his rivals but also his own men to conspire against him, leading to the momentous shoot-out that fatally ends his career. Salonga’s life has been depicted on film thrice before, in the 1961 Asiong Salonga, starring Joseph Estrada; the 1978 Salonga, starring Rudy Fernandez; and the 1990 Asiong Salonga: Hari ng Tondo, also starring Jeorge “ER” Estregan, then known as Jorge Estregan Jr.

Controversy erupted around Manila Kingpin days before it was to be screened at the 2011 Metro Manila Film Festival (MMFF) when Aguiluz disowned it and demanded that his name be removed from the credits because the producers had opted to release a cut different from the one Aguiluz had made.

Manila Kingpin won Best Picture, Best Director, Best Screenplay, Best Supporting Actor (Regala), Best Cinematography, Best Production Design, Best Editing, Best Musical Score, Best Sound Recording, Best Original Theme Song, and the Gatpuno Antonio J. Villegas Cultural Award at the 2011 MMFF. It also won various awards in 2012 at the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Awards, the Luna Awards of the Film Academy of the Philippines, the Golden Screen Awards of the Entertainment Press Society, and the Star Awards for Movies of the Philippine Movie Press Club.  Written by Jaime Oscar M. Salazar

text:
(I Kiss Your Hand) / 2002 / Color / Drama / 110 minutes / Direction: Joel C. Lamangan / Story: Lily Y. Monteverde and Roy C. Iglesias / Screenplay: Roy C. Iglesias / Cinematography: Leslie Garchitorena / Editing: Tara Illenberger / Production Design: Tatus Aldana / Sound: Albert Michael Idioma / Music: Von de Guzman / Visual Effects: Marc Ambat / Produced by Regal Entertainment / Cast: Maricel Soriano (Vera), Richard Gomez (Raf), Ara Mina (Richelle), Kris Aquino (Juliet), Eddie Garcia (Luis Go), Boots Anson-Roa (Eliza), Tirso Cruz III (Daniel), Eric Quizon (Joseph), Maxene Magalona (Emerson), Cogie Domingo, Jay Manalo, Gina Alajar, Amy Austria, and Nanding Josef

 

Mano Po follows three generations of a Chinese-Filipino family. Luis Go is the patriarch who defied his family in Fujian in order to live in the Philippines with his Filipino wife, Eliza. Luis rises to become a mogul and owner of a food-manufacturing conglomerate, which, on his 80th birthday, is now run by his son, Daniel. Luis has three granddaughters: Vera, the iron-fisted chief executive officer of the Go Group of Companies; Juliet, housewife of a tough husband, Joseph; and Richelle, the rebellious and disfavored granddaughter. Each granddaughter has to contend with her own problem. Vera’s dilemma is whether to marry Emerson or not. Juliet gets involved in the rescue of a kidnapped child. And Richelle, whose conflict puts the whole clan in a precarious situation, is arrested in a drug raid and, with the help of detective Raf, is made an informant against the corrupt police commissioner, who is a close friend of Luis. Richelle chooses to do the right, albeit dangerous, thing. But her act of courage pulls the family closer together.

Mano Po premiered in the 2002 Metro Manila Film Festival, where it won most of the awards: Best Picture, Best Director, Best Cinematography, Best Production Design, Best Editing, Best Original Story, Best Screenplay, Best Musical Score, Best Actor (Garcia), Best Actress (Mina), Best Supporting Actress (Aquino), and the Gatpuno Antonio J. Villegas Cultural Award. The film also won for Aquino the Best Supporting Actress trophy in the 2003 Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Awards.

Five other Mano Po films were made, although they are not really sequels. These are Mano Po 2: My Home, 2003; Mano Po 3: My Love, 2004; Mano Po 4: Ako Legal Wife (I Am the Legal Wife), 2005; Mano Po 5: Gua Ai Di (I Love You), 2006; and Mano Po 6: A Mother’s Love, 2009. All but one were directed by Lamangan; Mano Po 2 was directed by Erik Matti. A spin-off, Bahay Kubo : A Pinoy Mano Po! (Nipa Hut: A Pinoy Mano Po!), 2007, was also directed by Lamangan.  Written by Patrick Campos

text:
(Saint Peter’s Fighting Cock) / 1975 / Black and White / Comedy / Direction: Joe Macachor / Screenplay: Marcos Navarro Sacol / Produced by the Arong brothers in Cebuano / Cast: Stevan Escudero, Teresa Diez, and Porcing Torrevilas

The story begins with Teban walking home after losing his money in a cockfight. Teban belongs to a poor family. Upon reaching home, he learns that he has a guest, Lisa, a young woman from a rich family who wants to hire Teban so that she and Teban can pretend to be lovers and she can avoid the marriage that her family has fixed for her to a man she does not love. Because of the financial reward, Teban agrees. Together, Teban and Lisa go to the house of Lisa’s parents where Teban is introduced as her lover. But Lisa’s father explains why he wants to marry her off: her groom-to-be is the son of a wealthy business friend to whom he owes a substantial amount of money. The businessman tells Teban’s parents that their debt to him will be waived if Teban gives up Lisa so that she can marry his son. Teban and Lisa refuse to heed the businessman’s offer. This forces Lisa’s father to plot Teban’s death in various ways. The first plot involves hired men who are supposed to kill Teban in a boxing match. But Lisa interferes as soon as she hears the plan: she also hires men who will stop the planned murder of Teban. The second plot, however, suceeds. Teban drowns when he is thrown into the sea. Teban meets San Pedro in the afterlife and the saint tells him that he needs to go back to the world as his time is not yet up. San Pedro gives Teban a rooster and Teban soon wakes up on the shore with the rooster beside him. Not long after, Teban learns that the rooster can speak. The bird also begins to bring him fame and fortune by winning every cockfighting match that it joins. Teban becomes extremely arrogant, to the disappointment of many of the people who know him, including Lisa. One day, Teban loses a cockfighting match because the rooster that San Pedro gave him was replaced. Later, he realizes that the bird that won over the replacement was the rooster that San Pedro gave him. Meanwhile, Lisa is kidnapped by the wealthy businessman. Teban surrenders all his money in exchange for Lisa’s freedom. However, Teban is shot by the businessman. Upon meeting San Pedro once more, Teban learns that the businessman also died when his plane crashed. The old man is sent to hell and Teban is sent to heaven.

Ang Manok ni San Pedro was the first Cebuano full-length comedy that used the Super 8 format, a home-movie film that turned out to be a worthwhile investment for the Arong brothers as the film grossed over 10 times more than their initial investment in it at the end of its first week in the cinema.  Written by Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

text:
2000 / Color / Drama / 97 minutes / Direction: Gil Portes / Screenplay: Clodualdo del Mundo Jr / Cinematography: Johnny Araojo / Editing: George Jarlego / Production Design: Kay Abaño / Sound: Albert Michael Idioma and Ari Trofeo / Music: Joy Marfil / Produced by RVQ Productions / Cast: Dolphy (Walter), Eric Quizon (Walter), Jeffrey Quizon (Walter), Loren Legarda, Joel Lamangan, Ricci Chan, R.S. Francisco, Melvin Lee, Freddie Quizon, Dexter Doria, Nanding Josef, Bembol Roco, and Gio Alvarez

 

After watching a documentary about Filipina comfort women, 73-year-old Walter Dempster Jr, a real-life comfort gay, decides to tell his story to the public, courtesy of journalist Loren Legarda (playing herself). Walter, aka Walterina, narrates his story through flashbacks, beginning with his life as a young man dealing with identity issues and familial acceptance, to the time of the Japanese occupation of the Philippines when he is arrested, along with his other cross-dressing gay friends, for misleading a Japanese official about his real gender. While in captivity, Walter and his friends are raped by a group of Japanese soldiers, a tragedy that is repeated many times over until the end of the occupation. When the country is finally liberated, Walterina comes to terms with his newfound work as entertainer, this time as “Markova,” and later on as a makeup artist for various theater and film companies.

As the narrative moves through time, from present to the past and back to the present, Walterina recounts his daily concerns to the journalist, from his fear of acquiring AIDS, to his anxiety about people not believing his story as a comfort gay. By the end of the interview, faced with more doubts from the journalist, Walterina grabs the cassette tape from the recorder and refuses to continue with the interview. He realizes that his own truth about his past and his identity is the only thing that matters.

Markova: Comfort Gay won the 2001 Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences awards for Best Supporting Actor (J. Quizon) and Best Production Design, the 2001 Gawad Urian for Best Supporting Actor, the Metro Manila Film Festival award for Best Supporting Actor, and the 2002 Brussels International Independent Film Festival award for Best Performance by an Actor/Actress (triple tie for Dolphy, Eric Quizon, and Jeffrey Quizon).  Written by Anne Frances Sangil

text:
(The Masseur) / 2005 / Color / Drama / 76 minutes / Direction: Brillante Mendoza / Original Story: Ferdinand Lapuz / Story: Brillante Mendoza and Boots Agbayani Pastor / Screenplay: Boots Agbayani Pastor / Cinematography: Timmy Jimenez and Monchie Redoble / Editing: Herbert Navasca / Production Design: Benjamin Padero / Art Direction: Dennis Domingo, Christopher Marasigan, and Jetro Rafael / Sound: Nonoy Dadivas and Rudy Gonzales / Music: Jerrold Tarog / Produced by Gee Films Productions International and Center Stage Productions / Cast: Coco Martin (Iliac), Jaclyn Jose, Allan Paule, and Katherine Luna

Masahista revolves around Iliac, a young man who, in order to earn a living and help support his family in San Fernando, Pampanga, is employed in Manila in a seedy massage parlor that caters to gay clients. The massage administered in such establishments is usually a prelude to various forms of sex work, with each act corresponding to a price. Apart from servicing his customers, he must also satisfy the demands of his domineering girlfriend, who works as a bar girl in Japan. Interwoven in the film are scenes from one night at Iliac’s workplace, during which Illiac is engaged and then taken advantage of by a Tagalog romance novel writer, and sequences chronicling his journey back to his hometown, where he must return in order to attend to the preparations for the funeral and burial of his estranged father, who was an alcoholic. The movement and overlap between these two realms of Iliac’s experience, which he tries to keep separate, draw out and highlight the tensions and ambiguities that characterize his life.

Masahista won Best Film, Best Screenplay, Best Editing, Best Achievement in Cinematography and Visual Design, Best Achievement in Sound and Aural Orchestration, and Best Performance (Martin) at the Young Critics Circle (YCC) Film Desk Citations for 2005, becoming the first film in YCC history to win in all categories. Internationally, it won the Golden Leopard in the video section of the 2005 Locarno International Film Festival, the Interfaith Award at the 2006 Brisbane International Film Festival, and the Audience Award at the 2006 Torino Gay and Lesbian Film Festival.  Written by Jaime Oscar M. Salazar

article.value: (The Masseur) / 2005 / Color / Drama / 76 minutes / Direction: Brillante Mendoza / Original Story: Ferdinand Lapuz / Story: Brillante Mendoza and Boots Agbayani Pastor / Screenplay: Boots Agbayani Pastor / Cinematography: Timmy Jimenez and Monchie Redoble / Editing: Herbert Navasca / Production Design: Benjamin Padero / Art Direction: Dennis Domingo, Christopher Marasigan, and Jetro Rafael / Sound: Nonoy Dadivas and Rudy Gonzales / Music: Jerrold Tarog / Produced by Gee Films Productions International and Center Stage Productions / Cast: Coco Martin (Iliac), Jaclyn Jose, Allan Paule, and Katherine Luna

Masahista revolves around Iliac, a young man who, in order to earn a living and help support his family in San Fernando, Pampanga, is employed in Manila in a seedy massage parlor that caters to gay clients. The massage administered in such establishments is usually a prelude to various forms of sex work, with each act corresponding to a price. Apart from servicing his customers, he must also satisfy the demands of his domineering girlfriend, who works as a bar girl in Japan. Interwoven in the film are scenes from one night at Iliac’s workplace, during which Illiac is engaged and then taken advantage of by a Tagalog romance novel writer, and sequences chronicling his journey back to his hometown, where he must return in order to attend to the preparations for the funeral and burial of his estranged father, who was an alcoholic. The movement and overlap between these two realms of Iliac’s experience, which he tries to keep separate, draw out and highlight the tensions and ambiguities that characterize his life.

Masahista won Best Film, Best Screenplay, Best Editing, Best Achievement in Cinematography and Visual Design, Best Achievement in Sound and Aural Orchestration, and Best Performance (Martin) at the Young Critics Circle (YCC) Film Desk Citations for 2005, becoming the first film in YCC history to win in all categories. Internationally, it won the Golden Leopard in the video section of the 2005 Locarno International Film Festival, the Interfaith Award at the 2006 Brisbane International Film Festival, and the Audience Award at the 2006 Torino Gay and Lesbian Film Festival.  Written by Jaime Oscar M. Salazar

text:
(Manila: In the Claws of Light) / 1975 / Color / Drama / 123 minutes / Direction: Lino Brocka / Story: Edgardo M. Reyes / Screenplay: Clodualdo del Mundo Jr / Cinematography: Miguel de Leon / Editing: Ike Jarlego Jr and Totoy Jarlego / Sound: Ramon Reyes / Music: Max Jocson / Produced by Cinema Artists Philippines / Cast: Rafael Roco Jr (Julio Madiaga), Hilda Koronel (Ligaya Paraiso), Tommy Abuel (Pol), Tommy Yap (Ah Tek), Aning Bagabaldo (Mrs Cruz), Lou Salvador Jr, Joonee Gamboa, Lily Gamboa-Mendoza, Pio de Castro III, Rikki Jimenez, Jojo Abella, Pancho Pelagia, and Danilo Posadas

 

The story revolves around Julio Madiaga, a poor fisher, who goes to the city to look for his long lost love, Ligaya Paraiso. His search leads to a radical shift in his character, from that of a naive probinsiyano (country boy) to an angry man thirsting for justice. He works in a construction site, gets acquainted with unfair labor practices, meets both cynical and idealistic construction workers, loses his job, lands in a house of prostitution, and encounters, finally, his sweetheart inside a church in downtown Manila. Ligaya recounts her experience: how she was fooled by a Mrs Cruz, an illegal recruiter who set her up in a prostitution den, and how she fell into the hands of Ah Tek, a rich, possessive, and cruel benefactor, now her common-law husband and father of her child. Julio and Ligaya plan her escape. Ligaya is caught before she can flee and is killed by her husband. Julio learns of her death from his best friend, Pol, and they proceed to the funeral parlor. After paying his last respects to his love, he seeks out and kills Ah Tek. His violent revenge leads to his own death when he is trapped by a pursuing mob.

Maynila: Sa mga Kuko ng Liwanag is one of Lino Brocka’s best films. It is a successful adaptation into film of Edgardo Reyes’s Tagalog novel Sa mga Kuko ng Liwanag, serialized in Liwayway. It also introduced Bembol Roco, who became one of Philippine cinema’s best actors. Maynila won the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences awards for Best Picture, Best Director, Best Actor (Roco), Best Supporting Actor (Abuel), Best Story, Best Screenplay, Best Cinematography, Best Editing, and Best Sound. It was adjudged one of the 10 Best Films of the Decade by the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino. Its screenplay was published in Maynila …, ’Merika, Alyas Raha Matanda: Tatlong Dulang Pampelikula (Three Screenplays), 1992.

In 2013, a restoration of the film was executed by the Cineteca di Bologna/L’Immagine Ritrovata laboratory, in association with Mike de Leon, LVN, and Cinema Artists Philippines, as a result of a joint project between the Film Development Council of the Philippines and the Film Foundation/World Cinema Project of Martin Scorsese. The restored version had a world premiere at the 2013 Cannes Film Festival, as part of its Classics section. The restoration work was recognized with the Award for Best Archive Restoration/Preservation Title in the 2014 FOCAL (Federation of Commercial Audiovisual Libraries) International Awards.  Written by Luna Sicat, with notes from Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

text:
(Those Little Secrets) / 2012 / Color / Drama / 100 minutes / Direction and Screenplay: Jose Javier Reyes / Cinematography: Rodolfo Aves Jr / Editing: Vanessa de Leon / Production Design: Jay Custodio / Sound: Albert Michael Idioma and Addiss Tabong / Music: Jesse Lucas / Produced by Cinemalaya and Lagarista Entertainment / Cast: Judy Ann Santos (Mariel), Iza Calzado (Carla), Agot Isidro (Sandra), Janice de Belen (Olive), Lui Manansala, Madeleine Nicolas, Roeder Camañag, Gino de la Peña, Mikylla Ramirez, and Kim Rodriguez

When Mariel, a housewife, passes away from cancer, she leaves behind and entrusts her diaries to Carla, a smart advertising executive who is also one of Mariel’s three closest friends. At first, Carla is discouraged by Sandra, the group’s gold-digging socialite, and Olive, the group’s desperate housewife, from opening Mariel’s diaries, but Carla cannot resist the temptation of finding out the diaries’ contents and starts reading them anyway. She soon discovers some unpleasant secrets that her friends have kept from her all these years. As she relates the contents of Mariel’s diaries to Sandra and Olive, these newfound bits of secrets begin to affect their seemingly strong bond. Angered by these sudden revelations, the three eventually confront one another and engage in a shouting match. In the end, despite being hurt by the truth, they nevertheless decide to forgive one another. But only time can tell whether their friendship will ever go back to the way things were.

Mga Mumunting Lihim competed in the Directors Showcase section of the 2012 Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival where it won the awards for Best Screenplay, Best Editing, and an unprecedented ensemble performance award for Best Actress and Best Supporting Actress given to Judy Ann Santos, Iza Calzado, Agot Isidro, and Janice de Belen.  Written by Elvin Valerio

text:
(Small Voices) / 2002 / Color / Drama / 109 minutes / Direction: Gil M. Portes / Screenplay: Adolf Alix Jr, Gil M. Portes, and Senedy Que / Cinematography: Ely Cruz / Editing: George Jarlego / Production Design: Arthur Nicdao / Art Direction: Ramon Nicdao / Sound: Noel Cruz Bruan and Ari Trofeo / Music: Joy Marfil / Produced by Sky Island Film, CAP Philippines Inc, and Teamwork Productions / Cast: Alessandra de Rossi (Melinda Santiago), Gina Alajar, Dexter Doria, Amy Austria, Irma Adlawan, Bryan Homecillo, Nonie Buencamino, Tony Mabesa, Lailani Navarro, Keno Agaro, Rowell Reyes, Nanding Josef, Shamaine Buencamino, and Hamid Eton

 

A young teacher named Melinda Santiago struggles to find meaning in her chosen profession in a poor provincial public school. As she takes over her new class, she discovers the numerous difficulties a typical teacher in the barrio must face on a daily basis, including the lack of suitable classrooms, shortage of textbooks, inefficient school administrators and frivolous colleagues, uncooperative parents who prefer their children to work in the fields rather than study in school, and low and delayed salaries. The unending plea of her mother for her to leave the Philippines to work abroad where opportunities are better also adds to Melinda’s woes. Last but not least, the conflict between the military and the New People’s Army (NPA) rebels complicates things as two of her students are also the sons of an active NPA rebel. But things take a turn for the better when Melinda decides to involve her students in a singing contest to be held in the central school in town. Overcoming the stubbornness of the parents and the pessimism of the school administrator, Melinda organizes regular afternoon rehearsals. Meanwhile, she must also source some funds for the costumes of the children and cope with the death of one of her students who was caught in the cross fire between the military and the rebels. Through sheer will and hard work, Melinda and her students win the grand prize in the town contest. In the end, Melinda agrees to leave the school to go to the United States, only to come back a year later—to be a teacher in the Philippines for good.

Mga Munting Tinig won several local and international awards in 2003: the Gawad Urian for Best Picture, Best Director, and Best Production Design; the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences awards for Best Picture, Best Director, Best Editing, and Best Child Actor (Homecillo); and the Palm Beach International Film Festival awards for Best Director, Best Feature, and Best Screenplay. It was also nominated for the Golden Kinnaree Award (Best Film) in the 2003 Bangkok International Film Festival.  Written by Anne Frances Sangil

text:
1997 / Color / Drama / 130 minutes / Direction: Marilou Diaz-Abaya / Screenplay: Rolando S. Tinio, based on his play Kalapati (Dove) / Cinematography: Eduardo Jacinto / Editing: Jess Navarro / Production Design: Len Santos / Sound: Ramon Reyes / Music: Nonong Buencamino / Produced by Merdeka Film Productions / Cast: Sharmaine Arnaiz (Milagros), Dante Rivero (Mang Nano), Joel Torre (Junie), Raymond Bagatsing (Benneth), Nonie Buencamino (Ramonito), Elizabeth Oropesa (Meding), Mia Gutierrez, Tanya Gomez, and Rolando Tinio

 

Milagros, nicknamed Lagring, is a bar girl and dancer who is hungry for her absentee father’s love and remembers his promise to her that he will bring her to the mystical mountain of Banahaw. As the film opens, she finds out that her father has died, leaving her and her mother, Meding, in considerable debt. To pay for their debt, Milagros offers herself to work as a maid in the house of her father’s creditor, the widower Mang Nano, and his three sons. In this new life, she finds a family she has never had. To each man, the sensual and disconcertingly innocent Milagros provides understanding and sexual love. Mang Nano becomes fond of Milagros and her nurturing nature, so he ends up treating her as if she were his wife and mother at the same time. Junie, Nano’s married son, is attracted to Milagros for her qualities that his wife does not possess. Benneth despises Milagros for her relationship with his father and brothers and abuses her as the whore he believes her to be. Ramonito, the blind son, becomes the object of Milagros’s love. The complicated web of relationships causes strain in the family. But when Milagros unexpectedly suffers from leukemia, the men have to grapple with her impending death. In the close of the film, Milagros travels to Mount Banahaw to realize her dream of paternal love and die there.

Milagros won major awards in the 1998 Gawad Urian: Best Picture, Best Director, Best Actor (Bagatsing), Best Supporting Actress (Oropesa), Best Screenplay, Best Cinematography, Best Editing, Best Production Design, Best Music, and Best Sound. Buencamino was awarded Supporting Actor of the Year in the 1998 PMPC Star Awards for Movies. The film also won Best Achievement in Cinematography and Visual Design, Best Editing, and Best Achievement in Sound and Aural Orchestration in the Young Critics Circle Film Desk Citations for 1997.  Written by Patrick Campos

text:
2004 / Color / Drama / 131 minutes / Direction: Olivia M. Lamasan / Story: Raymond Lee / Screenplay: Olivia M. Lamasan and Raymond Lee / Cinematography: Shayne Sarte / Editing: Marya Ignacio / Production Design: Nuel Naval / Sound: Albert Michael Idioma / Music: Raul Mitra / Produced by Star Cinema / Cast: Claudine Barretto (Jenny), Piolo Pascual (Lino), Iza Calzado (Mary Grace), Ilonah Jean, Ryan Eigenmann, Pia Moran, Lotlot de Leon, Ward Luarca, Ana Capri, Cecil Paz, At Maculangan, Lollie Mara, Richard Arellano, Maritess Joaquin, and Irma Adlawan

 

Lino travels to Milan as an undocumented OFW in search of his wife, Mary Grace. Lino’s loneliness and aimlessness are exacerbated by his naivete and inexperience with life abroad. Lino meets Jenny, a street-smart Filipina, who extends her assistance to him and teaches him how to get by. Jenny is part of a closely knit Filipino community whose members are migrant workers who live together and support one another. The community becomes Lino’s home away from home as he struggles to work odd jobs and copes with racial discrimination and culture shock.

Their motivations for being in Milan reveal the source of conflict between Lino and Jenny. Lino is a romantic who is ready to give up everything for love, while Jenny is a workaholic who is willing to sacrifice personal relationships for financial gain. And yet the two fall in love, despite their differences. It is Jenny who finds Mary Grace, now married to an Italian, but Lino has decided not to pursue his wife anymore. The film ends on an open-ended note. Lino and Jenny have not closed their doors, but they have decided to part ways, to find themselves, and to learn what kind of personal sacrifices they could make in order to be together. The film also follows several subplots that give a bigger picture to the migrant workers’ experience in Italy. Interviews with “real” OFWs, interspersed throughout the film, provide a documentary-like texture to the story.

Pascual and Barretto won the Best Actor and Best Actress trophies, respectively, in the 2005 Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Awards. Barretto also won Best Actress in the 2005 Film Academy of the Philippines Awards, while Calzado earned the award for Breakthrough Performance by an Actress in the 2005 Golden Screen Awards.  Written by Patrick Campos

text:
(Children Only Once) / 1996 / Black and White / Documentary / 50 minutes / Direction: Ditsi Carolino and Sadhana Buxani / Script: Ditsi Carolino

Minsan Lang Sila Bata exposes the harsh realities of child labor in the Philippine archipelago. Recorded in black and white, the documentary chronicles three narratives of child labor: the first one focuses on children working in the slaughterhouse; the second group of children tells the story of young ones working as maghohornal (plantation laborers); and finally, the third story shows children working at the port. This documentary examines the state of children who are forced to do manual labor under inhumane conditions.

Minsan Lang Sila Bata won first prize and Best Work on Children, Documentary Video, at the 1996 Gawad CCP para sa Alternatibong Pelikula at Video. It was also awarded Best Documentary by the Film Academy of the Philippines, 1997. In 1998, Minsan Lang Sila Bata received the Grand Prix Toutes Categories at Festival Internationale du Film Independant in Brussels. At the 1999 New York Festival for TV Programming, it won the Grand Award for Documentary, the Gold Medal for Current Affairs and Issues, and the Silver Medal (UNESCO Prize).  Written by Mario Mendez Jr

text:
(One Moment More) / 2004 / Color / Drama / 90 minutes / Direction: Jeffrey Jeturian / Story and Screenplay: Armando Lao / Cinematography: Larry Manda and Marissa Floirendo / Editing: Danny Gloria, Jess Navarro, and Nonoy Dadivas / Production Design: Ronnie Cruz / Sound: Mark Cabaluna / Music: Lucien Letaba and Arnel de Pano / Produced by MLR Films / Cast: Jomari Yllana (Jerry),Ara Mina (Luna), Christian Vasquez (Alex), Tirso Cruz III (Jeremiah Toledo), Rio Locsin (Pacita), Dimples Romana, and Criselda Volks

 

When a two-timing father and musician, Jeremiah Toledo, leaves his family for a younger woman, his eldest son, Jerry, learns to become the breadwinner of the family. To support his mother, Pacita, and two siblings, he works as a tour guide in Cebu, bringing mostly Japanese tourists around. As a tour guide, he is warm and jovial, but he keeps everyone at arm’s length, calculating how he could earn commissions and extra tips, even doubling as a pimp and prostitute. When Luna, a preschool teacher, joins the tours, Jerry is smitten. But Luna’s boyfriend, Alex, also arrives in Cebu to propose to her. While in Cebu, Luna is always carrying around a camera, which she drops in the sea. When a vehicular accident befalls Alex and blinds him, he reneges on his promise to marry Luna. Luna returns to Cebu to recover the camera in an attempt to prove to Alex that her love has not waned despite his blindness. The search for the camera reconnects Luna and Jerry, only to confirm that Jerry’s feelings toward Luna will remain unrequited. As Jerry endeavors to find the camera for Luna, he learns to let go and not to expect anything in return, to forgive his father, and to open up his heart to a new love. text:
(Once a Moth) / 1976 / Color / Drama / 99 minutes / Direction: Lupita A. Concio / Story and Screenplay: Marina Feleo-Gonzalez / Cinematography: Jose Batac Jr / Editing: Edgardo Vinarao / Production Design: Socrates Topacio / Sound: Willie de Santos / Music: Restie Umali / Produced by Premiere Productions / Cast: Nora Aunor (Corazon de la Cruz), Jay Ilagan (Bonifacio Santos), Perla Bautista (Yolanda), Eddie Villamayor (Carlito), Paquito Salcedo (Ingkong), Gloria Sevilla, Lily Miraflor, Leo Martinez, Nanding Fernandez, Luz Fernandez, German Moreno, Carlos Padilla Jr, Michael Sandico, and Ricky Sandico

Minsa’y Isang Gamu-gamo focuses on two lower middle-class families in Pampanga, the de la Cruzes and the Santoses. Corazon de la Cruz is a nurse whose ambition is to work and live in America. Now that her papers are ready, she plans to get a “green card” after her one-year stint in an American hospital, then change her status to immigrant and finally petition for her family. Bonifacio Santos plans to enter the United States Navy and join his girlfriend, Corazon, later.

 

Because of personal ambition, both families, except Ingkong who remains critical of American intervention, ignore the brutal murders and the gross injustices resulting from the American military presence—until the tragedies occur.

Bonifacio’s mother, Yolanda, a US Navy Exchange employee, is wrongfully accused of theft and humiliated by a Filipino female merchandise control guard of the Provost Marshal’s Office. Yolanda files a suit against the Provost Marshal’s Office. In retaliation, her store is raided, forcing her to give up the case.

On the eve of Corazon’s departure for America, her younger brother, Carlito, is accidentally shot and killed by an American soldier while playing with other children at a dumpsite on the base. The soldier explains that he mistook the young boy for a wild boar. Corazon drops her plan to go to the United States and fights for justice.

Minsa’y Isang Gamu-gamo was the first important film to tackle the subject of the American presence and its consequences. It showed another face of the so-called special relations between the Philippines and the United States.

The film won Best Picture, Best Director, Best Story, Best Screenplay, and Best Editing in the 1977 Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Awards; and Best Story and Best Editing in the 1976 Metro Manila Film Festival. It was nominated in the Gawad Urian for Best Picture, Best Director, Best Screenplay, and Best Supporting Actor (Salcedo).  Written by Mauro Tumbocon and Nicanor G. Tiongson

text:
1925 / Black and White / Drama / Direction, Screenplay, and Editing: Vicente Salumbides / Produced by Malayan Movies / Cast: Vicente Salumbides, Elizabeth “Dimples” Cooper, Jose Carvajal, Hermogenes Ilagan, Juanita Angeles, Pacita Gonzales, and Pilar Castro

A young doctor falls in love with the picture of a magazine cover girl. Desiring to meet her in person, he goes to the address indicated and notices a “Wanted: Houseboy” sign at the gate. A servant mistakes him for an applicant for the job and invites him in. Seizing the opportunity to be close to the lady of his dreams, he accepts the job, hiding his true identity. The girl is impressed with his gentlemanly behavior and comes to regard him as her confidant, confessing to him that her parents are pressuring her to marry a wealthy old bachelor whom she does not love. The doctor in disguise has his own problems in the household. One of the domestics, a cook, is infatuated with him.

Things get out of hand and the young man is forced to reveal the truth about himself to the girl. The girl is elated, having secretly fallen in love with him, too. Their marriage is temporarily thwarted by the jealous cook, the old bachelor, and the girl’s parents, but the lovers prevail in the end and the girl’s parents come to accept the doctor as their son-in-law.

Miracles of Love is remarkable as one of the early films that used Hollywood techniques such as the close-up, the cutback, and parallel editing, which Salumbides introduced in silent pictures in the early 1920s. He was the first to edit film in such a way that the sequence of an action was broken to enable the viewer to see what was happening simultaneously in another place. The synchronized scenes hastened the pace of the movie, heightening the suspense in the elopement and chase scenes.  Written by Lena S. Pareja

Lorna Tolentino, left, Sandy Andolong, Anna Marin, and Gina Alajar in Moral, 1982

(Mario A. Hernando Collection)

text:
1982 / Color / Drama / 150 minutes / Direction: Marilou Diaz-Abaya / Story and Screenplay: Ricardo Lee / Cinematography: Manolo Abaya / Production Design: Fiel Zabat / Editing: Manolo Abaya and Marc Tarnate / Sound: Amang Sanchez / Music: George Canseco / Produced by Seven Stars Production / Cast: Lorna Tolentino (Joey), Gina Alajar (Kathy), Sandy Andolong (Sylvia), Anna Marin (Maritess), Ronald Bregendahl, Juan Rodrigo, Michael Sandico, Laurice Guillen, Mia Gutierrez, Lito Pimentel, Odette Khan, Dexter Doria, and Manny Luna

 

Moral is one of the few movies in local cinema that departs from the usual three-act structure with a tight cause-and-effect plot. It is a loosely structured film tracing the lives of four friends. The four women are authentically portrayed as real people set against the social, political, and economic milieu of 1979-82. The Filipino woman is shown not as victim but as shaper of her own destiny. It is the second of Diaz-Abaya’s film trilogy on women, done after Brutal, 1980, and before Karnal (Of the Flesh), 1983.

Joey bums around, with no particular place to call home. Beset by problems, she seeks release through drugs and casual sex. Kathy dreams of becoming rich and famous by singing professionally, unable to accept the fact that she is not a good singer. Maritess decides to be a housewife and mother, unable to develop her writing talents. Sylvia, a teacher, still loves her husband who has left her for a man. In the end, the four women make their separate decisions, which make them whole as persons.

Moral won the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences awards for Best Supporting Actress (Andolong) and Best Supporting Actor (Rodrigo). It was cited as the 2nd Best Picture at the 1982 Metro Manila Film Festival where it won the Best Screenplay award. It was nominated in the Gawad Urian for Best Picture, Best Director, Best Screenplay, Best Editing, Best Actress (Alajar and Tolentino), and Best Supporting Actress (Doria and Guillen). Some 20-30 minutes of film, however, was withheld by the censors from public viewing.  Written by Rosalie Matilac

text:
(Mulanay: Deep in Paradise) / 1996 / Color / Drama / 108 minutes / Direction: Gil Portes / Story and Screenplay: Clodualdo del Mundo Jr / Cinematography: George Tutanes / Editing: Racquel M. Cruz and Jesus Navarro / Production Design: Ronaldo Cadapan / Art Direction: Lito Victorino / Sound: Albert Michael Idioma / Music: Joy Marfil / Produced by Teamwork Productions / Cast: Gina Alajar (Norma), Jaclyn Jose (Ria Espinosa), Tommy Abuel, Nonie Buencamino, John Arcilla, Robert Arevalo, Rosemarie Gil, Alan Paule, and Mandy Ochoa

 

Ria Espinosa, a doctor fresh from medical school, decides to volunteer in the Doctors to the Barrios program. She was assigned to Mulanay, a fishing village in Quezon, where she meets and is guided around town by the midwife Norma. Coming from a middle-class Manila family, Ria tries to adjust to her new life in Mulanay: the power disruptions in the evening, the lack of basic medical supplies, the lack of funds to maintain cleanliness in the barangay, and the persistent problem of diarrhea and malnutrition in the community. Aside from being a doctor, Ria realizes that she needs to be an all-around superwoman—an environmental officer, an adult education officer, as well as a fund-raiser—to be able to fully serve the needs of the people. Ria is soon made aware of the bureaucracy in the local government as she tries to raise money to fund the construction of several deep wells in the barrio. Mulanay, with the help of their one and only doctor, attempts to deal with the growing epidemic that has been spreading across the barrio, resulting in the serious illness of many children and the death of Norma’s son. After the tragedy, the local government recognizes the epidemic and sends medical supplies to Mulanay. While her plans of constructing deep wells in the community are not realized due to lack of funds, Ria is able to build a small drugstore, thanks to the financial assistance of her mother. Tired of all the government bureaucracy, Ria decides to leave the town for good to pursue her own dreams, but not after a grand send-off from the townsfolk who accompany her as she visits one last time the office of the mayor in an attempt to explain the plight of the people of Mulanay.

Mulanay: Sa Pusod ng Paraiso was nominated in several categories in the 1997 Gawad Urian and won Best Supporting Actress (Alajar) and Best Music. It won for Alajar the Best Supporting Actress recognitions in the Film Academy of the Philippines Awards and the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Awards. Mulanay also won Best Picture, Best Director, Best Story, Best Screenplay, Best Actress (Jose), Best Actor (Arcilla), and Best Musical Score in the 1996 Manila Film Festival.  Written by Anne Frances Sangil

text:
(Shaman) / 1996 / Color / Drama / 130 minutes / Direction: Antonio Jose Perez / Screenplay: Amado Lacuesta and Antonio Jose Perez / Cinematography: Eduardo Jacinto / Production Design: Joey Luna / Editing: Manet Dayrit / Sound: Ramon Reyes, Albert Michael Idioma / Music: Jaime Fabregas / Produced by Viva Films and Johns Hopkins University / Cast: Raymart Santiago (Joseph Dumalilon), Angel Aquino (Dolores), Rachel Alejandro (Nancy Madrid), Albert Martinez, Joel Torre, Ruby Moreno, Ray Ventura, and Pen Medina

bright doctor who has plans of pursuing further studies at the Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore, USA. Upon learning that his father, a mumbaki or shaman of the Lidum tribe in their hometown in the Cordilleras, was killed by members of the rival Alimit tribe, Joseph is forced to leave his girlfriend, Dr Nancy Madrid, behind in the United States and return home. As a matter of tradition, he assumes, albeit reluctantly, the role of the mumbaki in order to appease the members of his tribe who believe that the epidemic that has been threatening their tribe is the result of their failure to avenge his father’s death. As he spends more time with his tribe, Joseph’s reluctance and conflicting feelings slowly turn into a realization that the best way to honor his father and the tribe is to stay and fulfill his duties, including avenging his father’s death and bringing peace to the warring tribes by marrying Dolores, the niece of the Alimit tribe’s chieftain. Thus, tradition and duty to the tribe prevail over personal ambitions.

One of the most awarded films of the year, Mumbaki won Best Picture, Best Director, Best Screenplay, Best Cinematography, Best Editing, Best Production Design, Best Musical Score, and Best Supporting Actor (Torre) in the 1997 Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Awards; Best Story and Best Production Design in the 1997 Film Academy of the Philippines Awards; and Best Sound in the 1997 Gawad Urian. It was chosen Movie of the Year in the 1997 PMPC Star Awards for Movies. It also won Best Film, Best Screenplay, and Best Achievement in Sound and Aural Orchestration in the Young Critics Circle Film Desk Citations for 1996.  Written by Elvin Valerio

text:
(Reef Hunters) / 1999 / Color / Drama / 114 minutes / Direction: Marilou Diaz-Abaya / Screenplay: Ricardo Lee and Jun Lana / Cinematography: Rody Lacap / Editing: Jesus Navarro / Production Design: Leo Abaya / Sound: Albert Michael Idioma / Music: Nonong Buencamino / Visual Effects: Marc Ambat / Produced by GMA Films / Cast: Cesar Montano (Fredo), Pen Medina (Dado), Jhong Hilario (Botong), Amy Austria, and Rebecca Lusterio

Fredo is a hardened fisherman who has lost his wife and child in a sea accident. Every year, this merciless slave-driver, addressed as Maestro, goes around fishing villages on the coast to recruit men and more than a hundred young male children from poor families to board his dilapidated and rat-infested ship, the Aurora. They are hired to catch a quota of hundreds of baskets of fish before Christmas.

 

Life in the ship is harsh. The fisherfolk are underfed and sleep in crowded bunks. They are harassed and made to dive at least eight times a day. They use the illegal muro-ami method in which deep-sea divers, without gears or protection, pound precious corals with rocks to scare fishes into nets. The method is not only dangerous, especially for the children, but also damaging to natural resources. Approaching New Year, Fredo pushes the people on edge until, with the stirring of Botong, the divers revolt against Fredo. They throw Fredo and his father, Dado, into the sea. Fredo survives and returns to the ship. A fight between Fredo and Botong ensues, resulting in an accident that burns down and sinks the Aurora. The children swim to shore as the sun rises and survive, but Fredo and Botong do not make it.

Muro-ami was an entry in the 1999 Metro Manila Film Festival, where it won Best Picture, Best Director, Best Cinematography, Best Production Design, Best Editing, Best Musical Score, Best Sound Recording, Best Supporting Actor (Medina), Best Child Performer (Lusterio), and the Gatpuno Antonio J. Villegas Cultural Award. The film won Best Picture, Best Director, Best Cinematography, Best Sound, and Best Child Actress (Lusterio) in the 2000 Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Awards. It won Best Cinematography, Best Musical Score, Best Sound, Best Supporting Actor (Hilario), Best Child Performer (Lusterio), and New Movie Actress of the Year (also for Lusterio) in the 2000 PMPC Star Awards for Movies. It also received the Best Picture and Best Actor (Montano) awards at the Bénodet International Film Festival in France, and was nominated for the Golden Maile Award for Narrative Feature at the 2000 Hawaii International Film Festival.  Written by Patrick Campos

Nora Aunor, Chanda Romero, and Jaclyn Jose in Naglalayag, 2004

text:
(Silent Passage) / 2004 / Color / Drama / 100 minutes / Direction: Maryo J. de los Reyes / Story and Screenplay: Irma Dimaranan / Cinematography: Odyssey Flores / Editing: Jesus Navarro / Production Design: Randy Gamier / Art Direction: Carmelo Sta. Maria / Sound: Nestor Mutia and Angie Reyes / Music: Lutgardo Labad / Theme Song: Rey Valera / Produced by Angorra Films / Cast: Nora Aunor (Dorinda), Yul Servo (Noah), Aleck Bovick (Rica), Celia Rodriguez, Chanda Romero, Jaclyn Jose, Pen Medina, and Irma Adlawan

 

Naglalayag revolves around a May-December affair that takes place between Dorinda and Noah. She is a widowed justice of the Court of Appeals already undergoing menopause—for which “naglalayag” or sailing, serves as a kind of euphemism—while he is a 20-year-old taxi driver whose father, also a taxi driver, was killed in an armed robbery. They come to know each other one night in the midst of a heavy downpour, during which they find themselves stranded by a flash flood. The unlikely friendship that arises between the two, particularly in view of the vast differences in their class, status, and age, soon develops into a torrid romance that is not without maternal undertones. Such a liaison, however, is not looked upon with favor by their family members, friends, and associates, particularly Rica, who is in love with Noah. The couple are subjected to various pressures that threaten to tear their apparently scandalous relationship apart. Things come to a head when Dorinda realizes that, notwithstanding her years, she is pregnant. Noah takes her to the province to live with a relative, but he must still return to the city to work and earn for his mother and siblings, a decision that leads him down the same path that ended his father’s life.

Naglalayag won Best Picture, Best Director, Best Story, Best Screenplay, Best Actor (Servo), Best Actress (Aunor), Best Supporting Actress (Jose), Best Musical Score, and Best Theme Song at the 2004 Manila Film Festival. article.value: Naglalayag revolves around a May-December affair that takes place between Dorinda and Noah. She is a widowed justice of the Court of Appeals already undergoing menopause—for which “naglalayag” or sailing, serves as a kind of euphemism—while he is a 20-year-old taxi driver whose father, also a taxi driver, was killed in an armed robbery. They come to know each other one night in the midst of a heavy downpour, during which they find themselves stranded by a flash flood. The unlikely friendship that arises between the two, particularly in view of the vast differences in their class, status, and age, soon develops into a torrid romance that is not without maternal undertones. Such a liaison, however, is not looked upon with favor by their family members, friends, and associates, particularly Rica, who is in love with Noah. The couple are subjected to various pressures that threaten to tear their apparently scandalous relationship apart. Things come to a head when Dorinda realizes that, notwithstanding her years, she is pregnant. Noah takes her to the province to live with a relative, but he must still return to the city to work and earn for his mother and siblings, a decision that leads him down the same path that ended his father’s life.

Naglalayag won Best Picture, Best Director, Best Story, Best Screenplay, Best Actor (Servo), Best Actress (Aunor), Best Supporting Actress (Jose), Best Musical Score, and Best Theme Song at the 2004 Manila Film Festival. It also won Best Picture, Best Director, Best Supporting Actress (Bovick), Best Story, Best Cinematography, Best Editing, and Best Movie Theme Song at the 2005 Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Awards; and Best Supporting Actress (Bovick) at the 2005 Luna Awards of the Film Academy of the Philippines. text:
(Mother Mameng) / 2012 / Color / Documentary / 45 minutes / Direction and Screenplay: Adjani Guerrero Arumpac / Cinematography: Adjani Arumpac, Chris Balleta, and Marco Lopez / Editing: Adjani Arumpac and Chris Balleta / Sound: Jedd Dumaguina / Music: Marx Diego / Creative Consultant: Bonifacio Ilagan / Produced by Jola Diones Mamangun, Tita Lubi, and Kodao Productions.

 

Carmen Deunida, popularly known as Nanay Mameng, is the subject of this documentary, which traces her rise as a charismatic leader of the urban poor and a well-known figure in the Philippine protest movement. Through a series of candid interviews, Nanay Mameng gets to narrate her own story—from her time as an adventurous young girl in postwar Manila, to her marriage to a man who abused her and whom she later left, her struggle as a single mother who had to raise seven children, and the gradual awakening of her political consciousness. She later joined various urban poor and women’s organizations and became a familiar face in the frontlines of many mass demonstrations, delivering powerful speeches that criticize the incompetence of government institutions, and inspiring a generation of emboldened activists. She has seen 13 presidents in the country and was one of the staunchest voices against the Arroyo and Aquino administrations. The documentary captures Nanay Mameng’s fiery but endearing personality, her strength as a mother and a leader who, despite her age and diminutive frame, has never faltered in championing the cause of the downtrodden and the disenfranchised.

Nanay Mameng won Best Documentary in the 2014 Gawad Urian. It was screened in the Philippines and Thailand, and had several private screenings in Europe in order to raise funds for Nanay Mameng’s health needs.   Written by Elmer L. Gatchalian

text:
(What Isn’t There) / 2012 / Color / Drama / 115 minutes / Direction: Marie Jamora / Screenplay: Marie Jamora and Ramon de Veyra / Cinematography: Ming Kai Leung / Editing: Edsel Abesamis and Marie Jamora / Production Design: Trinka Lat / Sound: Ditoy Aguila / Music: Jazz Nicholas, Mikey Amistoso, and Diego Mapa / Produced by Cinemalaya Foundation, National Commission for Culture and the Arts, Brainchild Studios, and Indie Pop Films. Cast: Dominic Roco (Gibson Bonifacio), Dawn Zulueta (Esme), Felix Roco (Jamie), Annicka Dolonius (Enid), Alcris Galura (Teddy), Bogs Jugo (Deacon), Boboy Garovillo, Mercedes Cabral, Marc Abaya, and Jenny Jamora

Gibson Bonifacio is a 20-year-old who returns home for Christmas after living abroad for 10 years. He left the country after witnessing the accidental death of his twin brother, Jamie. Because of this traumatic experience, Gibson’s family has become distant from one another; the mother, Esme, is especially distant from Gibson. Apparently, the mother was closer to Jamie and felt that Gibson caused the accident. As a result, Gibson decided to stop speaking since the accident and used his selective mutism as a means to dwell in his own private world. Now, he only speaks during his imaginary conversations with Jamie and communicates with people by typing on his mobile phone. Gibson reconnects with his old friend, Teddy, who introduces him to the local indie music scene, and to Enid, a pretty hipster who does not seem to mind his unusual silence. As her name suggests, Enid breathes “life” into Gibson’s quiet existence and he soon falls in love with her. He finally musters enough courage to confess his love for her, but he gets his heart broken when Enid admits that she is still hoping to get back with her ex-boyfriend Deacon. This experience allows Gibson to mature, and he finally learns to reach out to his family and let go of his twin brother.

Set amidst the backdrop of the local underground hipster music scene, this hugely popular coming-of-age comedy drama won the Audience Choice Award and Best Musical Score at the 2012 Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival.  Written by Elvin Valerio

text:
2014 / Color / Documentary / 70 minutes / Direction: Cha Escala and Wena Sanchez / Cinematography: Cha Escala / Editing: Bam Luneta, Apol Dating, and Cha Escala / Sound: Nonoy Dadivas / Music: Nani Naguit / Produced by QCinema and Hiraya Pictures

When super typhoon Haiyan (Yolanda) struck the Philippines in 2013, agriculturists and couple Ferdinand “Nick” Quieta and Doris “Chai” Quieta lost all their four children, leaving them nothing but an empty and devastated home. Shot in an observational style four months after the death of their children in Leyte, Tacloban, the Quieta couple display their grief and show how they cope with the loss. To rebuild their lives, they put all their energy setting up and implementing programs for vegetable farming in their distraught community. With the couple’s strength and selfless love, both are hoping that one day, they will all be together as a family.

 

Nick & Chai was awarded Best Picture at the 2014 QCinema International Film Festival’s Circle Competition, Best First Feature at the Young Critics Circle Film Desk Citations for 2014, and Audience Choice at the 2015 Anuu-ru Aboro International Film Festival, New Caledonia. It was in the official selection of the 2014 Busan International Film Festival and the 2014 International Documentary Film Festival Amsterdam.  Written by Rica Arevalo

text:
(Boy) / 2011 / Color / Drama / 100 minutes / Direction: Loy Arcenas / Screenplay: Rody Vera / Cinematography: Lee Meily / Editing: Danny Añonuevo / Production Design: Laida Lim-Perez / Sound: Albert Michael Idioma / Music: Jerrold Tarog / Produced by Handuwaran Films / Cast: Fides Cuyugan-Asensio (Celia), Shamaine Buencamino (Merced), Tony Mabesa (Gaspar), Raquel Villavicencio (Raquel), Art Acuña (Mombic), Diana Malahay (Katherine), Jhizhelei Deocareza (Antony), and Joaquin Valdes

 

The debt-ridden Celia, a renowned opera singer in her younger years, looks after her brother, Gaspar, a former lawmaker who was unable to fulfill his political ambitions and is now confined to his bed. Living with them is Merced, Celia’s daughter, who runs the household affairs, and Katherine, a boarder. This difficult but manageable arrangement is soon thrown into shambles when Mombic, Merced’s brother, arrives with the intention of leaving his young son, Antony, to the care of his mother and sister, as he intends to work abroad. Worse, Gaspar’s condition deteriorates and he slips into a coma. This compels Raquel, Gaspar’s daughter, to return from the United States with the objective of selling the beloved ancestral mansion that her relatives presently occupy, over Celia’s vehement objections, but in connivance with Mombic. As grudges, grievances, and secrets, long nursed and kept, spill out and deepen the rifts within the family, Celia can only pray for a miracle. In final bid to rouse her brother, she organizes a tertulia (social gathering) with her fellow opera singers, placing her hopes in the power of music and her fervent devotion to the Santo Niño (Infant Jesus), whom her grandson Antony imitates at play.

 

Niño won the Special Jury Prize, Best Supporting Actress (Buencamino), Best Supporting Actor (Acuña), and Best Production Design at the 2011 Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival; Best Supporting Actor at the 2012 Gawad Urian; Best Motion Picture (Drama), Best Performance by an Actress in a Supporting Role, and Best Performance by an Actor in a Supporting Role at the 2012 Golden Screen Awards; Digital Movie Production Designer of the Year at the 2012 PMPC Star Awards for Movies; and Best Screenplay at the Young Critics Circle Film Desk Citations for 2011. Internationally, it won the Best Supporting Actress (Buencamino) trophy at the 2012 Asian Film Awards, the Coup de Cœur du Jury Guimet and Special Mention of the International Jury at the 2012 Vesoul International Film Festival of Asian Cinema, and the New Currents Award at the 2011 Busan International Film Festival.  Written by Jaime Oscar M. Salazar

2011 / Color / Drama / 101 minutes / Direction: Ruel Santos Bayani / Story: Keiko A. Aquino, Jay Fernando, and Kris G. Gazmen / Screenplay: Kris G. Gazmen and Jay Fernando / Cinematography: Charlie S. Peralta / Editing: Vito Cajili / Production Design: Nancy Arcega / Art Direction: Rizza A. Fernandez, Agnes V. Lapdis, and Jonathan M. Quinquito / Sound: Aurel Claro C. Bilbao / Music: Raul Mitra / Produced by Star Cinema and Viva Films / Cast: Anne Curtis (Kara), Derek Ramsay (Ram), Cristine Reyes (Charmaine), Tirso Cruz III, Carmi Martin, John Arcilla, Ricci Chan, Niña Dolino, Ron Morales, Kat Alano, Kitkat, Peter Serrano, Marlann Flores, Fred Payawan, Melvin Lee, and Matt Evans

 

No Other Woman is a drama that attempts to explore the subject of infidelity. Ram, a furniture salesman, is married to Charmaine, a devoted homemaker. All is well until he travels to a new luxury resort to meet its owner, a prospective client. While there, Ram encounters Kara, who turns out to be the daughter of the owner of the resort and is instrumental in his landing a lucrative contract. Aware that Ram is married, Kara nevertheless strikes up a relationship with him, saying that it is merely out of fun, without emotional attachment. Things come to a head, however, when Charmaine’s suspicions are aroused and Kara realizes that she has fallen in love. The two women then fight for the affections of a man who seems unable to choose between them.

 

No Other Woman won Best Musical Score in the 2012 Luna Awards and Best Actress (Curtis) in the 2012 Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Awards. Praising the actors’ performances, the Cinema Evaluation Board gave the film a grade of “A,” which entitled its producers to an incentive equivalent to 100 percent of the amusement taxes imposed on it in highly urbanized areas of the Philippines. Despite mixed reviews, the movie proved immensely popular at the box office. It was briefly touted to be the highest-grossing Filipino film of all time, and other films tackling extramarital affairs followed quickly in its wake, including A Secret Affair, 2012, which also starred Curtis and Ramsay.  Written by Jaime Oscar M. Salazar
