text:
(Touch Me Not) / 1961 / Black and White / Drama / 180 minutes / Direction: Gerardo de Leon / Story: Jose P. Rizal (based on his novel Noli Me Tangere, 1887 /  Screenplay: Gerardo de Leon and Jose Flores Sibal / Cinematography: Emmanuel Rojas and Arsenio Banu / Editing: Vicente Calub and Joven Calub / Production Design: Carlos V. Francisco / Sound: Demetrio de Santos / Music: Tito Arevalo / Produced by Bayanihan/Arriva Pictures. Cast: Eddie del Mar (Crisostomo Ibarra), Edita Vital (Maria Clara), Johnny Monteiro (Padre Salvi), Oscar Keesee (Padre Damaso), Leopoldo Salcedo (Elias), Lina Cariño (Sisa), Teody Belarmino, Ruben Rustia, Robert Arevalo, Anna Marie, Engracio Ibarra, Jose Garcia, Fred Gonzales, Francisco Cruz, Lito Anzures, Max Alvarado, Lilian Laing de Leon, Andres Centenera, Ramon D’Salva, Veronica Palileo, Manny Ojeda, Joseph de Cordova, Nello Nayo, Salvador Zaragoza, Dely Villanueva, Jerry Pons, Pianing Vidal, Benny Mack, Eddie Ilagan, Paquito Salcedo, and Mario Sibal

 

Crisostomo Ibarra, a Spanish mestizo educated in Europe, returns home after many years to build a schoolhouse for his village. He is distressed by the deplorable conditions in his country. The colonial government has become more corrupt and oppressive, the friars more abusive, and there is widespread poverty and discontent. A distraught mother, Sisa, wanders around town looking for her sons, Basilio and Crispin, who were maltreated by the town priest. Ibarra’s own family is dispossessed of their land and his father denied a decent burial in the town’s Catholic cemetery. Even Ibarra’s love for Maria Clara is threatened by Padre Salvi, who lusts after Maria Clara.

 

During the cornerstone laying of the school building, a timely warning from a stranger, Elias, saves Ibarra from certain death. At the banquet following the “accident,” Ibarra violently reacts to the insulting remarks of Padre Damaso. Only the intervention of his sweetheart, Maria Clara, stops Ibarra from stabbing the priest. Not long after, an uprising is set up by Padre Salvi to implicate Ibarra. The authorities order his arrest but Ibarra escapes with the help of Elias. The two friends flee by boat down the Pasig, pursued by the guardia civiles (constables). Elias dives into the river to draw rifle fire away from Ibarra. Elias dies, but Ibarra is saved. With Ibarra gone and rather than marry someone she does not love, Maria Clara enters the nunnery.

 

Jose Rizal’s novel has been made into a movie a number of times, but only the 1961 Gerardo de Leon version is extant. Edward M. Gross made the first Noli in 1915 and Jose Nepomuceno did his own version in 1930. A.E. Litiatco, a film critic, singled out Nepomuceno’s Noli as the best Filipino film of 1930, citing the lavish banquet scene, the San Diego fiesta procession, the river party, and even details of 19th-century life—for example, cleaning shoes with banana leaves—as being typical of Rizal’s time.

 

In 1962, Noli Me Tangere won the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences awards for Best Picture, Best Director, Best Supporting Actor, and Best Supporting Actress (Cariño). Through the joint efforts of Goethe-Institut Manila, the Embassy of the Federal Republic of Germany, the Federal Archives in Bonn, the Federal Archives in Koblenz, and Lufthansa, the last-known surviving print of de Leon’s Noli was restored and turned over to the Philippine government through the Cultural Center of the Philippines on 22 May 1990.  Written by Lena S. Pareja

text:
(Norte, The End of History) / 2013 / Color / Drama / 250 minutes / Direction: Lav Diaz / Screenplay: Lav Diaz and Rody Vera / Cinematography: Lauro Rene Manda / Editing: Lav Diaz / Production Design: Perry Dizon / Sound: Corinne de San Jose, Boyet de Jesus, Itong del Pilar, and Mikko Quizon / Music: Perry Dizon / Produced by Kayan Productions and Wacky O Productions / Cast: Sid Lucero (Fabian), Angeli Bayani (Eliza), Archie Alemania (Joaquin), Mae Paner (Magda), Angelina Kanapi, Soliman Cruz, and Hazel Orencio

 

A loose adaptation of the novel Crime and Punishment by Russian writer Fyodor Dostoyevsky, the film explores the lives of three individuals whose circumstances are vastly changed on account of a brutal crime. Fabian is a brilliant law student who, for reasons that are unclear, has dropped out of school and resists the urgings of his professors and classmates to return. Joaquin is a simple family man who chafes at his inability to provide for his poor family after breaking his leg—an injury that depleted the funds that he and his wife, Eliza, had intended to use for setting up an eatery. The three are all clients of Magda, a vicious local loan shark. One night, Fabian, acting upon his frequently ventilated absolutist views about how the world must be radically changed, murders Magda and her daughter, but it is Joaquin who is fingered as the perpetrator, because he and his wife have run up an enormous debt to the pawnbroker. Joaquin had also previously attacked the usurer when she refused to return Eliza’s heirloom ring. As a consequence, Joaquin is sentenced to life in prison. Eliza contemplates killing her children and herself to end their suffering, but decides to persevere. The film then jumps forward by about four years, finding Eliza immersed in quiet drudgery, Joaquin adapted to the world of the penitentiary despite sadistic maltreatment from a fellow detainee, and Fabian so tormented by what he has done that he is driven to the brink of madness.

 

Norte was selected for the Un Certain Regard program of the 2013 Cannes International Film Festival, where it was first screened to wide acclaim. It won the 2013 Nuremberg International Human Rights Film Award; Best Director at the 2013 Cinemanila International Film Festival; Best Picture at the 2014 International Cinephile Society Awards; the Audience Award at the 2014 IBAFF International Film Festival of Murcia; Best Picture, Best Actress (Bayani), Best Screenplay, and Best Cinematography at the 2014 Gawad Urian.  Written by Jaime Oscar M. Salazar

2010 / Color / Drama / 104 minutes / Direction: Dondon Santos / Screenplay: Shugo Praico, Francis Xavier Pasion, Coco Martin, and Rondel Lindayag / Cinematography: Timmy Jimenez / Editing: Renewin B. Alano / Production Design: Glen Herbert Adriano / Sound: Ronald de Asis / Music: Carmina Cuya / Produced by Cinemedia Films and VIP Access Media / Cast: Coco Martin (Noy), Cherry Pie Picache (Letty), Erich Gonzales (Divine), Joem Bascon (Bong), Cheska Billiones (Tata), Baron Geisler (Caloy), Jhong Hilario, Ketchup Eusebio, and Vice Ganda

 

Noy is an ambitious young man who, by submitting fake academic credentials, gets the assignment of documenting the 2010 presidential campaign of Senator Benigno “Noynoy” Aquino. His wife, Divine, is apprehensive at first, but because they need the money, she decides to go along with Noy’s charade. Noy also takes care of his mother, Letty; his older brother, Bong; and his younger sister, Tata. Jealous of the money Noy makes, Bong joins Caloy and his group of drug dealers. Meanwhile, some envious reporters start investigating Noy’s background and find out about his fake credentials. As he is about to be fired, Noy is given one last chance and is assigned to cover Senator Aquino’s campaign in Tarlac. Upon his return home, Noy sees Bong being attacked by Caloy and his gang. As he helps his brother, Noy is killed by Caloy. The film ends with Noy’s family mourning his death, intercut with scenes showing Senator Aquino’s campaign speech.

 

Joem Bascon was named Best Supporting Actor in the 2011 Gawad Urian where Noy was also nominated for Best Picture, Best Director, Best Screenplay, Best Actor, and Best Editing. Coco Martin was named Best Actor in the 2011 PMPC Star Awards for Movies.  Written by Elvin Valerio

text:
(Speck in the Water) / 1976 / Color / Drama / 118 minutes / Direction: Ishmael Bernal / Story and Screenplay: Jorge Arago / Cinematography: Arnold Alvaro / Editing: Augusto Salvador / Production Design: Betty Gosiengfiao / Sound: Godofredo de Leon / Music: The Vanishing Tribe / Produced by Crown Seven Film Productions / Cast: Elizabeth Oropesa (Maria), George Estregan (Benjamin), Daria Ramirez (Chedeng), Ella Luansing (Banang), Rustica Carpio (Chayong), Nenita Jana (Adiang), Ruben Rustia (Pedro), Lem Garcellano (Pablo), and Leticia de Guzman (Ilo)

 

As the film opens, government workers introduce modernization to villagers on a sleepy island by persuading them to raise milkfish in fishpens. An epidemic hits the lake and wipes out the fishpen produce. Benjamin owns a motorized banca that ferries passengers between the island and the neighboring town. He aggressively woos Chedeng, an intelligent island lass. Chedeng gives in to Benjamin’s wishes but, with her training as a midwife, manages to avoid getting pregnant. At the same time, Benjamin conveys his amorous intentions to Maria, Chedeng’s neighbor-friend, who in turn appears to be in love with him in her own reticent way. Chedeng leaves to settle in another town as soon as she senses a rivalry with Maria.

 

Desirous of a better life, Benjamin decides to leave the island but only after he succeeds in seducing the acquiescent Maria. The encounter leads to Maria’s pregnancy, a condition that is frowned upon by the whole village, including Maria’s own family. Later, Chedeng returns to the island to be with her sick mother, eventually taking over the latter’s practice as a midwife. Chedeng assists Maria when she gives birth. Maria undergoes an extremely difficult labor and Chedeng accidentally injures the baby’s head during the delivery.

 

Tormented and confused, Chedeng runs off wondering whether what happened was an accident or deliberate on her part. Traumatized by her baby’s death, Maria sinks into dazed lethargy. Benjamin returns to the island and learns about what has happened. He claims Maria and brings her home. The film ends with Chedeng leaving the island.

 

A landmark film, Nunal sa Tubig deals with the city/country dichotomy and issues like pollution and the erosion of traditional values in a nonlinear narrative style. It was named one of the 10 Best Films of the Decade 1970-79 by the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino, and, despite its troubles with the censors, was the first to win laurels for Best Picture in the Catholic Mass Media Awards in 1978.  Written by Menchie R. Tajan

text:
1983 / Color / Documentary (Super 8) / 45 minutes / Direction, Screenplay, Cinematography, Editing, and Sound: Nick Deocampo / Produced by Hagmut Brockmann

 

Oliver is a documentary based on the life of Reynaldo Villarama, aka Oliver, a transvestite who supports his family by engaging in bizarre sex shows in Ermita, Manila’s red-light district. The documentary deals with how the gay impersonator/performer by night manages to be a devoted husband/father by day. Oliver lives with a laundrywoman and their child in Manila’s poorest district, Tondo. The documentary depicts the sharp visual and psychological contrasts between Ermita’s nightclub row and Oliver’s life in Tondo.

 

Deocampo’s film underscores the dismal reality of gay prostitution as it exists in places like Ermita. As if in a public confessional, the main character speaks to the audience about his life and work as a homosexual prostitute. The documentary tackles the relationship between prostitution and poverty in a human, personal way. To keep body and soul together and feed his family as well, Oliver has to go through the rigorous routine of bold shows and “sex work” nightly. Although gay sex is not shown directly or explicitly, it is suggested in the sequence of Oliver doing the daring “Spider Woman Act” where the camera captures a naked but covered with décor Oliver. His impersonation of the singer Grace Jones is another visual triumph on Super 8, with Oliver singing and dancing, his body all painted in gold.

 

Oliver was Nick Deocampo’s first major work. A censored version of the film was shown at the 1986 Independent Film and Video Festival held at Fiesta Cinema in Cubao, Quezon City. Oliver was shown in over 20 film festivals in key cities abroad: Brussels, Los Angeles, San Francisco, New York, London, and Hong Kong, among others. In 1989, Deocampo won the Grand Prize and Gold Medal at the International Super 8 and Video Festival in Brussels for his trilogy: Oliver, Children of the Regime, 1985, and Revolutions Happen Like Refrains in a Song, 1987.  Written by Rosalie Matilac

text:
2013 / Color / Action, Drama / 118 minutes / Direction and Story: Erik Matti / Screenplay: Michiko Yamamoto and Erik Matti / Cinematography: Francis Ricardo Buhay III / Editing: Jay Halili / Production Design: Richard V. Somes / Sound: Corinne De San Jose / Music: Erwin Romulo / Produced by Star Cinema and Reality Entertainment / Cast: Piolo Pascual (Francis Coronel), Gerald Anderson (Daniel), Joel Torre (Mario Maghari), Joey Marquez (Joaquin Acosta), Michael de Mesa (Manrique), Leo Martinez (Pacheco), Angel Aquino, Vivian Velez, Shaina Magdayao, William Martinez, Rayver Cruz, Empress Schuck, Rosanna Roces, Lito Pimentel, and Al Tantay

 

Inspired by true events, On the Job details a web of deceit in government, the military, and the police force. The story follows the thread of two plots and four men: two prisoners, Tatang Mario Maghari and Daniel, who double as hired killers; and two men of law, NBI agent Francis Coronel and SPO1 Joaquin Acosta, who are out to unravel the masterminds behind high-profile assassinations. Tatang and Daniel, who are mentor and protégé, respectively, are covertly furloughed from prison whenever high officials, led by the corrupt Congressman Manrique and General Pacheco, want to commit quick and clean murder. But Francis, the son-in-law of Manrique and whose father was ordered killed by Pacheco, is a principled investigator who is on the verge of uncovering the trail of a crime with the help of police veteran Acosta. Just when Francis is about to bring the powerful people to justice, he is assassinated by the now well-trained killer, Daniel. And when Tatang is granted parole, he kills Daniel out of mistrust. In the end, only the powerless Acosta is left with the fatal knowledge and onerous task of setting things right.

 

On the Job won Movie of the Year, Best Director, Best Screenplay, Best Cinematography, Best Editing, Best Sound, and Best Supporting Actor (Marquez) in the 2014 PMPC Star Awards for Movies. It won Best Actor (Torre) in the 2014 Gawad Urian. It participated in the Directors’ Fortnight at the 2013 Cannes Film Festival; the 2013 Sitges International Film Festival, where it was nominated for the Focus Asia Award; the 2013 Puchon International Fantastic Film Festival, where it won the Jury’s Choice Award for feature film and the Best Actor award (Torre); and the 2014 Cleveland International Film Festival.  Written by Patrick Campos

text:
(Fight for Us) / 1989 / Color / Drama / 94 minutes / Direction: Lino Brocka / Story and Screenplay: Jose F. Lacaba / Cinematography: Rody Lacap / Editing: George Jarlego, Sabine Mamou, and Bob Wade / Production Design: Benjie de Guzman / Produced by Cannon Films. Cast: Phillip Salvador (Jimmy Cordero), Bembol Roco (Kumander Kontra), Dina Bonnevie (Trixie), Gina Alajar (Esper), R. R. Herrera (Camilo), Ginnie Sobrino, Pen Medina, Abbo de la Cruz, Ray Ventura, Connie Lauigan-Chua, Raquel Villavicencio, and Joel Lamangan

 

The film opens in 1985, in the remote barrio of Dolores. Fanatical cultists under Kumander Kontra, known as the Orapronobis (Latin for “pray for us”), brutally kill a foreign priest who came to administer the last rites to an alleged rebel, earlier murdered by the same group. In the 1986 EDSA Revolt, Jimmy Cordero leads a group of political detainees in celebrating the toppling of the Marcos dictatorship. The new dispensation orders the release of all political prisoners, including Jimmy, an ex-priest who joined the underground revolutionary movement. Shortly after, Jimmy marries Trixie, a human rights activist.

 

Jimmy begins life anew as a human rights advocate. He joins a fact-finding mission to Dolores, where the Orapronobis massacred several men suspected of being rebels. Jimmy and his brother-in-law Roland join the mission despite Trixie’s fears and her jealousy over Esper, Jimmy’s former girlfriend in the barrio. Officers of the local military detachment and the Orapronobis warn the mission members against helping the rebels. Meanwhile, Jimmy learns from Esper that the seven-year-old Camilo is their son, but they agree not to reveal this to the boy who regards Esper’s late husband as his father.

 

The Orapronobis, in connivance with the military, intensify their terroristic activities, prompting the mission group to lead the barrio folk’s evacuation to the church in Santa Filomena town. Later, the mission decides to take the evacuees to Manila for their safety. One night, Jimmy gets an unexpected visit from a former colleague in the underground movement who urges him to rejoin them. Jimmy refuses since he believes the new situation calls for a new form of struggle. The visitor leaves his phone number as well as his gun with Jimmy as there are military checkpoints along the road. Armed men ambush Jimmy and Roland on their way home from a TV appearance. Roland dies on the spot while Jimmy manages to escape despite his wounds. He recovers shortly. Trixie gives birth to their child.

 

At the refugee center, the soldiers barge in and take for questioning several men identified by a masked spy as rebels. The refugees, together with some human rights activists, protest to the government. An armed group abducts Esper and her son. Jimmy and Trixie search for them in vain. It turns out to be a plot of the Orapronobis, who accuse Esper of helping the rebels. Kumander Kontra rapes and tortures Esper in front of her son. Esper fights back and shoots at Kontra. In a frenzied rage, Kontra guns down Esper and her son, the detained barrio men, and even his own followers. Jimmy rushes to the scene of the massacre, and painfully weeps over Esper and his son. The film ends with Jimmy on the phone, calling up his underground friend.

 

Orapronobis examines the human rights situation in the Philippines after the 1986 EDSA Revolt. It dramatizes a man’s excruciating realization that the people’s victory and hope for a just and peaceful society were for naught. Commissioned for the Cannes Film Festival and financed by foreign producers, it is indicative of Brocka’s international stature as director. Orapronobis was adjudged one of the 10 Best Films of the Decade 1980-89 by the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino. Brocka himself declared that none of his previous works earned as favorable a reception from the Cannes press as Orapronobis.  Written by Menchie R. Tajan

text:
(Gold, Silver, Death) / 1982 / Color / Drama / 194 minutes / Direction: Peque Gallaga / Story: Conchita Castillo, Mario Taguiwalo, and Peque Gallaga / Screenplay: Jose Javier Reyes / Cinematography: Rody Lacap / Editing: Jesus Navarro / Production Design: Don Escudero and Rodell Cruz / Sound: Luis Reyes, Ramon Reyes / Music: Jose Gentica V / Produced by Experimental Cinema of the Philippines / Cast: Manny Ojeda (Claudio Ojeda), Sandy Andolong (Maggie Ojeda), Cherie Gil (Trining), Fides Cuyugan-Asensio (Inday), Joel Torre (Miguel), Maya Valdez (Jo Russell), Lorli Villanueva (Viring), Ronnie Lazaro (Hermes Mercurio), Abbo de la Cruz (Melchor), Liza Lorena (Nena Ojeda), Mely Mallari (Estrella), and Agustin Gatia (Lucio)

 

A film about the decline of two aristocratic families in Negros during the Pacific War, it begins with the debut of Maggie Ojeda. In the garden, Trining is getting her first kiss from her childhood sweetheart, Miguel. Don Claudio Ojeda and his fellow hacenderos are discussing the war. Because Miguel is not joining the army, he is mocked for being a “Mama’s boy.” The news of the fall of Corregidor stops the celebration.

 

As war approaches the city, the Ojedas decide to take refuge with the Lorenzos, their longtime family friends, at their provincial hacienda. The matriarchs of these two families cling to their aristocratic lifestyle. Their deliberate refusal to accept the war is jarred by the frequent melancholic fits of Maggie who pines for her fiancé, and the transitions of Miguel and Trining from playful children to adventurous adults.

 

Two friends, Jo Russell and Viring, join the Ojedas and the Lorenzos. As the enemy approaches, the clans decide to move on further to the forest lodge of the Lorenzos. The relative peace is shattered when a group of harried guerrillas arrives. Jo treats their wounds. One of the wounded, Hermes Mercurio, is left behind. The family again mocks Miguel for his apathy and cowardice; Trining says Miguel did nothing when a Japanese soldier killed a woman bathing in the nearby river. It was Mercurio who killed the Japanese. Maggie consoles Miguel, and the boy decides to take shooting lessons from Mercurio.

 

Then Melchor, the trusted foreman, steals Viring’s jewelry, justifying the theft as payment for his services. He attempts to break the loyalty of the other servants and is driven away. Later, Melchor takes his revenge when he returns to the hut with bandits. They take supplies, rape Inday, and cut off Viring’s finger when she refuses to give up her ring. Despite the harm done to her family, Trining joins the bandits.

 

The experience forms a bond between Maggie and Miguel; the survivors cope by resuming their mahjong sessions. Miguel decides to hunt down the bandits and bring Trining back. He finds the bandits, but his newfound valor is replaced by a manic desire to kill. The bloody climax is followed by an epilogue. The setting is the same, but the time is shortly after the war. Maggie and Miguel announce their engagement. The survivors attempt to resume their old lifestyle despite their scars from the war.

 

Critics acclaimed Oro, Plata, Mata as a cinematic tour de force and a directorial triumph. It shows that war brings out the worst in human beings. The epic scale and production design are “operatic.” Regarded by many as Gallaga’s most important film, it launched the movie career of Joel Torre. It won the Gawad Urian for Best Picture, Best Director, Best Cinematography, Best Production Design, Best Sound, and Best Music; and the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences awards for Best Supporting Actress (Lorena) and Best Production Design. The Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino chose it as one of the 10 Best Films of the Decade 1980-89. A digitally restored version of Oro, Plata, Mata was released by ABS-CBN’s Film Archives in cooperation with Central Digital Laboratory in 2013.  Written by Luna Sicat, with notes from Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

text:
(The Blossoming of Maximo Oliveros) / 2005 / Color / Drama / 100 minutes / Direction: Auraeus Solito / Story and Screenplay: Michiko Yamamoto / Cinematography: Nap Jamir / Editing: Kanakan Balintagos and Clang Sison / Production Design: Christina Dy, Clint Catalan, and Lily Esquillon / Sound: Tad Ermitaño / Music: Pepe Smith / Produced by UFO Pictures / Cast: Nathan Lopez (Maximo Oliveros), J. R. Valentin (Victor), Soliman Cruz (Paco), Neil Ryan Sese (Boy), Ping Medina (Bogs), and Bodjie Pascua (Dominguez)

 

The effeminate 12-year-old Maximo Oliveros belongs to a family of macho and petty criminals. He takes on womanly chores for his widower-father Paco and two brothers, Boy and Bogs. One night, Maxi gets assaulted by two teenagers, and a policeman comes to his rescue. The rookie policeman Victor is new to the neighborhood. Maxi befriends his savior and falls in love with him. Later, Victor believes one of Maxi’s brothers may be involved in the murder case he is investigating. Victor tries to extract the truth from the boy. Paco finds out what the policeman has done and, together with his two sons, beats him up to teach him a lesson. Maxi attends to the bruised Victor and gets to steal a kiss. Victor stays away from the kid and asks him to find someone his own age. Maxi is brokenhearted.

 

A new chief, Dominguez, chooses Victor as his protégé. Victor and company search Maxi’s house and detain Bogs. Paco chastises Maxi for prioritizing Victor over his own family. The old enemies, Paco and Dominguez, meet face-to-face. Initiating Victor into the dark side of the law, Dominguez shoots Paco in full view of the rookie, and Maxi witnesses the murder, too. Bogs is set free. The two brothers plan to exact revenge, but Maxi implores them to stop for fear that they would die, too. Months after, on his way to school, Maxi is followed around by Victor. When Victor pulls over on the street corner, gets off the jeep, and poses for the boy’s attention, Maxi simply ignores his old flame. Forced to choose between family and first love, Maxi finally grows up.

 

In the first Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival, Ang Pagdadalaga won the Special Jury Prize, Best Production Design, and a Special Citation for the performance of Lopez. It won the Gawad Urian for Best Picture, Best Screenplay, Best Cinematography, and Best Editing. In 2011, it was chosen by the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino as one of the 10 Best Films of the Decade 2000-2009.

 

Ang Pagdadalaga has also enjoyed international acclaim, winning awards in, among others, the 2005 Montreal World Film Festival, 2006 Berlin International Film Festival, Las Palmas de Gran Canaria Film Festival, Rotterdam International Film Festival, and Torino International Gay and Lesbian Film Festival. In 2013, a stage adaptation of the film, Maxie: The Musicale, produced by Bit by Bit Company, was mounted at the PETA Theater Center.  Written by Ronald Baytan

text:
(At the Top) / 1971 / Black and White / Drama / 117 minutes / Direction, Story, and Screenplay: Ishmael Bernal / Cinematography: Delfin Carretas / Editing: Teofilo de Leon / Sound: Luis Reyes / Music: Francisco Buencamino Jr and George Sison / Produced by Frankesa Films / Cast: Rita Gomez (Paloma Miranda), Vic Vargas (Pinggoy Morales), Eddie Garcia (Ruben), Rosemarie Gil, Ronaldo Valdez, Zeneida Amador, Joonee Gamboa, Ernie Zarate, Ellen Esguerra, Subas Herrero, Mon Espeleta, Elvira Manahan, Leticia de Guzman, Narlina Robles, Edru Abraham, Jonas Sebastian, Petronilo Bn. Daroy, Roy Alvarez, and Edwin Tecson

 

The film is set in Manila during the bomba (sex-drama film) craze. Ruben, a respected director forced to make a bomba film, is in need of a substitute actor. He plucks Paloma Miranda, a taxi dancer, from a nightclub he once visited while on location shooting. Given the biggest break of her life, Miranda creates a fictionalized biography to hide her past from the press and her fans.

 

The new movie star then brings along the taxi driver Pinggoy Morales, a married man who was her lover when she was still working in the nightclub. She introduces him to the movies to become a stuntman. Eventually, he becomes her leading man. In due time, success goes to their heads and they become intoxicated with the fame and fortune of showbiz.

The moral disintegration is balanced by the director who strives to develop himself as an artist amidst all this commercialism. In the movie, the director tries to explain to his actress the meaning of and need for art, but the latter is too dense and intoxicated to care.

 

Pagdating sa Dulo is Ishmael Bernal’s first film. It won for him the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences award for Best Screenplay. Using the film-within-a-film structure, Pagdating is a commentary on commercialism and materialistic values, a sex melodrama, a love story, and an exposé on the movie industry in general and the making of a porno movie in particular. The film was chosen by the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino as one of the 10 Best Films of the Decade 1970-79. It marked the advent of Bernal as a serious director who would help revitalize the film industry.  Written by Rosalie Matilac

text:
(The Journey of Stars into the Dark Night) / 2012 / Color / Drama / 117 minutes / Direction and Screenplay: Arnel Mardoquio / Cinematography: Arnel Barbarona and McRobert Nacario / Editing: Arnel Barbarona / Production Design: Bagwani Ampalayo / Sound: Ditoy Aguila, Arbi Barbarona, and Machiaveli Serapio / Produced by Cinema One Originals, Skyweaver Productions, Red Motion Media, Hyde Out Entertainment, and Alchemy of Vision and Light / Cast: Fe Virtudazo-Hyde (Amrayda), Glorypearl Dy (Fatima), Irish Karl Monsanto (Faidal), Roger Gonzales (Bapa Indo), Perry Dizon, and Christine Lim

 

In Jolo, Sulu, Moro rebels, having turned to kidnapping for ransom, seek to evade the local and American troops that are hot on their trail. Among the rebels are the parents of a young boy named Faidal. Only Faidal and his mother are able to make it back home alive. She bears a backpack stuffed with money, and it is this that she entrusts to him some moments before the soldiers emerge to capture her. She ensures his narrow escape by sending him down a makeshift zipline. Faidal seeks out his aunt Amrayda. Together with her companion, Fatima, Amrayda approaches Bapa Indo, the family patriarch, and asks for his help in fleeing to a safer place. As they undertake their getaway, the trio must overcome obstacles and come to terms with the possibility of being caught in the seemingly endless violence that surrounds them, even as they cling to the hope for a different future. Their flight ends in tragedy, however, with their pursuers eventually managing to track them down.

 

Ang Paglalakbay ng Mga Bituin sa Gabing Madilim won the Special Jury Prize at the 2012 Cinema One Originals Digital Film Festival for which it was made. It also won the Grand Jury Prize at the 2012 Cinemanila International Film Festival, Best Picture at the 2013 Gawad Urian of the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino, and Best Screenplay at the Young Critics Circle Film Desk Citations for 2012.  Written by Jaime Oscar M. Salazar

article_title: Pagputi ng Uwak, Pag-itim ng Tagak
text:
(When the Crow Turns White, When the Heron Turns Black) / 1978 / Color / Drama / 150 minutes / Direction: Celso Ad. Castillo / Story: Celso Ad. Castillo and Ruben A. Nicdao / Screenplay: Celso Ad. Castillo, Ishko Lopez, Lando Perez Jacob, Ruben Arthur Nicdao / Cinematography: Romeo Vitug / Production Design: Peter Perlas / Music: George Canseco / Produced by VS Films / Cast: Vilma Santos (Julie Monserrat), Bembol Roco (Dido Ventura), Joonee Gamboa (Maestro Roque), Lito Anzures (Kumander Salome), Adul de Leon (Beatriz), Angie Ferro (Miguela), Mona Lisa, Yolanda Luna, Mervin Samson, Olivia O’Hara, Mario Escudero, and Robert Talabis

 

The film is set in a provincial town rife with agrarian unrest in the 1950s. Julie Monserrat, on vacation from school in Manila, stays with her aristocratic aunts, Beatriz and Miguela. During the town fiesta, she meets Dido Ventura, a young man from one of the town’s poor families. Dido falls in love with Julie despite his mother’s resentment of the old Monserrats who deprived the Venturas of their property. After a night of passion the two decide to elope. But Julie’s aunts intervene and she decides against going away with him.

 

Enraged and disappointed, Dido meets his former girlfriend Cristy, who berates him. He beats up the girl and causes the death of her brother. Cristy’s father, the town mayor, orders his arrest. Dido flees and joins the rebel movement.

 

Meanwhile, Julie’s brief liaison with Dido results in her pregnancy. She learns that her real father is the sarsuwela composer Maestro Roque, who influences her into deciding to keep her baby. Maestro Roque arranges a rendevous for Julie and Dido on the night of Good Friday. Dido, who is seeing his newborn child for the first time, is accompanied by Kumander Salome. The police, who have been tipped off about the meeting, attack and rout the outnumbered rebels. The only survivors of the dissident band are Julie and Dido’s baby.

 

Pagputi ng Uwak received the Gawad Urian for Best Picture, Best Director, Best Screenplay, Best Sound, and Best Supporting Actor (Gamboa). From the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences, it won awards for Best Picture, Best Director, Best Story, Best Cinematography, Best Musical Score, Best Production Design, and Best Supporting Actress (Ferro). The film is outstanding in its visual poetry and as a vehicle for the Castillo style of mixing history with political commentary.  Written by Menchie R. Tajan

text:
(Plea) / 1940 / Black and White / Musical, Drama / Direction: Octavio Silos / Story and Screenplay: Luis Nolasco and Octavio Silos / Cinematography: Cesar Silos / Sound: Arthur Meehleib / Music: Francisco Santiago and Miguel Velarde / Produced by Excelsior Films / Cast: Rosario Moreno (Amparing), Rudy Concepcion (Ernesto), Franco Garcia (Don Andres), Silvia Rosales, Naty Bernardo, Pedro Faustino, Nati Rubi, Billy Vizcarra, Joaquin Gavino, SSS Trio, Moonlight Troubadours, and the UP Dance Chorus

 

This musical romance revolves around the story of a poor country maiden, Amparing, who falls in love with Ernesto, the son of a wealthy hacendero, Don Andres. The young man disguises himself as a poor farmer to make sure that the girl is not just after his money or his name. Later, he discovers that his own father is his rival for the hand of the young lady. Taking advantage of the poverty of Amparing’s family, Don Andres offers financial assistance to Amparing for her ailing mother, leaving the girl with no choice but to marry the landlord. The climax is a fluvial procession that is supposed to take Amparing and her wedding entourage to church where the father waits. The young man shows up in a banca, arriving in time for the young couple to elope.

 

Pakiusap used Francisco Santiago’s famous kundiman (love song) for its title and theme song. It is one of the five surviving films from the pre-World War II period. The four others are Zamboanga (Fury in Paradise), 1937; Giliw Ko (My Love), 1939; Tunay na Ina (Real Mother), 1939; and Ibong Adarna (Adarna Bird), 1941.  Written by Ramon Jocson and Ellen Bomasang, with notes from Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

text:
(The Call of the River) / 2004 / Color / Drama / 120 minutes / Direction: Cesar Montano / Story: Cesar Montano / Screenplay: Cris Vertido / Cinematography: Ely Cruz / Editing: Renato de Leon / Production Design: Allan Leynes and Ron Heri Tan / Sound: Nestor Arvin Mutia and Angie Reyes / Music: Nonong Buencamino / Special Effects: Dick Sto. Domingo / Produced by CM Films / Cast: Cesar Montano (Duroy), Juliana Palermo (Iset), Jackie Woo (Fumio Ohkohara), Rebecca Lusterio (Bikay), Daria Ramirez (Miri), Caridad Sanchez (Lahi), Phil Anthony (John Smith), Reiven Bulado (Ibô), Hans Lindgreen (Father Silvio), Joel Torre, Ronnie Lazaro, and Suzette Ranillo

 

Panaghoy sa Suba is set in the island province of Bohol, Visayas, during the Japanese occupation of the Philippines and the years just before and after it. Duroy ferries a boat along the majestic Loboc River for a living. He is devoted to his family of two siblings, Ibo and Bikay, and his mother, Miri, who eventually dies of heartache and illness when their father deserts them for an American woman. Before the war, Duroy and Ibô fall in love with the same woman, Iset, but her aunt Lahi hopes that Iset could marry the American businessman and landowner John Smith, for whom Iset and Ibô work. Smith is also attracted to the beauty of Iset, but it is with Duroy that Iset is in love. Duroy, however, defers to his brother, Ibô, out of respect. One day, Smith fires Ibô for talking with Iset. Ibô retaliates violently and is killed by Smith. When the war erupts, Smith is drafted into the American army. The Boholanos, including Duroy, flee to the mountains to organize a guerrilla troop, while the women and children are left in town with a Spanish priest, Father Silvio. The Japanese commander Fumio Ohkohara is smitten by Iset, and Lahi once again attempts to marry her to the foreigner. But when Japanese soldiers publicly execute the priest, Iset turns against her family and runs off into the mountains to join the guerrillas. The Boholano men eventually launch an attack, and American troops arrive to help them defeat the Japanese forces. Duroy kills Ohkohara in the process. After the war, Smith returns to Bohol, expecting to pick up his life where he left off. But Duroy beats and humiliates him, although he spares Smith’s life. Iset also rejects Smith finally. In the end, peace is restored. Duroy and Bikay remember the dearly departed, the casualties of war. Duroy resumes his trade as a boatman and life goes on.

 

Panaghoy sa Suba was premiered in the 2004 Metro Manila Film Festival where it won Second Best Picture, Best Director, Best Screenplay, Best Cinematography, Best Musical Score, Best Supporting Actress (Lusterio), and the Gatpuno Antonio J. Villegas Cultural Award. It won Best Screenplay, Best Cinematography, and Best Musical Score in the 2005 Film Academy of the Philippines Awards; Best Picture, Best Director, Best Cinematography, Best Editing, Best Music, Best Sound, and Best Actor (Montano) in the 2005 Gawad Urian; and Best Screenplay and Best Visual Effects in the 2005 Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Awards. It was also exhibited in several international film festivals. At the 2005 Brussels International Independent Film Festival, the film won the Special Jury Prize and the Best Director award.  Written by Patrick Campos

text:
(The Blacksmith) / 1980 / Color / Fantasy, Adventure / Direction: Ronwaldo Reyes aka Fernando Poe Jr / Story: Carlo J. Caparas / Screenplay: Fred Navarro / Cinematography: Ver Reyes / Editing: Augusto Salvador / Sound: Cesar Lucas / Music: Ernani Cuenco / Produced by FPJ Productions / Cast: Fernando Poe Jr (Flavio), Max Alvarado (Lizardo), Liz Alindogan, Bentot Jr, Lito Anzures, and Paquito Diaz

 

Ang Panday is a fantasy film based on the komiks serial novel of Carlo J. Caparas. The film hero is Flavio, a blacksmith. While working one day, a shining, swirling metallic object appears before him. Flavio creates a sword out of this metallic object from outer space. The sword has powers against black magic.

 

With his sword, Flavio fights the evil of Lizardo, who practices black magic, summons zombies, monsters, and other creatures of darkness to terrorize the town where Flavio lives. Flavio successfully eradicates Lizardo’s denizens of darkness. Lizardo vows to destroy Flavio. It is believed that Lizardo is a difficult adversary because he cannot be killed.

 

Finally, Flavio and Lizardo meet in a fantastic duel. In the end, the magic sword kills Lizardo. The sword pierces the “immortal” Lizardo who slowly deteriorates into an old man until he dies.

 

Because of its enormous success, Ang Panday was followed by three other sequels. Pagbabalik ng Panday (Return of the Blacksmith), 1981, received the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) awards for Best Cinematography and Best Sound. Ang Panday … Ikatlong Yugto (The Blacksmith … Third Chapter), 1982, was awarded the FAMAS for Best Cinematography and Best Production Design. Ang Panday IV: Ika-Apat na Yugto (The Blacksmith IV: Fourth Book), 1984, won the FAMAS for Best Special Visual Effects. An animated series based on the story of Panday was also produced for television. Ramon “Bong” Revilla Jr played the protagonist in the 2009 remake of the movie, which was also followed by a sequel, Ang Panday 2, in 2011. In 2005, ABS-CBN adapted Ang Panday into a TV series that starred Jericho Rosales.  Written by Rosalie Matilac, updated by Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

text:
(Pepot Superstar) / 2005 / Color / Comedy, Drama / 110 minutes / Direction and Screenplay: Clodualdo del Mundo Jr / Cinematography: Herky del Mundo / Editing: Daniel Adapon / Production Design: Cesar Hernando / Art Direction: Yeye Calderon / Sound: Lorrie Ilustre and Rachelle Tesoro / Music: Lorrie Ilustre / Produced by Buruka Films / Cast: Elijah Castillo (Jose “Pepot” Rizalino), Jeffrey Quizon (Tirso), Bituin Escalante (Nora), Joy Soler-de Castro (Madam Hulatsky), Cedric Lamberte (Denggoy), Rio Locsin, Cris Villanueva, Nonie Buencamino, Shiela Mae Junsay, Jian Pascual, Lou Veloso, Yoyoy Villame, and Jose Javier Reyes

 

In the 1970s, Jose “Pepot” Rizalino is a 10-year-old boy who dreams of becoming a movie star. Born to a poor family, Pepot helps his parents by selling komiks in their neighborhood. While not an exceptionally bright student, Pepot participates in his school play, a production of Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura). Hoping to get the lead part, Pepot is disappointed that he is cast as the lion in the production, much to the amusement of his classmates. In between classes, Pepot whiles away his free time watching movies with his best friend Denggoy, as he continues to daydream about making it big in the entertainment industry. Meanwhile, his father leaves the family to work abroad, only to come home unsuccessful, as he was victimized by an illegal recruiter who promised him a job in Saudi Arabia. To drown his sorrows, the father holds a drinking session with his neighbors, with Pepot’s pet pigeons as pulutan (appetizer). Angry with his father, Pepot leaves his family and finds a temporary home in the fair, under the care of carnival performers Nora and Tirso who encourage Pepot to follow his dreams. Learning that a film director is on the lookout for young actors, Pepot goes about preparing for his audition. He goes back home to ask money from his mother so he can buy new clothes, but he loses all the money, no thanks to his bestfriend, in a game of cara y cruz (head or tail). Taking pity on the kid, Tirso and Nora, with the help of the carnival fortune-teller, Madam Hulatsky, sew a new wardrobe for Pepot and accompany him to his audition. Unfortunately, the director is not too keen on auditioning the kids, including Pepot, saying that the children do not look the part. Heartbroken, Pepot returns home to his pigeons, only to vanish without a trace eventually. In the end, the writer reveals that Pepot, while now a mere memory, is still with us—from karaoke corners to barangay singing contests, for Pepot Artista is the symbol of the country’s fascination with popular entertainment and escapist fantasy.

 

The film won the Balanghai trophy for Best Editing and Best Film in the 2005 Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival, the Silver Screen Award for Best Actor (Castillo) in the Singapore International Film Festival, and the PMPC Star Award for Child Performer of the Year (Castillo).  Written by Anne Frances Sangil

text:
(Fetch a Pail of Water) / 1999 / Color / Drama / 98 minutes / Direction: Jeffrey Jeturian / Screenplay: Armando Lao / Cinematography: Shayne Clemente / Editing: Robert Vasadre / Production Design: Ronnie Cruz / Sound: Joe Climaco / Music: Jay Durias / Produced by Good Harvest Productions / Cast: Ana Capri (Gina), Marcus Madrigal (Nonoy), Harold Pineda (Jimboy), Estrella Kuenzler (Cion), and Becky Misa (Mrs Alano)

 

Gina is a poor teenager who lives in the slums with her grandmother Cion and two siblings. She ekes out a living by street-vending and helping her grandmother who works as a laundrywoman for Mrs Alano, a loan shark in the public market who lives in the nearby tenement house. Gina is courted by Nonoy, the neighborhood tough guy who fetches water for the tenement people for a fee. But Gina intends to marry a rich man so she flirts openly with Jimboy, the son of Mrs Alano. Jimboy grabs the chance and takes Gina to a motel. Gina becomes pregnant and harbors thoughts of marrying Jimboy. Mrs Alano does not approve of Gina and goads her son to break up with her. When her grandmother dies and her brother runs away to become a call boy, Gina feels her world collapsing. Nonoy comes to her rescue and raises money for her by organizing some gambling during her grandmother’s wake. Then, he and his gang beat Jimboy to a pulp to teach him a lesson. A huge fire ravages the slum and Nonoy’s father dies. It is now Gina’s turn to console him.

 

Pila Balde is remembered for Jeturian’s realistic portrayal of the plight of the urban poor, which is reminiscent of Lino Brocka’s sociorealist films. The film won Best Screenplay, Best Production Design, and Best Editing at the 2000 Gawad Urian, while the Young Critics Circle gave the film its awards for Best Achievement in Cinematography and Visual Design and Best Editing. Internationally, the film won the Network for the Promotion of Asian Cinema Award at the 1999 Cinemanila International Film Festival and the Gold Award (for Independent Films–Mature category) at the 2000 WorldFest Houston.  Written by Elvin Valerio

text:
2008 / Color / Drama / 106 minutes / Direction: Dante Nico Garcia / Screenplay: Dante Nico Garcia and Benjamin Lingan / Cinematography: Charlie Peralta / Production Design: Raymund George Fernandez / Editing: Danny Añonuevo / Sound: Albert Michael Idioma / Music: Jessie Lasaten / Produced by Panoramanila Pictures / Cast: Judy Ann Santos (Ploning), Gina Pareño (Intang), Mylene Dizon (Celeste), Meryll Soriano (Alma), Ces Quesada (Nieves), Tony Mabesa (Susing), Cedric Amit (Digo), Crispin Pineda (Toting), Eugene Domingo (Juaning), and Lucas Agustin (Siloy)

 

A mysterious Taiwanese fisherman Muo Sei lands in the sleepy town of Cuyo, Palawan, looking for a woman named Ploning. Flashback to the 1980s and Ploning is a 30-year-old beautiful woman who patiently waits for the return of her lover Tomas, a man who left Cuyo 14 years ago in search of a better life in Manila. Cuyo is a place that has not seen rain in several years. Meanwhile, Ploning continues with her various roles—a dutiful daughter to the town patriarch Susing; a committed supporter to the grieving Intang; an honorary sister to her extended family, Nieves and Toting; a wise ally to simpleton Alma; a supporter to the brokenhearted Siloy; and a co-mother to the half-paralyzed Juaning. Juaning’s young son Digo looks up to Ploning as a surrogate mother.

 

One day, Ploning finally decides to go to Manila to look for Tomas. Afraid that he might lose Ploning for good, Digo seeks the help of the nurse Celeste, a guest of the town. Celeste claims to have known and fallen in love with a man named Tomas and followed him to Cuyo to find out if he loved him back. Ploning denies that her Tomas and the man Celeste fell in love with are the same man. On the day of the fiesta, the rain finally comes but Ploning has disappeared. Flashforward to the present and it is revealed that Muo Sei is actually Digo, and he has not stopped searching for Ploning.

 

Ploning won Best Musical Score and Best Visual Effects in the 2009 Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Awards, and Movie Musical Scorer of the Year in the 2009 PMPC Star Awards. It also won the Swarovski Trophy for Director at the 2008 Asian First Film Festival.  Written by Elvin Valerio

article_title: A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino

photos.desc:
Naty Crame-Rogers, Vic Silayan, and Daisy Avellana in A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino, 1965

(Photo courtesy of Mike de Leon)

text:
1965 / Black and White / Drama / 107 minutes / Direction: Lamberto V. Avellana / Story: Nick Joaquin / Screenplay: Donato Valentin and Trinidad Reyes / Cinematography: Mike Accion / Editing: Enrique Jarlego / Sound: Demetrio Carianga, Luis Reyes / Music: Mike Velarde Jr / Produced by Diadem Pictures / Cast: Daisy H. Avellana (Candida), Naty Crame-Rogers (Paula), Conrad Parham (Tony Javier), Pianing Vidal (Lorenzo Marasigan), Vic Silayan (Bitoy), Nick Agudo (Manolo), Sarah K. Joaquin (Pepang), Francisco “Koko” Trinidad (Don Perico), Oscar Keesee, Veronica Palileo, Manuel Ojeda, Rino Bermudez, Alfred Xeres-Burgos, Nena Ledesma, Polly Anders, and Miriam Jurado

 

The film, based on the celebrated play by Nick Joaquin of the same title, revolves around the lives of Candida and Paula, the spinster daughters of Don Lorenzo Marasigan, the distinguished painter.

 

Because of hard times and dwindling resources, Candida and Paula cannot pay their bills and are pressured by their brother Manolo and sister Pepang to give up their house, which the latter want to sell. Candida and Paula blame their plight on their father who squandered their mother’s fortune on his “art,” and now has become an indifferent recluse, seldom leaving his studio. The old man angrily works on a painting depicting a scene in Virgil’s Aeneid, showing Aeneas carrying his father Anchises on his shoulder away from the burning city of Troy. In the painting, Lorenzo shows two sides of himself—as the young man Aeneas in his prime, and as the sickly man Anchises in the twilight of his years. After bequeathing the painting to his daughters and encouraging them to sell it, Don Lorenzo attempts suicide but his life is spared. Feeling guilty about driving their father to suicide, the daughters decide to keep the painting.

 

The priceless painting becomes the object of greed. Tony Javier, a boarder of the Marasigans as well as Paula’s unscrupulous suitor, schemes to make himself prosperous by brokering the sale of the painting to an American collector. Candida, too, imagines that the painting would bring them money and end their economic woes. Because of this, Candida allows Tony Javier to seduce Paula so she will agree to sell the painting.

 

In the end, Paula realizes Tony Javier’s hidden motives and in a fit of rage destroys the painting. Daughters are thus liberated from their selfishness. The old man reconciles with them and ends his isolation. The ironic happy ending is highlighted by the sights and sounds of the October feast of La Naval in honor of the Virgin of the Rosary. For the first time in years, Don Lorenzo and his daughters celebrate the event as one family together with Manolo, Pepang, and old friends against a backdrop of memory, nostalgia, and approaching war, the war that will doom the Marasigans, their way of life, and Intramuros, the old Manila.

 

Portrait was exhibited at the 1967 Frankfurt Film Festival. A digitally restored copy of the movie premiered at the Cultural Center of the Philippines in 2015. The restoration was funded by the Film Development Council of the Philippines and the National Film Archive of the Philippines, and initiated by Mike de Leon. The screening was preceded by the launch of a commemorative book, Contra Mundum, by Angelo Lacuesta.  Written by Rosalie Matilac, with notes from Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

(Shackled) / 2012 / Color / Drama / 95 minutes / Direction, Editing, and Production Design: Lawrence Fajardo / Screenplay: Zig Dulay / Cinematography: Louie Quirino / Sound: Albert Michael Idioma, Addis B. Tabong, and Wildsound / Music: Joseph Lansang / Produced by Quantum Films / Cast: Nico Antonio (Jess Biag), Bangs Garcia (Grace Rosuello), Art Acuña (Inspector Domingo), Nor Domingo (PO1 Damian), Jake Macapagal (PO2 Santiago), Wendy Valdez, and Susan Africa

 

The story happens one day in the life of Jess Biag and his run-in with the city police. Jess is a petty thief who prowls the crowded streets surrounding Quiapo Church. He routinely snatches wallets, jewelry, and cellular phones from unwitting pedestrians to sell or trade for money he uses to help his mother support their family. On this particular day, he grabs the phone of the callcenter agent Grace Rosuello, who persists in retrieving her phone for fear of leaking her scandalous videos with her boyfriend. Grace reports the theft to the police who apprehend Jess after a long chase. For the first time, Jess goes through the debilitating process of investigation, which begins with getting official documents from the barangay clinic and the fiscal’s office to getting brutally beaten up and detained. The three policemen handling his case, Inspector Domingo, PO1 Damian, and PO2 Santiago, go to great lengths to terrorize Jess and drag him through the initial process of criminal prosecution. When the guilt of Jess is established, he is instead offered freedom and protection by the policemen on one condition—that he would, hereon, become a vigilante-for-hire. At day’s end, Jess is baptized by fire, as he is made, at gunpoint, to kill his first criminal. In the end, the stolen cellular phone is recovered and returned to Grace, and Jess leaves the police station, now an agent for crimes committed by the police.

 

Posas competed in the Directors Showcase section of the 2012 Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival, where it won Best Film and Best Supporting Actor (Acuña). Acuña also received the Best Supporting Actor award in the 2013 Gawad Urian. It won Best Film in the 2013 Hanoi International Film Festival.  Written by Patrick Campos

(The President) / 2012 / Color / Historical Drama / 162 minutes / Direction, Story, and Screenplay: Mark Meily / Cinematography: Carlo Mendoza / Editing: Jason Cahapay and Ryan Orduña / Production Design: Danny Red / Sound: Albert Michael Idioma / Music: Jessie Lasaten / Theme Song: Marizen Deneza Soriano, Apl.de.Ap., Jamir Garcia, and Leandro Ansing / Special Effects: Erick Torrente / Supervising Historian: Emmanuel Calairo / Produced by Scenema Concept International Inc, CMB Films, Wavepost Inc, and Viva Films / Cast: Jeorge Ejercito Estregan (Emilio Aguinaldo), Nora Aunor (Maria Agoncillo), Christopher de Leon (Antonio Luna), Cesar Montano (Andres Bonifacio), Cristine Reyes (Hilaria Aguinaldo), Ronnie Lazaro (Gen Candido Tirona), Bayani Agbayani (Gen Baldomero Aguinaldo), Felix Roco (Gregorio del Pilar), Troy Montero (Col Frederick Funston), Allan Paule, Allen Dizon, Alvin Anson, Baron Geisler, Emilio Garcia, Wendell Ramos, John Arcilla, Mike Lloren, Ian de Leon, Alicia Meyer, Sunshine Cruz, Joko Diaz, Gary Estrada, Sid Lucero, Ronnie Quizon, Joonee Gamboa, Yul Servo, Lou Veloso, Ian Veneracion, Dennis Padilla, Roi Vinzon, Archie Adamos, Soliman Cruz, Epy Quizon, Pen Medina, William Martinez, Tony Mabesa, Hero Bautista, and John Regala

 

El Presidente is a biopic on the life of controversial historical figure Emilio Aguinaldo. The film is related through a series of flashbacks occasioned by Aguinaldo’s writing of his autobiography, Mga Gunita ng Himagsikan (Memoirs of the Revolution), 1964. The film shows his youth and his induction into the secret revolutionary organization Katipunan, as well as his assumption of leadership of the organization’s Cavite chapter. Much of the film is devoted to representing Aguinaldo’s military career as general during the revolution against Spain, as he marshals his forces in spite of lack of weapons, to his participation in the struggle against American occupation, aided by the young general Gregorio del Pilar. It dramatizes the conflict between the Magdalo and Magdiwang factions of the Katipunan, which leads to the killing of Andres Bonifacio; Aguinaldo’s signing of the Pact of Biak-na-Bato in Bulacan; his return from exile in Hong Kong to declare Philippine independence; and his eventual capture by Col Frederick Funston. The closing sequences of the film show Aguinaldo in his old age, through the years of American colonization, the Japanese occupation, and his death in 1964.

 

El Presidente garnered awards in the 2012 Metro Manila Film Festival, including Second Best Picture, Best Supporting Actor (Montano), Youth Choice Award, Best Sound, Best Musical Score, and Best Original Theme Song. It won Best Picture, Best Director, Best Screenplay, Best Story, Best Cinematography, Best Production Design, Best Editing, Best Musical Score, Best Sound, Best Actor (Estregan), Best Supporting Actor, Best Visual and Special Effects, and Best Original Theme Song in the 2013 Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Awards; Best Picture, Best Cinematography, Best Production Design, Best Music, and Best Sound in the 2013 Film Academy of the Philippines Awards; and Movie of the Year, Movie Director of the Year, Original Screenplay of the Year, Cinematographer of the Year, Movie Production Designer of the Year, Movie Editor of the Year, Movie Actor of the Year, and Movie Original Theme Song of the Year in the 2013 PMPC Star Awards for Movies.  Written by Patrick Campos

text:
(Golden Dagger) / 1933 / Black and White / Drama / Direction: Jose Nepomuceno / Story: Antonio Sempio / Produced by Felix Paterno and Francisco Sta. Maria / Cast: Alma Bella (Dalisay), Carlos Padilla (Dante), Paco Zamora (Don Sergio), and Tina del Rosario

 

Dalisay is a poor woman being punished by Don Sergio. Her only sin is bearing and loving the child of Dante, Don Sergio’s son. The angry, cruel Don Sergio forcibly separates the lovers during their wedding. He tries to bribe Dalisay to leave his son but fails. After giving birth, Dalisay tries to start a new life in the province by starting a small store, which Don Sergio burns to the ground. Later, he even manipulates the law and imprisons Dalisay for the crime of theft. Dalisay, after imprisonment, puts up a cabaret called Templo ni Benus where she attempts to poison the cruel old man. She is slapped with charges of attempted murder but is given temporary liberty. When Dante finally returns to Dalisay, he discovers that she has lost her mind. She dies of heart failure. Don Sergio repents.

 

Based on the popular novel of Antonio Sempio, Punyal na Ginto was the first talking picture in Tagalog and the first Filipino film with sound in its entirety. During its grand premiere, a 20-piece orchestra furnished the background. The movie’s lavish settings were made by technicians imported from Hollywood, and the production was considered to be technically advanced during its time. A major turning point in motion picture production, the film heralded a new era in Philippine cinema.  Written by Rosalie Matilac

text:
(An Affair) / 1982 / Color / Drama / 114 minutes / Direction: Ishmael Bernal / Screenplay: Ricardo Lee, Raquel Villavicencio, and Ishmael Bernal / Cinematography: Sergio Lobo / Editing: Augusto Salvador / Production Design: Benjie de Guzman / Sound: Vic Macamay / Music: Winston Raval / Produced by Regal Films / Cast: Vilma Santos (Marilou), Christopher de Leon (Emil), Jimi Melendez, Bing Caballero, Olive Madrilejos, Beth Mondragon, and Thaemar Panuncialman

 

Emil is a married college instructor who is having an affair with Marilou, a planetarium guide. Temporarily separated from his wife, Emil moves in with Marilou in an old house he has inherited from relatives. The initially blissful relationship turns sour as Emil’s real character comes to the fore. He turns out to be a domineering male chauvinist who dictates to Marilou how she should run the house, how she should behave with or without him around. Marilou becomes more and more dissatisfied with the relationship, as Emil continues to be insensitive to her needs. Marilou’s friends give her all sorts of advice: she should break up with him, stick it out with him, get a lover to make him feel insecure, pack up and leave for the United States. Marilou goes back to her parents. It does not take long for her to miss Emil so she sees him again. However, Emil’s wife has come back. Marilou settles for an arrangement where Emil spends three days of the week with her. During one of those days, Emil gets very sick. Marilou takes him to the hospital. The doctors tell her that Emil has brain aneurysm. She calls up Emil’s wife who takes over the task of looking after him. While spending a weekend at Marilou’s place, Emil suffers a fatal stroke. After the funeral, his widow collects all of Emil’s things kept by Marilou, leaving only a picture of the deceased. In the end Marilou decides to leave for the United States to begin life anew.

 

Relasyon deals frankly with the sensitive issues of gender roles and divorce. It makes a statement against machismo and presents the validity of divorce. Relasyon won for Vilma Santos all the best actress awards from the four major award-giving bodies: the Catholic Mass Media Awards, Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino, Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences, and Film Academy of the Philippines.  Written by Menchie R. Tajan

text:
(Life on the Tracks) / 2002 / Color / Documentary / 70 minutes / Direction: Ditsi Carolino / Cinematography: Ditsi Carolino and Nana Buxani / Editing: Valerio Bonelli / Sound: Peter Marquez / Produced by the National Film and Television School (United Kingdom) and Ditsi Carolino

 

This documentary is an intimate portrait of a poor Filipino couple named Eddie and Pen Renomeron and their five children who reside along the train tracks of Sampaloc, Manila. Eddie is a balut vendor, barely making a living for the family. Pen’s health is deteriorating due to breast cancer, adding to the family’s economic woes and unsettling situation.

 

Shot in cinema verité style, the film shows the everyday struggles of a poor family to make ends meet in a dilapidated squatter’s area they consider home. Bickering and sweet, Eddie and Pen use humor and resiliency in facing their Herculean economic and emotional problems.

 

Riles won Best Documentary Film at the 2003 Cinemanila International Film Festival, was listed in the Top 10 Audience Awards at the 2002 International Documentary Film Festival Amsterdam, earned the Best Factual Film (Student) at the 2003 Royal Television Society Award, London, and was acquired for broadcast by the British Broadcasting Corporation in 2005.  Written by Rica Arevalo

text:
(Rizal in Dapitan) / 1997 / Color / Historical Drama / 100 minutes / Direction: Tikoy Aguiluz / Screenplay: Jose F. Lacaba / Story Research and Additional Screenplay: Vic Torres, Noel Vera, Lualhati Bautista, Mirana Medina-Bhunjun, and Tikoy Aguiluz / Cinematography: Nap Jamir and Romy Vitug / Editing: Mirana Medina-Bhunjun / Production Design: Judy Lou de Pio and Presly Ruiz / Sound: Albert Rima / Music: Jaime Fabregas / Produced by Independent Cinema Association of the Philippines Inc and MovPix International Inc / Cast: Albert Martinez (Jose Rizal), Amanda Page (Josephine Bracken), Roy Alvarez (Captain Carnicero), Jaime Fabregas (Father Sanchez), Cris Michelena (Father Obach), Paul Holmes (George Taufer), Rustica Carpio, Nonie Buencamino, and Soliman Cruz

 

After publishing his incendiary novels in Europe and coming home to found La Liga Filipina, Jose Rizal was arrested by Spanish officials in 1892 for charges of rebellion. Rizal sa Dapitan is a chronicle of his four-year exile in Dapitan, in the province of Zamboanga, Mindanao. Here the widely traveled polyglot and cosmopolitan doctor Rizal adapts to the rural life of his open prison in the last years of his life. Rizal befriends Captain Carnicero, the colonial authority in Dapitan; rebuffs the efforts of Father Sanchez to win him back to the Catholic Church; and resists the machinations of Father Obach to make him renounce his heretical beliefs. In spite of Father Obach’s efforts to ostracize him and scare the townspeople away from having relations with a heretic under pain of damnation, Rizal begins to affect the whole town for the better. He creates a water-supply system and establishes a makeshift hospital that services even the poorest folks of Dapitan. The film details Rizal’s life as a teacher in the school that he founded, innovatively instructing his students in the languages and arithmetic, as well as in athletics and the arts, and imparting the value of courage. The film also tells the stormy love story of Rizal and Josephine Bracken, the Eurasian stepdaughter of Rizal’s patient, George Taufer. It shows their life together as common-law husband and wife. The film ends with Rizal leaving Bracken and Dapitan to be a doctor in Cuba. The townspeople gather on the shore, mourning as they bid him farewell.

 

In the 1998 Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Awards, Rizal sa Dapitan won Best Picture, Best Director, Best Screenplay, Best Story, and Best Production Design, as well as the Centennial Award. It also won Movie of the Year, Movie Director of the Year, Original Screenplay of the Year, Cinematographer of the Year, and Movie Sound Engineer of the Year in the 1998 PMPC Star Awards for Movies.  Written by Patrick Campos

text:
2010 / Color / Animation, Adventure, Drama / 105 minutes / Direction: Luis C. Suárez / Story: Raymond Lee and Luis C. Suárez / Screenplay: Luis C. Suárez, Jade Francis Castro, and Tey Clamor / Editing: Joey Conejos and Joana Vasquez / Storyboards: Carlo Y. Santos / Production Design: William O. Moraga / Animation Rigging Lead: Angelo C. Cardona / Animation Lead: Paul I. Eliscupides / Modeling Lead: Leon Anthony M. Enriquez / Texture and Lighting Lead: Avril Grace B. Villodres / SFX and Compositing Lead: Aylmer Alfred Ong Velez / Sound Design: Ronaldo B. de Asis and Connie M. Valdriz / Sound Effects Editing: Connie M. Valdriz / Audio Post Supervision: Ronaldo B. de Asis and Lynnel de Mesa / Music: Ria Osorio and Gerard Salonga / Produced by Ambient Media, Thaumatrope Animation Production, and Star Cinema / Voice Actors: Zaijan Jaranilla (Nico), Aga Muhlach, Vhong Navarro, Eugene Domingo, Mika dela Cruz, and Jairus Aquino

 

RPG Metanoia is an animated film that follows the adventures of Nico who spends most of his time playing either the online game Metanoia or Philippine games, like yo-yo, patintero (block the enemy), agawan base (capture the base), and tumbang preso (knock the can down). Nico, through his avatar Zero, has unwittingly found a powerful game item, the helmet, that might have allowed the online game to put thousands of players into a trance. Players around the world have become slaves to the game, unable to turn their faces away from their computer monitors. But Nico and his friends have been unaffected.

 

Nico now takes it upon himself, with the help of his friends, to enter the world of the online game to find the source of the evil power and to save the other players. It turns out that Zero has taken a life of its own and is out to trap Nico in Metanoia. Nico squares it off with Zero, revealing in the process that the real kid is more powerful than his online version. The children face many other powerful enemies besides, but they triumph with the teamwork that they have developed as friends and the skills that they have honed in playing street games in the real world.

 

RPG Metanoia is the first Philippine feature-length film in 3D animation. It was premiered in the 2010 Metro Manila Film Festival where it won Third Best Picture, Best Sound Engineering, Best Original Theme Song, and the Most Gender-Sensitive Film award. It won Best Sound in the 2011 Film Academy of the Philippines Awards and Best Visual Effects in the 2011 Golden Screen Awards. It was also nominated for Best Animated Feature in the2011 Asia Pacific Screen Awards.  Written by Patrick Campos

text:
1939 / Black and White / Historical Drama / Direction: Lamberto V. Avellana / Cinematography: William Jansen / Produced by Filippine Films / Cast: Leopoldo Salcedo (Montalan), Salvador Zaragosa (Sakay), Arsenia Francisco, Bert LeRoy, and Pedro Faustino

 

During the early years of the American colonial regime, Sakay, a barber from Tondo, tries to revive the Katipunan in Manila but is arrested and thrown in jail on charges of sedition. Following the proclamation of amnesty in July 1902, he is released from prison but joins the guerrillas in the mountains of Laguna. Eventually, he takes over command of the guerrillas, assisted by Montalan.

When it was shown in 1940, Sakay was chosen as the best picture by a jury of journalists. It was the first movie directed by Lamberto V. Avellana. text:
1993 / Color / Historical Drama / 90 minutes / Direction: Raymond Red / Story: Raymond Red and Ian Victoriano / Screenplay: Ian Victoriano / Cinematography: Lauro Rene Manda and Raymond Red / Editing: Lauro Rene Manda and Raymond Red / Production Design: Danny Red / Art Direction: Danny Red and Ronald Red / Sound: Gaudencio Barredo / Music: Ronnie Quesada / Produced by Alpha Omega Productions and Zeta Enterprises / Cast: Julio Diaz (Macario Sakay), Tetchie Agbayani (Elena), Pen Medina (Lucio de Vega), Leopoldo Salcedo, Ray Ventura, Karlo Altomonte, Archie Adamos, Nanding Josef, Raul Arellano, and John Arcilla

 

In the early years of the 20th century after the capture of Emilio Aguinaldo by the Americans, a band of Filipino fighters led by Macario Sakay continue to challenge the American forces and to destabilize its colonial occupation and rule of the Philippines following the defeat of the Spanish colonizers. Establishing the Tagalog Republic with its own constitution, Sakay and his men (referred to as “bandits” by the new colonizers) operating in the Southern Tagalog region enjoy popular support from the native peasants, and even from some members of the principalia (ruling class). As the uprising continues, the Americans adjust their battle plan, consequently driving the locals against Sakay and his militia. While the American Constabulary soldiers pursue Sakay and his men into the forest, some members of the principalia decide to cooperate with the American forces, believing that the promised National Assembly composed of Filipinos who will be trained by the Americans on how to run a government is the proper course of action. Encouraged by the thought of such an assembly, Sakay and his men decide to leave camp in order to discuss terms with the Americans, but they are captured by the American soldiers and, ultimately, tried for their crimes against the government. Found guilty of banditry, Sakay and his general Lucio de Vega are condemned to die by public hanging.

 

Sakay won the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences award for Best Art Direction and was nominated in several categories—namely, Best Picture, Best Director, Best Actor (Diaz), and Best Supporting Actor (Medina). It was also nominated in the 1994 Gawad Urian for Best Picture, Best Director, Best Supporting Actor, Best Cinematography, Best Production Design, and Best Sound.  Written by Anne Frances Sangil

text:
1981 / Color / Drama / 105 minutes / Direction: Laurice Guillen / Story: Laura A. Guillen / Screenplay: Ricardo Lee / Cinematography: Romeo Vitug / Editing: Efren Jarlego / Production Design: Santiago Bose / Sound: Luis Reyes / Music: Ernani Cuenco / Produced by Bancom Audiovision Corporation / Cast: Gina Alajar (Salome), Johnny Delgado (Kario), Dennis Roldan (Jimmy), Bongchi Miraflor, Bruno Punzalan, Armida Siguion-Reyna, Tony Santos, Venchito Galvez, Lily Miraflor, Edna Mae Landicho, Francisco “Koko” Trinidad, Cris Vertido, Carpi Asturias, and Jimmy Santos

 

Salome has fatally stabbed a city-bred young fellow, Jimmy. The reason for the crime is deceptively simple: she stabbed him because he became too amorous in his advances, and she is a married woman. However, as the story unfolds, Salome’s husband Kario, an ordinary farmer, owns the crime himself. The story becomes more complex as the film explores the three conflicting versions of the crime.

 

Salome claims that she killed Jimmy in self-defense as he tried to rape her. According to her, Jimmy forced his way into her hut while her husband was away. On the other hand, the people in the fishing village refuse to believe Salome whom they view as a seductress. One woman accuses Salome of luring one of her sons to his death, and believes that what happened to her son must also have happened to Jimmy. Kario’s version contradicts the first two versions. He claims that he caught Salome and Jimmy committing adultery and in anger forced her to kill her lover. The film ends with Kario and Salome leaving the village to start life anew. At the beach, Salome looks sadly at the sea. Kario embraces her from the back, as though protecting her from the wind. Slowly he draws his knife and drives it into Salome’s back. Her face registers pain at first, then liberation and peace.

 

The film deviates from the normal single narrative in the three conflicting accounts of the same murder. This, and the film’s psychological scope and highly visual storytelling technique, are the director’s homage to Japanese master filmmaker Akira Kurosawa, particularly his film, Rashomon. The picture’s atmosphere objectifies moods and feelings of characters in the sea and the earth, in wind and fire.

 

Salome won the Gawad Urian for Best Picture, Best Director, Best Screenplay, Best Actress (Alajar), and Best Editing.  Written by Luna Sicat

text:
(Second Chances) / 1995 / Color / Drama / 121 minutes / Direction: Olivia M. Lamasan / Story: Jose Javier Reyes and Olivia M. Lamasan / Screenplay: Mel Mendoza-Del Rosario, Shaira Mella Salvador, and Olivia M. Lamasan / Cinematography: Romeo Vitug / Editing: George Jarlego / Production Design and Art Direction: Randy Gamier / Sound: Ramon Reyes / Music: Willy Cruz / Produced by Star Cinema / Cast: Aga Muhlach (Jerry), Lea Salonga (Agnes), William Martinez, Cherry Pie Picache, Tina Paner, Rosemarie Sonora, Tommy Abuel, Gina Pareño, Eula Valdez, Lorli Villanueva, Raoul Aragonn, Ric Arellano, and Mandy Ochoa

 

Jerry and Agnes are young lovers whose relationship is tested when Agnes is petitioned by her US-based mother to live with her in San Francisco. Agnes flies to America but only with the intention of staying temporarily, as she waits for Jerry to save enough money so they can finally get married. Their brief separation allows Jerry to advance in his career, minus the distractions of being in a relationship, and forces Agnes to be independent as she struggles with her own job as a caregiver in the United States. Their long-distance relationship takes its toll on both Agnes and Jerry, and they find themselves pulled farther apart as they get used to their setup. By the time Jerry is able to visit Agnes with hopes of winning her back, Agnes has risen from the ranks and is now a successful real estate agent living independently and comfortably in the States. Jerry decides to stay in the United States, giving up his white-collar job in Manila for a life of odd jobs in the States, just to be with Agnes. As Jerry experiences firsthand the difficulties of staying and working illegally in America, sometimes even at the hands of cruel Filipino employers, he realizes the injustice and discrimination many Filipinos go through and so chooses to go back to the Philippines. Agnes follows Jerry back to the Philippines and the two reunite in the middle of the city bustle.

 

Sana Maulit Muli won Best Picture, Best Actor (Muhlach), Best Screenplay, and Best Production Design in the 1996 Gawad Urian; Best Screenplay, Best Cinematography, and Best Production Design in the 1996 Film Academy of the Philippines Awards; and Best Theme Song (“Sana Maulit Muli” by Gary Valenciano) in the 1996 Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Awards.  Written by Anne Frances Sangil

text:
(Enter Love) / 1998 / Color / Drama / 99 minutes / Direction: Jeffrey Jeturian / Screenplay: Armando Lao / Cinematography: Lee Meily / Editing: Roberto Vasadre / Production Design: Ronnie Cruz / Sound: Willie Islao / Music: Joy Marfil / Produced by Good Harvest Productions / Cast: Nida Blanca (Linda), Angel Aquino (Karen), Gerald Madrid (Mike), Chinggoy Alonzo (Eulogio), Julio Diaz (Jun Perez), Richard Bonnin (Norman), Vangie Labalan (Tinang), and Pinky Amador (Marie Perez)

 

When Eulogio, a respected university professor, dies from a heart attack, his wife, Linda, is left behind to bear the pain of his loss. Meanwhile, her youngest son, Mike, traces the things his father left behind, leading him to one of Eulogio’s former students, Karen, a part-time computer saleslady who had an affair with his father. He meets her and finds out that she is pregnant with his father’s baby. He befriends her, sees her regularly, and soon develops feelings for her. One day, as Linda rummages through the things in her husband’s office, she is stunned to see several pictures of Eulogio and Karen together. Linda searches for Karen’s address and when she finally finds her house, she is shocked to see Mike there. Discovering the things that her husband and now her son have kept from her, Linda breaks down and cries uncontrollably. However, in time, Linda allows herself to forgive Karen, even visiting her as she gives birth to Eulogio’s child. In the end, there is a bond between the two women that only they can understand.

 

Sana Pag-ibig Na was part of producer Lily Monteverde’s experiment in discovering new filmmakers, who were required to work within a small budget and tight production schedule. The film was a critical but not a commercial success. Nida Blanca stood out for her performance and was named Best Actress by the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences in 1999. The film also won Best Editing in the Young Critics Circle Film Desk Citations and was nominated in nine categories at the 1999 Gawad Urian.  Written by Elvin Valerio

text:
1955 / Black and White / Action, Drama / 96 minutes / Direction: Gerardo de Leon / Story: Ho Chapman and Teodorico C. Santos / Screenplay: Teodorico C. Santos and Jack Gutierrez / Cinematography: Emmanuel Rojas / Editing: Vic Calub / Production Design: Jose de los Reyes / Sound: Demetrio de Santos / Music: Tito Arevalo / Produced by Vistan-Chapman / Cast: Jose Padilla Jr (Sanda Wong), Danilo Montes (Liu Chen), Lola Young (Lan Ying), Gil de Leon (Koh Loo), Lilia Dizon, Mario Bari, Vicente Liwanag, Bruno Punzalan, Santiago Agapito, Bonifacio Vistan, Jose Lapid, and Lee Ngan

 

The wealthy landowner Liu Chen and his lovely bride Lan Ying are about to be married when they are disrupted by the unexpected visit of Sanda Wong, who has come to rob Liu Chen. Sanda Wong is easily recognized by Koh Loo, the garrison captain, who is a treacherous man. A trap is set and Sanda Wong is ensnared, but he manages to escape, ironically through the help of the man he came to rob, Liu Chen.

 

The incident draws the two men close to each other; they come to treat each other almost like blood brothers. Sanda Wong thanks Liu Chen for saving his life. Unknown to Liu Chen, during his absence his bride is raped by Koh Loo. As a result, she commits suicide. When Liu Chen returns, Koh Loo has him arrested. Liu Chen escapes and becomes a member of Sanda Wong’s band. But complications set in when he falls in love with Sanda Wong’s betrothed. Not wishing to risk his friendship with Sanda Wong, Liu Chen leaves the band. He is captured by Koh Loo. But Sanda Wong comes to the rescue, and the two men renew their friendship.

 

Sanda Wong was shot in the Wader Studio in Hong Kong. It was a co-production venture between a Filipino producer, Manuel Vistan Jr, and his Chinese counterpart, Ho Chapman. The 1950s saw other Philippine co-productions with Asian filmmakers. Another Hong Kong-based film company, Golden Harvest Productions, co-produced Hongkong Holiday, 1957, and Pagoda, 1958, with Sampaguita Pictures. LVN co-produced Hawayana (Hawaiian Girl), 1953, with an Indonesian-based film studio, P. T. Persari Films.   Written by Agustin Sotto
