text:
(For We Are Only Human) / 1963 / Black and White / Drama / Direction: Armando de Guzman / Story: Mario Mijares Lopez / Screenplay: Johnny Pangilinan / Music: Tony Maiquez / Produced by Hollywood Far East Productions / Cast: Lolita Rodriguez, Marlene Dauden, Eddie Rodriguez, Maria Theresa, Nello Nayo, Patricia Mijares, Anthony Gonzales, Lyn D’Amour, Joseph de Cordova, and Joe Sison

 

A self-made entrepreneur and his wife are happily married. Conflict starts when he is attracted to a beautiful woman, who becomes his mistress.

 

Sapagkat started the series of dramatic hits that dealt with the same story formula: the man caught between two women. After Sapagkat, Eddie Rodriguez would be typecast in the part for many years: a good family man in his 30s, well-dressed, successful, so nice and sweet that the “other woman” cannot help but fall in love with him. If he is driven into the other woman’s arms, it is not because he is bad, or that the other woman is scheming and sly. Rather, he is driven to infidelity by circumstances or events created by the wife or the family situation.

 

Sapagkat won Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences awards in 1963 for Best Story, Best Screenplay, Best Music, Best Actor (Rodriguez), and Best Supporting Actress (Dauden). The theme song by Tony Maiquez became a popular hit for decades.  Written by Rosalie Matilac

text:
(In the Navel of the Sea) / 1998 / Color / Drama / 116 minutes / Direction: Marilou Diaz-Abaya / Story and Screenplay: Jun Lana / Cinematography: Romy Vitug / Editing: Jess Navarro / Production Design: Len Santos / Sound: Ramon Reyes / Music: Nonong Buencamino / Produced by GMA Films and Film Experts (FILMEX) Inc / Cast: Jomari Yllana (Peping), Chin Chin Gutierrez (Mrs Santiago), Elizabeth Oropesa (Rosa), Apple Zuñiga (Maya), Rolando Tinio, Pen Medina, Tanya Gomez, Mia Gutierrez, Ronnie Lazaro, Manjo del Mundo, Lawrence Dilag, and Jhong Hilario

 

Based on Jun Lana’s Mga Bangka sa Tag-araw (The Boats in Summer), which won first prize in the screenplay category of the 1996 Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature, Sa Pusod ng Dagat tells the magical realist story of a male midwife. Set in a remote fishing island after the war, Peping grows up with no choice but to learn the trade of his mother Rosa, the only midwife in their village. Peping loses his beloved father to the sea at a very young age, and so he is reared only by his independent mother. At first, the boy does not mind learning the trade of Rosa; but as he grows up, he becomes increasingly aware of prejudices and more and more embarrassed by the arrangement. At the same time, Peping is coming of age. He is beginning to see his childhood friend Maya in a different way. But Maya runs away and goes to town, before anything between them could develop. Peping leaves the village to follow Maya. In town, he unexpectedly begins an affair with a married woman, Mrs Santiago. But Mrs Santiago cannot leave her husband to be with him, and Maya is leaving for Manila with big ambitions. Peping returns home a changed young man. He learns that his mother, pregnant out of wedlock, has committed suicide to save him from shame. After all of Peping’s experiences with women, he finally accepts the responsibility of being the village midwife.

 

Sa Pusod ng Dagat won Best Cinematography and Best Screenplay in the 1999 PMPC Star Awards for Movies, and Best Sound in the 1999 Film Academy of the Philippines Awards. It had its world premiere in the 1998 Berlin Film Festival, and was screened in many other international film festivals, including Hong Kong, Fukuoka, Tokyo, Bombay, London, Barcelona, Nantes, Oslo, Toronto, Montreal, Cairo, Haifa, New York, and Chicago. It won the International Federation of Film Critics/Network for the Promotion of Cinema Award in the 1998 Singapore International Film Festival and the Audience Favorite Choice Award (Honorable Mention) in the 1999 Cinequest San Jose Film Festival.  Written by Patrick Campos

Sa Pusod ng Dagat won Best Cinematography and Best Screenplay in the 1999 PMPC Star Awards for Movies, and Best Sound in the 1999 Film Academy of the Philippines Awards. It had its world premiere in the 1998 Berlin Film Festival, and was screened in many other international film festivals, including Hong Kong, Fukuoka, Tokyo, Bombay, London, Barcelona, Nantes, Oslo, Toronto, Montreal, Cairo, Haifa, New York, and Chicago. It won the International Federation of Film Critics/Network for the Promotion of Cinema Award in the 1998 Singapore International Film Festival and the Audience Favorite Choice Award (Honorable Mention) in the 1999 Cinequest San Jose Film Festival.  Written by Patrick Campos

text:
(The Kite) / 1999 / Color / Drama / 85 minutes / Direction: Gil M. Portes / Story and Screenplay: Jose Y. Dalisay Jr and Gil M. Portes / Cinematography: Louie Quirino / Editing: Tara Illenberger / Production Design: Tanny Perez / Sound: Albert Michael Idioma / Music: Joy Marfil / Produced by GMA Films and Teamwork Productions / Cast: Ricky Davao (Homer Agustines), Lester Lansang (Rex), Jennifer Sevilla (Anita), Mark Gil (Jack Lumauig), Roy Alvarez, and Nanding Josef

 

Since the death of his wife, Homer Agustines, a policeman, has tried to raise his 10-year-old son, Rex, the best way he can. Rex looks up to Homer, and Homer is careful to be upright and worthy of his son’s admiration. But Homer has a temper and is given to drunkenness, which proves to be a fatal combination. One morning, while nursing a hangover, Homer allows his irritation to cloud his judgment. He shoots a boy whom he suspects is a thief, but who is only trying to retrieve a kite from the rooftop. He then attempts a series of cover-ups, even as he is hounded by guilt. Unbeknownst to Homer, Rex is a witness to the crime, and the boy is weighed down by guilt. He tries to find solace from Miss Anita, his teacher, but to no avail. The town is crying for justice, while the investigator, Jack Lumauig, is slowly piecing together what happened. When the father attempts to leave town with his son, Rex is unable to bear the injustice, the lies, and the knowledge of his father’s crime, and tells on Homer. In the end, Homer is sentenced to jail.

 

Davao received the top acting honors in the 2000 Gawad Urian and the 2000 PMPC Star Awards for Movies. The latter also honored the film with the Original Screenplay of the Year award. Lansang won the 2000 Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Best Child Actor award. The film was nominated for theGolden George in the1999 Moscow International Film Festival.  Written by Patrick Campos

photos.desc:
Jose Padilla Jr, Rita Gomez, and Anita Linda in Sawa sa Lumang Simboryo, 1952

(Cesar Hernando Collection)

text:
(Python in the Old Dome) / 1952 / Black and White / Drama, Fantasy / Direction: Gerardo de Leon / Story: Amado Yasofta (as serialized in Mabuhay Komiks) / Screenplay: Teodorico C. Santos and Pierre Salas / Cinematography: Emmanuel Rojas / Editing: Frank Estepa / Sound: Demetrio de Santos / Music: Tito Arevalo / Produced by Premiere Productions / Cast: Jose Padilla Jr (Tulume), Anita Linda (Sabel), Rita Gomez (Marta), Lauro Delgado, Boy Francisco, Jose Romulo, Corazon Rivas, Vicente Liwanag, Max Alvarado, Miguel Anzures, Elvie Calderon, Ding Tello, Pancho Pelagio, and Tony Tolman

 

Tulume is a simple farmer peacefully tilling his land when his wife is killed by Spanish guardias civiles (constables). Their brutality drives him to join a band of outlaws. Some years later, the leader of the outlaws is killed in an encounter with militia and Tulume becomes their leader. Marta, the daughter of the former bandit leader, endorses him heartily because she is in love with him. Tulume is entrusted with a precious amulet that has power over snakes guarding a treasure.

 

One day, another victim of Spanish cruelty falls into their hands. This is Sabel, a pretty lass whose father was murdered by the Spaniards. Tulume is clearly attracted to Sabel from the very start, arousing the jealousy of Marta. To destroy the relationship between them, Marta discredits Tulume before his men, and he is forced to resign as chief of the outlaws. With a heavy heart, Tulume takes his leave, taking Sabel with him. Under an assumed name, he tries to lead a new life with the help of Sabel, burying his past behind him. But their idyllic existence is short-lived. The Spanish authorities discover his real identity, and once more he becomes a fugitive. For the sake of Sabel, he is forced to seek the help of Marta, promising the guarded treasure in return for Sabel’s life.

 

The film established de Leon’s mastery over film material utilizing popular komiks and native folklore. He shot this movie on location in Santa Maria, Ilocos Sur, where a century-old church sits on a hill amidst breathtaking scenery. He made Gomez ride a horse up and down the hundred-step stone stairs of the church so that the men, who were afraid to hurdle the steps on their horses, would follow her example. He also commissioned his brother, Arevalo, to compose a haunting ballad sung by children to frame the komiks story within the structure of an awit or korido (metrical romance), as a tale handed down from generation to generation.

 

Sawa sa Lumang Simboryo won the first Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences awards for Best Picture and Best Cinematography in 1953.  Written by Agustin Sotto

article_title: Ang Sayaw ng Dalawang Kaliwang Paa

photos.desc:
Rocco Nacino and Paulo Avelino in Ang Sayaw ng Dalawang Kaliwang Paa, 2011

(Cinemalaya)

text:
(The Dance of Two Left Feet) / 2011 / Color / Drama / 85 minutes / Direction and Screenplay: Alvin Yapan / Cinematography: Arvin Viola / Editing: Mai Dionisio and Ramil Plofino / Production Design: Aped Santos / Sound: Mark Locsin, Cedric Regino, Arnold Reodica, and Cedrik Valera / Music: Christine Muyco and Jema Pamintuan / Choreography: Eli Jacinto / Produced by Alem Chua Productions / Cast: Jean Garcia (Karen), Paulo Avelino (Marlon), and Rocco Nacino (Dennis)

 

Weaving together poetry and dance to examine feminist and gay concerns, the film depicts the charged relationships that develop between Karen, a university literature teacher, and two of her students, Marlon and Dennis. Marlon, who has a crush on Karen, wants to impress her but is floundering in class. He discovers that she moonlights as a dance instructor, with Dennis, his classmate, acting as her assistant. Marlon asks Dennis to teach him the basics of movement before formally enrolling at Karen’s studio, hoping to catch her attention by being able to display seemingly untutored skill. Although Karen sees through the scheme and confronts Marlon about it, she encourages Marlon’s interest, pushes the two boys to reconcile when Marlon wrongly accuses Dennis of revealing the ruse, and casts them as the leads for a performance of the epic Humadapnon. As Marlon delves more deeply into the world of dance, he gradually discovers its kinship to poetry and struggles with the intricate complexities of desire when he and Dennis foster a closeness that goes beyond the bounds of friendship, which Marlon acknowledges in the end.

 

Ang Sayaw ng Dalawang Kaliwang Paa won Best Cinematography and Best Musical Score in the New Breed section of the 2011 Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival. It also won Best Picture, Best Director, Best Screenplay, Best Actor (Avelino), Best Supporting Actress (Garcia), Best Cinematography, and Best Music at the 2012 Gawad Urian; Best Performance by an Actress in a Lead Role (Drama) and Breakthrough Performance by an Actor (Nacino) at the 2012 Golden Screen Awards; New Movie Actor of the Year (Nacino) at the 2012 Star Awards for Movies; and Best Achievement in Sound Design and Aural Orchestration at the Young Critics Circle Film Desk Citations for 2011. Internationally, it won the Bronze Award at the 2011 Festival de Cine de Bogota, and received nominations for several categories at the 2012 SoHo International Film Festival and the 2011 Hawaii International Film Festival.  Written by Jaime Oscar M. Salazar

text:
1985 / Color / Drama / 126 minutes / Direction: Peque Gallaga / Story: T. E. Pagaspas and Romel Bernardino / Screenplay: Rosauro Q. dela Cruz / Cinematography: Ely Cruz / Editing: Jess Navarro / Production Design: Don Escudero / Sound: Rudy Baldovino / Music: Jaime Fabregas / Produced by Regal Films / Cast: Daniel Fernando (Danny), Anna Marie Gutierrez, Orestes Ojeda, and Amanda Amores

 

This film revolves around the lives of three characters, their passions and violence that erupt against the background of a dilapidated Binondo accesoria (apartments). Danny, a student boarder and peeping Tom, is obsessed with the wife of a security guard. The couple occupies the room directly beneath Danny’s apartment. The young man’s perverse fixation grows more intense when he begins to spy on the unsuspecting couple through holes in the floor. Each night, after the guard’s shift, the voyeur would watch the man undress his wife and make love to her. Emboldened by his sexual fantasies, he corners the wife one night while the husband is away. Much to his surprise, his advances are welcomed by the woman. They carry on a steamy, passionate affair, building up to the climax when the husband catches them in the act. The film ends with the guard’s brutal murder of his wife and her lover.

 

Scorpio Nights attempted to explore the limits of depicting sex in Filipino movies. Its merits lie largely in its production values, which raise it above its origins in porno film. Especially notable is Gallaga’s ability to manipulate the sexual encounters between the three characters to advance the plot. Critics have also cited the film’s exceptional production design and skillful cinematography, blended with competent editing. It won the Gawad Urian for Best Cinematography, Best Music, and Best Sound.  Written by Galileo Zafra

text:
(Dead Sure) / 1996 / Color / Drama / 111 minutes / Direction: Tikoy Aguiluz / Screenplay: Tikoy Aguiluz, Jose F. Lacaba, and Amado Lacuesta / Cinematography: Jun Dalawis / Editing: Mirana Medina-Bhunjun and Edgardo Vinarao / Production Design: Edgar Martin Littaua / Art Direction: Aris dela Cruz / Sound: Albert Rima / Music: Jessie Lasaten / Produced by Neo Films / Cast: Michelle Aldana (Karen), Gary Estrada (Sonny), Ruby Moreno (Ruby), Albert Martinez (Jake), Julio Diaz (Eddie), Pen Medina (Mang Pepe), Liza Lorena, Teresa Loyzaga, Suzette Ranillo, Eddie Rodriguez, Manjo del Mundo, Evelyn Vargas, Cesar Bendigo, Vangie Labalan, Ace Espinosa, and Philip Lazaro

 

Karen is an insurance agent who moonlights as a guest relations officer in a club at night. Her success as an insurance agent is dependent on how well she treats her male clients. Karen uses sex to encourage her clientele to buy insurance policies from her company. One of her clients is Sonny, a married man and a car salesman, who eventually falls in love with her. But Karen wants to keep things professional since she herself is married and is only trying to save up enough money for her family back in lahar-ravaged Pampanga. Things take a wild turn when her best friend’s lover Jake attempts to sexually assault Karen after a night of drinking. Karen escapes with the help of her longtime taxi driver, Mang Pepe. She asks Mang Pepe to take her back to her hometown, but the driver brings her to a secluded area where he rapes Karen and eventually murders her. In the end, her friend Ruby and Sonny visit Karen’s family in Pampanga to offer their condolences and to give Eddie, Karen’s husband, the life insurance policy Karen bought for herself, with her family as beneficiaries of the one million peso policy payout.

 

Segurista was nominated in several award-giving bodies and won Best Picture, Best Director, Best Supporting Actor (Martinez), Best Screenplay, Best Editing, and Best Production Design in the 1997 Gawad Urian. It also received the 1997 Film Academy of Philippines award for Best Supporting Actor. The film was the official Philippine entry in the Oscar Awards for Best Foreign Language Film in 1996.  Written by Anne Frances Sangil

text:
(Service) / 2008 / Color / Drama / 87 minutes / Direction:  Brillante Mendoza / Story: Armando Lao and Boots Agbayani Pastor / Screenplay: Armando Lao / Cinematography: Odyssey Flores / Editing: Claire Villa-Real / Production Design: Benjamin Padero and Carlo Tabije / Art Direction: Harley Alcasid and Deans Habal / Sound: Emmanuel Nolet Clemente / Music: Gian Gianan / Produced by Center Stage Productions and Swift Productions, in association with the Asian Cinema Fund and the Hong Kong Asia Film Financing Forum / Cast: Gina Pareño (Flor Pineda), Jaclyn Jose (Nayda), Julio Diaz (Lando), Coco Martin (Alan), Kristoffer King (Ronald), Dan Alvaro (Jerome), Mercedes Cabral (Merly), Bobby Jerome Go (Jonas), Roxanne Jordan, Dido dela Paz, and Benjie Filomeno

 

Flor Pineda is the matriarch of a family that lives in several rooms inside a run-down moviehouse called Family Theater. This theater exclusively shows pornographic movies frequented daily by gay patrons who are after quick and sleazy sexual transactions. Amidst the daily maintenance concerns that hound them in managing the theater, the family members must also deal with their own personal problems. Flor is in the middle of a bigamy lawsuit she filed against her husband, but her own son Jerome stands as witness in favor of the father. Nayda, Flor’s daughter, despite being a nursing graduate, is burdened by the overall upkeep of the theater, in addition to being a wife to Lando and mother to Jonas. And Alan, a relative living with the family and the cinema’s resident billboard painter, gets his girlfriend Merly pregnant, to the great disappointment of Flor. In the end, after having lost her case, Flor vows to appeal the court’s decision, Alan packs his bag and leaves both Merly and the theater, and Nayda has to cope with her husband’s discovery of her feelings toward the theater’s projectionist Ronald, another relative who lives with the family.

 

Nominated for the Palme d’Or in the 2008 Cannes International Film Festival, Serbis won the Golden Kinnaree Award in the Southeast Asian Competition section of the 2008 Bangkok International Film Festival; the Best Director and Best Actress (Pareño) awards in the 2008 Pacific Meridian International Film Festival of Asian-Pacific Countries in Vladivostok, Russia; and the Best Supporting Actress (Pareño) award in the 2009 Asian Film Awards. It won Best Picture, Best Director, Best Cinematography, and Best Production Design in the 2009 Gawad Urian. It was also honored by the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino as one of the 10 Best Films of the Decade 2000-2009.  Written by Anne Frances Sangil

text:
1984 / Color / Horror / 124 minutes / Direction: Emmanuel H. Borlaza, Ishmael Bernal, and Peque Gallaga / Screenplay: Jose Carreon, Amado Lacuesta, and Rosauro dela Cruz / Cinematography: Ely R. Cruz / Editing: Jess Navarro / Production Design: Don Escudero, Ben Payumo, and Elmer Manapul / Sound: Rudy Baldovino / Music: Jaime Fabregas / Produced by Athena Productions / Cast: (“Baso”) Joel Torre (Johnny), Rey PJ Abellana (Paolo), Arlene Muhlach (Girlie), Rosemarie Gil, Tony Carreon; (“Pridyider”) Charito Solis (Lorna), Janice de Belen (Virgie), William Martinez (Dodong), Lito Gruet (Carlos Torres), Mon Alvir, Emily Loren; (“Manananggal”) Herbert Bautista (Douglas), Irma Alegre (Anita), Peewee Quijano, and Mary Walter

 

Shake, Rattle & Roll is a horror film consisting of three distinct episodes. The first episode, “Baso” (Glass), directed by Borlaza and written by Carreon, is about three teenage friends, Paolo, Girlie, and Johnny, whose game of spirit of the glass in a haunted house goes wrong. When the spirits escape from the glass, the teenagers suddenly find themselves inhabiting two time frames. They become Ibarra, Isabel, and Juanito, respectively, during the Spanish era, entwined in a fatal love triangle. The present bodies of Paolo and Johnny are possessed by Ibarra and Juanito, who kill each other tragically before the helpless Girlie.

 

The second episode, “Pridyider” (Fridge), directed by Bernal and written by Lacuesta, is about a monstrous refrigerator who lures and kills attractive female victims. Lorna and her family recently move into a house in which a series of murders have been mysteriously committed. There are several suspects, but the investigator, Carlos Torres, discovers that the haunted refrigerator is the killer and is able to save Lorna in the nick of time. This episode was remade into a full-length film, Pridyider, in 2012, directed by Rico Maria Ilarde.

 

The third episode, “Manananggal” (Self-Segmenting Ghoul), a horror-comedy directed by Gallaga and written by de la Cruz, is about a teenager, Douglas, who is tasked by his grandmother to kill the manananggal, whose body splits in half at the waist. He is able to prevent the winged torso of the monster from rejoining its legs, but then he must protect his family from the creature’s ferocious attacks, which he succeeds in doing. Shake, Rattle & Rollwas premiered in the 1984 Metro Manila Film Festival, where Bautista received the Best Actor award.

 

The omnibus format of Shake, Rattle & Roll recalls the popular horror classics, notably Gabi ng Lagim (Night of Terror), 1960. Six years after its release, Shake, Rattle & Roll, with the same format, was revived by Regal Films, and the company has since produced 15 variations, between 1990 and 2014. Most of these films were premiered in the annual Metro Manila Film Festival.  Written by Patrick Campos

article_title: Si Juan Tamad at Si Juan Masipag sa Pulitikang Walang Hanggan
text:
(Lazy Juan and Industrious Juan in Never-Ending Politics) / 1963 / Black and White / Comedy / Direction: Manuel Conde / Story and Screenplay: Manuel Conde and Jun Urbano / Music: Juan Silos Jr / Produced by Zultana International / Cast: Manuel Conde (Juan Tamad/Juan Masipag), Tessie Quintana (Zorahayda), Sylvia Guimabao (Leah), Naty Bernardo (Laging Litga), Greg Urbano (Gat Uto), Rosa Aguirre (Ninang Diwa ng Bayan), Johnny Wilson (Jak Ep Kenny), Alfonso Carvajal, Flaviano Miranda, and Adora Nery

 

Juan’s father is preparing to attend the party convention (Liberal Party Presidential Convention) that will choose the party’s presidential candidate for the next elections. At the convention hall, vendors are hawking all kinds of wares, including votes. Meanwhile, Juan Tamad’s mother reveals to him that he had a twin brother who got lost while the family was wandering through the forest. In that forest, the twin brother has now grown into Juan Masipag, an industrious nitwit, under the care of Ninang Diwa ng Bayan, who now educates him on the corruption and influence peddling in government, and the three types of convention delegates: those who sell their votes, those who are ignorant, and those who consider what is best for the country. Diwa then reveals to Masipag his true parents and says it is time Masipag joined his real family. She gives him three eggs, which Masipag can break when he needs Diwa’s help. Swallowing the first egg, Masipag is transported to Gat Uto’s house and reunited with his real family.

 

Litga and Uto are worried that their coconut oil business will die like all other native industries because of the influx of imported goods. So they send Juan Tamad, Leah, and Zorahayda to ask their friend Jak Ep Kenny (John F. Kennedy) for a loan. The three travel to the other mountain and talk to Jak inside a cave where Jak sits on a rocking chair surrounded by rockets and sputniks. Jak decides to give the loan but will send it directly to Uto. Eventually, the loan is brought to the Philippines by a Peace Corps volunteer, whom Laging Litga immediately assigns to do the dishes.

 

In the elections, Sultan Abe Maka Pobre (Diosdado Macapagal) wins, so Laging Litga sends Juan Tamad and Akbar to get 100 camotes (financial loan) from the Camote Bodega (Central Bank or CB) and Juan Masipag and Zorahayda to the pier to pick up the bakya (wooden clogs) that Litga’s sister had sent her. Tamad and Akbar come upon hordes of people at the CB because the past governor and the newly appointed one are literally fighting over the governor’s chair. In the pier, the customs officer asks Masipag to pay 50 pesos for each foot. Masipag observes that smuggling is on the rise because taxes are exorbitant.

 

The new sultan asks Tamad what people are saying about him. Tamad replies that 70 percent of the people approve of the sultan, but are wondering why there are so many appointed in an acting capacity, and why the sultan does so much traveling. The sultan says he wants to try out his appointees first before he assigns them permanently. Also, he travels a lot because he has to get help from people from all around the country. Finally, he says that he has already gotten rid of many rats in government but the biggest ones are the most difficult to get rid of because they cry “political harassment.” But even as the sultan and Tamad speak, Uto has been giving out jobs at the EEA (Macapagal’s Emergency Employment Agency), hoping to get more votes in the coming elections.

 

But the rivalry between Juan Tamad and Juan Masipag over Zorahayda comes to a head. Zorahayda is in a dilemma because he must choose between one who is bright but lazy, and another who is industrious but dumb. Gat Uto breaks an egg and Diwa appears to help solve Zorahayda’s problem, which she likens to the perennial problem of the Filipino people who in every election must choose between two evils. Using her magical powers, Diwa then cleanses the two Juans of their negative traits and conjoins them into one positive person whom she calls Juan de la Cruz, the ideal leader that the people must continue to look for. In the end, Zorahayda/the nation is married to the ideal husband/leader.  Written by Nicanor G. Tiongson

Manuel Conde in Siete Infantes de Lara, 1950

(Photo courtesy of Nene Urbano)

text:
(Seven Devils) / 1950 / Black and White / Action, Adventure / Direction: Manuel Conde / Screenplay: Carmen P. Urbano and Catalina V. Flores (adapted from an awit or metrical romance) / Cinematography: Emmanuel Rojas / Production Design: Carlos V. Francisco / Sound: Flaviano Villareal / Music: Juan Silos Jr / Produced by Manuel Conde Productions / Cast: Manuel Conde (Duke Busto de Lara / Morado), Elvira Reyes, Mario Montenegro (Infante), Eddie Garcia (Infante), Johnny Monteiro (Infante), Luningning (Gismenia), Jose Villafranca, Rolando Liwanag, Ely Nakpil, Julio Anguita, Africa de la Rosa, Andres Centenera, Cecilio Joaquin, Isa Riño, Rick Bustamante, and Gracita Dominguez

 

The Siete Infantes are the seven warrior-sons of Duke Busto de Lara who are in the service of the Spanish court of Haring Felipe. A scheming couple, Konde Velasquez and Kondesa Lambra, succeed in having de Lara sent as an envoy to Emperador Almanzor in Granada. Almanzor is led to believe that de Lara is an enemy. The emperor’s daughter, Gismenia, saves the duke from execution by making him her gardener. De Lara’s seven sons battle against Granada’s forces and lose. The duke is presented with the heads of his seven sons and is imprisoned when he attempts to kill the palace guards. Gismenia joins him in prison after professing publicly her love for him. They escape but the duke dies during the pursuit by palace guards.

 

Gismenia survives and gives birth to Morado, the duke’s son. Morado becomes a famous warrior, especially after defeating the superior Arabian army of Haring Gramahan. During his famed combats, spectators see the ghosts of the Siete Infantes aiding Morado, who is himself unaware of their presence.

 

Sarina, Haring Gramahan’s daughter, plots to kill Morado by masquerading as a slave bought by one of Morado’s men. But she is snatched by Rodrigo, son of Konde Velasquez, who fancied her when he first saw her being auctioned off in an Arabian market. In a feast held by Emperador Almanzor, a sword fight between Morado and Rodrigo over Sarina takes place. To save his son, Konde Velasquez treacherously throws a dagger at Morado but he is killed by Gismenia. Sarina tries to stab Morado who kisses her instead. Sarina realizes she loves the man she vowed to destroy.

 

Siete set a standard for costume pictures produced in the Philippines. Processed in black and white, this movie was considered a major film achievement since its artistry and quality made it comparable to internationally produced films. The film was retitled Seven Devils for foreign release and exhibition.  Written by Rosalie Matilac

text:
1951 / Black and White / Drama / Direction: Gerardo de Leon / Story: Jose P. Rizal (from his novel Noli Me Tangere, 1887) / Screenplay: Teodorico C. Santos / Cinematography: Arsenio Doña and Tommy Marcelino / Editing: Vic Calub / Sound: Demetrio de Santos / Music: Ariston Avelino / “The Song of Maria Clara,” melody by Juan S. Hernandez and lyrics by Jose Rizal / Produced by Premiere Productions / Cast: Anita Linda (Sisa), Bebong Osorio (Basilio), Boy Francisco (Crispin), Reynaldo Dante, Eddie del Mar, Eddie Infante, Nati Rubi, Pancho Pelagio, Tony Tolman, Ruben Rustia, Don Danon, Rosita Noble, Andres Benitez, and Fernando Santiago

 

Sisa is a simple woman favored with good looks and wooed by various suitors. She earns the anger of a captain of the guardia civil (constable) when she turns him down in favor of another suitor, who turns out to be a wife beater and gambler, and who robs her of her hard-earned money. Years later, the husband is arrested and sent to prison on trumped-up charges by the captain whom Sisa turned down. Her two children, Basilio and Crispin, serve as sacristans (altar boys) in the parish church. However, the kampanero (bell ringer) is also a spurned suitor and frames the boys. They are accused of robbing the church and tortured by the parish priest to make them confess to the theft. Crispin dies from the injuries inflicted on him, but Basilio escapes. Sisa goes in search of her fugitive son. Hounded and eventually raped by the militia, she loses her mind. A former admirer, Elias, hovers in the background, helping her when he can.

 

Sisa won the Maria Clara award for Best Picture of 1951 and gave Anita Linda her first trophy as Best Actress of the year.  Written by Lena S. Pareja

Tony Santos and Vilma Santos in Sister Stella L., 1984

(Cesar Hernando)

text:
(Sister Stella L./Crossroads) / 1984 / Color / Drama / 96 minutes / Direction: Mike de Leon / Screenplay: Jose F. Lacaba, Jose Almojuela, and Mike de Leon / Cinematography: Rody Lacap / Editing: Jess Navarro / Production Design: Cesar Hernando / Art Direction: Lea Locsin and Fernando Modesto / Sound: Ramon Reyes / Music: Ding Achacoso / Produced by Regal Films / Cast: Vilma Santos (Sister Stella Legaspi), Jay Ilagan (Nick Fajardo), Gina Alajar (Gigi), Laurice Guillen (Sister Stella Bautista), Tony Santos (Ka Dencio), Anita Linda, Liza Lorena, J. Eddie Infante, Ruben Rustia, Adul de Leon, Rody Vera, Crispin Medina, Jojo Sanchez, Malu de Guzman, Raquel Villavicencio, and Fred Capulong

 

Sister Stella L. works as a counsellor in her religious congregation’s home for unwed mothers. She visits her friend and namesake, Sister Stella Bautista, who is assigned in the industrial town of Aguho. She arrives to find her friend in the thick of preparations for the workers’ strike at the Republic Oil Company. Sister Stella B. takes the young nun to the picket line. Sister Stella L. is so moved by the workers’ plight that she asks her superior to allow her to work in the town. Gradually, her involvement in the workers’ struggle deepens.

 

She meets Nick Fajardo, her former boyfriend, now a journalist, who is doing an article on activism in the Church. Nick asks the nun to turn her back on the Church and resume their relationship. As hired goons harass the striking workers, Sister Stella L. is recalled to the congregation’s convent to resume her work with unwed mothers. Her heart, however, already longs for a life with the workers. She applies for a formal transfer to the town just as one of the unwed mothers, Gigi, who is deeply attached to her, is about to give birth. Depressed, Gigi commits suicide. Her death prompts Sister Stella L. to engage in activism more fully.

 

Sister Stella B. leaves to attend to other pressing matters in the South. She bequeathes her responsibilities to Sister Stella L. The union leader, Ka Dencio, is abducted and tortured. Sister Stella L. and Nick get their share of brutality from the goons who want to frighten them off. Ka Dencio is finally “salvaged” (summarily executed). The harrowing experience affects the nun deeply, but she recovers to carry on the struggle. Sister Stella L. renews her vow of service to God and the people.

 

Sister Stella L. defied certain taboos during the last years of the Marcos regime by dealing with explosive issues like labor unrest and repression of media. Mike de Leon’s first explicitly political film, done after Benigno Aquino Jr’s assassination, was also Regal Films’ first and last serious political film to date.

 

The film won 10 Gawad Urian for the year 1984, including Best Picture, Best Director, Best Screenplay, Best Actor (Ilagan), Best Actress (Santos), Best Supporting Actor (Santos), Best Supporting Actress (Guillen), Best Music, Best Editing, and Best Sound. It was chosen by the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino as one of the 10 Best Films of the Decade 1980-89. It also won Best Picture and Best Director in the Film Academy of the Philippines Awards and PMPC Star Awards. It was in competition at the Venice Film Festival.  Written by Menchie R. Tajan

text:
(Saintly Girl) / 2012 / Color / Drama / 105 minutes / Direction and Story: Emmanuel Quindo Palo / Screenplay: Liza Magtoto and Emmanuel Quindo Palo / Cinematography: Nor Domingo / Editing: Chrisel Galeno-Desuasido and Tara Illenberger / Production Design: Aped Santos / Sound: Albert Michael Idioma / Music: Dean Rosen / Produced by Cinemalaya Foundation and CCM Creative / Cast: Coco Martin (Paulino “Pol” Mungcal), Alessandra de Rossi (Madel), Anita Linda, Angel Aquino, Irma Adlawan, Nanding Josef, Lui Manansala, Joe Gruta, Bea Garcia, Dax Alejandro, and Rie Batingana

 

While laboring in a quarry that has been buried by lahar from Mount Pinatubo, Paulino “Pol” Mungcal unexpectedly stumbles upon the casket of Marikit, his daughter who died at two years of age. Ten years have passed since his daughter’s death, but her corpse remains well-preserved, showing no signs of decay. Pol decides to take the casket with the corpse and brings it to his home that he shares with his ailing grandmother. The incorrupt state of Marikit’s body is attributed to a miracle, and the townspeople begin to treat the child as an object of devotion. The religious fervor intensifies when several ailing people, including the governor, are apparently healed of their ailments, and soon Pol is persuaded to lobby skeptical church officials to declare Marikit a saint, even leading a rally of the faithful in a show of force before the bishop. In the process, however, he also wrestles with questions of shame, sin, and salvation, forced as he is to confront the past, particularly his failed relationship with his cousin Madel, the mother of Marikit, for which the town had condemned him. Pol is eventually moved to seek atonement, participating in the annual Lenten ritual of their hometown by consenting to carry a cross and be crucified.

 

Sta. Niña won the following awards: Best Supporting Actress (de Rossi) at the 2013 Gawad Urian; Best Performance by an Actress in a Supporting Role (Linda) at the 2013 Golden Screen Awards; and Best Supporting Actress (Linda) in the New Breed section of the 2012 Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival. Internationally, it won Best Picture, Best Actress (de Rossi), and Best Supporting Actress (Linda) at the 2013 ASEAN International Film Festival and Awards; and the Suvarna Chakoram (Golden Crow Pheasant) Award at the 2012 International Film Festival of Kerala.  Written by Jaime Oscar M. Salazar

text:
1971 / Color / Drama / 145 minutes / Direction: Lino Brocka / Story: Mars Ravelo / Screenplay: Orlando Nadres and Lino Brocka / Cinematography: Freddie Conde / Music: Jose Mari Chan / Produced by LEA Productions / Cast: Lolita Rodriguez (Toyang), Walter Navarro (Joey Galvez), Hilda Koronel (Myra Lopez), Mario O’Hara (Emong Perez), Jimmy Morato (Ralph Mendez), Eddie Garcia (Asiong), Lotis Key, Tita Muñoz, Celeste Legaspi, Ruben Rustia, Veronica Palileo, Joonee Gamboa, Marissa Delgado, and Mary Walter

 

Toyang, an ambitious mother and frustrated actress, pushes her favorite son Joey into show business, hoping that as a film star he will be able to help her and her older son Emong to rise above their poverty. His success as an actor brings him in contact with the rich and famous, whom he soon finds out are also predatory and morally bankrupt. As the actor becomes part of this tinsel world, he realizes that he must distance himself from his mother who is dying to crash into that world. Because she is a simple illiterate woman, the son is afraid that any link with her would expose his humble background.

 

The other son is the opposite of his brother. An ordinary worker with a mature outlook, Emong cheerfully accepts himself, even if his mother does not believe in him. He is diligent and hardworking. Eventually, he marries a pretty and industrious girl who helps him acquire a house and lot of their own. When the mother begins to drink out of disappointment over her actor-son, the couple take her in. One night, they are watching TV when the mother witnesses on the screen the killing of her actor-son at the premiere of his film in a downtown theater. She, her son, and her daughter-in-law rush to the lobby of the theater, but everyone is gone. As the mother gazes at the bright lights that spell out her son’s name, she weeps at the death of her son and the end of all her dreams.

 

Stardoom examines the world of the movie industry to which Brocka himself belonged. Although deeply involved in its operations, he could look at it with a critical eye, inviting the viewer to share his own perspectives. Stardoom won for Brocka the Best Director award from the Citizens Council for Mass Media.  Written by Hubert Adoreno

Eventually, he marries a pretty and industrious girl who helps him acquire a house and lot of their own. When the mother begins to drink out of disappointment over her actor-son, the couple take her in. One night, they are watching TV when the mother witnesses on the screen the killing of her actor-son at the premiere of his film in a downtown theater. She, her son, and her daughter-in-law rush to the lobby of the theater, but everyone is gone. As the mother gazes at the bright lights that spell out her son’s name, she weeps at the death of her son and the end of all her dreams.

Stardoom examines the world of the movie industry to which Brocka himself belonged. Although deeply involved in its operations, he could look at it with a critical eye, inviting the viewer to share his own perspectives. Stardoom won for Brocka the Best Director award from the Citizens Council for Mass Media.  Written by Hubert Adoreno

text:
(Stop Crying Now, Empoy) / 1977 / Color / Drama / 90 minutes / Direction: Lino Brocka / Story and Screenplay: Jose Y. Dalisay Jr / Cinematography: Jose Batac Jr / Editing: Augusto Salvador / Production Design: Fiel Zabat / Sound: Luis Reyes and Sebastian Sayson / Music: Ernani Cuenco / Produced by Lotus Films Inc / Cast: Niño Muhlach (Empoy), Snooky, Alicia Alonzo, Armida Siguion-Reyna, Rosa Aguirre, Orlando Nadres, Lorli Villanueva, Mario O’Hara, Rodel Naval, and Allan Ronald Muhlach

 

A young widow swallows her pride and goes back to live with her insensitive brothers and sisters. She earlier left her family to elope with a man they disapproved of. She suffers a lot of humiliation, especially at the hands of her elder sister, but she endures all this so that her two children may have food to eat. In the end, however, fortune smiles on the young mother who asserts herself in a violent confrontation with her oppressive sister, so that she can reclaim her children and live a happier life elsewhere.

 

In the 1978 Gawad Urian, the film won the award for Best Supporting Actress (Siguion-Reyna) and got nominations for Best Picture, Best Director, Best Screenplay, Best Actress (Alonzo), and Best Music. text:
(A Change of Heart) / 2000 / Color / Drama / 112 minutes / Direction: Laurice Guillen / Screenplay: Shaira Mella Salvador, Raymond Lee, and Laurice Guillen / Cinematography: Lee Meily / Editing: George Jarlego / Production Design: Edgar Martin Littaua / Sound: Ramon Reyes / Music: Nonong Buencamino / Produced by Star Cinema / Cast: Gloria Romero (Loleng), Hilda Koronel (Celine), Johnny Delgado (Danny), Dina Bonnevie (Grace), Edu Manzano (Art), Joel Torre (Francis), Jericho Rosales (Rommel), Marvin Agustin (Boyet), Cherry Pie Picache, Dominic Ochoa, Carol Banawa, Janet McBride, Shaina Magdayao, John Prats, Lou Veloso, and CJ Ramos

 

The story revolves around the matriarch Loleng, a devout Catholic, and her three grown-up children, Danny, Art, and Grace, and their respective families. In her old age, Loleng finds herself in the middle of a sibling quarrel, one that has been going on for years, between her sons Danny and Art, and is now aggravated by the planned sale of their family-owned land in Pampanga. While Danny finds himself and his family in constant financial difficulties, and Grace is in the United States working nonstop with her husband Francis to support their own family, Art continues to be financially well-off. Tension escalates when Loleng is diagnosed with Alzheimer’s disease, compelling Art to decide on his own to bring Loleng to live in Manila with his family. Art figures that since he is the most financially stable in the family, he is in the best position to take good care of Loleng. But this decision only causes even more tension. Worse, the long-standing feud between the brothers is carried over to their respective sons. Danny’s eldest son Boyet idolizes his uncle Art to the chagrin of his own father. On the other hand, Art’s son Rommel has serious problems with his dad because of Art’s harsh and demanding ways as a parent. As the family matriarch continues to succumb to her debilitating sickness, each member of the extended family figures out individual ways of dealing with their own problems, learning as well how to forgive each other in the process.

 

The movie won Best Picture, Best Director, Best Actor (Delgado), Best Actress (Romero), Best Cinematography, Best Original Story, Best Screenplay, Best Musical Score, and the Gatpuno Antonio J. Villegas Cultural Award in the 2000 Metro Manila Film Festival; Best Picture, Best Director, Best Actress, and Best Sound in the 2001 Film Academy of the Philippines Awards; Best Director and Best Actress in the 2001 Gawad Urian; Best Picture (tied with Bayani ng 3rd World [Third World Hero], 1999), Best Screenplay, and Best Performance by the entire cast in the Young Critics Circle Film Desk Citations for 2000; and Best Picture, Best Director, Best Actor, Best Actress, Best Child Actress (Magdayao), Best Story, Best Cinematography, Best Editing, and Best Musical Score in the 2001 Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Awards.  Written by Anne Frances Sangil

Dolphy and Niño Muhlach in Ang Tatay Kong Nanay, 1978

(Mario A. Hernando Collection)

text:
(My Father the Mother) / 1978 / Color / Drama / 116 minutes / Direction: Lino Brocka / Story and Screenplay: Orlando R. Nadres / Cinematography: Jose Batac Jr / Editing: Augusto Salvador / Production Design: Fiel Zabat / Music: Lutgardo Labad / Produced by Lotus Films Inc / Cast: Dolphy (Coring), Niño Muhlach (Nonoy), Phillip Salvador (Dennis), Marissa Delgado (Mariana Jimenez), Lorli Villanueva (Bebang), Soxy Topacio, Orlando Nadres, Larry Leviste, Joe Galvez, Rene Salud, Inday Badiday, Fred Capulong, Benjie Ledesma, Jun Macapinlac, Rudy Soriano, Joey Luna, Feling Cudia, Gigette Reyes, Edna May Landicho, Daniel Martin, and the PETA Kalinangan Ensemble

 

Coring is a gay beautician who likes dressing in women’s clothes. He has been taking care of Dennis, his lover of five years. Dennis dumps him for a bar hostess, Mariana Jimenez. After some time, Dennis returns to Coring with a baby boy. He leaves the baby behind when he leaves to join, as he says, the United States Navy. Coring is now saddled with a child who is baptized Marlon Brando Derecho, or Nonoy for short.

 

Coring resolves to spare Nonoy the tormenting identity crisis he himself suffered. He tries hard to be a father to the boy. He acts straight when he is with Nonoy. This alienates his gay friends who are also forced to act like men when they are with the boy. After several years, Dennis reappears and tries to resume his relationship with Mariana, now a rich widow. Mariana wants her child back, but Coring will not give up Nonoy. After consulting his aunt Bebang, however, Coring agrees to give up the child. But Nonoy does not get along with his real mother and decides to return to Coring.

 

In a gay beauty contest, it is Coring’s turn to speak. He talks about the gay life, its trials and sorrows, joys and rewards. Rain cuts short his speech and he rushes back home. He finds Nonoy in the crowd (the boy was roused from his sleep and decided to look for Coring). He realizes that Nonoy, from whom he had tried to conceal his homosexuality, has seen him in drag. In the end, Nonoy reassures Coring that he loves Coring, no matter what he is—Tatay or Nanay (father or mother).

 

The movie is significant because it reinterprets and deepens the stereotype role of the bakla (homosexual) that Dolphy became famous for. If Tubog sa Ginto (Dipped in Gold), 1971, is Brocka’s depiction of the tragic fate of a homosexual upper-class businessman, Ang Tatay Kong Nanay is his comic portrayal of a warm relationship between an ordinary gay beautician and his adopted child.  Written by Agustin Sotto

Mario O’Hara and Lolita Rodriguez in “Bukas, Madilim, Bukas,” one of the episodes of Tatlo, Dalawa, Isa, 1974

(Cesar Hernando Collection)

text:
(Three, Two, One) / 1974 / Color / Drama / 156 minutes / Direction: Lino Brocka / Story: Tony Perez, Sr Mary Angela Barrios, and Orlando Nadres / Screenplay: Tony Perez, Mario O’Hara, and Orlando Nadres / Cinematography: Romeo Vitug / Editing: Augusto Salvador / Production Design: Bobby Bautista / Sound: Manuel Daves / Music: Minda Azarcon / Produced by CineManila Corporation / Cast: (“Mga Hugis ng Pag-asa”) Jay Ilagan (Noni), Perla Bautista, Laurice Guillen, Jojo Abella, Pio de Castro III, Moey Chuidian, Fernando Josef, Rudy Hermano, Roger Mariscal, Mark Migallos, Bembol Roco, and Soxy Topacio; (“Hellow Soldier”) Hilda Koronel (Gina), Anita Linda (Lucia), Claude Wilson Jr (Tom), Barbara Browne, Bey Vito, Mely Mallari, Estrella Kuenzler, Melvi Pacubas, Dante Balois, Edwin O’Hara, and the PETA Kalinangan Ensemble; (“Bukas, Madilim, Bukas”) Lolita Rodriguez (Rosenda), Mary Walter (Nyora Atang), Mario O’Hara (Miguelito), Lily Miraflor, and Manny Ojeda

 

The film is a trilogy, the thematic thread of which tackles the common conflict of a drug addict, a “GI baby,” and an aging single woman. Each is imprisoned in his or her own metaphoric cell, “groping for the key.”

 

The first episode, “Mga Hugis ng Pag-asa” (The Shapes of Hope), is the story of Noni, a young man who takes to drugs to escape the bitter reality that he belongs to a broken family. At the drug rehabilitation center known as Bahay Pag-asa (House of Hope), he gets to know his fellow inmates who are all from various backgrounds. He also learns to work hard and develop a sense of self-worth and discipline. In the end, Noni becomes whole again by learning to accept and love himself and others.

 

The second episode, “Hellow Soldier,” is set during the postwar liberation period. An illiterate laundrywoman, Lucia, has a daughter by Tom, an American GI. The girl, Gina, writes to her father to come and get her so she can live with him in the United States. He responds to her letter, but the girl has a change of heart when she realizes that her going to the United States will make her mother very unhappy. The episode celebrates the bond between mother and daughter.

 

The third episode, “Bukas, Madilim, Bukas” (Tomorrow, the Darkness), revolves around Rosenda, an aging single woman. She is an only daughter who has stayed single to take care of her invalid mother, Nyora Atang. What Rosenda does not know is that her selfish mother has been pretending for 30 years to be an invalid, to stop her daughter from marrying and leaving her. One day, Rosenda meets Miguelito in the church where she spends her afternoons praying. Their encounters become frequent and soon develop into an affair. Nyora Atang finds out about the affair and dies from a stroke. The discovery that her mother is not an invalid after all drives Rosenda to insanity. Alone and old, she can no longer enjoy the money and properties that Nyora Atang left her. In the last sequence, the deranged, frustrated Rosenda dons a wedding gown.

 

This trilogy differs in form from the typical commercial movie. Each episode is an experiment in form. The first episode is documentary in style, with the camera taking in all that is happening. The second is presented as a one-act play highlighting the mother-and-daughter relationship. The third is a showcase for Rodriguez’s unique acting talent. Each episode gives Brocka an opportunity to work with difficult moods and themes. In the process he displays a versatility that transcends the usual plot-oriented film.

 

Tatlo, Dalawa, Isa garnered three awards from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences in 1975: Best Supporting Actress (Linda), Best Story, and Best Screenplay.  Written by Rosalie Matilac

(Mario A. Hernando Collection)

text:
(Three Godless Years) / 1976 / Color / 124 minutes / Direction, Story, and Screenplay: Mario O’Hara / Cinematography: Conrado Baltazar / Editing: Ike Jarlego Jr and Efren Jarlego / Production Design: Ricardo de Guzman / Art Direction: Vicente Bonus / Sound: Gaudencio Barredo / Music: Minda D. Azarcon / Produced by NV Productions / Cast: Nora Aunor (Rosario), Christopher de Leon (Masugi), Bembol Roco (Crispin), Peque Gallaga, Mario Escudero, Yolanda Luna, Licerio N. Tabalon Jr, Orlando Nadres, Chiqui Xerez-Burgos, and PETA Kalinangan Ensemble.

 

Tatlong Taong Walang Diyos is set in Laguna during the Japanese occupation. Captain Masugi of the Japanese Imperial Army is attracted to Rosario, a schoolteacher. Rosario spurns his affections as she is already engaged to Crispin who is with the United States Army Forces in the Far East. Masugi persists in his suit to the extent of raping Rosario and getting her pregnant. They get married. Eventually, Rosario develops a love for the Japanese officer. Crispin returns from the battlefield and sees Rosario, but she refuses to be unfaithful to her husband. When the American forces return to the Philippines and the Japanese withdraw from occupied areas, the townspeople exact their revenge. Supported by the guerrillas, they kill Masugi, his child, and Rosario’s family. Rosario, alone and grief-stricken, has nowhere to go, and returns to the village. The townspeople shave her head and kill her.

 

Tatlong Taong Walang Diyos is an unusual war film in that it focuses on a Japanese officer as a sympathetic central character and refers to the Americans as imperialists like the Japanese. It marked the transition of popular superstar Nora Aunor into a serious dramatic actress. Aunor won Best Actress in both the Gawad Urian and the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) Awards in 1977. The film was nominated in the FAMAS for Best Picture, Best Director, Best Screenplay, Best Story, Best Musical Score, Best Sound Direction, and Best Theme Song, and in the Gawad Urian for Best Cinematography.  Written by Emelie Capulong

text:
1980 / Color / Comedy / 113 minutes / Direction: Joey Gosiengfiao / Story and Screenplay: Toto Belano / Cinematography: Ricardo Jacinto / Editing: Rogelio Salvador / Production Design: Mel Chionglo / Art Direction: Dennis Cid / Sound: Rolly Ruta and Vic Macamay / Music: Jun Latonio / Produced by Regal Films / Cast: Dina Bonnevie (Dina), Azenith Briones (Azenith), Jennifer Cortez (Suzanne), Bambi Arambulo (Bambi), Deborah Sun (Maria), Ricky Belmonte (Ricardo), Alfie Anido (Alfred), Domingo Sabado (Umberto), and Jonas Sebastian (Joshua)

 

Four women—colegiala (coed) Dina, opulent lady Suzanne, former rich girl Bambi, and scheming secretary Azenith—make it to the finals of the 1980 Miss Manila Sunshine Contest. On their yachting cruise, the boat catches fire, and the four women find themselves stranded on an island together with the photographer Ricardo, the waiter Umberto, Dina’s admirer Alfred, the socialite and pageant co-chair Joshua, and Suzanne’s nanny Maria.

 

Starving to death and struggling to survive, the female survivors bitch against each other and bond with the men. Ricardo gets closer to Bambi as he moves farther away from his gay benefactor Joshua; Umberto and Azenith hit it off; Dina and Alfie flirt with each other; Suzanne is lonesome but she has a “maid” to keep her company. Three couples make out that evening (Umberto and Azenith, Ricardo and Bambi, Alfie and Suzanne) as Maria dances to her heart’s content all by herself. Alfie’s betrayal results in the combat between Dina and Suzanne, which Dina wins. Dina confronts Alfie, and during their lovers’ quarrel, the two discover Joshua dead, buried in the sand. Famished and desperate, the group decides to eat Joshua and sings “Somewhere.” Soon, the rescue team arrives.

 

During the pageant finals, the four women give their speeches: Dina emphasizes love and a woman’s place in society; Suzanne takes the opportunity to thank everyone, especially Maria; Bambi talks about discovering the self and learning from the “island of temptations”; Azenith states she wants to take a long break and to settle down. Suzanne wins the title and takes Maria with her to the United States for the trip. Ricardo and Bambi get married. Azenith chooses her crook-boyfriend over Umberto. Alfie and Dina kiss and make up.

 

The exaggeration, irony, and humor combined with the hilarious and witty dialogue make Temptation Island an excellent model of camp in Philippine cinema. In 2003, Chris Martinez adapted the film for the stage and directed it as Temptation Island … Live! Gay actors portrayed the role of the beauty contestants. The film was also remade by Martinez in 2011, starring Marian Rivera, Lovi Poe, Solenn Heusaff, Rufa Mae Quinto, Heart Evangelista, and John Lapus.  Written by Ronald Baytan

On their yachting cruise, the boat catches fire, and the four women find themselves stranded on an island together with the photographer Ricardo, the waiter Umberto, Dina’s admirer Alfred, the socialite and pageant co-chair Joshua, and Suzanne’s nanny Maria.

Starving to death and struggling to survive, the female survivors bitch against each other and bond with the men. Ricardo gets closer to Bambi as he moves farther away from his gay benefactor Joshua; Umberto and Azenith hit it off; Dina and Alfie flirt with each other; Suzanne is lonesome but she has a “maid” to keep her company. Three couples make out that evening (Umberto and Azenith, Ricardo and Bambi, Alfie and Suzanne) as Maria dances to her heart’s content all by herself. Alfie’s betrayal results in the combat between Dina and Suzanne, which Dina wins. Dina confronts Alfie, and during their lovers’ quarrel, the two discover Joshua dead, buried in the sand. Famished and desperate, the group decides to eat Joshua and sings “Somewhere.” Soon, the rescue team arrives.

During the pageant finals, the four women give their speeches: Dina emphasizes love and a woman’s place in society; Suzanne takes the opportunity to thank everyone, especially Maria; Bambi talks about discovering the self and learning from the “island of temptations”; Azenith states she wants to take a long break and to settle down. Suzanne wins the title and takes Maria with her to the United States for the trip. Ricardo and Bambi get married. Azenith chooses her crook-boyfriend over Umberto. Alfie and Dina kiss and make up.

The exaggeration, irony, and humor combined with the hilarious and witty dialogue make Temptation Island an excellent model of camp in Philippine cinema. In 2003, Chris Martinez adapted the film for the stage and directed it as Temptation Island … Live! Gay actors portrayed the role of the beauty contestants. The film was also remade by Martinez in 2011, starring Marian Rivera, Lovi Poe, Solenn Heusaff, Rufa Mae Quinto, Heart Evangelista, and John Lapus.  Written by Ronald Baytan

text:
2011 / Color / Drama / 111 minutes / Direction: Paul Soriano / Story: Froi Medina, Rino Que, and Paul Soriano / Screenplay: Froi Medina and Paul Soriano / Cinematography: Odyssey Flores / Editing: Fabienne Bucher and Mark Victor / Production Design: Nina Torres / Music: Brad Haehnel / Produced by Time Horizon Pictures, Abracadabra, and Underground Logic / Cast: Maja Salvador (Thelma), Jason Abalos (Sammy), Tetchie Agbayani (Floring), and Eliza Pineda (Hannah)

 

Inspired by true stories of athletes, including that of track-and-field champion Elma Muros who essays a minor role, Thelma charts the development of its titular character, the elder daughter of an impoverished couple in rural Ilocos, from wayward adolescent into responsible adult. Although born with the gift of speed, which she inherited from her mother Floring who was a track-and-field champion in her youth, Thelma uses her talent mainly as a way to let off steam until, as a result of her own neglect, her younger sister Hannah, whose academic brilliance makes her the hope of their family, figures in a vehicular accident that paralyzes her. Thelma participates in a local race in order to be able to purchase Hannah a wheelchair, and catches the attention of her school’s coach. She is eventually awarded an athletic scholarship in Manila, which provides her with a stipend that she can send home, and paves the way for a potentially brighter future. While training in the city, far away from her loved ones, Thelma must prove her mettle not only on the track against rival athletes, but also off it, especially when she learns that her mother is afflicted with a grave illness. Thelma must choose whether to stay the course or return to the bosom of her family. Encouraged by the words of her mother, she decides to keep on running.

 

Thelma won the following awards: Best Director, Best Actress (Salvador), Best Screenplay, and Best Cinematography at the 2012 Luna Awards of the Film Academy of the Philippines; Best Actress at the 2012 Gawad Urian of the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino; and Digital Movie of the Year, Digital Movie Director of the Year, Digital Movie Original Screenplay of the Year, and Digital Movie Cinematographer of the Year at the 2012 Star Awards for Movies of the Philippine Movie Press Club.  Written by Jaime Oscar M. Salazar

text:
2012 / Color / Drama / 105 minutes / Direction: Brillante Mendoza / Screenplay: Henry Burgos / Cinematography: Odyssey Flores / Editing: Kats Seraon / Production Design: Dante Mendoza / Sound: Albert Michael Idioma / Music: Teresa Barrozo / Produced by Center Stage Productions and Film Development Council of the Philippines / Cast: Nora Aunor (Shaleha), Bembol Roco (Bangas-an), Lovi Poe (Mersila), Ruby Ruiz, and Mercedes Cabral

 

Set in the island province of Tawi-Tawi, the film chronicles the story of a middle-aged Sama Dilaut (Badjao) couple, Shaleha and Bangas-an, who make a living from fishing and weaving mats. On occasion, Shaleha also serves as a midwife, but she is incapable of bearing any offspring herself. Knowing that Bangas-an still desires to have a child after all this time, she consents to let him take a second wife, notwithstanding the inevitable rupture that this will cause in the life that they have thus far shared only with each other. A wife is found in Mersila. Soon, Mersila bears Bangas-an’s child, with Shaleha performing her role as midwife, not knowing that Mersila had already convinced Bangas-an to separate from Shaleha.

 

Thy Womb won Best Actress (Aunor) and Best Production Design at the 2013 Gawad Urian; Indie Movie Cinematographer and Indie Movie Production Designer of the Year at the 2013 PMPC Star Awards for Movies; Best Performance (Aunor) at the Young Critics Circle Film Desk Citations for 2012; and Best Actress, Best Director, Best Story, Best Cinematography, Best Production Design, Gatpuno Antonio J. Villegas Cultural Award, and Most Gender-Sensitive Film Award at the 2012 Metro Manila Film Festival. Internationally, it won Premio Bisato d’Oro for Best Actress of the Festival (Aunor) from Premio della Critica Indipendente, La Navicella-Venezia Cinema Award, and P. Nazareno Taddei Award (Special Mention) at the 2012 Venice International Film Festival; Achievement in Directing and Best Performance by an Actress at the 2012 Asia Pacific Screen Awards; Best Actress at the 2013 Asian Film Awards; Special Jury Mention at the 2013 Granada Film Festival Cines del Sur; and Best Actress at the 2013 Sakhalin International Film Festival.  Written by Jaime Oscar M. Salazar

text:
2012 / Color / Action, Horror, Comedy / 102 minutes / Direction and Screenplay: Erik Matti / Cinematography: Francis Ricardo Buhay III / Editing, Jay Halili / Production Design: Peter Collias and Benjamin Padero / Sound: Corinne de San Jose and Ditoy Aguila / Music: Von de Guzman / Visual Effects: Dave Yu / Produced by Reality Entertainment, Agosto Dos Pictures, and GMA Films / Cast: Dingdong Dantes (Makoy), Lovi Poe (Sonia), Janice de Belen (Fely), Joey Marquez (Nestor), Rina Reyes (Pacing), RJ Salvador (Kulot), Ramon Bautista, and LJ Reyes

 

Makoy, an arrogant unemployed engineer, goes to a remote village for his pregnant girlfriend Sonia, who went home to her parents after she and Makoy had a big fight. Sonia and her mother Fely drive Makoy away, but Makoy finds an ally in Sonia’s father Nestor. To win Sonia back, Makoy volunteers to pay for the pig that will be roasted for a birthday celebration. Nestor’s oddball cousin recommends a slaughterhouse where they can buy a live pig at a cheaper price. Later that night, Nestor starts hearing a peculiar yet familiar sound, a sign that an aswang (mythological ghoul) is nearby. Little do they know that the pig they bought has transformed into Kulot, the leader of the street urchins who sold them the pig. Kulot and his gang of aswang assemble outside and are after the baby inside Sonia’s womb. The embattled family, joined by nosy neighbor Pacing, brace to defend themselves with asin (salt), bawang (garlic), buntot pagi (manta ray’s tail), methanol bombs, and a bottle of lana (oil) that boils when an aswang is nearby.

 

Tiktik: The Aswang Chronicles was shot entirely against a “green screen” (a technology that allows for computer-generated images and special effects to be added during postproduction), resulting in exciting visuals never before seen in local cinema. It won Best Visual Effects, Best Cinematography, Best Actor (Dantes), and Best Supporting Actress (de Belen) at the 2013 Golden Screen Awards. It also won Movie Sound Engineer of the Year and Movie Supporting Actress of the Year at the 2013 PMPC Star Awards for Movies.  Written by Elvin Valerio

text:
(Weighed But Found Wanting) / 1974 / Color / Drama / 126 minutes / Direction and Story: Lino Brocka / Screenplay: Mario O’Hara / Cinematography: Jose Batac Jr / Editing: Augusto Salvador / Sound: Gregorio Ella / Music: Lutgardo Labad / Theme Song: Emmanuel Lacaba / Produced by CineManila Corporation / Cast: Lolita Rodriguez (Kuala), Christopher de Leon (Junior), Mario O’Hara (Bertong Ketong), Eddie Garcia (Cesar Blanco), Hilda Koronel (Evangeline), Laurice Guillen (Milagros), Rosa Aguirre (Lola Jacoba), Orlando Nadres (Mr del Mundo), Lilia Dizon, Anita Linda, Alicia Alonzo, Joonee Gamboa, Ernie Zarate, Mely Mallari, Estrella Kuenzler, Bey Vito, Lorli Villanueva, Lily Miraflor, Chito Ponce Enrile, and Joseph Sytangco

 

Kuala, a deranged woman, wanders about in dirty clothes and with mangy hair. The townsfolk make fun of Kuala. She is pushed into a watering hole and almost drowns. Bertong Ketong, a leper lonely for female companionship, attracts Kuala with a rattle and takes her to his shack in the cemetery. Junior makes friends with them, defying the prohibitions of his father Cesar Blanco, a politician.

 

Junior asks Berto’s advice concerning his problems with an eccentric teacher, Mr del Mundo, who has a crush on him. Junior has problems too with his girlfriend Evangeline, who flirts with her escort during a Santacruzan. The jealous Junior leaves the procession and seeks the company of Milagros, who seduces him.

 

The Asociacion de las Damas Cristianas is scandalized to discover that Kuala is pregnant. She is forced to live under the custody of the pious Lola Jacoba. Junior shows up and helps the pregnant Kuala make her way back to Berto’s shack.

 

As she starts to bleed, Kuala’s previous experience at childbirth comes to her in a flashback. She is revealed as the mistress of Blanco, Junior’s father. Kuala was forced to have an abortion in a remote place. Something went wrong, and the abortionist and Blanco fled, leaving her unconscious and bleeding. It was this traumatic experience that drove her out of her mind.

 

Berto rushes out to fetch a doctor. When the doctor refuses to come, Berto threatens to kill him. Before they reach the shack in the cemetery, the doctor escapes. In the ensuing chase, Berto is shot by one of the townspeople. As Junior comforts his dying friend, the cries of a newborn infant are heard. Kuala’s mind clears momentarily and she recognizes Cesar among the people around her. But the memory of her previous abortion returns and she loses consciousness.

 

The film’s title is derived from a passage in the Old Testament’s Book of Daniel that speaks of compassion for human frailties. The film dramatizes and dissects a number of characters in a typical community inspired by Brocka’s own hometown in San Jose, Nueva Ecija. The musical score features indigenous instruments (gong, flute, kulintang, etc.).

 

Tinimbang won six Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences awards: Best Picture, Best Director, Best Actor (de Leon), Best Actress (Rodriguez), Best Music, and Best Theme Song. It was de Leon’s first major film role.  Written by Lena S. Pareja

(Slingshot) / 2007 / Color / Drama / 86 minutes / Direction: Brillante Mendoza / Screenplay: Joel Ralston Jover / Cinematography: Jeffrey de la Cruz, Brillante Mendoza, Gary Tria, and Julius Palomo Villanueva / Editing: Charliebebs Gohetia / Art Direction: Harley Alcasid and Deans Habal / Sound: Ditoy Aguila and Junel Valencia / Music: Teresa Barrozo / Produced by Center Stage Productions and Rollingball Entertainment in association with Ignite Media / Cast: Jiro Manio (Odie), Coco Martin (Caloy), Kristoffer King (Rex), Nathan Lopez (Leo), Angela Ruiz (Tess), Jaclyn Jose, Julio Diaz, Simon Ibarra, and Harold Montano

 

Set amidst the slums of Quiapo and during the celebration of Lent, the film centers on shanty dwellers Caloy, Rex, Leo, and Odie who try to make ends meet by doing odd jobs in the city. When Caloy’s pedicab is repossessed, Caloy has no choice but to turn to pickpocketing, a crime that Rex has mastered. Rex, on the other hand, if not taking care of his baby boy with his wife Tess, spends most afternoons doing drugs with his friends. Separately, the boys turn to shoplifting, conning unsuspecting pedestrians, and doing other fraudulent activities. Meanwhile, the death of Odie’s pickpocket of a father during the procession of the Black Nazarene leaves the young boy with nothing but the same blind hope that afflicted his father—that of winning the lotto. All of these lives and petty crimes are underscored by the corruption of politicians who are campaigning and buying the people’s votes. The film ends with a raw footage of an actual national campaign, with various senatorial candidates giving speeches about fighting corruption and ending poverty.

 

The film won the Caligari Film Award in the 2008 Berlin International Film Festival; the Special Jury Award (tied with the Russian entry Kremen, 2007) in the 2007 Marrakech International Film Festival; the Network for the Promotion of Asian Cinema Award in the 2008 Singapore International Film Festival; and Best Picture, Best Director, Best Supporting Actress (Ruiz), Best Cinematography, and Best Sound in the 2008 Gawad Urian.  Written by Anne Frances Sangil

text:
(All, All is Terror) / 2006 / Color / 110 minutes / Direction and Editing: John Torres / Screenplay: John Torres and Joel Toledo / Cinematography: John Torres and Albert Banzon / Sound: John Torres and Arvie Bartolome / Music: Khavn, Armi Millare, and Earl Drilon / Produced by Peliculas Los Otros / Cast: Olga Aliseichyk, Bughaw, Earl Drilon, Lav Diaz, and Regiben Romana

John Torres’s debut feature is a genre-bending film. It is part documentary, which utilizes “video diary” footage of Torres’s travels in Berlin and an account of his relationship with a Belarusian girl, Olga Aliseichyk, as well as his activities in the alternative art scene of Metro Manila and his interactions with filmmakers, musicians, visual and performance artists. These images are interwoven with a collage of reenactments, voice-overs, texts and graphics onscreen, and multilayered sound design. Taken together, these elements in Todo Todo Teros follow the flow of consciousness and physical drifting of an artist—a composite of a fictive persona and Torres himself—who wakes up one day as a terrorist. This bizarre premise allows Torres to juxtapose ruminations on the nature of cinema, fragments of a love story, records of the urban milieu of alternative art, critiques of the war on global terrorism, and criticisms against the government that has allowed the branding of Filipino artists as terrorists in travel advisories at the time when the film was shot in 2005.

The film won the Dragons and Tigers Award for Young Cinema at the 25th Vancouver International Film Festival; the International Federation of Film Critics/Network for the Promotion of Asian Cinema Award in the 2006 Singapore International Film Festival; and a Jury Special Mention in the 2006 Jogja-NETPAC Asian Film Festival. In 2007, it received the Best Editing award from the Gawad Urian. The film also competed in the 2006 Sopot Film Festival and the 2008 Cinefest: International Festival of Young Filmmakers. It was screened in more than 20 international film festivals.  Written by Patrick Campos

(Tribe) / 2007 / Color / Drama / 95 minutes / Direction and Screenplay: Jim Libiran / Cinematography: Albert Banzon / Editing: Lawrence Ang / Production Design: Armi Cacanindin / Sound: Mark Laccay / Music: Francis de Veyra / Produced by 8 Glasses Productions / Cast: Shielbert “OG Sacred” Manuel (Makoy), Karl Eigger Balingit (Ebet), Honey “Hi C” Concepcion, Malou Crisologo, Charena Escala, Jamir Garcia, Rey Javier Guevarra, Apollo “Young Cent” Labastida, Gilbert “Ghe Ghe” Lozano, Ira Marasigan, Albert Moreno, and Resty Perez

 

Told from the point of view of a 10-year-old boy named Ebet, the story begins when members of the Thugz Angels gang chance upon the murdered body of a member of the Sacred Brown Tribe (SBT). The police tag the Thugz Angels as suspects and arrest one of them. Makoy, the leader of the SBT, vows to avenge the murder and instructs his gang to conduct their own investigation. Soon they learn that another rival gang, the much older and more notorious Diablos, is really behind the murder. The SBT forms an unlikely alliance with the Thugz Angels and one night, after attending the wake of their murdered friend, the two teenage gangs plan an attack on the Diablos, leading the story to its violent and bloody climax.

 

Shot with a digital camera, Tribu is an exploration into the lives of teenagers living in Tondo, Manila, by first-time director Jim Libiran, a broadcast journalist and himself a native of Tondo. The film stands out not so much for its story but for its subject matter and the fact that its main cast are real-life gang members from Tondo. The film’s noteworthy score features original hip-hop and rap music written by the gang members themselves. Tribu won Best Film, Best Sound, and Best Actor (ensemble of nonprofessional actors) at the 2007 Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival and Best Ensemble at the 2007 Cinemanila International Film Festival. It also won the Young Filmmaker Award at the 2008 Paris Cinema Festival and Best Music at the 2008 Gawad Urian.  Written by Elvin Valerio

(Dipped in Gold) / 1970 / Color / Drama / 150 minutes / Direction and Screenplay: Lino Brocka / Story: Mars Ravelo (serialized in Bulaklak Komiks ) / Cinematography: Steve Perez / Editing: Felizardo Santos / Music: Doming Valdez / Produced by Lea Productions / Cast: Lolita Rodriguez (Emma), Eddie Garcia (Don Benito), Mario O’Hara (Diego), Jay Ilagan (Santi), Luis Gonzales (Celso), Hilda Koronel (Jone), Marissa Delgado (Gracita), Veronica Palileo (Chichi), Jimmy Morato

 

Don Benito is a millionaire who dons a macho image to disguise his homosexuality. Because of his lack of interest in his wife Emma, she is driven to adultery. His teenage son Santi, who idolizes him, turns against him when he catches his father together with his male lover, Diego. Diego turns to blackmailing Don Benito for money. Everything builds up to a climax when Don Benito is forced to kill his lover for attempting to rape Emma. In desperation, Don Benito then kills himself.

 

Tubog sa Ginto was one of the first attempts to use homosexuality as subject and theme in a serious melodrama film. Previously, gays were depicted only in light comedies, like the Dolphy movies Jack and Jill, 1954, and Fefita Fofonggay, 1973. Brocka approached the long-forbidden topic with sensitivity and sympathy. Tubog sa Ginto was the first movie that made people recognize the potential of Brocka as a director of serious drama. This film won for Brocka his first Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) award for Best Director, and for Garcia his second FAMAS Best Actor award in 1971. The film was also nominated for Best Picture, Best Actress (Rodriguez), Best Supporting Actor (O’Hara), Best Story, Best Screenplay, Best Editing, Best Color Cinematography, and Best Music.   Written by Galileo Zafra

text:
(Larger Than Life) / 2001 / Color / Drama / 105 minutes / Direction: Jeffrey Jeturian / Screenplay: Armando Lao / Cinematography: Shayne Clemente, Sherman So, and Boy Yñiguez / Editing: Ronald Allan Dale / Production Design: Ron Henri Tan / Sound: Arnold Reodica and Adiss Tabong / Music: Jay Durias / Produced by Regal Films / Cast: Ina Raymundo (Floring), Klaudia Koronel (Hasmin), Jaclyn Jose (Violeta), Irma Adlawan (Perla), Dante Rivero (Leon), Nante Montreal (Gabino), Crispin Pineda, and Frank Rivera

 

Gabino has been having an incestuous relationship with both his daughter Perla and his granddaughter Floring. When news of this breaks out, Perla and Floring are visited by two filmmakers who offer to buy the rights to their story with the assurance that the film will expose Gabino’s depravity. Perla and Floring agree, and a movie, salaciously titled Hayok sa Laman (Lust for Flesh), is eventually made starring Jaclyn Jose as Violeta (representing Perla), Klaudia Koronel as Hasmin (Floring), and Dante Rivero as Leon (Gabino). Perla and Floring attend the night of the premiere and are dismayed to find their story turned into a mere sexploitation flick, complete with badly written dialogue and over-the-top acting. Memories of all the suffering they endured suddenly return, together with the revelation that Floring is really Perla’s daughter by Gabino. Both Perla and Floring leave the theater halfway through the film, feeling they have been violated all over again.

 

Tuhog was hailed as one of the 10 Best Films of the Decade 2000-2009 by the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino. It won Best Picture, Best Screenplay, Best Cinematography, and Best Music at the 2002 Gawad Urian. Dante Rivero received the Best Supporting Actor trophy at the 2002 Film Academy of the Philippines Awards. The film was also named Movie of the Year at the 2002 PMPC Star Awards for Movies.   Written by Elvin Valerio
