text:
(Real Mother) / 1939 / Black and White / Drama / 96 minutes / Direction, Story, and Screenplay: Octavio Silos / Cinematography: Cesar Silos / Editing: E. Villanueva / Sound: William Smith / Music: Miguel Velarde Jr / Produced by Excelsior Pictures / Cast: Rosario Moreno (Magdalena), Rudy Concepcion (Roberto), Tita Duran (Tita), Naty Bernardo (Anday), Exequiel Segovia (Antonio), Nati Rubi (Doña Luisa), Joaquin Gavino (Gabino), Precioso Palma (Don Alberto), and Mercedes de Gavino (Faustina)

 

Magdalena, who was raped by Antonio, gives birth to a girl. Magdalena’s father decides to give the child away so that Magdalena can be properly married to Roberto. Not wishing to mislead Roberto whom she loves, Magdalena writes him a letter revealing her past. Magdalena asks her aunt to mail the letter for her. The aunt does not post the letter in order to “protect” her niece’s future.

 

Roberto proposes marriage to Magdalena. Presuming that he has decided to disregard her past, Magdalena accepts his proposal. The two are married and have a child, Junior. But Magdalena soon realizes that Roberto never received her letter. She has not forgotten her first child. Through her aunt, she finds out that the child, now named Tita, was given to a young woman, Anday.

 

Magdalena and her aunt look for the child, but Anday’s family has moved. In their search, they encounter a little girl begging for alms. Talking to the girl’s “mother,” Magdalena comes to the conclusion that Tita is her lost child. Magdalena tries to get the child back, but Anday will not let her go, saying she is the real mother. Neither will the child give up the only mother she has known.

 

Meanwhile, Antonio, who is Roberto’s friend, decides to blackmail Magdalena. He first asks for five thousand pesos, which Magdalena agrees to pay in order to keep her secret from Roberto. But when Antonio comes back for more money, she rebuffs him. Antonio reveals Magdalena’s past to Roberto, who angrily sends Magdalena away. To add to her sorrows, Junior, her child by Roberto, dies. Roberto gets hold of the letter that Magdalena wrote but was never mailed to him. Convinced of Magdalena’s sincerity, Roberto is reunited with Magdalena at the tomb of their child.

 

Meanwhile, Magdalena has become close to Tita and Anday. Anday falls sick. On Christmas Eve, as Tita and the other children perform at Magdalena’s party, Anday’s health takes a turn for the worse. Everyone rushes to her side, and finding no doctor in the barrio, Roberto rushes Anday to the hospital and saves her life. In the final scene, Roberto and Magdalena ask Anday and Tita to stay with them permanently. They agree, and Tita, ensconced between Magdalena and Anday, says she is lucky to have two “real mothers.”

 

The movie features songs like “Buhat” (Ever Since), “Maawa, Maawa” (Have Pity), “Ave Maria,” “Maligayang Pasko” (Merry Christmas), and others. This is one of the movies that made Tita Duran a major child star. This classic melodrama is one of the five pre-World War II Filipino movies that has survived to the present.  Written by Nicanor G. Tiongson

text:
1981 / Color / Drama, Documentary / Direction and Screenplay: Kidlat Tahimik (pseud. of Eric de Guia) / Cinematography: Roberto Yñiguez / Editing: K. H. Fugunt / Art Direction: Santi Bose / Sound: Neidhart Franke, Ed de Guia, and Rolly Ruta / Music: Mandy Afuang / Produced by Kidlat Kulog Productions / Cast: Homer Abiad, Iñigo Vito, Maria Pehipol, Patricio Abari, Bernarda Pacheco, Katrin Luise, Claudia Aderes, Mino Aco, Riri Afuang, Silberio Galvez, Alma Almasan, Nita Alejo, Johnny Ching, Radi Dalit, Joseph Anderes, Cupido Arevalo, Manuel de Guia, Juanito Cahicas, Seferino Balino, Cristino Balino, Alejandro Macabaso, Vicente de Ramas, and the people of Pakil, Laguna

 

This 16 mm film focuses on a family in Pakil that makes papier-mâché dolls for a living. People from far and near come to admire and buy the family’s products. The father is a man of many talents. He has a good singing voice with which he regales the townsfolk during the Turumba festival in honor of the Blessed Virgin. The children are happy, cooperative workers who gladly pitch in to augment the family income. The grandmother sets the standards for quality control, and despite her many household chores sees to it that no imperfection mars the finished product before it leaves her home. They dream of getting rich someday. This dream comes close to fulfillment when a department store dealer, a foreigner, imports their products. At first everything about the enterprise seems to go well. But later they realize that the overall effect is devastating. The father stops singing for the Turumba festival. The grandmother becomes a cranky old woman. The children lose interest in their work. Without being pedantic or dogmatic, the film clearly points out that family relations deteriorate as a result of the inordinate pursuit of material wealth.

 

Turumba shows the exploitation of the Third World by transnational corporations. It is the work of a concerned independent filmmaker who is aware of the power of cinema to reveal the truth. Kidlat Tahimik shows how the personal life is connected with the social, religious, and economic aspects of society.  Written by Lena S. Pareja

text:
(The Life of Rosa) / 2001 / Color / Drama / 113 minutes / Direction: Chito S. Roño / Story and Screenplay: Armando Lao / Cinematography: Neil Daza / Editing: Vito Cajili and Joyce Bernal / Production Design: Gerry G. Pascual / Sound: Addiss Tabong and Alex Tomboc / Music: Jay Oliver Durias / Produced by Star Cinema / Cast: Rosanna Roces (Rosa), Diether Ocampo (Dado), Liza Lorena (Azen), Jiro Manio (Enteng), Angel Aquino (Jing), Pen Medina (Lupo), Vic Diaz (Tiyong), Jhong Hilario, Nonie Buencamino, Albert Martinez, Olga Natividad, Katrina Nazario, Ihman Esturco, Rey Bejar, Angie Ferro, Dodie Acuña, Joe Gruta, Cris Vertido, Cris Michelena, Irma Adlawan, Tom Olivar, and Connie Chua 

 

Rosa and her boyfriend Dado are con artists who are involved in all kinds of criminal activities, from kidnapping and carnapping to blackmailing and stealing gifts at a wedding reception. They are under the supervision of Tiyong and his right-hand man Lupo, on whom they depend for their protection and “steady income” through smuggling and housebreaking. But Rosa and Dado want to make more money, and their greed leads to a falling out with the underworld boss. As a result, they start to live in fear and paranoia, with the danger of being assassinated always hounding them, at the same time that the police are also after them. Their fugitive lives end tragically in the hands of both criminals and the law.

La Vida Rosa is a noir crime thriller that presents the urban milieu of organized crime, while giving a human face to the criminals in the mold of gangster films. Dado is coarse, but he worries about his former girlfriend, Jing, and her daughter. Rosa is not only a femme fatale but also a doting mother to her bastard son, Enteng, and a loving daughter to the blind Azen.

La Vida Rosa won Best Screenplay, Best Editing, and Best Actress (Roces) in the 2002 Gawad Urian of the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino, where it was nominated for nine other major awards.  Written by Patrick Campos

text:
1985 / Color / Drama / 120 minutes / Direction: Peque Gallaga / Story: T. E. Pagaspas / Screenplay: Rosauro Q. dela Cruz / Cinematography: Conrado Baltazar / Editing: Jess Navarro / Production Design: Don Escudero / Sound: Rudy Baldovino / Music: Jaime Fabregas / Produced by Regal Films / Cast: Sarsi Emmanuelle (Native Woman), Miguel Rodriguez (Ilustrado), Abel Jurado (Indio), Ama Quiambao, Pepito Bosch, Arbie Antonio, Rolando Tinio, Jed Arboleda, Crispin Medina, E. A. Rocha, and Abbo de la Cruz.

 

1901. The Filipinos are at war with the United States, which had decided to take over the Philippines as the new colonial master. Two American officers pretending to be captives of Filipino revolutionary soldiers lead a band of Macabebe mercenaries to capture the president of the republic in Palanan, Isabela. In a small town in Tayabas, the band is compelled to drag along three persons—an ilustrado (educated native), an indio (Christianized native) fisher, and a runaway native woman—who had inadvertently learned of the American plot. The trio are not politically oriented, but in the course of the journey, they become increasingly drawn to take the side of Aguinaldo against the Americans and their henchmen. They escape from the band and try to reach Palanan ahead of their captors. They fail to save the president but the experience they shared in “the virgin forest” bonds them together, each one projecting a symbolic role in the emergence of a young nation.

Virgin Forest succeeds in driving home its message about the emerging Filipino national consciousness at the turn of the century. It won Best Production Design and Best Musical Score in the 1986 Film Academy of the Philippines Awards.  Written by Bienvenido Lumbera

text:
(Crazy Visa) / 2005 / Color / Comedy / 105 minutes / Direction and Screenplay: Mark Meily / Cinematography: Lee Meily / Editing: Danny Añonuevo and Ike Veneracion / Production Design: Norman Regalado / Sound: Raffy Magsaysay / Music: Vincent de Jesus / Produced by Unitel Pictures International / Cast: Robin Padilla (Jess Huson), Paul Holme (Nigel Adams), Johnny Delgado, Rufa Mae Quinto, Tessie Tomas, Noel Trinidad, Isay Alvarez, Robert Seña, Marissa Sanchez, Evangeline Pascual, Dante Rivero, Ricky Davao, Eddie Gutierrez, and Joonee Gamboa

A nursing graduate working as a limousine driver, Jess Huson wishes to go to the United States to be with his girlfriend in California, but he is denied a US visa. Supporting an ailing father, Jess tries to supplement his earnings by serving as a driver and tour guide for an American TV show celebrity named Nigel Adams who is currently in the country to document paranormal and superstitious happenings in the Philippines. All the paranormal activities suggested by Jess, though, prove to be bogus. Adams, upon learning that Jess’s father used to be a Kristo (penitent whose penance is to be crucified on a cross), makes a deal with Jess. If his father will agree to be filmed while being crucified, Adams will vouch for Jess as a caregiver to his brother-in-law’s retirement facility in Florida. Jess’s father refuses; since nobody else wants to do it for free, they have to pay another man to play the Kristo for the camera. On the day of the filming, the man to be crucified skips town; so, Jess, desperate to go to the United States, volunteers to play the Kristo. After the successful documentation of his crucifixion, Jess goes to the embassy and finally receives the much-coveted US visa. After everything has been said and sung, courtesy of the pabasa (chanting of the passion of Christ) chorus that interjects between scenes, Jess decides not to go to the United States and to stay in the Philippines with his father and his former girlfriend and her son.

In 2006, the film won the Gawad Urian for Best Actor (Padilla) and Best Music, the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences award for Best Actor, and the Film Academy of the Philippines award for Best Supporting Actor (Delgado).  Written by Anne Frances Sangil

article.value: A nursing graduate working as a limousine driver, Jess Huson wishes to go to the United States to be with his girlfriend in California, but he is denied a US visa. Supporting an ailing father, Jess tries to supplement his earnings by serving as a driver and tour guide for an American TV show celebrity named Nigel Adams who is currently in the country to document paranormal and superstitious happenings in the Philippines. All the paranormal activities suggested by Jess, though, prove to be bogus. Adams, upon learning that Jess’s father used to be a Kristo (penitent whose penance is to be crucified on a cross), makes a deal with Jess. If his father will agree to be filmed while being crucified, Adams will vouch for Jess as a caregiver to his brother-in-law’s retirement facility in Florida. Jess’s father refuses; since nobody else wants to do it for free, they have to pay another man to play the Kristo for the camera. On the day of the filming, the man to be crucified skips town; so, Jess, desperate to go to the United States, volunteers to play the Kristo. After the successful documentation of his crucifixion, Jess goes to the embassy and finally receives the much-coveted US visa. After everything has been said and sung, courtesy of the pabasa (chanting of the passion of Christ) chorus that interjects between scenes, Jess decides not to go to the United States and to stay in the Philippines with his father and his former girlfriend and her son.

In 2006, the film won the Gawad Urian for Best Actor (Padilla) and Best Music, the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences award for Best Actor, and the Film Academy of the Philippines award for Best Supporting Actor (Delgado).

text:
(Street-smart) / 1994 / Color / Drama / 81 minutes / Direction: Ishmael Bernal / Story and Screenplay: Floy Quintos / Cinematography: Charlie Peralta / Editing: Danny Gloria / Production Design: Jayjay Medina and Len Santos / Sound: Joe Climaco / Music: Jaime Fabregas / Produced by MAQ Films / Cast: Carmina Villarroel (Rosel), Richard Gomez (Ardo), Cherie Gil (Anya), Janice de Belen (Julie), Bembol Roco (Bert), Celeste Legaspi (Mercedes Castrense), and Dave Brodett (Sangalang)

 

Bernal’s last film explores the world of crime and corruption through the eyes of a young woman Rosel who is staying in a rehabilitation center with her older sister Julie. Raped by her own father, Rosel grows up thinking she cannot trust anyone. After Julie is adopted by the rich religious matron Mercedes Castrense, Rosel escapes the center and bumps into a petty thief, Ardo. They make a good pair and are eventually taken in as con artists by the socialite Anya who, with the help of her right-hand man Bert, is running a “carnapping” syndicate controlled by the corrupt governor Sangalang. It turns out that Mercedes is involved in human trafficking and is sending the innocent Julie to Brunei. Seeing the hopelessness of the underworld, Ardo and Rosel plan to escape. In the meantime, Bert wants Rosel to replace Anya. These two plans, however, fail when Rosel is accidentally reunited with her sister Julie while she is trying to “carnap” Mercedes’s car. A car chase ensues, and Ardo, Rosel, and Julie end up at Anya’s den. Sensing her trusted man’s treachery, Anya hits Bert with an iron bar and burns him alive, but her hours are numbered because the governor—in an effort to clear his name—is letting her fry by tipping off the media about her syndicate. Rosel, Ardo, and Julie try to flee, but Anya shoots Julie. Ardo and Rosel manage to escape and end up somewhere in the province. In the final scene, they hitch a ride and the driver resembles Jesus Christ.

Wating earned various nominations from the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino and the Young Critics Circle and won Best Actor (Gomez) and Best Production Design in the 1995 Gawad Urian.  Written by Ronald Baytan

text:
(Affliction) / 2008 / Color / Horror, Drama / 95 minutes / Direction: Richard Somes / Screenplay: Richard V. Somes and Dwight Gaston / Cinematography: Hermann Claravall and Lyle Sacris / Editing: Borgy Torre / Production Design: Michael Español, Donald Camon, and Rashim Gumacal / Sound: Joey Santos and Eduardo Velasquez / Music: Von de Guzman / Produced by Cinema One Originals, Reality Entertainment, Larger Than Life, and Strawdogs Studio / Cast: Ronnie Lazaro (Junior “Nyor” Villacin), Tetchie Agbayani (Inday), Joel Torre (Dolpo), Aleera Montalla (Amor), Gio Respall (Toto), Erik Matti (Lazarus), and Leon Gaston (Baby Leon)

 

Junior “Nyor” Villacin is a family man in a small, peaceful town where everyone knows everyone. One day, Nyor’s daughter Amor comes home ill after spending time in another town to work. The town physician tells Nyor that Amor is suffering from a stomach infection and prescribes antibiotics. Amor’s illness persists and one evening she jumps out of her bedroom window, then wanders into the woods where she attacks and kills two barangay officials patrolling the community. Amor later returns to her family. Upon seeing her all bloodied up, Nyor chains her to the bed to keep her from harming other people. Nyor’s wife Inday invites the local shaman Lazarus to treat Amor, to no avail. Apparently, Amor’s condition has taken a turn for the worse; she is now an aswang and will start killing people. Unable to bear the pain his daughter is going through, Nyor frees Amor from her chains and asks her to do what she must, but to spare her family in the process. Amor starts killing several people, prompting Nyor’s friend Dolpo, the town official, to scour the community for possible suspects. Dolpo unsuspectingly shoots a creature in the dark and as he, his officials, and Nyor track down the creature, Dolpo realizes that the creature he shot is his goddaughter Amor. Fearful that Dolpo will further hurt his daughter, Nyor kills Dolpo and brings the wounded Amor back home. As Nyor tries to stop Amor’s bleeding, she escapes, but not before taking her own nephew from the crib. Upon seeing Amor eating his grandchild, Nyor accuses her of being a monster. Amor, in a moment of lucidity, begs Nyor to kill her. Finally, the father kills his daughter.

Filmed entirely in Hiligaynon/Ilonggo, Yanggaw won Best Actor (Lazaro), Best Supporting Actress (Montalla), and Best Sound in the 2009 Gawad Urian; Best Director, Best Actor (Lazaro, tied with Mark Gil for Alon [Wave], 2008), Best Supporting Actor (Torre), Best Supporting Actress (Agbayani), Best Editing, Best Sound, and the Audience Award in the 2008 Cinema One Originals Digital Film Festival.  Written by Anne Frances Sangil

text:
(Fury in Paradise) / 1937 / Black and White / Drama / 65 minutes / Direction: Eduardo de Castro / Cinematography: William H. Jansen / Editing: Ralph Dixon / Sound: Louis R. Morse / Music: Edward Kilenyi / Produced by Filippine Films / Cast: Fernando Poe (Danao) and Rosa del Rosario (Minda Mora)

 

Subtitled “A Fanciful Tale of the Moro Sea Gypsies,” Zamboanga is set along the coasts of Sulu, inhabited by a seafaring tribe ruled by the kind Datu Tanbuong. His beautiful granddaughter, Minda Mora, is engaged to be married to Danao, a deep-sea pearl diver. When Danao finally returns with precious pearls, Datu Tanbuong calls for a celebration. Danao marries Minda, and among the wedding visitors is Hadji Razul, the ruler of a tribe of Moros from another island. He leads a band of pirates and has illicit collaborations with a “white man,” an American captain of a schooner who ferries smuggled Chinese coolies. During one of Danao’s journeys, Hadji abducts Minda. The treacherous act triggers a tribal war. In the end, Danao rescues Minda and kills Hadji, thereby restoring peace in the land.

Zamboanga was produced by George Harris and Eddie Tait, Americans who pioneered the first well-equipped film studio in the Philippines in 1932. Shot on location in the remote islands of Sulu in 1936, Zamboanga was post-produced in the United States. It premiered in California and was screened in New York in 1937. Thought to be a lost film, it was recovered in 2004 through the efforts of film historian Nick Deocampo.

Zamboanga is one of five pre-World War II films that have survived. The others are Octavio Silos’s Tunay na Ina (Real Mother), 1939; Carlos Vander Tolosa’s Giliw Ko (My Beloved), 1939; Silos’s Pakiusap (Plea), 1940; and Vicente Salumbides’s Ibong Adarna (Adarna Bird), 1941.

Zamboanga was remade in 1966, this time starring Poe’s son, Fernando Poe Jr, with Susan Roces as Minda and Johnny Monteiro as Hadji Razul. However, the remake, directed by Efren Reyes, has a different narrative. The protagonist is a Christian sea trader who falls in love with a Muslim woman. Their forbidden love becomes the point of conflict.  Written by Patrick Campos

text:
(Zsazsa Zaturnnah: The Movie) / 2006 / Color / Musical, Comedy / 114 minutes / Direction: Joel Lamangan / Screenplay: Dinno Erece / Cinematography: Lyle Nemenzo Sacris / Editing: Jay Halili / Production Design: Edgar Martin Littaua / Art Direction: Carlo Vergara / Sound,: Ditoy Aguila / Music: Vincent de Jesus / Produced by Regal Entertainment, Regal Multimedia, and Ignite Media / Cast: Zsa Zsa Padilla (Zsazsa Zaturnnah), Rustom Padilla (Ada), Pops Fernandez (Queen Femina Suarestellar Baroux), Chokoleit (Didi), and Alfred Vargas (Dodong)

 

Adapted from the National Book Award-winning graphic novel that was initially self-published in two parts by Carlo Vergara, Zsazsa Zaturnnah Ze Moveeh revolves around Ada, a gay man who owns a beauty salon in the countryside. Turned cynical by failed relationships, he has moved away from the city and dedicated himself to running his business. One fateful night, a small meteorite falls through his roof and on him just as he is taking a bath. At the goading of Didi, his assistant and best friend, Ada swallows the rock and utters the mysterious word etched on it, “Zaturnnah.” Instantly, he transforms into a woman with superhuman abilities who will come to be known as Zsazsa Zaturnnah. Shortly after testing the powers of his newfound alter ego, Ada finds himself having to use these in order to safeguard his hometown from a spate of attacks by uncanny adversaries: a gigantic frog; a horde of zombies; and the Amazonistas, a group of alien women who have taken it upon themselves to rid the universe of men, led by Queen Femina Suarestellar Baroux. Amid all this, he must also resolve lingering issues he has with his deceased father, acknowledge his loneliness, and entertain the possibility of loving once again.

Zsazsa Zaturnnah won Best Music and Best Actor (Padilla) at the 2007 Gawad Urian of the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino, Best Musical Score at the 2007 Luna Awards of the Film Academy of the Philippines, and Movie Production Designer of the Year and Movie Musical Scorer of the Year at the 2007Star Awards for Movies of the Philippine Movie Press Club.  Written by Jaime Oscar M. Salazar
